Options A, B, D, and E are all explicit requirements under s.386.

questions.text: "Linton Ltd" has one class of ordinary shares. The directors propose to pay a final dividend recommended by them and to be approved by the members in general meeting. The shareholders pass an ordinary resolution approving the dividend. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this final dividend?

options.label: A
options.text: Once declared by the members, it becomes a debt due from the company to each shareholder.

options.label: B
options.text: It remains a discretionary distribution until actually paid, and the directors can rescind the resolution if they later believe it imprudent.

options.label: C
options.text: The directors are legally obliged to pay it immediately upon the passing of the resolution, even if the company subsequently becomes insolvent.

options.label: D
options.text: It can only be paid if the company has sufficient cash at bank, regardless of the level of distributable profits.

options.label: E
options.text: It is unlawful if any shareholder votes against the resolution.

questions.explanation:
Option A is correct. A final dividend, when declared by the company in general meeting (or by the directors if they have the power), creates a debt enforceable by the shareholders. This contrasts with an interim dividend, which is discretionary until paid.
Option B is incorrect; this describes an interim dividend, not a declared final dividend.
Option C is incorrect; while it becomes a debt, if the company becomes insolvent, the shareholders rank as unsecured creditors and may not be paid.
Option D is incorrect; the legal test is based on distributable profits, not cash liquidity (though liqui...

questions.text: "Masham Ltd" grants a floating charge to its bank "over the company's undertaking and all its property and assets present and future." The company later purchases a new piece of equipment. Which of the following describes the status of this new equipment regarding the floating charge?

options.label: A
options.text: The equipment is not covered by the charge because it was acquired after the charge was created.

options.label: B
options.text: The equipment is automatically subject to a fixed charge in favour of the bank.

options.label: C
options.text: The equipment is automatically subject to the existing floating charge, as it falls within future property.

options.label: D
options.text: The company must seek the bank's consent to use the equipment in its business.

options.label: E
options.text: The equipment is free from any security interest unless a new charge is created over it.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. A floating charge expressed to cover "undertaking and all assets present and future" will attach to after-acquired property automatically, subject to the company's right to deal with it in the ordinary course of business until crystallisation.
Option A is incorrect; floating charges commonly cover future assets.
Option B is incorrect; it remains subject to the floating charge, not a fixed charge.
Option D is incorrect; the company can use the asset in the ordinary course without consent.
Option E is incorrect; the floating charge attaches.

questions.text: "Nidderdale Ltd" has distributable profits of £100,000. It also has a share premium account of £50,000. The directors wish to use these funds to issue bonus shares to existing shareholders. Can the share premium account be used for this purpose?

options.label: A
options.text: No, the share premium account can only be used to pay up bonus shares if the company passes a special resolution to reduce capital.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, the share premium account can always be used to finance the issue of fully paid bonus shares.

options.label: C
options.text: No, the share premium account is part of the company's capital and can never be distributed to shareholders.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the company also has sufficient distributable profits to cover the issue.

options.label: E
options.text: No, the share premium account can only be used to write off preliminary expenses or issue expenses.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Under the Companies Act 2006, s.610, the share premium account may be applied in paying up unissued shares to be allotted to members as fully paid bonus shares. This is a permitted use without a court-approved reduction of capital.
Option A is incorrect; a special resolution is not required for this specific use.
Option C is incorrect; while it is part of capital and cannot be distributed as cash dividends, it can be used for bonus shares.
Option D is incorrect; it can be used independently of distributable profits for this purpose.
Option E is incorrect; while it can also...

questions.text: "Otley Ltd" takes out a term loan from a bank. As security, the company grants a fixed charge over its land and a floating charge over its other assets. The bank also requires a personal guarantee from the company's main director, David. If the company defaults and the bank enforces the personal guarantee, which of the following is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: David, having paid under the guarantee, is subrogated to the bank's rights as a secured creditor and can enforce the charges.

options.label: B
options.text: David becomes an unsecured creditor of the company for the amount he paid.

options.label: C
options.text: The bank's charges are automatically transferred to David upon his payment.

options.label: D
options.text: David has no right of recovery from the company; the guarantee is a gift.

options.label: E
options.text: The bank must choose between enforcing the charges and calling the guarantee; it cannot do both.

questions.explanation:
Option A is correct. The doctrine of subrogation entitles a guarantor who pays the debt to step into the shoes of the creditor and enforce any securities held by the creditor, subject to the terms of the guarantee.
Option B is incorrect; the guarantor is subrogated to the secured position.
Option C is incorrect; the charges are not automatically transferred; the guarantor acquires an equitable right to the securities.
Option D is incorrect; a guarantor has a right of indemnity from the principal debtor (the company).
Option E is incorrect; the bank can both enforce the charges and call the gua...

questions.text: "Ripon Ltd" has a financial year ending 31 January 2025. Its directors hold a board meeting on 1 May 2025 to approve the accounts. The company is private and small. What is the deadline for sending copies of the annual accounts to members?

options.label: A
options.text: Within 9 months of the year-end (i.e., by 31 October 2025).

options.label: B
options.text: Within 6 months of the year-end (i.e., by 31 July 2025).

options.label: C
options.text: At least 21 days before the general meeting at which they are to be laid (if any).

options.label: D
options.text: The later of 9 months after the year-end or 3 months after the date of approval.

options.label: E
options.text: The later of 6 months after the year-end or 1 month after the date of approval.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. For a private company, the period for sending copies of the annual accounts to members is 6 months after the end of the relevant accounting period (Companies Act 2006, s.423). The approval date is irrelevant for this deadline. The year-end is 31 January 2025, so the deadline is 31 July 2025.
Option A is the filing deadline for a private company (9 months), not the sending deadline.
Option C is the rule for sending copies before a general meeting, but for private companies, the default is sending within 6 months of year-end, regardless of a meeting.
Option D and E are incor...

questions.text: Thomas is the sole director of "Cedar Trading Ltd," a private company with two shareholders. Thomas uses £50,000 of the company's funds to purchase a luxury car for his personal use, without any discussion with the shareholders. He believes this is acceptable because the company is profitable and he works very hard. A shareholder discovers the transaction and challenges it. Which of the following director's duties under the Companies Act 2006 has Thomas most clearly breached?

options.label: A
options.text: Duty to promote the success of the company.

options.label: B
options.text: Duty to exercise independent judgment.

options.label: C
options.text: Duty to avoid conflicts of interest.

options.label: D
options.text: Duty not to accept benefits from third parties..

options.label: E
options.text: Duty to exercise reasonable care, skill and diligence (s.174).

questions.explanation:
Option A is correct. The duty under s.172 requires a director to act in the way he considers, in good faith, would be most likely to promote the success of the company for the benefit of its members as a whole. Using company funds for a personal luxury item with no commercial justification is a classic breach of this duty, as it constitutes a failure to act for the benefit of the company.
Option B is incorrect. While related, the core issue is not about independence of judgment but about the improper purpose of the expenditure.
Option C is incorrect. This was a direct misuse of company propert...

questions.text: "Ashbourne PLC" has seven directors. The board wishes to approve a substantial property transaction with a company in which one of the directors, Fatima, holds a 30% shareholding. The proposed transaction is at market value. Which of the following is required for this transaction to be lawfully approved by the company?

options.label: A
options.text: The transaction must be approved by an ordinary resolution of the shareholders, with Fatima and any connected persons abstaining from voting.

options.label: B
options.text: The transaction must be approved by the board of directors, provided Fatima declares her interest and does not vote, and the other directors approve it.

options.label: C
options.text: The transaction requires both approval by the board (with Fatima’s interest declared and her not voting) and subsequent approval by an ordinary resolution of the shareholders.

options.label: D
options.text: The transaction is prohibited absolutely under the Companies Act 2006 because Fatima has a substantial interest in the other company.

options.label: E
options.text: The transaction must be approved by a special resolution of the shareholders, with Fatima and any connected persons abstaining from voting.

questions.explanation:
Option A is correct. This is a substantial property transaction with a director-connected person under s.190 of the Companies Act 2006. For a public company, such a transaction requires approval by a resolution of the members (shareholders). Director approval alone is insufficient. The director concerned cannot vote on the shareholder resolution.
Option B is incorrect. Board approval is insufficient for a substantial property transaction with a connected person; shareholder approval is mandatory.
Option C is incorrect. While board approval may be sought, the Act only mandates shareholder appro...

questions.text: The board of "Marlow Ltd" wants to remove David, a director appointed for a fixed term of three years, after only one year. The company's articles do not contain any special provisions for removal. David is also a shareholder. What is the correct procedure to remove David as a director?

options.label: A
options.text: The board can pass a resolution to remove him by a simple majority, provided they give him notice of the meeting.

options.label: B
options.text: The shareholders can pass an ordinary resolution provided special notice is given to the company.

options.label: C
options.text: David can only be removed by a unanimous written resolution of all shareholders, as he is also a member.

options.label: D
options.text: David cannot be removed before his three-year term expires, as this would be a breach of his service contract.

options.label: E
options.text: The shareholders must pass a special resolution (75% vote in favour) because removal is an alteration of his contract.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. S.168 of the Companies Act 2006 provides that a company may by ordinary resolution remove a director before the expiration of his period of office, notwithstanding anything in the articles or any service agreement. Special notice (28 days) must be given to the company by the shareholder proposing the resolution.
Option A is incorrect. Directors cannot generally remove a fellow director unless the articles permit it. The primary statutory power resides with the shareholders.
Option C is incorrect. Unanimity is not required; an ordinary resolution suffices.
Option D is incor...

questions.text: "Beacon Ltd" has three shareholders: Alex (70% of shares), Ben (20%), and Chloe (10%). Alex is also the sole director. Alex consistently makes decisions that benefit another company he owns, to the detriment of Beacon Ltd. Ben and Chloe are frustrated but are outvoted on every shareholder resolution Alex proposes. Which of the following remedies might be available to Ben and Chloe as minority shareholders?

options.label: A
options.text: They can requisition a general meeting to pass an ordinary resolution to overrule the director's decisions.

options.label: B
options.text: They can apply to court for an order on the grounds that the company's affairs are being conducted in a manner unfairly prejudicial to their interests.

options.label: C
options.text: They can initiate a derivative claim on behalf of the company against Alex for breach of duty, without needing the court's permission.

options.label: D
options.text: They can demand that the company purchase their shares at a fair value, and if refused, petition for the company to be wound up.

options.label: E
options.text: They have no remedy because Alex, as the majority shareholder, is entitled to run the company as he sees fit.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. S.994 provides a remedy where a company's affairs are being conducted in a manner unfairly prejudicial to the interests of its members generally or of some part of its members. Alex using his control to benefit himself at the company's expense is classic unfairly prejudicial conduct.
Option A is incorrect. As Alex controls over 50% of the votes, he can defeat any ordinary resolution they propose.
Option C is incorrect. A derivative claim requires permission from the court to continue (s.261). It is not automatic. Furthermore, a s.994 petition is often a more direct remedy ...

questions.text: The shareholders of "Denby Ltd" wish to pass a written resolution to approve a disposal of a major asset. The resolution is proposed as an ordinary resolution. There are 100 shares in issue. On 1 June, the company circulates the resolution. By 15 June, shareholders holding 55 shares have signed and returned their agreement. The holders of the remaining 45 shares are opposed but do not respond. When is the resolution passed?

options.label: A
options.text: On 15 June, when the majority (55%) of total shares has agreed.

options.label: B
options.text: On 1 July, provided no shareholders have revoked their agreement, as there is a 28-day deemed passage period.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not passed, because written resolutions require unanimous consent from all shareholders.

options.label: D
options.text: It is passed at the end of the 21-day period from circulation (i.e., on 22 June), provided the assents received represent a simple majority of the total voting rights.

options.label: E
options.text: It is passed at the end of the 28-day period from circulation (i.e., on 29 June), provided the assents received represent a simple majority of the total voting rights.

questions.explanation:
Option E is correct. Under the Companies Act 2006, s.296, a written resolution is passed when the required majority (for an ordinary resolution, a simple majority of the total voting rights) is achieved. However, the resolution is not effectively passed until the end of the circulation period (default 28 days from circulation), provided the required majority is met at that point (s.296(3)-(4)).
Option A is incorrect. While the majority has assented, the resolution is not formally passed until the end of the circulation period.
Option B is incorrect. The resolution is passed at the end of the 2...

questions.text: "Elton Ltd" is a private company with four shareholders. The directors wish to issue 100 new ordinary shares to a new investor. The company's articles give the directors authority to allot shares, but they contain pre-emption rights on issue for cash in favour of existing shareholders. Which of the following procedures must the directors follow to issue the shares lawfully to the new investor?

options.label: A
options.text: They must first offer the shares to existing shareholders pro rata, and only if those shareholders decline can they issue to the new investor.

options.label: B
options.text: They can issue the shares directly to the new investor, provided they pass a board resolution to that effect.

options.label: C
options.text: They must obtain an ordinary resolution of the shareholders disapplying the pre-emption rights for this specific issue.

options.label: D
options.text: They must obtain a special resolution of the shareholders authorising the allotment, as the directors have no existing authority.

options.label: E
options.text: They can issue the shares to the new investor if they believe it is in the best interests of the company, as pre-emption rights are not legally binding.

questions.explanation:
Option A is correct. Unless disapplied, statutory pre-emption rights (s.561 of the Companies Act 2006) require that new equity shares offered for cash must first be offered to existing shareholders in proportion to their holdings. The company's articles often reinforce this.
Option B is incorrect. The board resolution is necessary for the allotment, but it does not override the pre-emption rights.
Option C is incorrect. While shareholders can pass a special resolution to disapply pre-emption rights (s.570), it is not required for each issue if the directors follow the pre-emption procedure. Th...

questions.text: Grace is a director of "Fenton Products Ltd." She is negotiating a contract on the company's behalf with "Harper Supplies Ltd," a company owned by her husband. At a board meeting, she discloses that her husband owns Harper Supplies but states she believes the terms are favourable. What must the board do to ensure the transaction is not voidable for conflict of interest?

options.label: A
options.text: Nothing, because Grace has disclosed her interest, and the transaction is fair.

options.label: B
options.text: The board must formally approve the transaction, and Grace must neither vote nor be counted in the quorum for that decision.

options.label: C
options.text: The board must formally approve the transaction, and Grace can vote and  be counted in the quorum for that decision.

options.label: D
options.text: The transaction must be approved by an ordinary resolution of the shareholders after full disclosure.

options.label: E
options.text: The transaction is automatically voidable unless approved by the shareholders in general meeting.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Under s.175 of the Companies Act 2006, a director must avoid a conflict of interest. The conflict can be authorised by the directors provided the matter is proposed to the board, the interest is declared, and the conflicted director does not vote or count in the quorum (unless the articles permit otherwise). This is the standard procedure for board authorisation. Therefore, option C is incorrect.
Option A is incorrect. Disclosure alone is insufficient; the conflict must be authorised by the directors (or shareholders).
Option D is incorrect. Shareholder approval is an alte...

questions.text: "Irwell Ltd" holds its Annual General Meeting (AGM). The company's articles require an AGM every year. Due to an administrative error, the notice of the AGM was sent to shareholders only 12 days before the meeting date, instead of the required 14 clear days. What is the legal effect of this shorter notice period?

options.label: A
options.text: The meeting and any business conducted are void.

options.label: B
options.text: The meeting is valid if all shareholders entitled to attend and vote agree to short notice.

options.label: C
options.text: The meeting is valid only for the passing of ordinary resolutions, but special resolutions would be void.

options.label: D
options.text: The meeting is valid because private companies are no longer required to hold AGMs.

options.label: E
options.text: The meeting is valid if a majority of shareholders (by voting rights) agree to short notice.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Under s.307 of the Companies Act 2006, the notice period for a general meeting is 14 clear days. However, s.307(5) & (6) allow for shorter notice if agreed by a majority in number of members holding at least 90% of the voting rights (for a private company) or by all members entitled to attend and vote (for a public company). The most accurate general statement for a private company is that it requires agreement of the members.
Option A is incorrect. The meeting is not automatically void; it can be validated by shareholder agreement.
Option C is incorrect. The rule for shor...

questions.text: "Jarrow Ltd" has two directors, Mark and Nina. Mark holds 60% of the shares, Nina holds 10%, and an external investor holds 30%. Nina is removed as a director by an ordinary resolution of shareholders. She wishes to challenge her removal. Which of the following best describes her legal position?

options.label: A
options.text: She cannot be removed because she is also a shareholder, and this protects her directorship.

options.label: B
options.text: Her removal is valid, but she may have a claim for unfair prejudice if she can show she had a legitimate expectation of participation in management.

options.label: C
options.text: Her removal is invalid unless the company also buys back her shares at a fair price.

options.label: D
options.text: Her removal is invalid because it requires a special resolution under s.168.

options.label: E
options.text: She can only be removed for cause, such as misconduct, and can challenge the removal if no cause is shown.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. The power to remove under s.168 is broad, and the removal itself is valid. However, in a small quasi-partnership company where a shareholder-director has a legitimate expectation of participating in management, removal without good reason could form the basis of an unfair prejudice petition under s.994.
Option A is incorrect. Shareholding does not confer an indefeasible right to be a director.
Option C is incorrect. There is no legal link between removal as director and a compulsory share purchase.
Option D is incorrect. S.168 explicitly requires only an ordinary resolutio...

questions.text: The board of "Kendal PLC" is proposing a substantial transaction that will require shareholder approval via a special resolution. They are concerned about a minority shareholder who is opposed and may try to disrupt the general meeting. What is the minimum percentage of voting rights that a shareholder (or group acting together) must hold to demand a poll vote on a special resolution at a general meeting?

options.label: A
options.text: 5% of the voting rights.

options.label: B
options.text: 10% of the voting rights.

options.label: C
options.text: Members holding at least 5% of the voting rights or 100 members, whichever is less.

options.label: D
options.text: Any single member, regardless of shareholding.

options.label: E
options.text: 25% of the voting rights.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Under the Companies Act 2006, s.321, the right to demand a poll on a resolution is available to (among others) members representing not less than one-tenth of the total voting rights of all members having the right to vote on the resolution.
Option A is incorrect. 5% is the threshold for requiring the circulation of a resolution or statement (s.292).
Option C is incorrect. This is the threshold for requiring circulation of a resolution (s.292), not for demanding a poll.
Option D is incorrect. While articles can give any member the right to demand a poll, the statutory mini...

questions.text: "Lytham Ltd" has three directors. One director, Oliver, resigns unexpectedly. The remaining two directors wish to appoint a new director to fill the vacancy. What is the correct procedure, assuming the company's articles are the Model Articles for private companies?

options.label: A
options.text: They can appoint a new director by a majority decision of the remaining directors.

options.label: B
options.text: They must call a general meeting of shareholders to pass an ordinary resolution appointing the new director.

options.label: C
options.text: They must obtain the unanimous written consent of all shareholders.

options.label: D
options.text: They cannot fill the vacancy; the company must continue with only two directors.

options.label: E
options.text: They can appoint a new director, but the appointment is only valid until the next AGM, where shareholders must confirm it.

questions.explanation:
Option A is correct. Model Article 17(1) for private companies provides that the directors may appoint a person as a director, either to fill a vacancy or as an additional director. The standard rule is that such a decision is made by a majority of the directors.
Option B is incorrect. While shareholders can also appoint directors by ordinary resolution, the articles typically give the directors the power to fill a casual vacancy.
Option C is incorrect. Unanimous consent is not required.
Option D is incorrect. Directors can fill vacancies to maintain the board.
Option E is incorrect. There is ...

questions.text: "Mauldeth Ltd" fails to file its annual confirmation statement (Form CS01) with Companies House within the 14-day deadline after its review period. The registrar has not taken any action. What is the potential consequence for the company and every officer in default?

options.label: A
options.text: The company is automatically dissolved after 6 months.

options.label: B
options.text: The company and every officer in default commit an offence and are liable to a fine.

options.label: C
options.text: The company's assets are frozen until the statement is filed.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no consequence; the confirmation statement is a voluntary filing.

options.label: E
options.text: The company's registered office address is struck from the register.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Failure to deliver a confirmation statement by the deadline is an offence under s.853 of the Companies Act 2006. The company and every officer in default is liable to a fine.
Option A is incorrect. Failure to file confirmation statements can lead to the company being struck off the register, but this is not automatic after 6 months; it is a separate process.
Option C is incorrect. There is no provision for freezing assets for this filing failure.
Option D is incorrect. Filing the confirmation statement is a mandatory requirement.
Option E is incorrect. The registered offic...

questions.text: Naomi is a shareholder in "Neston Ltd," holding 15% of the shares. She is concerned about a recent transaction approved by the board that she believes involved a conflict of interest. She wants to inspect the company's statutory books and records to investigate. Which of the following records is Naomi entitled to inspect as of right without needing a court order?

options.label: A
options.text: The minutes of board meetings.

options.label: B
options.text: The register of directors' residential addresses.

options.label: C
options.text: The company's accounting records (e.g., sales ledgers).

options.label: D
options.text: The register of members and the register of directors' service addresses.

options.label: E
options.text: Directors' service contracts.

questions.explanation:
Option D is correct. Under the Companies Act 2006, shareholders have a statutory right to inspect the register of members (s.116) and the register of directors (which contains service addresses) (s.162). These are public documents.
Option A is incorrect. Shareholders have a right to minutes of general meetings (s.358), not board meetings.
Option B is incorrect. The register of directors' usual residential addresses is confidential and not open for inspection by shareholders (s.165).
Option C is incorrect. Accounting records are not open for shareholder inspection as of right; they are private ...

questions.text: "Orrell Ltd" has one class of share. The directors wish to recommend a final dividend. The company's articles state that dividends are declared by ordinary resolution. What is the effect of the shareholders passing the resolution to declare the dividend?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates an immediate debt owing by the company to each shareholder in proportion to their shareholding.

options.label: B
options.text: It gives the directors discretion to pay the dividend if, and when, they think it prudent.

options.label: C
options.text: It must be paid within 14 days of the resolution, or it lapses.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only valid if the company had distributable profits both at the time of the resolution and at the time of payment.

options.label: E
options.text: It authorises the directors to pay an interim dividend of the same amount.

questions.explanation:
Option A is correct. A final dividend, once declared by the company in general meeting, becomes a debt due from the company to the shareholders. This contrasts with an interim dividend, which is declared by directors and remains discretionary until paid.
Option B is incorrect. This describes an interim dividend.
Option C is incorrect. There is no statutory 14-day rule; the debt is enforceable within the limitation period.
Option D is incorrect. The lawfulness of a dividend is judged at the time it is paid (or becomes a debt in the case of a declared final dividend). For a final dividend, the r...

questions.text: Peter, a director of "Pendle Ltd," is exploring a business opportunity that falls within the company's existing line of business. He does not tell the board and sets up a separate company to pursue it. Which duty has Peter most clearly breached?

options.label: A
options.text: Duty to exercise reasonable care, skill, and diligence (s.174).

options.label: B
options.text: Duty to promote the success of the company (s.172).

options.label: C
options.text: Duty to avoid conflicts of interest (s.175).

options.label: D
options.text: Duty to declare an interest in a proposed transaction (s.177).

options.label: E
options.text: Duty not to accept benefits from third parties (s.176).

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. S.175 imposes a duty to avoid conflicts of interest, which specifically includes exploiting any property, information, or opportunity of the company. Taking a corporate opportunity for himself without authorisation is a direct breach of this duty.
Option A is incorrect. While his actions may lack diligence, the primary breach is the conflict.
Option B is incorrect. The breach of the s.172 duty is a consequence of the conflict; the most direct and specific breach is of s.175.
Option D is incorrect. S.177 relates to declaring an interest in a transaction with the company. Th...

questions.text: "Quarry Bank Ltd" has four shareholders. The directors propose to amend the company's articles of association to introduce a new power for directors to refuse the transfer of shares. Shareholder A, who holds 30%, strongly objects. How can the articles be validly amended?

options.label: A
options.text: By a special resolution  passed at a general meeting.

options.label: B
options.text: By a written resolution agreed by shareholders holding 75% of the voting rights.

options.label: C
options.text: By an ordinary resolution passed at a general meeting.

options.label: D
options.text: By a unanimous written resolution of all shareholders.

options.label: E
options.text: Either A or B is correct.

questions.explanation:
Option E is correct. Under s.21 of the Companies Act 2006, a company's articles can be amended by a special resolution. A special resolution can be passed either at a general meeting (s.283) or as a written resolution (s.288). Both require the same majority: 75% of the total voting rights.
Option A is correct but incomplete, as B is also a valid method.
Option B is correct but incomplete, as A is also a valid method.
Option C is incorrect. An ordinary resolution is insufficient to amend the articles.
Option D is incorrect. While unanimity would achieve the 75% threshold, it is not required; 75...

questions.text: "Rivington Ltd" has an audit committee. The committee is reviewing the independence of the external auditors. The finance director mentions that the audit partner's brother has recently been appointed as the company's Head of Internal Audit. Under the UK Corporate Governance Code, which principle is most directly threatened by this situation?

options.label: A
options.text: The auditors must be appointed by the majority shareholders.

options.label: B
options.text: The auditors must exercise professional scepticism.

options.label: C
options.text: The auditors must be, and be seen to be, independent.

options.label: D
options.text: The auditors must rotate every 12 years.

options.label: E
options.text: The audit committee must comprise only non-executive directors.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. A core principle of audit regulation is that auditors must be independent in fact and appearance. A close family connection between the audit partner and a key company officer (Head of Internal Audit) creates a clear threat to perceived independence.
Option A is incorrect. It does not address the independence issue raised.
Option B is incorrect. Professional scepticism is a separate requirement.
Option D is incorrect. Partner rotation is a specific rule to safeguard independence, but the principle at stake here is independence itself.
Option E is incorrect. This relates to...

questions.text: Sadia holds 8% of the shares in "Stalybridge Ltd." She wishes to propose a resolution at the next AGM to remove the current chairman from the board. The company has received her notice. What must the company do in these circumstances?

options.label: A
options.text: Include the resolution in the notice of the AGM and circulate it at Sadia's expense if she requests it.

options.label: B
options.text: Refuse to include the resolution because only the board can propose resolutions for an AGM.

options.label: C
options.text: Include the resolution only if the board agrees that it is in the company's best interests.

options.label: D
options.text: Circulate the resolution to members at the company's expense, as she holds more than 5% of the voting rights.

options.label: E
options.text: Require Sadia to obtain the support of shareholders holding at least 25% of the voting rights before including it.

questions.explanation:
Option A is correct. Under s.338 of the Companies Act 2006, members representing 5% of the voting rights can require the company to give notice of a resolution at a general meeting. The company must include it in the notice of the meeting. Under s.340, the costs of circulation are borne by the requisitionists unless the company resolves otherwise.
Option B is incorrect. Shareholders have the statutory right to propose resolutions if they meet the threshold.
Option C is incorrect. The company has no discretion to refuse based on the merits of the resolution if the procedural requirements are me...

questions.text: "Timperley Ltd" is a private company. Its directors are considering making a loan to a director, Uzma, to help her with temporary personal financial difficulties. The company's articles are silent on this matter. Which of the following is true regarding such a loan?

options.label: A
options.text: It is absolutely prohibited under the Companies Act 2006.

options.label: B
options.text: It is permissible if approved by an ordinary resolution of the shareholders.

options.label: C
options.text: It is permissible if approved by the board of directors, provided Uzma declares her interest.

options.label: D
options.text: It is permissible only if the company is a money-lending company in the ordinary course of its business.

options.label: E
options.text: It is permissible if the value of the loan does not exceed £10,000.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. S.197 of the Companies Act 2006 prohibits loans to directors unless they are approved by a resolution of the members (shareholders). Board approval is insufficient.
Option A is incorrect. It is not absolutely prohibited; member approval makes it lawful.
Option C is incorrect. Board approval is insufficient for a loan to a director.
Option D is incorrect. This is an exception under s.209 for quasi-loans and credit transactions, but for a straightforward loan, member approval is the primary route.
Option E is incorrect. There is no de minimis threshold for loans to directors...

questions.text: "Uppermill Ltd" has three shareholders in a quasi-partnership: Vikram (40%), Will (40%), and Yasmine (20%). All three are directors. Deadlock arises, and Vikram and Will pass a board resolution to exclude Yasmine from management and the company premises. Yasmine remains a shareholder. What is Yasmine's most appropriate legal remedy?

options.label: A
options.text: Derivative claim for breach of director's duties by Vikram and Will.

options.label: B
options.text: Petition for the company to be wound up on the just and equitable ground.

options.label: C
options.text: Petition for relief on the grounds of unfairly prejudicial conduct.

options.label: D
options.text: Action for wrongful dismissal from her directorship.

options.label: E
options.text: Requisition a general meeting to remove Vikram and Will as directors.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. In a quasi-partnership, exclusion from management in which a shareholder had a legitimate expectation to participate is the paradigm case of unfairly prejudicial conduct under s.994. This is the standard and most appropriate remedy, typically leading to a court order for the other shareholders to buy her shares.
Option A is incorrect. While breaches of duty may have occurred, a derivative claim is for wrongs to the company. The wrong here is to Yasmine as a member, making s.994 the direct remedy.
Option B is incorrect. Winding up is a remedy of last resort ("just and equit...

areas.name: Partnership decision-making and authority of partners:

questions.text: James and Sarah are in a general partnership running a hardware store under the Partnership Act 1890, with no written agreement. James, without consulting Sarah, enters into a contract with a supplier to purchase a large quantity of expensive power tools on credit for the shop. Sarah believes this is an excessive commitment and objects. Under the Partnership Act 1890, is the partnership bound by this contract?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because James had no actual authority from Sarah, and major purchases require the consent of all partners.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because every partner is an agent of the firm and James had implied authority to buy stock for the business in the usual way.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the contract was for credit, and partners only have implied authority to buy for cash unless otherwise agreed.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the supplier can prove that Sarah had given James express authority for this specific transaction.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the power tools are not 'ordinary' stock for a hardware store and therefore outside the usual course of business.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Section 5 of the Partnership Act 1890 states that every partner is an agent of the firm for the purpose of the business. Purchasing stock for resale is within the ordinary course of a retail hardware business, giving James implied authority to bind the firm.
Option A is incorrect. The default rule is that a partner's act in the usual course of business binds the firm, even without the consent of other partners. Unanimous consent is only required for acts outside the ordinary course.
Option C is incorrect. There is no default rule in the 1890 Act that implied authority is r...

questions.text: Michael, Chloe, and David are partners in a firm of architects. Their written partnership agreement states: "No single partner shall enter into any contract exceeding £20,000 in value without the prior written consent of all other partners." Michael, in the firm's name, signs a contract with a client for a £35,000 project without consulting Chloe or David. The client was unaware of the restriction in the agreement. Is the partnership bound to the £35,000 contract?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the partnership agreement expressly prohibited Michael from entering into such a contract.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because the client dealt with Michael in good faith and had no notice of the internal restriction, so the firm is bound under the principle of apparent authority.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because Michael acted fraudulently and in breach of his fiduciary duty, which negates his authority.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if Chloe and David later ratify the contract after discovering it.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the contract is for professional services, not the sale of goods, and different rules apply.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Under s.8 of the Partnership Act 1890, an act relating to the business which is done in the firm's name by a partner is binding if it falls within his apparent authority. Internal restrictions (like those in a partnership agreement) do not affect third parties who have no knowledge of them.
Option A is incorrect. The agreement governs relations between partners but does not automatically invalidate transactions with third parties unaware of the restriction.
Option C is incorrect. While Michael may be in breach of duty to his partners, this does not automatically void the c...

questions.text: Thomas and Emily are partners in a bakery. Their partnership is governed by the default rules of the Partnership Act 1890, with no written agreement. Thomas wants to hire his niece, Grace, as a full-time shop assistant. Emily strongly objects, believing Grace is not suitable. Can Thomas hire his niece?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, as hiring staff for the shop is within the implied authority of a partner in a trading partnership.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the admission of a new employee requires the unanimous consent of all partners under the 1890 Act.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but only if Thomas pays Grace's salary from his personal funds, not from partnership assets.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because hiring a relative creates a conflict of interest which is automatically prohibited.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but Emily can apply to court to have the hiring set aside as unfairly prejudicial.

questions.explanation:
Option A is correct. Hiring shop staff is an ordinary matter connected with the day-to-day running of a retail bakery. Under the default rules, a partner has implied authority to perform such acts, which bind the firm, even if another partner disagrees.
Option B is incorrect. Unanimity is required for matters outside the ordinary course of business (s.24(8)). Hiring shop staff is an ordinary matter.
Option C is incorrect. If Thomas hires her as a shop assistant for the firm, it is a firm liability. He cannot unilaterally decide to pay from personal funds to circumvent partnership authority.
Op...

questions.text: Daniel, Olivia, and Ben are in a partnership running a café. They have a written partnership agreement which states: "All decisions regarding the renovation or refurbishment of the café premises must be made by a majority of partners." Daniel and Olivia vote to spend £15,000 on a full refurbishment. Ben votes against. Which of the following best describes the legal position?

options.label: A
options.text: The decision is invalid because substantial capital expenditures require the unanimous consent of all partners.

options.label: B
options.text: The decision is valid and binding on Ben, as the partnership agreement expressly provides for majority decision-making on this issue.

options.label: C
options.text: The decision is valid, but Ben is not personally liable for any losses arising from the refurbishment if it proves unprofitable.

options.label: D
options.text: The decision is invalid because it alters the nature of the partnership business, which requires unanimity under the 1890 Act.

options.label: E
options.text: The decision is valid only if Daniel and Olivia provide a personal guarantee for the loan needed to fund the refurbishment.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. The Partnership Act 1890 rules are default provisions. Partners are free to modify them by agreement. Here, the written agreement specifically provides that refurbishment decisions are made by majority, so Daniel and Olivia's vote binds the firm.
Option A is incorrect. The default rule in s.24(8) requires unanimity for changes to the nature of the business, but the partners have contracted out of this default by agreeing to a majority rule for refurbishment.
Option C is incorrect. All partners are jointly liable for the firm's debts incurred in the course of business, incl...

questions.text: Sophie and Luke are partners in a garden landscaping business with no written agreement. Without telling Luke, Sophie uses the partnership van as security for a £5,000 personal loan from a friend, Henry. She signs a document pledging the van 'on behalf of the partnership'. Henry is unaware she is acting for personal reasons. What is the status of the security granted to Henry?

options.label: A
options.text: It is valid, as Sophie had apparent authority to deal with partnership assets in the ordinary course.

options.label: B
options.text: It is void, because a partner has no authority to pledge partnership property for a private debt.

options.label: C
options.text: It is voidable at Luke's option, because Sophie breached her fiduciary duty.

options.label: D
options.text: It is valid only if the loan money is paid into the partnership bank account.

options.label: E
options.text: It is valid, but Sophie must indemnify Luke for any loss if the van is seized.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Under the Partnership Act 1890, a partner's implied authority does not extend to using partnership property as security for their own personal debt. This is not an act for carrying on the business in the usual way. Henry cannot rely on apparent authority for this non-business purpose.
Option A is incorrect. Apparent authority only covers acts in the ordinary course of the firm's business. Pledging a business asset for a personal loan is not within the ordinary course.
Option C is incorrect. The transaction is likely void ab initio against the firm, not merely voidable, as ...

questions.text: Jessica and Robert are partners in a bookshop under the Partnership Act 1890 with no written agreement. Jessica decides, without consulting Robert, to open a second bookshop in a neighbouring town, signing a two-year lease in the firm's name. Is the partnership bound by this lease?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because expanding the business is within the implied authority of a partner in a trading firm.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because opening a new branch fundamentally changes the scope of the partnership business which requires unanimous consent.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but only if the new shop is profitable in its first year of trading.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because a lease is a contract concerning land, and partners have no implied authority to bind the firm to interests in land.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but Robert can dissolve the partnership immediately if he does not approve.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Under s.24(8) of the Partnership Act 1890, unanimous consent is required for any act which would make it impossible to carry on the ordinary business of the partnership. Committing to a two-year lease for a new branch is a major expansion altering the scope and risk of the firm, requiring consent of all partners.
Option A is incorrect. While buying stock is ordinary, a major expansion like opening a new premises is not considered a day-to-day trading decision.
Option C is incorrect. The binding nature of the contract is determined at the time of entry, not by subsequent pr...

questions.text: Elena and Mark are partners in a dental practice. Their partnership agreement is silent on decision-making procedures. Elena wishes to purchase a new, very expensive digital X-ray machine for the practice. Mark refuses, believing the current equipment is adequate. Can Elena proceed with the purchase?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because purchasing medical equipment is within the implied authority of a partner in a professional practice.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the purchase of a major capital asset is outside the ordinary course of business and requires Mark's consent.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but only if she funds the purchase entirely from her personal savings.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because partnerships can only purchase assets for cash, and such a large purchase would require financing which needs unanimous consent.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, because a majority decision is sufficient for any partnership decision where the agreement is silent.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Under the default rules of the Partnership Act 1890, a partner's implied authority covers acts in the ordinary course of business. Purchasing a major, expensive piece of capital equipment is not an ordinary, day-to-day decision for a dental practice; it is a substantial commitment that changes the financial structure of the firm. Such an act likely falls under s.24(8), requiring unanimous consent.
Option A is incorrect. While buying standard supplies is ordinary, a major capital expenditure on specialised equipment is not.
Option C is incorrect. If she purchased it persona...

questions.text: Peter and Rachel are partners in a car repair garage with no written agreement. Peter accepts a customer's luxury car for a complex engine repair, quoting a price of £8,000. Rachel, who specialises in bodywork, was not consulted. The repair goes wrong, causing significant further damage to the car. The customer sues the partnership. Is the partnership liable for the customer's loss?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because Peter acted outside his ordinary authority by accepting such a complex and expensive job without Rachel's skill or consent.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because Peter, as a partner, had apparent authority to accept repair work for the garage.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because liability in a partnership is several, not joint, so only Peter is personally liable for his own negligent work.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only up to the value of the partnership assets; Peter alone is personally liable for any excess.

options.label: E
options.text: No, unless Rachel personally participated in or supervised the failed repair work.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Accepting cars for repair is the core business of the garage. Peter had apparent authority to bind the firm in such contracts. Under s.10 of the Partnership Act 1890, the firm is liable for the wrongful acts of a partner acting in the ordinary course of business.
Option A is incorrect. Accepting repair work, even complex jobs, is within the ordinary business of a garage. The default rule does not require consent of other partners for such core trading acts.
Option C is incorrect. Under s.9-12, partners are jointly liable for partnership debts and obligations arising from w...

questions.text: Laura and Nicholas are partners in a delicatessen. Their partnership agreement states that all decisions must be unanimous. Laura, while Nicholas is on holiday, signs a one-year contract with a new cheese supplier to ensure stock continuity. Nicholas dislikes the new supplier upon his return. What is the legal position regarding this contract?

options.label: A
options.text: The contract is binding on the partnership because Laura had apparent authority to buy stock in the ordinary course.

options.label: B
options.text: The contract is not binding on Nicholas because the partnership agreement required unanimity, which was not obtained.

options.label: C
options.text: The contract is binding on the partnership because Nicholas's holiday constituted implied consent to Laura making necessary decisions.

options.label: D
options.text: The contract is voidable at Nicholas's option because Laura breached the partnership agreement.

options.label: E
options.text: The contract is binding only if the new supplier can prove they were unaware of the unanimity clause.

questions.explanation:
Option A is correct. Buying stock from a supplier is within the ordinary course of a retail business. The internal unanimity clause does not affect a third party (the supplier) who has no notice of it. Laura had apparent authority, so the firm is bound.
Option B is incorrect. The agreement governs relations between Laura and Nicholas. Nicholas may have a claim against Laura for breach of agreement, but the contract with the supplier is valid.
Option C is incorrect. There is no doctrine of "implied consent due to holiday" that overrides a written agreement between partners. The binding nature s...

questions.text: Anthony and Zoe are partners in a florist shop under the Partnership Act 1890 with no written agreement. Anthony wishes to retire. Zoe wants to continue the business. They agree Anthony will leave and Zoe will pay him his capital contribution over six months. What is the minimum requirement for this retirement to be effective against future creditors of the old firm?

options.label: A
options.text: A written and signed agreement between Anthony and Zoe stating he has retired.

options.label: B
options.text: A notice of the retirement must be placed in the London Gazette.

options.label: C
options.text: Notification must be given to all existing creditors of the partnership.

options.label: D
options.text: No formalities are required; the private agreement between them is sufficient.

options.label: E
options.text: The retirement must be advertised in a local newspaper circulating in the area where the business is carried on.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Under s.36 of the Partnership Act 1890, a partner who retires does not cease to be liable for partnership debts incurred before their retirement. However, they may be discharged from liability for future debts by an agreement with the continuing partners and the creditors themselves. Failing that, a public notice in the London Gazette is effective to discharge the retiring partner from future debts to persons who had no prior dealings with the firm.
Option A is incorrect. A private agreement does not protect Anthony from future creditors.
Option C is incorrect. Notificatio...

questions.text: Benjamin and Katherine are partners in a bakery with no written agreement. Benjamin holds himself out as the "Managing Partner" on the shop signage and stationery. He enters into a contract to cater a large wedding for £5,000. The wedding client had never dealt with the bakery before. Katherine was unaware of the contract. Is the partnership bound?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because catering for weddings is not in the ordinary course of a bakery's business.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because Benjamin held himself out as the managing partner, giving him enhanced apparent authority in the eyes of a new customer.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the value of the contract is large and therefore outside the scope of implied authority.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the bakery had previously done some catering work.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because Katherine did not consent.

questions.explanation:
Option A is correct. The implied authority of a partner is limited to acts in the ordinary course of that type of business. For a retail bakery, selling goods over the counter is ordinary. Taking on a large, one-off catering contract is a different type of venture, likely outside the ordinary course. The client, as a new customer, cannot assume it is ordinary.
Option B is incorrect. The title "Managing Partner" does not, by itself, extend the scope of ordinary business. Apparent authority is based on the usual business of a bakery.
Option C is incorrect. While value can be a factor, the primar...

questions.text: Olivia and Sebastian are partners in a graphic design firm. Their written agreement states profits are shared 60:40. It is silent on losses. The firm incurs a significant loss due to a bad debt from a client who went bankrupt. How is this loss to be shared?

options.label: A
options.text: In the same proportion as profits, i.e., 60:40

options.label: B
options.text: Equally

options.label: C
options.text: It is borne solely by Olivia

options.label: D
options.text: In proportion to the partners' capital contributions, which is the default rule under the Act.

options.label: E
options.text: The loss remains a firm loss and is carried forward; it is not allocated to individual partners until dissolution.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Section 24(1) of the Partnership Act 1890 provides that, subject to any agreement, partners share capital, profits, and losses equally. An agreement on profit-sharing is not automatically an agreement on loss-sharing. Since the agreement is silent on losses, the default equal sharing rule applies.
Option A is incorrect. The courts have held that a profit-sharing ratio does not necessarily imply an identical loss-sharing ratio unless the agreement clearly states so.
Option C is incorrect. There is no such rule.
Option D is incorrect. The default rule for loss sharing is equ...

questions.text: Henry and Isabella are partners in a bookmaking business (taking bets on sports). Henry, without Isabella's knowledge, accepts a very large bet from a customer which the firm cannot cover if it loses. The bet loses, and the customer demands payment. Is the partnership liable to pay the customer?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because accepting a bet of such size was reckless and outside the ordinary course of prudent business.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because accepting bets is the ordinary business of the firm, and Henry had apparent authority to do so.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because gambling contracts are void and unenforceable under the Gambling Act 2005.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but Isabella can sue Henry for an indemnity for the full amount.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the customer should have known that such a large bet required approval from both partners.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. The business is bookmaking. Accepting bets is its ordinary business. A partner has apparent authority to conduct that business. The size of the bet, while imprudent, does not necessarily take it outside the ordinary course of that specific business. The firm is bound.
Option A is incorrect. While imprudent, the act is of the type the firm exists to perform. The question of ordinary course is judged by the nature of the business, not the prudence of a single act.
Option C is incorrect. While the Gambling Act 2005 made gambling contracts enforceable, not void. This does not ...

questions.text: Christopher and Maria are partners in a restaurant. They have no written agreement. Christopher wants to introduce his son, Alex, as a new partner. Maria refuses. Can Christopher introduce Alex as a partner?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because a partner has implied authority to manage the staff and hiring, which includes admitting new partners.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the introduction of a new partner requires the unanimous consent of all existing partners

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but Alex's share of profits must come solely from Christopher's existing share.

options.label: D
options.text: No, unless the partnership agreement expressly permits the introduction of family members.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, provided Alex contributes significant capital to the business.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Under s.24(7) of the Partnership Act 1890, "no person may be introduced as a partner without the consent of all existing partners." This is a fundamental default rule.
Option A is incorrect. Admitting a partner is fundamentally different from hiring an employee; it alters the mutual agency and financial liability of the firm.
Option C is incorrect. Even if profit shares were rearranged, the admission itself requires consent.
Option D is incorrect. The default rule in the 1890 Act requires unanimity. An agreement could modify this, but here there is no agreement.
Option E i...

questions.text: Daniel and Emma are partners in a health food shop. Their partnership agreement states that the partnership shall continue for a fixed term of five years. In year three, a serious disagreement arises. Daniel serves notice on Emma that he is exercising his right to dissolve the partnership. Can Daniel dissolve the partnership unilaterally?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the partnership is for a fixed term, and neither partner can dissolve it before the expiry of that term without consent or a court order.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because any partner has the right to dissolve the partnership at any time by giving notice under s.26 of the Partnership Act 1890.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because dissolution requires a majority resolution of the partners.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but he will be liable to Emma for damages for breach of the partnership agreement.

options.label: E
options.text: No, unless he can prove that Emma has been guilty of conduct prejudicial to the business.

questions.explanation:
Option D is correct. Under s.27 of the Partnership Act 1890, a partnership entered into for a fixed term can still be dissolved by notice if a partner chooses. However, this constitutes a breach of the partnership agreement, and the dissolving partner may be liable in damages to the other partner(s) for any loss caused by the premature dissolution.
Option A is incorrect. S.27 allows for dissolution before the end of a fixed term.
Option B is incorrect. S.26 applies to partnerships at will (with no fixed term). S.27 governs fixed-term partnerships.
Option C is incorrect. Dissolution by notice i...

questions.text: David is a director of "Tower Trading Ltd," which is insolvent and on the brink of collapse. One month ago, David arranged for the company to repay in full a £50,000 unsecured loan from his wife, while leaving other unsecured trade creditors unpaid. The company has now entered administration. Which of the following is most likely to allow the administrator to recover this repayment from David’s wife?

options.label: A
options.text: Wrongful trading.

options.label: B
options.text: A transaction at an undervalue.

options.label: C
options.text: A preference

options.label: D
options.text: Fraudulent trading

options.label: E
options.text: Setting aside a floating charge under s.245 of the Insolvency Act 1986.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. A preference occurs when a company does something that puts a creditor (or surety/guarantor) into a better position in a potential insolvency than they would otherwise have been. Repaying a connected party (David’s wife) shortly before insolvency, to the detriment of other creditors, is a classic example of a voidable preference under s.239.
Option A is incorrect. Wrongful trading relates to a director continuing to trade when there was no reasonable prospect of avoiding insolvency, not to the repayment of specific debts.
Option B is incorrect. A transaction at an underval...

questions.text: "Birchwood Ltd" is in financial difficulty. Its directors, Emma and Frank, know the company is insolvent but continue to accept customer deposits for goods they have no realistic chance of delivering, using the money to pay pressing wage bills. The company later enters compulsory liquidation. Which of the following presents the greatest personal liability risk to Emma and Frank in these circumstances?

options.label: A
options.text: Being investigated for misfeasance

options.label: B
options.text: A declaration of wrongful trading and a contribution order

options.label: C
options.text: A criminal prosecution for fraudulent trading

options.label: D
options.text: Being held liable for transactions at an undervalue

options.label: E
options.text: Disqualification from acting as a director

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. The scenario describes taking deposits with no intent or ability to supply the goods, which is indicative of actual dishonesty. This is the hallmark of fraudulent trading, which can be both a civil matter (s.213 IA 1986) and a criminal offence (s.993 CA 2006). Criminal liability carries the greatest personal risk.
Option A is incorrect. Misfeasance is a breach of fiduciary duty, but the conduct described goes beyond mere breach of duty into potential criminality.
Option B is incorrect. Wrongful trading (s.214) applies where directors ought to have known there was no reason...

questions.text: "Ashcroft Ltd" enters administration. The administrator is realising assets. The company’s assets comprise: (i) £50,000 from the sale of a factory subject to a fixed charge; (ii) £30,000 from the sale of stock subject to a floating charge; (iii) £10,000 cash at bank (unsecured). The fixed charge holder is owed £60,000. The floating charge holder is owed £40,000. Preferential creditors (mainly employees) claim £8,000. The administrator’s fees and expenses are £5,000. In what order should these funds be distributed?

options.label: A
options.text: 1. Administrator’s fees; 2. Preferential creditors; 3. Fixed charge holder; 4. Floating charge holder; 5. Unsecured creditors.

options.label: B
options.text: 1. Fixed charge holder ; 2. Administrator’s fees ; 3. Preferential creditors ; 4. Floating charge holder; 5. Unsecured creditors.

options.label: C
options.text: 1. Administrator’s fees (from all assets); 2. Fixed charge holder; 3. Preferential creditors; 4. Floating charge holder; 5. Unsecured creditors.

options.label: D
options.text: 1. Preferential creditors; 2. Administrator’s fees; 3. Fixed charge holder; 4. Floating charge holder; 5. Unsecured creditors.

options.label: E
options.text: 1. Fixed charge holder; 2. Floating charge holder; 3. Administrator’s fees; 4. Preferential creditors; 5. Unsecured creditors.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. The fixed charge holder has first claim on the proceeds of their specific asset (£50k, leaving a £10k shortfall as an unsecured claim). Assets subject to the floating charge (£30k from stock) are distributed in the statutory order under the Insolvency Act 1986: first, the costs of the administrator (s.176ZA), then preferential creditors, then the floating charge holder. Any remaining funds (the £10k cash) are for unsecured creditors.
Option A is incorrect because it does not segregate the fixed charge asset proceeds.
Option C is incorrect because administrator’s fees are p...

questions.text: George is an individual with significant credit card debts and an unsecured personal loan. He has a steady job but cannot meet his monthly repayments. He wants to avoid bankruptcy and have a legally binding arrangement to pay back an affordable portion of his debts over time. Which procedure is most suitable for George?

options.label: A
options.text: Administration.

options.label: B
options.text: A Company Voluntary Arrangement (CVA).

options.label: C
options.text: An Individual Voluntary Arrangement (IVA).

options.label: D
options.text: Debt Relief Order (DRO).

options.label: E
options.text: Compulsory Liquidation.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. An Individual Voluntary Arrangement (IVA) is a formal agreement between an individual and their creditors, supervised by an insolvency practitioner, to pay back debts over a set period (usually 5 years). It is designed to avoid bankruptcy.
Option A is incorrect. Administration is a corporate insolvency procedure.
Option B is incorrect. A CVA is a procedure for companies.
Option D is incorrect. A DRO is for individuals with low income, low assets, and debts below a specific threshold; it is not a repayment plan.
Option E is incorrect. Compulsory liquidation is a process to ...

questions.text: "Denby Products Ltd" granted a floating charge to its bank, SecuredBank Ltd, on 1 March 2025 to secure an existing overdraft from the previous year. The company went into administration on 1 June 2025. The charge was registered at Companies House on 5 March 2025. Can the administrator seek to set aside this floating charge under s.245 of the Insolvency Act 1986?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the charge was properly registered at Companies House.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because it was a floating charge created within 12 months of the onset of insolvency.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because it secured money paid before the charge was created (the existing overdraft).

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if it can be shown that the company was already insolvent when the charge was created.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, because it was a floating charge created within 6 months of the onset of insolvency.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. S.245 of the Insolvency Act 1986 provides that a floating charge created within 12 months of the onset of insolvency (with certain exceptions) is invalid except to the extent of new money, goods, or services provided at the time of or after the creation of the charge. The charge here was created on 1 March, and administration began on 1 June, which is within 12 months.
Option A is incorrect. Registration is a separate requirement; it does not protect a charge from being set aside under s.245.
Option C is incorrect. The fact it secured past debt (the existing overdraft) is ...

questions.text: Helen is the sole director of "Kestrel Ltd." As the company nears insolvency, she transfers its main delivery van, worth £15,000, to a competing business owned by her brother for £5,000. The company enters liquidation two months later. Which provision allows the liquidator to challenge this transaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Fraudulent trading.

options.label: B
options.text: Wrongful trading

options.label: C
options.text: A transaction at an undervalue

options.label: D
options.text: A Preference

options.label: E
options.text: Misfeasance

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. A transaction at an undervalue under s.238 occurs where a company makes a gift or receives ‘significantly less’ in money or money’s worth than it provides. Selling a £15,000 van for £5,000 is a clear example.
Option A is incorrect. Fraudulent trading involves carrying on business with intent to defraud creditors, not a specific asset transfer.
Option B is incorrect. Wrongful trading relates to the period of trading when insolvency was inevitable.
Option D is incorrect. A preference involves improving the position of a creditor. Here, the brother is not a creditor; he is a ...

questions.text: "Lakeside Ltd" is put into compulsory liquidation by its creditors. The liquidator discovers that three months before the liquidation, the company paid its electricity bill, which was six months overdue, in full. The electricity company was an unconnected, ordinary trade creditor. Can the liquidator recover this payment as a preference?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the electricity company was not connected to the directors.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because any payment to a creditor within 6 months of liquidation is a voidable preference.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because paying an overdue utility bill is in the ordinary course of business.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the company was insolvent at the time of the payment and it had the effect of preferring that creditor.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the payment was for a legitimate debt and the creditor gave no fresh value.

questions.explanation:
Option D is correct. For a preference under s.239, the liquidator must show the company was influenced by a desire to put the creditor in a better position (which can be inferred in the case of a connected person, but must be proven for an unconnected person like the electricity company). The company must also have been insolvent at the time or become insolvent because of the transaction.
Option A is incorrect. Preferences can apply to unconnected persons, but the ‘desire’ test is harder to prove.
Option B is incorrect. Not every payment is a preference; the statutory conditions must be met.
O...

questions.text: Mohammed is an individual debtor. He has no realisable assets, lives in rented accommodation, and has debts of £25,000. He is unemployed and on benefits. Which insolvency solution is likely to be most appropriate and accessible for him?

options.label: A
options.text: Bankruptcy.

options.label: B
options.text: An Individual Voluntary Arrangement (IVA).

options.label: C
options.text: A Debt Relief Order (DRO).

options.label: D
options.text: A Consolidation Loan.

options.label: E
options.text: Administration.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. A Debt Relief Order (DRO) is designed for individuals with low income, low assets (under £2,000), debts under £30,000, and no realistic prospect of repaying them. It results in debts being discharged after one year without requiring monthly payments.
Option A is incorrect. Bankruptcy is an option but involves higher fees and is more severe; a DRO is a simpler, cheaper alternative for those who qualify.
Option B is incorrect. An IVA requires a regular income to make monthly payments, which Mohammed does not have.
Option D is incorrect. A consolidation loan is not an insolve...

questions.text: "Norton Ltd" is in administration. The administrator is considering whether to adopt a contract for the supply of services which was entered into by the company before administration. The contract is loss-making. What is the primary legal consequence if the administrator adopts this contract?

options.label: A
options.text: The administrator becomes personally liable for any debts incurred under the contract from the time of adoption onwards.

options.label: B
options.text: The costs of fulfilling the contract will rank as an expense of the administration with priority.

options.label: C
options.text: The contract is automatically terminated, and the other party can only claim damages as an unsecured creditor.

options.label: D
options.text: The company’s pre-administration liabilities under the contract are paid in full immediately.

options.label: E
options.text: The administrator must obtain court approval before continuing with the contract.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Under para 99 of Schedule B1 to the Insolvency Act 1986, if an administrator adopts a contract, any liability incurred under it during the administration is payable as an expense of the administration, which ranks in priority to the administrator’s own remuneration and floating charge holders.
Option A is incorrect. The administrator does not incur personal liability; the liability is an expense of the administration payable from company assets.
Option C is incorrect. Adoption means the contract continues, not that it is terminated.
Option D is incorrect. Pre-administratio...

questions.text: "Oakfield Ltd" is wound up voluntarily. Its statement of affairs shows: Assets of £100,000; Fixed Charge Holder owed £80,000; Floating Charge Holder owed £60,000; Preferential Creditors owed £15,000; Unsecured Creditors owed £150,000; and Liquidation costs of £10,000. What is the prescribed part' under s.176A of the Insolvency Act 1986, and who is it for?

options.label: A
options.text: A sum set aside from the assets for the benefit of the company’s members (shareholders).

options.label: B
options.text: A sum set aside from the assets subject to a floating charge for the payment of the liquidator’s fees.

options.label: C
options.text: A sum set aside from the assets subject to a floating charge for the payment of unsecured creditors.

options.label: D
options.text: A sum set aside from all assets for the payment of preferential creditors.

options.label: E
options.text: A sum set aside from the assets subject to a fixed charge for the payment of employee claims.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. S.176A requires that a prescribed part’ of the company’s net property which is subject to a floating charge must be set aside for the benefit of unsecured creditors. The amount is capped (currently 50% of the first £10,000 and 20% of the remainder, with an overall maximum of £800,000).
Option A is incorrect. Members are last in the order of priority.
Option B is incorrect. Liquidation costs are paid before the prescribed part is calculated.
Option D is incorrect. Preferential creditors are paid from floating charge assets before the floating charge holder, but the prescrib...

questions.text: Three months before "Pinehurst Ltd" entered administration, its director, Sarah, who had personally guaranteed the company’s bank loan, arranged for the company to pay £20,000 to the bank, reducing the guarantee exposure. Other unsecured creditors were not paid. Which of the following is the most relevant claim for the administrator?

options.label: A
options.text: Transaction at an undervalue against the bank (s.238).

options.label: B
options.text: Preference in favour of Sarah as a surety (s.239).

options.label: C
options.text: Wrongful trading against Sarah (s.214).

options.label: D
options.text: Fraudulent trading against Sarah (s.213).

options.label: E
options.text: Setting aside a floating charge (s.245).

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. A payment to a creditor which has the effect of putting a surety or guarantor (here, Sarah) in a better position can be a preference of that surety under s.239. The company’s payment reduced Sarah’s potential liability under her guarantee, thereby preferring her.
Option A is incorrect. The payment was for full value (reducing a debt), not an undervalue.
