Option C and D are incorrect. They relate to the conduct of trading, not a specific payment.
Option E is incorrect. The scenario involves a payment, not the creation of a charge.

questions.text: Raj is an individual who has been declared bankrupt. He owns a house jointly with his wife, which has £100,000 equity. He also has a valuable vintage car collection. What is the general rule regarding these assets in his bankruptcy?

options.label: A
options.text: Both the house equity and the car collection will automatically vest in his trustee in bankruptcy immediately.

options.label: B
options.text: The house is protected if it is the family home, but the car collection will vest in the trustee.

options.label: C
options.text: Both assets are exempt if their total value is below a certain threshold.

options.label: D
options.text: All of Raj’s assets vest in his trustee in bankruptcy, subject to certain exemptions and the rights of secured creditors.

options.label: E
options.text: Only assets acquired after the bankruptcy order vest in the trustee.

questions.explanation:
Option D is correct. Upon bankruptcy, the bankrupt’s estate (with limited exceptions) vests in the trustee in bankruptcy under s.306 of the Insolvency Act 1986. The trustee will realise these assets for creditors. The family home is not automatically exempt, but the trustee has three years to deal with it, and the spouse may have rights. The car collection is not an exempt asset unless it is a vehicle used for personal travel, which may be of limited value.
Option A is incorrect. While they vest, the process is not automatic in the sense of immediate seizure; the trustee must take steps.
Optio...

questions.text: "Summit Ltd" is in creditors’ voluntary liquidation. The order of payment from the company’s assets is being determined. Which of the following is the correct order of priority for payment?

options.label: A
options.text: 1. Secured creditors with a fixed charge; 2. Liquidation expenses; 3. Preferential creditors; 4. Secured creditors with a floating charge; 5. Unsecured creditors; 6. Members.

options.label: B
options.text: 1. Liquidation expenses; 2. Preferential creditors; 3. Secured creditors with a fixed charge; 4. Secured creditors with a floating charge; 5. Unsecured creditors; 6. Members.

options.label: C
options.text: 1. Secured creditors with a fixed charge; 2. Liquidation expenses; 3. Preferential creditors; 4. Secured creditors with a floating charge; 5. Unsecured creditors; 6. Members.

options.label: D
options.text: 1. Liquidation expenses; 2. Secured creditors with a fixed charge; 3. Preferential creditors; 4. Secured creditors with a floating charge; 5. Unsecured creditors; 6. Members.

options.label: E
options.text: 1. Preferential creditors; 2. Liquidation expenses; 3. Secured creditors (fixed then floating); 4. Unsecured creditors; 5. Members.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. The fixed charge holder is paid from the proceeds of the asset over which the charge is held. Liquidation expenses are then paid from the general assets. Preferential creditors are paid next from assets not subject to a fixed charge (primarily from floating charge assets, after expenses). Then the floating charge holder is paid. Then unsecured creditors. Finally, any surplus to members.
Option A is incorrect because it places liquidation expenses after the fixed charge holder, but expenses are paid from the general estate before preferential creditors.
Option B and D are i...

questions.text: "Torridge Ltd" is insolvent. Its director, Chloe, knows the company cannot pay its debts as they fall due but continues to trade for four months, incurring £50,000 of new credit from suppliers. The company then goes into liquidation. What must the liquidator prove to obtain a contribution order against Chloe for wrongful trading under s.214?

options.label: A
options.text: That Chloe acted dishonestly in incurring the new debts.

options.label: B
options.text: That Chloe knew the company was insolvent and continued to trade.

options.label: C
options.text: That at some point before the commencement of winding up, Chloe knew there was no reasonable prospect of avoiding insolvent liquidation, and she failed to minimise loss to creditors.

options.label: D
options.text: That she preferred some creditors over others during the four-month period.

options.label: E
options.text: That she transferred assets out of the company at an undervalue.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. This is the precise statutory test for wrongful trading under s.214 of the Insolvency Act 1986. It is an objective test (ought to have concluded) and requires a failure to take minimising steps.
Option A is incorrect. Dishonesty is the test for fraudulent trading, not wrongful trading.
Option B is incorrect. Simply knowing the company is insolvent is not enough; the test requires knowledge that there was no reasonable prospect of avoiding insolvent liquidation.
Option D is incorrect. Preferences are a separate matter under s.239.
Option E is incorrect. Transactions at an u...

questions.text: An Individual Voluntary Arrangement (IVA) has been approved by Daniel’s creditors. Three years into the five-year arrangement, Daniel receives an unexpected inheritance of £50,000. What is the likely consequence of this?

options.label: A
options.text: The inheritance is Daniel’s to keep; it does not affect the IVA as it is a windfall after the arrangement started.

options.label: B
options.text: The IVA will fail automatically, and Daniel will be made bankrupt.

options.label: C
options.text: Daniel must inform his insolvency practitioner, who will likely require the inheritance to be paid into the IVA for the benefit of creditors.

options.label: D
options.text: Daniel can use the inheritance to make a full and final settlement offer, but he is under no obligation to do so.

options.label: E
options.text: The inheritance is protected as it is not income from his employment.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. Standard IVA terms include a ‘windfall clause’ requiring any unexpected assets or sums received during the term (like an inheritance) to be paid into the arrangement for creditors.
Option A is incorrect. IVAs typically capture windfalls during their term.
Option B is incorrect. A windfall does not cause automatic failure; it is provided for in the terms.
Option D is incorrect. While a full and final settlement is possible, he is obliged to pay the windfall in under the terms.
Option E is incorrect. The source is irrelevant; it is a windfall captured by the IVA.

questions.text: "Vale Ltd" enters administration. The administrator sells the business and assets as a going concern to a new company. Six months prior to administration, Vale Ltd had made a gift of a piece of machinery to its chairman. Can the administrator recover this gift?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the gift was made more than 6 months before the administration.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, as a transaction at an undervalue, provided Vale Ltd was insolvent at the time or became insolvent because of it.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the chairman was not a creditor.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if it can be shown the chairman influenced the directors to make the gift.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the administrator’s role is to rescue the company, not to pursue historic transactions.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. A gift is the clearest form of transaction at an undervalue under s.238. The relevant time period is 2 years before the onset of insolvency if the transaction is with a connected person (like a chairman). The administrator can apply to court to have it set aside.
Option A is incorrect. The relevant look-back period for transactions at an undervalue with connected persons is 2 years, not 6 months.
Option C is incorrect. Recovery under s.238 does not require the recipient to be a creditor.
Option D is incorrect. While influence may be relevant to preferences, for a transacti...

questions.text: William is made bankrupt. He has an outstanding student loan. What is the status of this student loan in his bankruptcy?

options.label: A
options.text: It is discharged upon his discharge from bankruptcy (usually after one year).

options.label: B
options.text: It is treated as an ordinary unsecured debt and included in the bankruptcy.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a non-provable debt and survives his bankruptcy.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a preferential debt and must be paid in full by the trustee.

options.label: E
options.text: It is a secured debt against his future earnings.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. Student loans (of the type administered by the Student Loans Company) are specifically excluded from being provable debts in bankruptcy under the Insolvency Rules 2016. Therefore, they are not discharged by bankruptcy and remain payable.
Option A is incorrect. Only provable debts are discharged; student loans are an exception.
Option B is incorrect. They are not provable, so not included.
Option D is incorrect. They are not preferential debts.
Option E is incorrect. They are not secured debts.

questions.text: "Westgate Ltd" is in administration. The administrator is trying to decide which of the statutory objectives to pursue. The company has no viable business to rescue, but its assets are greater than would be achieved in a winding-up. Which objective should the administrator pursue?

options.label: A
options.text: Rescuing the company as a going concern.

options.label: B
options.text: Achieving a better result for the company’s creditors as a whole than would be likely in a winding up.

options.label: C
options.text: Realising property to make a distribution to one or more secured or preferential creditors.

options.label: D
options.text: Immediately moving the company into creditors’ voluntary liquidation.

options.label: E
options.text: Selling the assets piecemeal as quickly as possible.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Under para 3(1)(b) of Schedule B1 to the Insolvency Act 1986, if rescuing the company is not reasonably practicable, the administrator must pursue the objective of achieving a better result for creditors as a whole than in a winding up. The scenario describes this situation.
Option A is incorrect. The question states there is no viable business to rescue.
Option C is incorrect. This is the third objective (para 3(1)(c)), but it is only to be pursued if the administrator thinks neither of the first two objectives is achievable. Objective B is achievable here.
Option D is in...

questions.text: "Yewtree Ltd" granted a floating charge to its bank on 1 January 2025. The company went into liquidation on 1 November 2025. The charge secured an overdraft facility that was already fully drawn on 1 January 2025. No new money was advanced when the charge was created. What is the status of this floating charge?

options.label: A
options.text: It is valid and ranks above preferential creditors.

options.label: B
options.text: It is invalid except to the extent of any interest accruing after 1 January 2025.

options.label: C
options.text: It is void as a floating charge created for past consideration within 12 months of liquidation.

options.label: D
options.text: It is void as a floating charge created for past consideration within 6 months of liquidation.

options.label: E
options.text: It is voidable at the option of the liquidator as a preference.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. S.245 of the Insolvency Act 1986 renders a floating charge created within 12 months of the onset of insolvency invalid, except to the extent of new money, goods, or services provided at the time of or after the charge’s creation. Here, the charge secured an existing overdraft (past consideration) and was created within 12 months of liquidation, so it is invalid.Therefore, Option D is incorrect.
Option A is incorrect. S.245 invalidates such charges.
Option B is incorrect. The exception is for new value, not interest on old value.
Option E is incorrect. S.245 is a specific p...

questions.text: Zara is the sole director of "Apex Ltd." The company is insolvent. To keep a key supplier happy, Zara arranges for the company to pay that supplier’s invoice of £10,000 in full, while leaving other similar suppliers unpaid. The payment is made two months before the company enters compulsory liquidation. The supplier is not connected to Zara. Can the liquidator recover this payment?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the supplier was not a connected person.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, automatically, as it is a preference within the relevant period.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because it was a genuine business decision to maintain a key relationship.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the liquidator can prove that Zara was influenced by a desire to prefer that supplier.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the payment was in the ordinary course of business.

questions.explanation:
Option D is correct. For an unconnected person, to establish a preference under s.239, the liquidator must prove the company was influenced by a desire to put the creditor in a better position. This is a subjective test and can be difficult to prove, but it is the correct legal hurdle.
Option A is incorrect. Preferences can apply to unconnected persons, but the ‘desire’ test applies.
Option B is incorrect. It is not automatic; the conditions, including the ‘desire’ for unconnected persons, must be proven.
Option C is incorrect. The commercial rationale may be a factor, but it is not an absolut...

areas.name: Core institutions of the state and how they interrelate

questions.text: The "European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018" repealed the European Communities Act 1972 and provided that EU-derived domestic legislation should continue to have effect in UK law. Section 5 of the Act states that the principle of the supremacy of EU law does not apply to any enactment or rule of law passed or made on or after the specified exit day. However, Section 5(3) states that this is "subject to relevant case law." How does this legislative framework affect the traditional doctrine of parliamentary sovereignty post-Brexit?

options.label: A
options.text: It fully restores the traditional Diceyan doctrine, as Parliament has expressly ended the supremacy of EU law.

options.label: B
options.text: It creates a new form of statutory entrenchment for retained EU law, which future Parliaments cannot amend.

options.label: C
options.text: It represents a self-imposed limitation by Parliament, but one that a future sovereign Parliament could choose to disregard by expressly repealing or amending the 2018 Act.

options.label: D
options.text: It permanently transfers sovereignty from Parliament to the judiciary, as the courts must interpret future law in line with retained EU case law.

options.label: E
options.text: It has no effect, as the supremacy of EU law was always a political fiction and not a legal constraint.

questions.explanation: Option C is correct. The 2018 Act represents a complex statutory scheme that Parliament has created. It preserves certain EU laws and their interpretive principles as a body of domestic law ("retained EU law"). While this constrains future legislation by implication, the sovereignty of Parliament means that a future Parliament could pass an Act that explicitly amends or repeals the 2018 Act, or that expressly states it is to take effect notwithstanding retained EU law. The constraint is political and practical, not legal. This reflects the principle in Thoburn v Sunderland City Council (the "M...

questions.text: Following a major public inquiry into a failed infrastructure project, the House of Commons passes a motion finding the Secretary of State for Transport "in contempt of Parliament" for refusing to hand over key documents to a select committee. The Minister remains in post, and the Prime Minister defends him. What does this scenario best demonstrate about ministerial responsibility in the UK constitution?

options.label: A
options.text: The legal enforcement of collective responsibility through the courts.

options.label: B
options.text: The erosion of the convention of individual ministerial responsibility, as resignation is no longer automatic.

options.label: C
options.text: The supremacy of Parliament, as demonstrated by its power to imprison the Minister.

options.label: D
options.text: The operation of the Ministerial Code as a legally binding document.

options.label: E
options.text: The direct accountability of ministers to the electorate, bypassing Parliament.

questions.explanation: Option B is correct. The convention of individual ministerial responsibility holds that ministers are accountable to Parliament and should resign for serious failures in their department. However, this convention is increasingly political rather than automatic. A finding of contempt is a severe parliamentary censure. The Minister's survival, backed by the Prime Minister, demonstrates that resignation is not an automatic legal consequence but a political judgement. The convention has eroded, with ministers often only resigning if they lose the confidence of the Prime Minister or their party, no...

questions.text: The Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011 was repealed by the Dissolution and Calling of Parliament Act 2022. The 2022 Act states: "The prerogative power to dissolve Parliament is revived." It further provides that "the power to dissolve Parliament is exercisable by His Majesty by proclamation" and that "a proclamation dissolving Parliament is to be made by His Majesty on the advice of the Prime Minister." What is the principal constitutional effect of this legislative change?

options.label: A
options.text: It transferred the legal power to dissolve Parliament from the House of Commons to the Crown.

options.label: B
options.text: It restored a non-statutory constitutional convention to its pre-2011 position, but now within a statutory framework that recognises it as a prerogative power.

options.label: C
options.text: It made the dissolution of Parliament a justiciable matter for the courts, as it is now governed by statute.

options.label: D
options.text: It entrenched the Prime Minister's power, making a vote of no confidence legally irrelevant.

options.label: E
options.text: It removed the Monarch's personal discretion to refuse a dissolution request.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. The 2011 Act had removed the prerogative power of dissolution and put it on a statutory footing. The 2022 Act repealed that framework and explicitly "revived" the prerogative power. However, by putting this in a statute, it creates a new, clearer statutory recognition of the power. The convention that the Monarch acts on the Prime Minister's advice in this matter is now referenced in the statute, but the power itself is characterised as a prerogative. It returns to a non-statutory convention-based system, albeit with a statutory acknowledgment.
Option A is misleading; the ...

questions.text: The Minister for the Cabinet Office issues a revised "Ministerial Code." The Preface, written by the Prime Minister, states: "The consequences of a breach of the Code are primarily a matter for the Prime Minister, as the ultimate judge of the standards of behaviour expected of ministers." An opposition MP argues that this undermines the role of the Independent Adviser on Ministerial Interests and the accountability of ministers to Parliament. What does this preface most clearly illustrate about the nature of the Ministerial Code?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a legally enforceable code of conduct, breach of which gives rise to a cause of action in court.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a set of rules, the interpretation and enforcement of which are ultimately within the political discretion of the Prime Minister of the day.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a statutory instrument, and its provisions override the conventions of individual ministerial responsibility.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a document issued by the Crown, and therefore its enforcement is a matter for the Monarch.

options.label: E
options.text: It is a codification of common law duties, making them justiciable.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. The Ministerial Code is a prime ministerial document, not grounded in statute. It sets out rules and conventions governing ministerial conduct. The Preface explicitly states that the Prime Minister is the "ultimate judge." This confirms its nature as an instrument of internal executive discipline, policed politically by the Prime Minister, not by Parliament or the courts. The role of the Independent Adviser is advisory only, lacking powers of investigation or sanction without the Prime Minister's approval.
Option A is incorrect; it is not legally enforceable.
Option C is i...

questions.text: The "Welsh Devolution Act 2024" is a UK Parliament statute that amends the Government of Wales Act 2006. It devolves further powers to the Senedd, including authority over youth justice and the probation service. Section 10 of the Act states: "A Minister of the Crown may not exercise any function in relation to a devolved Welsh matter without the agreement of the Welsh Ministers." What is the most accurate description of the legal status of Section 10?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a legally binding clause that the courts can enforce, preventing UK minister action without consent.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a statutory recognition of the Sewel Convention, but its enforcement remains political rather than strictly legal.

options.label: C
options.text: It is unconstitutional because it attempts to bind the UK executive, which derives its authority from the Crown.

options.label: D
options.text: It is redundant, as the Government of Wales Act 2006 already prohibits UK ministers from acting in devolved areas.

options.label: E
options.text: It creates a new federal structure, making Wales legally co-equal with England.

questions.explanation: Option B is correct. Section 10 appears to put a "Sewel-like" convention (that the UK government will not normally act in devolved areas without consent) into statutory language. However, whether such a clause is justiciable (enforceable by courts) depends on its precise wording and context. Even in statutory form, matters of inter-governmental agreement are often considered non-justiciable, involving political discretion. The clause likely creates a strong political expectation and a legal duty to seek agreement, but a court might be reluctant to adjudicate on the substance of "agreement" or ...

questions.text: The "Northern Ireland Protocol Act 2025" is passed by the UK Parliament. It gives a UK minister the power to disapply parts of the Northern Ireland Protocol (an international treaty) in domestic law. The Scottish Government argues that aspects of the Act affect devolved competences in Scotland (e.g., food standards for goods moving to Northern Ireland) and that a Legislative Consent Motion (LCM) should have been sought, but was not. What is the most significant factor in determining whether an LCM was constitutionally required?

options.label: A
options.text: The political pressure from the Scottish National Party.

options.label: B
options.text: The legal enforceability of the Sewel Convention as interpreted by the Supreme Court in UK Withdrawal from the EU (Legal Continuity) (Scotland) Bill.

options.label: C
options.text: The fact that the Act alters the executive competence of Scottish Ministers.

options.label: D
options.text: Whether the Act's provisions relate to matters that are within the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament.

options.label: E
options.text: The size of the UK Government's majority in the House of Commons.

questions.explanation: Option D is correct. The Sewel Convention, as set out in the Scotland Act 1998 (s.28(8)), states that Westminster will not "normally" legislate on devolved matters without the consent of the Scottish Parliament. The key test is whether the Westminster legislation "relates to" a devolved matter. If the Act affects food standards (a devolved matter) in Scotland, even incidentally, it touches on devolved competence. The requirement for an LCM is a political/constitutional convention triggered by this subject-matter test. The Supreme Court in the Continuity Bill case confirmed the convention is no...

questions.text: – Devolution, Reserved Matters, and Statutory Guidance The UK Parliament passes the Artificial Intelligence Regulation Act, creating a new statutory body called the Regulator for Artificial Intelligence. The regulator is tasked with overseeing the development and deployment of advanced AI systems across the entire United Kingdom, Under Schedule 2 of the Act, UK ministers are given the power to issue statutory guidance to the regulator on matters relating to “national security and defence interests.” The Act states that the regulator must “have regard to” such guidance when exercising its functions. Following intelligence briefings, the UK Secretary of State for Science and Security, Andrew, issues guidance instructing the regulator not to investigate a private technology company based in Edinburgh that is developing AI systems for use in military defence projects. The Scottish Ministers, led by Fiona, strongly object. They argue that AI research carried out at Scottish universities and private research centres falls within devolved competence, specifically education and research, and that the guidance unlawfully interferes with Scotland’s devolved powers. What is the best characterisation of the constitutional issue?

options.label: A
options.text: A conflict between a UK statute and an Act of the Scottish Parliament, resolved in favour of the UK Act under sovereignty.

options.label: B
options.text: A dispute about the scope of the regulator's statutory remit, a pure matter of administrative law.

options.label: C
options.text: A tension between a reserved matter and a devolved matter, where the UK statute prioritises the reserved matter.

options.label: D
options.text: A challenge to the monarch's independent exercise of the defence prerogative.

options.label: E
options.text: A demonstration of the legislative supremacy of the Scottish Parliament in its own competences.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. This scenario illustrates a classic devolution tension between a reserved matter and a devolved matter. Under the Scotland Act 1998, national security and defence are expressly reserved to the UK Parliament. By contrast, education and research are devolved matters.
However, devolved competence does not extend to activities that relate to reserved matters. Although AI research ordinarily falls within devolved competence, where that research is connected to national defence, it engages a reserved matter. The UK Parliament is therefore constitutionally entitled to legislate i...

questions.text: – Uncodified Constitution and Ministerial Roles Following a general election, the Prime Minister, Daniel, announces a cabinet reshuffle. As part of his plans to reinforce the unity of the UK, he creates a new role titled “Minister for the Union.” The role is given to a senior cabinet member, Christopher, and is described as responsible for coordinating policy affecting all parts of the UK and strengthening relationships with the devolved administrations. The First Minister of Scotland, Margaret, publicly criticises the appointment, describing it as a “constitutional gimmick” that undermines the existing role of the Secretary of State for Scotland and disrespects the devolution settlement. She argues that such a position should require statutory authority and consultation with devolved governments.

options.label: A
options.text: The flexibility of the UK's uncodified constitution, allowing for new ministerial roles without legislation.

options.label: B
options.text: The statutory basis for all cabinet positions, requiring an Act of Parliament.

options.label: C
options.text: The Monarch's personal prerogative to create new ministers.

options.label: D
options.text: The legal requirement for a minister from each devolved nation to be in the Cabinet.

options.label: E
options.text: The supremacy of the Prime Minister's power to appoint ministers over the wishes of devolved leaders.

questions.explanation:
Option A is correct. The UK has an uncodified constitution, meaning many aspects of government operate through convention, prerogative, and political practice, rather than rigid legal rules. The Prime Minister has broad discretion to organise the executive, including creating new ministerial titles and cabinet roles, without primary legislation.
This power derives from the royal prerogative of appointment, exercised by the Monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister, and supplemented by statutes such as the Ministers of the Crown Act 1975. The creation of roles like “Minister for the Union” de...

questions.text: – UK Inquiries and Devolution Following the Covid-19 pandemic, the UK Government establishes the UK Covid-19 Public Inquiry under the Inquiries Act 2005. The inquiry, chaired by Sir Jonathan, is tasked with examining the UK’s preparedness, decision-making, and response to the pandemic. Separately, the Scottish Government establishes its own Scottish Covid-19 Inquiry, chaired by Lady Eleanor, focusing on decisions taken by Scottish Ministers in devolved areas such as health and social care. As part of its investigation, the UK Inquiry issues formal notices requiring Scottish Ministers, including the former Health Secretary Peter, to give oral evidence and produce internal government documents. The Scottish Government initially refuses, arguing that health is devolved and that a UK inquiry has no authority to compel evidence relating to devolved matters. What is the key legal principle governing the UK Inquiry's powers in this devolution context?

options.label: A
options.text: The UK Inquiry has no power in Scotland, as devolved matters are exclusively for the Scottish inquiry.

options.label: B
options.text: The UK Inquiry, established under a UK statute, has the statutory power to compel evidence anywhere in the UK, regardless of devolution.

options.label: C
options.text: The principle of comity requires the UK Inquiry to defer to the Scottish inquiry on all devolved matters.

options.label: D
options.text: The Scottish Parliament's legislative competence shields its ministers from any UK-level investigative process.

options.label: E
options.text: The matter can only be resolved by a joint committee of both inquiries.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. An inquiry established under the Inquiries Act 2005 derives its powers directly from that statute. Unless Parliament expressly limits those powers, they apply throughout the UK, including in devolved territories.
Devolution limits the legislative competence of devolved legislatures, not the power of the UK Parliament to legislate for the entire UK. The devolution of health does not prevent Parliament from authorising a UK-wide inquiry with coercive powers.
While political conventions and intergovernmental comity are relevant, they do not limit the legal authority of a UK s...

questions.text: Following a General Election, no single party has a majority in the House of Commons. The leader of the largest party meets with the Monarch and informs her that he can form a government with the support of a smaller party on a "confidence and supply" basis. The Monarch asks for assurance that this government can command the confidence of the House of Commons. What is the constitutional purpose of the Monarch seeking this assurance?

options.label: A
options.text: To exercise the Monarch's personal political judgement about the proposed government's policies.

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure that the Prime Minister has the legal authority to appoint ministers under the Ministers of the Crown Act.

options.label: C
options.text: To uphold the convention that the Monarch appoints as Prime Minister the person most likely to command the confidence of the House of Commons.

options.label: D
options.text: To trigger a statutory provision in the Dissolution and Calling of Parliament Act 2022.

options.label: E
options.text: To allow the Privy Council to vote on the appointment.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. In a hung parliament, the Monarch's role is to facilitate the formation of a government that can sustain itself in office. The key constitutional convention is that the Monarch appoints as Prime Minister the person who can command the confidence of the House of Commons. This is not about policy but about parliamentary arithmetic and political agreements. By seeking assurance, the Monarch is ensuring the convention is followed, protecting the political neutrality of the Crown and ensuring the government has the necessary parliamentary foundation.
Option A is incorrect; the ...

questions.text: Jonathan is a constitutional lawyer advising a parliamentary select committee examining proposals to modernise the UK legislative process. The government introduces a Bill titled the Royal Assent Act 2024, promoted by the Lord Chancellor, Michael, as a purely procedural reform reflecting the reality that Royal Assent is now a formality. The Bill provides that once legislation has passed through both the House of Commons and the House of Lords, it will automatically become law upon the issue of a certificate signed by the Speakers of both Houses. The Bill expressly states that no signification of Royal Assent by the Monarch will be required. During committee scrutiny, several MPs raise concerns that Royal Assent is a fundamental constitutional requirement and question whether Parliament even has the legal authority to abolish it. Jonathan is asked to advise on the constitutional consequence if the Act were passed and received Royal Assent in the usual manner. What would be the constitutional consequence of this Act if it were passed and given Royal Assent in the usual way?

options.label: A
options.text: It would be ineffective, as the requirement for Royal Assent is a fundamental common law rule that cannot be abolished by statute.

options.label: B
options.text: It would abolish the royal prerogative of assent, demonstrating parliamentary sovereignty by legislating to change a core rule of the constitution.

options.label: C
options.text: It would require a referendum, as it alters the role of the Monarch.

options.label: D
options.text: It would be void unless consented to by all Commonwealth realms.

options.label: E
options.text: It would transfer the power of assent to the Supreme Court.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Royal Assent is a royal prerogative power, not an immutable constitutional requirement. Under the doctrine of parliamentary sovereignty, Parliament has the authority to legislate on any matter whatsoever, including altering or abolishing prerogative powers and core constitutional procedures.
This is well illustrated by historical precedent. The Parliament Acts 1911 and 1947 fundamentally altered the legislative process by limiting the House of Lords’ ability to block legislation. Similarly, legislation removing the requirement for Royal Assent would be a valid exercise of ...

questions.text: – Devolution and Legislative Consent Motions Rachel is a legal adviser to the Welsh Government. The UK Parliament passes the Government of Wales Act 2006 (Amendment) Act 2024, which removes the Senedd’s power to set Welsh income tax rates and restores that power to Westminster. The Act is passed despite the Senedd refusing to pass a Legislative Consent Motion (LCM). The Presiding Officer of the Senedd, Gareth, publicly condemns the Act as a “serious constitutional affront” and argues that it is legally invalid because it undermines the devolution settlement without Welsh consent. Rachel is asked to advise whether the failure to obtain an LCM has any legal effect on the validity of the 2024 Act. What is the legal effect of the absence of a Legislative Consent Motion?

options.label: A
options.text: It renders the 2024 Act void and of no legal effect in Wales.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a political breach of convention but does not affect the Act’s legal validity.

options.label: C
options.text: It triggers an automatic referendum in Wales on the transfer of powers.

options.label: D
options.text: It requires the Supreme Court to strike down the Act unless it is approved by the Senedd within 60 days.

options.label: E
options.text: It means the Act only applies to England, as Wales is exempt without consent.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. The requirement for legislative consent is embodied in the Sewel Convention, which provides that Westminster will not “normally” legislate on devolved matters without the consent of the devolved legislature. In Wales, this is recognised in s.107 of the Government of Wales Act 2006.
However, the Supreme Court has made it clear that constitutional conventions are not legally enforceable. In Miller [2017] UKSC 5 and reaffirmed in the Welsh Continuity Bill case, the Court held that conventions, even when referenced in statute, do not limit Parliament’s legal sovereignty.
As a ...

areas.name: Constitutional conventions, Perogative power and Parliamentary privilege

questions.text: Following a general election, the leader of the party with the most seats in the House of Commons, but without an overall majority, is invited by the Monarch to form a government. The leader accepts and becomes Prime Minister without first demonstrating through a formal vote that they command the confidence of the House of Commons. The government then loses its first major vote on the Queen's Speech. Which of the following constitutional conventions is most directly engaged by this sequence of events?

options.label: A
options.text: The convention that the Monarch must remain politically neutral.

options.label: B
options.text: The convention that the Prime Minister must be a member of the House of Commons.

options.label: C
options.text: The convention that the government must retain the confidence of the House of Commons.

options.label: D
options.text: The convention of collective cabinet responsibility.

options.label: E
options.text: The convention that the Monarch appoints the person most likely to command the confidence of the House.

questions.explanation: Option C is correct. The fundamental convention of the UK's parliamentary system is that the government must retain the confidence of the elected House of Commons. Losing a major vote on the Queen's Speech (which outlines the government's programme) is a clear indicator that it does not command that confidence. The sequence shows the initial appointment relied on the Monarch's assessment (guided by convention E), but the subsequent loss of the vote engages the ongoing requirement of confidence (convention C). The proper course would be for the Prime Minister to resign or request a dissolution....

questions.text: The Prime Minister reorganises the Cabinet, moving a senior minister to a different department. The minister publicly refuses the new post, criticising the Prime Minister's judgement and the government's policy direction in a newspaper interview. The Prime Minister demands the minister's resignation from the government, but the minister refuses to resign. What is the likely outcome based on established constitutional conventions?

options.label: A
options.text: The Minister automatically ceases to be a minister as their refusal of a post constitutes resignation.

options.label: B
options.text: The Prime Minister can advise the Monarch to dismiss the minister, as the convention of collective responsibility has been breached.

options.label: C
options.text: The Minister is protected by parliamentary privilege, and the Prime Minister cannot force them out.

options.label: D
options.text: The matter must be put to a vote of confidence in the House of Commons.

options.label: E
options.text: The Minister can only be removed by an address (vote) of the House of Commons.

questions.explanation: Option B is correct. The appointment and dismissal of ministers is a prerogative power exercised by the Monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister. The convention of collective responsibility requires ministers to support government policy publicly or resign. By publicly criticising policy and refusing a post, the minister has breached this convention. While a minister can technically refuse to resign, the Prime Minister can then advise the Monarch to revoke their appointment (dismiss them). This power stems from the principle that the Prime Minister must be able to control the composition of...

questions.text: The Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011 was repealed by the Dissolution and Calling of Parliament Act 2022. The 2022 Act states that the power to dissolve Parliament is a prerogative power, exercisable by the Monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister. A Prime Minister with a working majority in the House of Commons advises the Monarch to dissolve Parliament, triggering a general election. Political opponents argue this is an abuse of power for partisan advantage. Which of the following best describes the constitutional status of the Monarch's decision to act on this advice?

options.label: A
options.text: The Monarch has a personal discretion to refuse the advice if the dissolution is for partisan advantage.

options.label: B
options.text: The Monarch is bound by a legal duty under the 2022 Act to act on the Prime Minister's advice.

options.label: C
options.text: The Monarch is bound by a constitutional convention to accept the Prime Minister's advice, making refusal unconstitutional except in extraordinary circumstances.

options.label: D
options.text: The decision is subject to judicial review on grounds of rationality and proportionality.

options.label: E
options.text: The Monarch must first consult the Privy Council, which can veto the advice.

questions.explanation: Option C is correct. The 2022 Act recognises the power as a prerogative one but does not alter the underlying constitutional convention governing its exercise. The long-standing convention is that the Monarch grants a dissolution when requested by the Prime Minister. The Monarch's personal discretion to refuse is residual and is only exercisable in extraordinary and hypothetical circumstances (e.g., if a dissolution were requested very soon after a prior election, or if an alternative government could be formed without an election). Refusal based on a judgement of "partisan advantage" would be...

questions.text: The UK government wishes to ratify an international trade agreement. The Constitutional Reform and Governance Act 2010 (CRAG) requires that treaties be laid before Parliament for 21 sitting days before ratification. The government lays the treaty, but before the 21-day period elapses, it announces that ratification will proceed immediately due to "commercial urgency." An opposition MP seeks judicial review. Which of the following best describes the legal effect of CRAG on the prerogative power to make treaties?

options.label: A
options.text: CRAG has abolished the prerogative power; all treaties now require an Act of Parliament.

options.label: B
options.text: CRAG has created a statutory precondition that the courts can enforce, preventing ratification if breached.

options.label: C
options.text: CRAG has put the Ponsonby Rule (a convention) into statute, but a court would likely find the duty is owed to Parliament, not justiciable by an individual MP.

options.label: D
options.text: CRAG is merely advisory; the prerogative power remains unfettered and non-justiciable.

options.label: E
options.text: CRAG applies only to treaties that require changes to domestic law.

questions.explanation: Option B is correct. The Constitutional Reform and Governance Act 2010 gives statutory force to the former conventional Ponsonby Rule. Section 20 states a treaty "is not to be ratified" unless the laying requirements are met. Section 22 allows a minister to ratify despite a parliamentary resolution of objection, but it does not provide an exception to the 21-day laying period. The courts have indicated that statutory procedures replacing prerogative powers are justiciable (see R (Miller) v Secretary of State for Exiting the EU). Therefore, a failure to comply with the mandatory 21-day period w...

questions.text: The House of Commons passes a motion declaring that a Minister has misled the House and is in contempt of Parliament. The motion calls for the Minister to be suspended from the service of the House. The Minister is a member of the government and refuses to comply with the suspension. What is the source of the House's power to punish one of its members in this way?

options.label: A
options.text: The Ministerial Code, which is legally binding.

options.label: B
options.text: The inherent power of parliamentary privilege, specifically the right of each House to regulate its own composition and discipline its members.

options.label: C
options.text: The Parliament Acts 1911 and 1949.

options.label: D
options.text: A statutory power under the Contempt of Parliament Act 1985.

options.label: E
options.text: The royal prerogative, exercised by the Speaker on behalf of the Crown.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Parliamentary privilege includes the right of each House to control its own proceedings and discipline its members. This is part of the common law privilege of "exclusive cognisance." The power to suspend an MP is an exercise of this inherent privilege, not derived from statute. While the House's standing orders provide the procedure, the authority itself is a fundamental privilege necessary for the House to function independently. The historical case of Sir John Eliot's Case and the Bill of Rights 1689 underpin this.
Option A is incorrect; the Ministerial Code is non-stat...

questions.text: The government faces defeat on a key piece of legislation in the House of Lords. To avoid this, a minister arranges for over a dozen individuals who support the government to be appointed as life peers. These appointments are made quickly using the prerogative power. The opposition claims this is an abuse of the prerogative to "swamp" the Lords and undermine its role as a revising chamber. What is the principal constitutional limitation on the power to create peers that is engaged by this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: The House of Lords Appointments Commission has a statutory veto over all peerage appointments.

options.label: B
options.text: The power is limited by the Life Peerages Act 1958, which restricts the number of appointments per year.

options.label: C
options.text: The power is a prerogative exercised on ministerial advice, but its use is constrained by constitutional convention and political propriety, not legal limits.

options.label: D
options.text: The Monarch has a personal discretion to refuse such advice if it would undermine the constitution.

options.label: E
options.text: All peerage creations require the approval of the Privy Council.

questions.explanation: Option C is correct. The power to create life peers is a prerogative of the Crown, exercised on the advice of the Prime Minister. There is no legal limit on the number that can be created (the Life Peerages Act 1958 enables the creation but does not cap numbers). The constraint is conventional and political. The "Salisbury-Addison Convention" and the Lords' role as a revising chamber rely on the government not abusing the appointment power to swamp the Lords. Such an action would be a major breach of political propriety, but it is not legally prohibited. The House of Lords Appointments Commiss...

questions.text: An MP uses parliamentary privilege to make a speech in the House of Commons alleging serious criminal conduct by a prominent businessperson. The speech is covered by absolute privilege and reported widely. The businessperson later sues the MP for defamation, relying on evidence that the MP knew the allegations were false when they made them. What is the likely outcome of the defamation claim?

options.label: A
options.text: The claim will succeed because the MP abused privilege by knowingly making false statements.

options.label: B
options.text: The claim will be struck out because statements made in proceedings in Parliament are protected by absolute privilege

options.label: C
options.text: The claim will succeed if the businessperson can prove malice, as malice removes the protection of privilege.

options.label: D
options.text: The claim will be stayed until the House of Commons committee on privileges investigates the MP's conduct.

options.label: E
options.text: The claim can proceed, but only for damages, not for an injunction.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Article 9 of the Bill of Rights 1689 provides that "the freedom of speech and debates or proceedings in Parliament ought not to be impeached or questioned in any court or place out of Parliament." This establishes absolute privilege for statements made in parliamentary proceedings. The protection is complete, regardless of the member's motive or knowledge of falsity. The courts cannot inquire into such statements for any purpose, including defamation. This was reaffirmed in R v Chaytor and is a cornerstone of parliamentary independence.
Option A is directly contrary to Art...

questions.text: The Prime Minister commits UK armed forces to sustained combat operations in a foreign country without seeking prior parliamentary approval. This is done using the royal prerogative. A group of MPs bring a claim for judicial review, arguing that a convention has developed since 2003 that the House of Commons should have a vote before such action is taken. In determining the claim, how should the court approach the alleged convention?

options.label: A
options.text: The court can recognise the existence of the convention and enforce it as a legal limitation on the prerogative.

options.label: B
options.text: The court can recognise the convention's existence but cannot enforce it, as conventions are political rules.

options.label: C
options.text: The court must ignore the convention, as it conflicts with the legal prerogative power.

options.label: D
options.text: The court should refer the question of the convention's existence to the House of Commons for resolution.

options.label: E
options.text: The court can adjudicate on the convention only if it has been codified in the Ministerial Code.

questions.explanation: Option B is correct. The courts can recognise the existence of constitutional conventions as part of understanding the constitutional context (as in the Miller I case regarding devolution). However, conventions are not legally enforceable by the courts; they are enforced by political means. The 2003 Iraq war and subsequent practice (e.g., Syria votes in 2013 and 2018) have established a strong political convention for parliamentary approval, but it is not a legal requirement. The court would likely acknowledge the convention but hold that the legal power to deploy troops remains a prerogative ...

questions.text: The "Recall of MPs Act 2015" provides a statutory process for constituents to trigger a by-election if an MP is suspended from the House for at least 10 sitting days. An MP is suspended for 12 sitting days following a report by the Committee on Standards. The MP claims the suspension is invalid because the Committee's procedures were unfair, and seeks judicial review to stop the recall process. What is the likely outcome regarding the court's jurisdiction?

options.label: A
options.text: The court will hear the case because the recall process is statutory and justiciable.

options.label: B
options.text: The court will refuse to hear the case because matters relating to the internal disciplinary procedures of the House are protected by parliamentary privilege and are not justiciable.

options.label: C
options.text: The court will hear the case only if the Speaker of the House certifies that privilege is not engaged.

options.label: D
options.text: The court will hear the case but will apply a standard of extreme deference to the House's decision.

options.label: E
options.text: The court will refer the matter to the Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards.

questions.explanation: Option B is correct. The disciplinary proceedings of the House against its own members, including suspension, are proceedings in Parliament protected by Article 9 of the Bill of Rights and the principle of exclusive cognisance. The courts have consistently held that they have no jurisdiction to question the fairness of such internal procedures (see R v Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards, ex parte Al Fayed). The fact that a statutory consequence (recall) is triggered by the suspension does not give the courts a warrant to review the underlying parliamentary proceeding. The recall process ...

questions.text: The government introduces a bill that includes a clause stating: "No court or tribunal may entertain any proceedings which call into question the validity of any decision made by a minister under this Act." During debate, the Minister justifies the clause by saying it is needed to provide legal certainty for a major infrastructure project. Which aspect of constitutional principle does this "ouster clause" most directly engage?

options.label: A
options.text: The sovereignty of Parliament, as Parliament can indeed exclude judicial review.

options.label: B
options.text: The rule of law, as it seeks to exclude the courts from determining the legality of executive action.

options.label: C
options.text: The royal prerogative, as it transfers power from the courts to ministers.

options.label: D
options.text: Parliamentary privilege, as it prevents MPs from questioning the minister in the House.

options.label: E
options.text: The separation of powers, but only if the clause is found to be ambiguous.

questions.explanation: Option B is correct. Ouster clauses that attempt to completely exclude the jurisdiction of the courts to review the legality of executive action engage the fundamental constitutional principle of the rule of law, as articulated by figures like A.V. Dicey and in cases such as Anisminic v Foreign Compensation Commission. The courts strongly presume that Parliament does not intend to oust judicial review, and will interpret such clauses narrowly, often finding they do not protect decisions that are ultra vires or made in error of law. A clause attempting to make a minister's decision unquestionab...

questions.text: The Sewel Convention, as set out in the Scotland Act 1998, states that the UK Parliament will not "normally" legislate on devolved matters without the consent of the Scottish Parliament. In the UK Withdrawal from the European Union (Legal Continuity) (Scotland) Bill case, the UK Supreme Court was asked to rule on whether the UK Parliament's legislation required such consent. What did the Supreme Court decide about the legal status of the Sewel Convention?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a legally enforceable limit on parliamentary sovereignty.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a political convention, and the policing of its scope and operation is not a matter for the courts.

options.label: C
options.text: It is justiciable, but only where the Scottish Parliament has passed a legislative consent motion withholding consent.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a constitutional statute that takes precedence over later inconsistent UK legislation.

options.label: E
options.text: It is a rule of common law that the courts must apply.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. In the Continuity Bill reference, the UK Supreme Court (para 148) explicitly held that the Sewel Convention is a political convention, and that "the policing of its scope and the manner of its operation does not lie within the constitutional remit of the judiciary." The court acknowledged the convention's vital importance but confirmed that its enforcement is a matter for the political branches, not the courts. This maintains the distinction between legal rules (enforced by courts) and constitutional conventions (enforced politically).
Option A is the opposite of the rulin...

questions.text: The Prime Minister holds the office of First Lord of the Treasury. Most of the Prime Minister's powers are not derived from statute but from convention and their position as head of the government. Which of the following is a power that the Prime Minister does exercise under a specific statutory authority?

options.label: A
options.text: The power to appoint and dismiss other ministers.

options.label: B
options.text: The power to create cabinet committees.

options.label: C
options.text: The power to recommend the dissolution of Parliament to the Monarch.

options.label: D
options.text: The power to recommend the appointment of life peers to the Monarch.

options.label: E
options.text: The power to declare war.

questions.explanation: Option A is correct. While the power to appoint ministers is a royal prerogative, its exercise is now largely governed by statute. The Ministers of the Crown Act 1975 provides statutory authority for the payment of ministers and limits their numbers. More importantly, the Constitutional Reform and Governance Act 2010 (s.3) requires that the Prime Minister publish information about ministerial appointments. The Prime Minister's role in recommending appointments to the Monarch is underpinned by these statutory frameworks, though the source of the power remains the prerogative. The other options ...

questions.text: The House of Commons passes a bill. The House of Lords proposes several significant amendments. The government, controlling the Commons, uses its majority to reject all the Lords amendments. The Lords, insisting on its amendments, delays the bill until the end of the session, causing it to run out of time. The bill is lost. Which of the following statements about the relationship between the Houses is the most accurate in this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: The House of Lords has acted unconstitutionally, as the Parliament Acts 1911 and 1949 allow the Commons to override the Lords.

options.label: B
options.text: The House of Lords has exercised its legitimate power under the Parliament Acts to delay legislation.

options.label: C
options.text: The Lords has the power to reject or delay legislation, subject to the Parliament Acts.

options.label: D
options.text: The government can advise the Monarch to create new peers to secure the bill's passage, and the Monarch must comply.

options.label: E
options.text: The Commons can invoke the "Salisbury Convention" to compel the Lords to pass the bill.

questions.explanation: Option C is correct. The Parliament Acts provide a mechanism for the Commons to bypass the Lords, but only after specific delays and for most public bills (excluding money bills and bills to extend Parliament's life). The Lords retains the power to reject or amend legislation, and to delay it for at least two sessions (or one year under the 1949 Act). If a bill runs out of time in a session due to Lords insistence, it falls. This is a legitimate, if sometimes controversial, use of the Lords' power within the constitutional framework. The scenario describes a bill being lost to delay, which is ...

questions.text: During Prime Minister's Questions, an MP makes allegations of improper conduct against a named senior judge. The judge wishes to sue the MP for defamation. The MP claims their statement is protected by parliamentary privilege. What is the impact of parliamentary privilege in this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: The judge cannot sue because the statement was made in Parliament, but the judge can complain to the Committee on Standards.

options.label: B
options.text: The judge can sue because the MP has abused privilege by making an unfair attack on the judiciary, which is not a proceeding in Parliament.

options.label: C
options.text: The judge can sue, but only if they can prove the MP acted with malice, as malice removes the protection of privilege.

options.label: D
options.text: The judge cannot sue, and neither can they complain to any external body, as the matter is entirely within the jurisdiction of Parliament.

options.label: E
options.text: The judge can seek a declaration from the court that the statement was false, but not damages.

questions.explanation:
Option A is correct. Statements made in proceedings in Parliament (including PMQs) are protected by absolute privilege under Article 9 of the Bill of Rights 1689. This means no legal action for defamation can be brought based on those statements. The judge's only recourse is to raise the matter in Parliament, perhaps through a point of order or a complaint to the Speaker, or to ask an MP to table a motion for the matter to be referred to the Committee on Standards. The courts have no jurisdiction over the content of the statement.
Option B is incorrect; the statement was made in a proceeding i...

areas.name: Legitimacy, separation of powers and the rule of law:

questions.text: The Senedd Cymru passes the "Agricultural Subsidies (Wales) Act 2025." Section 1 empowers the Welsh Ministers to make regulations establishing a new subsidy scheme. Section 1(5) states: "Regulations under this section may make any provision which could be made by an Act of the Senedd, including provision modifying this Act." The Welsh Ministers use this power to create regulations that significantly alter the eligibility criteria set out in the parent Act. A farmers' union challenges the regulations, arguing that Section 1(5) is an unlawful delegation of legislative power. Which of the following principles is MOST DIRECTLY engaged by this challenge?

options.label: A
options.text: The rule of law, specifically the principle that laws must be prospective and clearly defined.

options.label: B
options.text: The separation of powers, specifically the principle that a legislature cannot delegate its core law-making function.

options.label: C
options.text: The sovereignty of the UK Parliament, which prevents the Senedd from delegating broad powers.

options.label: D
options.text: The principle of legality, which requires ministers to act within the scope of powers granted by Parliament.

options.label: E
options.text: The constitutional convention that secondary legislation should not amend primary legislation (the 'Henry VIII clause' convention).

questions.explanation: Option B is correct. The challenge engages the separation of powers principle concerning delegation. The fundamental concept is that a democratically elected legislature should not delegate its core legislative function (making primary law) to the executive without clear limits. A provision allowing ministers to amend the parent Act via regulations is known as a "Henry VIII clause." While such clauses are permitted, they are subject to constitutional scrutiny. The courts apply a principle of statutory interpretation that Parliament (or the Senedd) does not intend to grant sweeping amending pow...

questions.text: The UK Government, using powers under the Public Order Act 2024, makes the "Public Processions (Amendment) Regulations 2025." These regulations impose strict new conditions on protests near Parliament. The regulations were made using the "negative resolution procedure" and came into force 21 days after being laid before Parliament, during which time neither House objected. A protest organiser challenges the regulations, arguing they disproportionately interfere with the right to protest under the Human Rights Act 1998. The government argues the regulations are valid as they were made in accordance with the parent Act's prescribed parliamentary procedure. Which of the following best describes the judicial approach to this challenge?

options.label: A
options.text: The courts cannot review the substance of the regulations because they have been approved by Parliament.

options.label: B
options.text: The courts can review whether the regulation-making power was exercised for the purpose intended by Parliament and whether it is compatible with the Human Rights Act

options.label: C
options.text: The courts can only review the procedural correctness of how the regulations were made, not their content.

options.label: D
options.text: The courts must defer to the minister's judgement because the regulations concern national security and public order.

options.label: E
options.text: The challenge is non-justiciable because it involves political judgement about the balance between protest and order.

questions.explanation: Option B is correct. Secondary legislation, even when made under a valid procedure, is subject to judicial review. The courts can review whether the minister acted within the "four corners" of the power granted by the parent Act (the vires) and whether the regulations are compatible with the Human Rights Act 1998. The fact that the negative resolution procedure was followed does not immunise the regulations from substantive review. The courts will assess whether the interference with the right to protest (Article 11 ECHR) is justified and proportionate. This is a core aspect of the rule of law...

questions.text: The "Welsh Taxes Act 2024" is an Act of the Senedd that creates a new landfill tax for Wales. Section 10 states: "The Welsh Ministers may by regulations specify the rate of tax." No further guidance or limits are provided in the Act. The Welsh Ministers set a rate of 500%, which is vastly higher than any comparable tax in the UK, effectively prohibiting landfill operations in Wales. A waste management company challenges the rate-setting regulation. What is the strongest legal argument for the company?

options.label: A
options.text: The Senedd lacks the legislative competence to set tax rates, as taxation is a reserved matter.

options.label: B
options.text: The delegation of power in Section 10 is so broad and unfettered that it constitutes an unlawful delegation of the Senedd's legislative function.

options.label: C
options.text: The regulation is irrational (Wednesday unreasonable) and therefore ultra vires.

options.label: D
options.text: The regulation amounts to a deprivation of property without compensation, violating the Human Rights Act 1998.

options.label: E
options.text: The Welsh Ministers failed to consult the waste industry before making the regulations, breaching a legitimate expectation.

questions.explanation: Option B is correct. This scenario tests the limits of permissible delegation. While legislatures can delegate powers to ministers, they must provide a sufficient "skeleton" or framework within which the discretion is to be exercised. A power to set a tax rate with no guiding criteria or upper limit may be argued to be so broad that it amounts to an abdication of the Senedd's legislative role, violating the separation of powers. The court would consider whether the parent Act provides an "intelligible principle" to guide the exercise of discretion. A naked power to "specify the rate" with no c...

questions.text: The Senedd passes the "Welsh Language Standards Act 2024." Its long title states it is "An Act to promote and facilitate the use of the Welsh language." Section 1 imposes a duty on "all private companies providing a public service in Wales" to publish certain documents bilingually. The Bill was passed after the Welsh Government rejected several amendments proposed by a Senedd committee that would have clarified the definition of "public service." A large retail chain, operating private stores in Wales, is prosecuted under the Act. It defends itself by arguing the Act is unconstitutionally vague and that the Senedd's failure to properly scrutinise and refine the Bill renders it illegitimate. What is the likely judicial response to this defence?

options.label: A
options.text: The court will invalidate the Act because vague legislation violates the rule of law.

options.label: B
options.text: The court will examine the quality of the legislative process to determine if the Act is valid.

options.label: C
options.text: The court will interpret the term "public service" using standard principles of statutory interpretation, but will not inquire into the internal sufficiency of the Senedd's legislative process.

options.label: D
options.text: The court will refer the question of definition to the Welsh Government for clarification.

options.label: E
options.text: The court will stay the case until the Senedd passes a clarifying amendment.

questions.explanation: Option C is correct. Under the doctrine of parliamentary (and Senedd) privilege and the separation of powers, the courts do not inquire into the internal procedures of a legislature or the quality of debate that led to an enactment. An Act lawfully passed and within the Senedd's competence is valid. The remedy for vague legislation is for the courts to interpret it as best they can, using the standard tools (purposive interpretation, consulting explanatory notes, etc.). The rule of law requires clarity, but it is for the court to provide that clarity through interpretation, not to strike down ...

questions.text: The "United Kingdom Internal Market Act 2020" gives UK ministers a power to provide financial assistance to any sector or region. Using this power, a UK Minister awards a large grant directly to a manufacturing company in Wales for a project that falls within the devolved competence of the Welsh Ministers (economic development). The Welsh Ministers had declined to fund the same project. The Welsh Ministers seek judicial review, arguing the UK Minister's action undermines the devolution settlement and the legitimacy of the Welsh Government's democratic decision-making. Which of the following is the most relevant constitutional principle in assessing this claim?

options.label: A
options.text: The legislative supremacy of the UK Parliament, which authorised the spending power.

options.label: B
options.text: The rule of law, requiring the UK Minister to act fairly towards the Welsh Ministers.

options.label: C
options.text: The separation of powers between the UK executive and the Senedd as a legislature.

options.label: D
options.text: The constitutional conventions of comity and mutual respect between the UK and devolved governments.

options.label: E
options.text: The principle of subsidiarity, which is part of EU law but not UK domestic law.

questions.explanation: Option A is correct. The core issue is one of legal competence. The UK Internal Market Act 2020 is a statute of the UK Parliament. If it confers a spending power that is legally exercisable in devolved areas without the consent of the devolved administration, then the action is intra vires the UK Minister. The principle of parliamentary sovereignty means that a UK statute can modify the practical effect of devolution, even if it clashes with conventions of mutual respect (D). The court's role is to interpret the statute. If the power is clearly granted, the political complaint about underminin...

questions.text: The "Healthcare Reform Act 2024" is a UK Act that applies to England only. Section 15 allows the Secretary of State to make regulations "conferring functions on NHS bodies in England." A regulation is made under Section 15 that creates a new approval process for hospital construction. The regulation also states: "This approval process applies to any new hospital construction in Wales that receives more than 50% of its funding from the UK Treasury." A Welsh health board challenges the application of this regulation to Wales. What is the strongest ground for challenging the territorial reach of this regulation?

options.label: A
options.text: The parent Act applies to England only, so the regulation cannot apply to Wales.

options.label: B
options.text: The subject matter (hospital construction in Wales) is devolved, so the UK minister lacks competence.

options.label: C
options.text: The regulation is ultra vires Section 15 because it purports to extend a function to Wales when the parent Act is geographically limited.

options.label: D
options.text: The Sewel Convention required the consent of the Senedd, which was not obtained.

options.label: E
options.text: The regulation is irrational because it creates a dual regulatory regime in Wales.

questions.explanation: Option C is correct. The principle of vires is central. The regulation-making power is found in a UK Act that, by explicit statement or necessary implication, applies to England only. Secondary legislation cannot have a wider territorial application than the parent Act from which it derives its authority. Therefore, a regulation made under Section 15 that purports to apply to Wales is likely ultra vires (outside the powers granted) because the minister was not authorised by Parliament to make law for Wales via this route. This is a strict legal point about the scope of the delegated power. Opt...

questions.text: The "Senedd and Elections (Wales) Act 2024" extends the Senedd term from four to five years. Section 5 of the Act states: "This Act, and any provision amended by it, may not be repealed or amended unless the repeal or amendment is approved by a two-thirds majority of the Senedd." A subsequent Senedd, elected on a manifesto to revert to four-year terms, passes a simple majority Act that repeals the 2024 Act. The Presiding Officer refers the repeal Act to the Supreme Court to test its validity, citing the "entrenchment" clause in Section 5. Based on constitutional principles applicable to the Senedd, what is the likely outcome?

options.label: A
options.text: The repeal Act is invalid because the earlier Act lawfully entrenched itself, protecting the constitutional reform.

options.label: B
options.text: The repeal Act is valid because the Senedd cannot bind its successors

options.label: C
options.text: The repeal Act requires the consent of the UK Parliament before it can take effect.

options.label: D
options.text: The repeal Act is valid only if it also obtains a two-thirds majority.

options.label: E
options.text: The Supreme Court will decline to answer, as this is a political question for the Senedd.

questions.explanation: Option B is correct. The principle that a legislature cannot bind its successors is a core aspect of legislative supremacy. This applies to the UK Parliament and, by analogy, to the Senedd within its area of competence. The Senedd derives its power from the UK Parliament (Government of Wales Act 2006). While that Act could theoretically impose "manner and form" requirements (like super-majorities), a simple majority Act of the Senedd cannot self-entrench. A provision in Act A stating that Act A can only be repealed by a special procedure is not legally binding on a future Senedd passing Act B ...

questions.text: The UK Government introduces a bill to implement an international trade agreement. The bill includes clauses that modify the functions of Welsh Ministers in devolved areas (e.g., agriculture). The UK Government does not seek a Legislative Consent Motion from the Senedd, arguing the changes are "incidental and consequential" to a reserved matter (international trade). The Senedd passes a resolution stating it withholds consent. The bill is enacted anyway. From the perspective of the legitimacy of the devolution settlement, what is the most significant consequence of proceeding without consent?

options.label: A
options.text: The Act is legally invalid and can be struck down by the Supreme Court.

options.label: B
options.text: The Act is legally valid but represents a major breach of the Sewel Convention, damaging the political legitimacy of the union.

options.label: C
options.text: The Welsh Ministers can legally refuse to implement the parts of the Act that modify their functions.

options.label: D
options.text: The Monarch should refuse Royal Assent to an Act that breaches a convention.

options.label: E
options.text: The Act automatically does not apply to Wales because consent was withheld.

questions.explanation: Option B is correct. The Sewel Convention is a fundamental political understanding underpinning the devolution settlement. While the Supreme Court has ruled it is not legally enforceable (Continuity Bill case), its breach is a serious matter of political constitutionality. Proceeding without consent, especially where the Senedd has explicitly withheld it, undermines the mutual respect and partnership at the heart of devolution. It damages the political legitimacy of the UK Parliament's action in the eyes of Wales and weakens the union. This is a classic example of a tension between legal valid...

questions.text: – Processions and Police Conditions (Public Order Act 1986)

options.label: A
options.text: Only where the procession is likely to involve serious violence.

options.label: B
options.text: Where the procession is likely to result in serious public disorder, serious damage to property, serious disruption to the life of the community, or intimidation.

options.label: C
options.text: Only where the organisers fail to give advance notice of the procession.

options.label: D
options.text: Where the police reasonably believe the views expressed are offensive or controversial.

options.label: E
options.text: Only where a court has authorised the imposition of conditions.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Under section 12 Public Order Act 1986, a senior police officer may impose conditions on a procession if they reasonably believe it may result in serious public disorder, serious damage to property, serious disruption to the life of the community, or intimidation. The threshold is not limited to violence alone and includes disruption.
Option A is incorrect: Serious violence is not the sole ground; the statute is broader.
Option C is incorrect: Failure to give notice is a separate offence but does not define the power to impose conditions.
Option D is incorrect: The police ...

questions.text: During a lawful protest march in Manchester, police impose conditions under section 12 limiting the procession to a specific route. Daniel, a protester, deliberately leads a group away from the authorised route to block a major road, despite being informed of the conditions by police officers. Daniel is arrested and charged with an offence under the Public Order Act 1986. He argues that he was exercising his right to protest and that the police conditions were unreasonable. What offence, if any, has Daniel committed?

options.label: A
options.text: No offence, as protest rights override police conditions.

options.label: B
options.text: An offence only if serious violence actually occurred.

options.label: C
options.text: An offence of knowingly failing to comply with conditions imposed on a procession.

options.label: D
options.text: An offence only if the procession was unlawful from the outset.

options.label: E
options.text: A common law offence of unlawful assembly.

questions.explanation:
