Evidence of prior oral negotiations cannot generally be admitted to add to, vary, or contradict the written terms (Jacobs v Batavia and General Plantations Trust). While there are exceptions (e.g., for collateral contracts or to establish a custom), the starting point is that the written document contains the full contractual terms. Sarah's strongest defence is to invoke this rule.

questions.text: (Incorporation by Signature) Amanda signs a 12-page equipment lease agreement with "OfficeLease Ltd" without reading it. Clause 14, in small but clear print on page 10, states: "The Lessee agrees to indemnify the Lessor for all legal costs incurred in enforcing this agreement, regardless of outcome." Amanda falls behind on payments. OfficeLease Ltd sues and, having won, seeks full legal costs from Amanda under Clause 14. Amanda argues she should not be bound by a clause she did not read. Is Amanda bound by Clause 14?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the clause was not brought to her attention reasonably, being in small print.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because she signed the document, and in the absence of misrepresentation, she is bound by its terms.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because an indemnity for costs is an onerous term requiring special notice.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if OfficeLease Ltd can prove they highlighted the clause before she signed.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the clause is an unfair penalty and therefore unenforceable.

questions.explanation: The general rule from L'Estrange v F Graucob Ltd is that a party who signs a document is bound by its terms, whether they have read them or not, in the absence of fraud or misrepresentation. This is a strict application of the objective principle. The fact that the term is onerous or in small print does not, by itself, prevent incorporation by signature.

questions.text: (Incorporation by Course of Dealing) Nina, a freelance graphic designer, has completed 15 projects for "Creatify Ltd" over two years. For each project, Creatify emailed a standard purchase order. The reverse of the printed version of this form (which Nina rarely printed) contained terms, including a clause limiting liability for late delivery to a refund of the fee. Nina never expressly agreed to these printed terms but always started work upon receiving the email, which did not attach the full terms. On the 16th project, Nina delivers late. Creatify seeks to rely on the limitation clause. Is the limitation clause incorporated into the contract?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because a consistent course of dealing over 15 projects is sufficient to incorporate the terms.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the terms were never actually provided to Nina in the emails that formed the basis of each transaction.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because Nina, as a businessperson, should have known standard terms would apply.

options.label: D
options.text: No, unless Creatify can prove Nina had actual knowledge of the printed terms.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only if the email explicitly stated that the order was subject to the terms on the reverse of the standard form.

questions.explanation: Incorporation by a previous course of dealing requires consistency and regularity, and the terms must have been knowingly received in the past (McCutcheon v David MacBrayne Ltd). Here, the course of dealing was based on emails that did not include the terms. The fact that a printed version existed is irrelevant if it was not the document consistently used to form the contracts. Therefore, there is insufficient evidence that the terms were part of the parties' established routine.

questions.text: (Term Implied by Common Law - Business Efficacy) Tom hires a barge from Riverways Ltd to transport his machinery from London to Oxford. The contract is silent on the barge's fitness for the journey. The barge sets off but becomes stuck in a shallow, rarely used section of the canal, causing significant delay and damage. It transpires the barge has a deeper draft than is suitable for the full route. Tom claims Riverways breached an implied term that the barge was reasonably fit for its purpose. Will the court imply such a term?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the contract was silent, and the parties are sophisticated enough to have included such a term if desired.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, under the "officious bystander" test, as it is so obvious it goes without saying.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, under the "business efficacy" test  as such a term is necessary to make the contract work.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because the risk of unsuitable canals is a normal commercial risk Tom accepted.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only if Tom can prove he made his specific purpose known to Riverways at the time of contracting.

questions.explanation: The common law can imply a term to give business efficacy to a contract where it is necessary to make it work as intended by the parties (The Moorcock). Here, the central purpose of the contract is transportation. A term that the barge must be reasonably fit for the agreed route is necessary for that purpose. The "officious bystander" test (Option B) is an alternative formulation, but The Moorcock's business efficacy test is the classic authority for such implied terms in commercial contracts.

questions.text: (Term Implied by Statute - Sale of Goods) Clara buys a new "UltraClean" dishwasher from an electronics retailer. The sales brochure states it has a "super-quiet operation." At home, Clara finds it is very noisy. An engineer confirms it is working within normal technical parameters but admits it is louder than competing models. Clara rejects the dishwasher, claiming it is not of satisfactory quality under the Sale of Goods Act 1979. Which of the following is the MOST relevant factor in determining if the dishwasher is of "satisfactory quality"?

options.label: A
options.text: Whether the noise level makes the dishwasher unfit for its basic purpose of washing dishes.

options.label: B
options.text: Whether the retailer knew or should have known about the noise level.

options.label: C
options.text: The description applied to the goods, including the "super-quiet" claim in the brochure.

options.label: D
options.text: The price paid for the dishwasher relative to other models.

options.label: E
options.text: Whether a reasonable person would find the noise level acceptable.

questions.explanation: Under s.14(2) of the Sale of Goods Act 1979, the standard of satisfactory quality includes fitness for common purposes, appearance and finish, freedom from minor defects, safety, and durability. Critically, under s.14(2B), any public statements about the specific characteristics of the goods made by the seller, producer, or their representative (e.g., in advertising) are a relevant circumstance. The "super-quiet" claim is a public statement about a specific characteristic and is central to the assessment of quality (R&B Customs Brokers Co Ltd v United Dominions Trust Ltd).

questions.text: (Term Implied by Statute - Supply of Services) Daniel hires "ProFix," a specialist IT contractor, to recover data from a crashed server. The contract states a fixed fee but is silent on the standard of service. ProFix works on the server but accidentally corrupts the only backup drive, making all data permanently unrecoverable. Daniel refuses to pay and sues for the value of the lost data. What is ProFix's likely liability, assuming no exclusion clause?

options.label: A
options.text: ProFix is not liable; they only promised to attempt recovery, not guarantee success.

options.label: B
options.text: ProFix is liable only for a refund of their fee, as the contract was for a fixed fee.

options.label: C
options.text: ProFix is liable for breach of an implied term under the Supply of Goods and Services Act 1982 to perform the service with reasonable care and skill.

options.label: D
options.text: ProFix is only liable if Daniel can prove gross negligence.

options.label: E
options.text: ProFix is not liable because data loss is a foreseeable risk Daniel accepted.

questions.explanation: Under s.13 of the Supply of Goods and Services Act 1982, a term is implied into a contract for the supply of a service that the supplier will carry out the service with reasonable care and skill. Corrupting the only backup drive is a clear failure to exercise reasonable care and skill. Liability is not limited to a refund of the fee; Daniel can claim damages for the consequential loss (the value of the data), subject to rules on remoteness.

questions.text: (Exemption Clause - The Rule of Construction)

options.label: A
options.text: Whether the clause is reasonable under the Unfair Contract Terms Act 1977.

options.label: B
options.text: Whether the wording of the clause, as a matter of ordinary language, is wide enough to cover liability for negligence.

options.label: C
options.text: Whether the customer had sufficient notice of the clause before the contract was made.

options.label: D
options.text: Whether the employee's act constituted gross negligence, which cannot be excluded.

options.label: E
options.text: Whether the clause is a penalty clause.

questions.explanation: Before considering reasonableness or incorporation, the court must construe the clause. The common law rule of construction states that a clause will not be construed as covering liability for negligence unless it does so expressly or by necessary implication (Canada Steamship Lines Ltd v The King). The court must first ask: Does the wording, on its ordinary meaning, extend to the loss caused by negligence? If it does not expressly mention "negligence," it must be clear that it applies to that type of liability.

questions.text: (Exemption Clause - Unfair Contract Terms Act 1977, s.2)

options.label: A
options.text: It is valid and effective, as Fatima signed the contract and warning signs were present.

options.label: B
options.text: It is void as excluding liability for death or personal injury resulting from negligence is prohibited

options.label: C
options.text: Its validity depends on whether it satisfies the requirement of reasonableness under UCTA s.2(2).

options.label: D
options.text: It is invalid because it is an unfair term under the Consumer Rights Act 2015.

options.label: E
options.text: It is valid because the gym's negligence was not the sole cause; Fatima should have seen the sign.

questions.explanation: UCTA 1977, s.2(1) states that a person cannot, by reference to any contract term or notice, exclude or restrict liability for death or personal injury resulting from negligence. This is an absolute prohibition in business-to-consumer contracts. The clause attempts to exclude liability for personal injury "however caused," which includes negligence. Therefore, it is void in respect of the negligence claim. The Consumer Rights Act 2015 would now apply to consumer contracts, but its Schedule 2, para. 1 contains an equivalent blacklisted term.

questions.text: (Exemption Clause - Reasonableness Test UCTA s.11)

options.label: A
options.text: Whether Builder Ltd had the opportunity to insure against the loss.

options.label: B
options.text: Whether the clause was contained in Supplier Co's written standard terms of business.

options.label: C
options.text: Whether the clause satisfies the requirement of reasonableness.

options.label: D
options.text: Whether the parties had equal bargaining power.

options.label: E
options.text: The precise definition of "consequential loss" in commercial law.

questions.explanation: UCTA 1977 applies to business-to-business contracts. Section 3(2)(a) states that where one party deals on the other's written standard terms, they cannot exclude liability for breach except in so far as the term satisfies the requirement of reasonableness. The question of whether the clause is part of standard terms (B) is a threshold issue, but the ultimate test for effectiveness, given UCTA applies, is reasonableness under ss. 3 and 11. Factors like bargaining strength and insurance are relevant to the reasonableness test.

questions.text: (Interpretation - Condition vs Warranty) In a contract for the sale of a ship, it is stated: "The vessel is currently classed with Lloyd's Register. Maintenance of this classification is a condition of this agreement." Two months after delivery, the ship fails its annual survey and loses its classification for three weeks while repairs are made. The buyer wishes to reject the ship and terminate the contract. What is the legal consequence of breaching a term expressly labelled a "condition"?

options.label: A
options.text: The buyer can always terminate, as labelling a term a condition indicates it is of the essence.

options.label: B
options.text: The court will ignore the label and assess the seriousness of the breach to decide if termination is allowed.

options.label: C
options.text: The buyer can terminate only if the breach deprives them of substantially the whole benefit of the contract.

options.label: D
options.text: The buyer can terminate, as the parties' own classification of the term is decisive (L Schuler AG v Wickman Machine Tool Sales Ltd).

options.label: E
options.text: The buyer can terminate only if they have suffered significant financial loss.

questions.explanation: Where parties expressly designate a term as a "condition," this is strong evidence that they intend any breach of that term, regardless of its actual consequences, to give rise to a right to terminate (L Schuler AG v Wickman Machine Tool Sales Ltd). This provides commercial certainty. The court will generally uphold this intention unless the label is clearly misused. Here, the term is explicitly labelled a condition, so its breach gives the buyer the right to terminate, subject to any possible waiver.

questions.text: (Interpretation - Innominate Term)

options.label: A
options.text: As a warranty, because it relates to the state of the ship.

options.label: B
options.text: As a condition, because seaworthiness is fundamental to a charter.

options.label: C
options.text: As an innominate term, where the right to terminate depends on the nature and effect of the breach

options.label: D
options.text: As a condition, because any breach relating to safety is fundamental.

options.label: E
options.text: As a warranty, because the delay was only 48 hours.

questions.explanation: The Hongkong Fir Shipping Co Ltd v Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha Ltd case established the category of "innominate" (or intermediate) terms. For such terms, the remedy for breach is not automatic. The court looks at the consequences of the actual breach. If the breach deprives the innocent party of substantially the whole benefit of the contract, they may terminate; otherwise, only damages are available. Seaworthiness is a classic example of an innominate term; a trivial defect may only justify damages, while a serious one may justify termination.

questions.text: (Interpretation - Entire Agreement Clause)

options.label: A
options.text: It prevents the buyer from claiming misrepresentation based on the oral forecasts.

options.label: B
options.text: It is conclusive evidence that there were no pre-contractual representations.

options.label: C
options.text: It may prevent pre-contractual statements from being raised as contractual terms, but does not automatically exclude liability for misrepresentation.

options.label: D
options.text: It is ineffective unless reasonable under UCTA 1977.

options.label: E
options.text: It may prevent pre-contractual statements from being raised as contractual terms, but automatically excludes liability for misrepresentation.

questions.explanation: An Entire Agreement clause aims to define the contractual boundaries and prevent pre-contractual statements from being incorporated as terms. However, it does not, by itself, exclude liability for misrepresentation. To do that, the contract would need a separate "non-reliance" clause or an explicit exclusion clause for misrepresentation, which would then be subject to reasonableness tests under UCTA s.3 (AXA Sun Life Services Plc v Campbell Martin Ltd). The clause here only states it supersedes prior agreements/understandings, not that no representations were made or relied upon.

questions.text: (Interpretation - Contra Proferentem Rule) An insurance policy taken out by a small business states: "This policy does not cover damage caused by electrical or mechanical breakdown." A fire breaks out due to the overheating of a faulty motor (a mechanical breakdown), causing extensive damage. The insurer denies cover, citing the exclusion clause. Applying the contra proferentem rule, how is the clause likely to be interpreted?

options.label: A
options.text: The fire damage is excluded because it was caused by a mechanical breakdown.

options.label: B
options.text: The fire damage is covered because the clause only excludes the cost of repairing the broken motor itself, not the resultant fire damage.

options.label: C
options.text: The clause is void for ambiguity.

options.label: D
options.text: The fire damage is covered because "breakdown" is too vague a term.

options.label: E
options.text: The clause must be interpreted in the way most favourable to the drafter (the insurer).

questions.explanation: The contra proferentem rule states that any ambiguity in an exemption or exclusion clause is construed against the party who drafted it (the proferens). The clause excludes "damage caused by... breakdown." This is ambiguous: does it mean all damage that results from a breakdown, or only the damage constituting the breakdown itself? Given the ambiguity, the court will interpret it narrowly against the insurer, likely limiting it to the cost of repairing the faulty motor, not the separate, resultant fire damage (Alisa Craig Fishing Co Ltd v Malvern Fishing Co Ltd).

questions.text: (Variation - Consideration) Lydia has a two-year contract to supply office stationery to "AccountPlus Ltd" at a fixed price. Due to a sudden spike in paper costs, Lydia tells AccountPlus she can no longer supply at the old price. AccountPlus's manager orally agrees to a 10% price increase for the remaining year to ensure continuity of supply. Lydia continues to deliver. Six months later, a new manager at AccountPlus refuses to pay the increased price, demanding a return to the original contract price. Is the oral variation to increase the price binding?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because AccountPlus received the practical benefit of continued supply.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because Lydia was only performing her existing contractual duty, which is not fresh consideration.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because the variation was agreed orally and performed.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because the variation was not in writing, as required by the original contract's amendment clause.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, because AccountPlus's agreement waived its right to insist on the original price.

questions.explanation: In Williams v Roffey Bros, the court held that a promise to pay more for the performance of an existing duty can be supported by the "practical benefit" obtained by the promisor. Here, AccountPlus obtained the practical benefit of securing continued supply from a known supplier, avoiding the hassle and cost of finding a new one. This constitutes sufficient consideration to support the variation promise, making the price increase binding.

questions.text: (Variation - Waiver by Election)

options.label: A
options.text: No, because its email constituted a variation agreeing to a new completion date.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because time remained of the essence, and the email did not expressly waive the deadline.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because its conduct, amounted to a waiver of the right to terminate for that breach.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if it can prove it suffered loss from the delay.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the delay was only two weeks, which is not a serious breach.

questions.explanation: This illustrates the doctrine of waiver by election (or equitable forbearance). Where one party, knowing of a breach that would entitle them to terminate, unequivocally communicates (by words or conduct) an intention to affirm the contract, they lose the right to terminate for that specific breach (Charles Rickards Ltd v Oppenhaim). HomeOwner Ltd's email, urging completion and not reserving its rights, followed by allowing continued performance, likely constitutes an election to affirm, waiving the right to terminate for the 1st June deadline. It can still claim damages for late completion.

questions.text: (Variation - Formalities)

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the parties' subsequent conduct cannot override a formal variation clause.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because the parties' subsequent conduct can override a formal variation clause.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because variations to contracts over three years must be in writing under the Law of Property (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1989.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, because Landlord Co waived the requirement for writing by accepting the reduced payments.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because consideration was not provided for the reduction in rent.

questions.explanation: In MWB v Rock Advertising, the Supreme Court confirmed that a "no oral modification" (NOM) clause is legally effective. However, it also held that such a clause can itself be varied or waived by subsequent oral agreement or conduct. The parties, by their conduct (offering and accepting reduced rent), may have orally agreed to vary the original contract, including its NOM clause. Therefore, the oral variation could be effective. Option D ("waiver") is a related but distinct concept; the analysis here is one of a new oral agreement that varies the entire contract, including its formalities claus...

questions.text: (Interpretation - Implied Term of Good Faith) Two companies enter a long-term "joint marketing agreement." It requires them to "co-operate in good faith to promote the joint brand." After a year, Company A launches a very similar competing product with a different partner. Company B claims this breaches the implied duty of good faith. Is a duty of good faith generally implied into English commercial contracts?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, it is a universal term implied by law into all contracts.

options.label: B
options.text: No, English law does not recognise a general implied duty of good faith in commercial contracts (Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust v Compass Group UK and Ireland Ltd).

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but only in contracts involving a fiduciary relationship.

options.label: D
options.text: No, unless the contract is one of utmost good faith (uberrimae fidei) like insurance.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only in relational contracts of long duration, where the court may imply such a duty

questions.explanation:
English law is traditionally reluctant to imply a general duty of good faith. However, recent case law, notably(Yam Seng Pte Ltd v International Trade Corporation Ltd).
, has opened the door to implying such a duty in certain "relational" contracts, long-term agreements requiring a high degree of communication, cooperation, and mutual trust. Whether this particular joint marketing agreement qualifies is fact-sensitive. The express term to "co-operate in good faith" would likely be enforceable on its own, but the question asks about implied terms.
The most accurate general statement is E, refle...

questions.text: (Exemption Clause - Fundamental Breach)

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the doctrine of fundamental breach prevents a party from relying on an exclusion clause where they have breached a fundamental term.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, provided the clause, on its true construction, is wide enough to cover the loss and is reasonable.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because gross negligence can never be excluded.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, because the parties freely allocated this risk by contract.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the breach (failure to secure) was different from the loss (theft), so the clause does not apply.

questions.explanation:
T
he doctrine of "fundamental breach" as an automatic rule of law was rejected in Photo Production Ltd v Securicor Transport Ltd. The modern approach is purely one of construction: does the clause, as a matter of language, cover the breach that occurred? If it does, it will be effective unless rendered unenforceable by statute (e.g., UCTA). The fact the breach is serious or negligent is relevant to construction (the court will require clear words to cover such events) and potentially to reasonableness, but it is not an automatic bar.

questions.text: (Terms Implied by Custom/Trade Usage) Leo, new to the diamond trade in Antwerp, buys a batch of gems from a long-established dealer, Sofia. Their written contract is brief. When a dispute arises, Sofia argues that, by long-standing trade custom in Antwerp, all sales are subject to arbitration by the Diamond Bourse. This custom is not mentioned in their contract. Leo disputes this. When will a term be implied based on trade custom or usage?

options.label: A
options.text: Only if it is necessary to give business efficacy to the contract.

options.label: B
options.text: Only if both parties were actually aware of the custom at the time of contracting.

options.label: C
options.text: If the custom is certain and reasonable, and not contrary to the express terms .

options.label: D
options.text: Never, if the contract is in writing and appears complete.

options.label: E
options.text: Only if it is a statutory custom applicable to all trades in that location.

questions.explanation:
A term can be implied into a contract based on a well-established trade custom or usage. The requirements are that the custom is (1) certain, (2) notorious (widely known in the trade), (3) reasonable, and (4) not inconsistent with the express terms of the contract (Hutton v Warren). It does not require both parties' actual knowledge if it is so notorious that they are presumed to have contracted with reference to it. Actual knowledge (B) can be a basis, but presumed knowledge through notoriety is sufficient.
D) Vitiating factors in contracts

questions.text: (Misrepresentation - Fraudulent vs Negligent) Victor, a car dealer, sells a vintage sports car to Priya. Victor tells her, "This car is a 1965 model with matching numbers, fully restored." He makes this statement believing it to be true, based on paperwork from the previous owner, but he has made no effort to verify its accuracy. Priya later discovers the car is a "recreation" built from parts, with a 1968 chassis. She would not have purchased it had she known. Priya seeks to rescind the contract and claim damages. What is the most accurate characterisation of Victor's statement and its legal consequence?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an innocent misrepresentation; Priya can only seek rescission, and the court has discretion to award damages in lieu.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a negligent misstatement; Priya can claim damages for tortious negligence under Hedley Byrne principles, but rescission is not available.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a fraudulent misrepresentation, as Victor made a statement of fact without caring whether it was true or false.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a negligent misrepresentation, Victor is liable in damages unless he can prove he had reasonable grounds to believe his statement was true.

options.label: E
options.text: It is a mere sales puff, as Victor believed it to be true.

questions.explanation: Option D is correct. This scenario mirrors the principle from Howard Marine and Dredging Co Ltd v A Ogden & Sons (Excavations) Ltd. Where a statement of fact is made by a party in the course of negotiations, and it induces the contract, it is a representation. The Misrepresentation Act 1967, s.2(1) creates a statutory liability for negligent misrepresentation: a representor is liable in damages unless they can prove they had reasonable grounds to believe the statement was true. Victor, as a dealer making a specific factual claim about authenticity and restoration, would struggle to prove reaso...

questions.text: (Misrepresentation - Silence and Duty to Disclose) Gareth is selling his suburban house to Fiona. The basement has suffered from persistent damp, which Gareth has cosmetically covered with fresh paint and plasterboard. Fiona asks, "Is the basement dry and usable?" Gareth replies, "We've never had a problem with it," knowing this is literally true only because they have never attempted to use the space. Fiona buys the house and later discovers the extensive damp. She claims she was misled. Is Gareth liable for misrepresentation?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because his statement was literally true; they had never personally had a problem.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because caveat emptor applies to property sales, and there is no general duty to disclose defects.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because his statement, while literally true, was a half-truth that created a false overall impression and was therefore misleading.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, because he actively concealed the damp, which constitutes fraudulent conduct.

options.label: E
options.text: No, unless Fiona can prove Gareth intended to deceive her.

questions.explanation:
The correct option is C. This reflects the principle established in cases like Nottingham Patent Brick and Tile Co v Butler. A statement which is literally true can still be a misrepresentation if it is a "half-truth" that omits critical qualifying information, thereby creating a false impression. By stating "We've never had a problem," while having actively concealed the damp, Gareth's statement conveyed the false impression that the basement was inherently sound and dry. This is an actionable misrepresentation. The active concealment reinforces the misleading nature of the statement.
A is in...

questions.text: Leo contracted to buy a specific vintage painting, "The Harbour at Dawn," from Claudia's art gallery. Unbeknownst to both parties, a fire at the warehouse where it was stored had destroyed the painting the night before they signed the contract. The contract made no allocation of risk for this event. Leo has paid a deposit. What is the legal position?

options.label: A
options.text: The contract is void for common mistake. Claudia must return the deposit.

options.label: B
options.text: The contract is valid but frustrated. Claudia is discharged from performance.

options.label: C
options.text: The contract is voidable for misrepresentation by Claudia.

options.label: D
options.text: The contract is valid; Claudia is in breach for failing to deliver.

options.label: E
options.text: The contract is void for common mistake, but only if the painting was uniquely identified.

questions.explanation:
This is a classic application of the doctrine of common mistake at common law, specifically res extincta (a thing destroyed). Where, at the time of contracting, the subject matter has already ceased to exist, and both parties are ignorant of this fact, the contract is void ab initio (from the outset) for common mistake, as there is a fundamental assumption that the thing exists. The leading authority is Couturier v Hastie. The deposit must be returned as there was never a valid contract.
B is incorrect. The doctrine of frustration applies to supervening events that occur after the contract is ...

questions.text: (Mistake - Mutual Mistake as to Identity of Subject Matter) Archie agreed to sell his car to Ben. Archie owns two cars: a red 2020 sports car and a blue 2015 family hatchback. Archie, thinking Ben wants the hatchback as a runaround, offers it at £5,000. Ben, believing he is getting the sports car for a bargain, agrees at £5,000. Both believe they are in agreement, but they are thinking of different cars. The written contract simply states "Archie's car." Is there a binding contract?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, the contract is for 'Archie's car'; whichever one he tenders will satisfy it.

options.label: B
options.text: No, this is a mutual mistake as to the identity of the subject matter, negating agreement.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but Ben can rescind for unilateral mistake if he can prove Archie was aware of his mistake.

options.label: D
options.text: No, the contract is void for uncertainty, as it is impossible to determine which car was intended.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, the objective interpretation would favour the meaning given by the offeror, Archie.

questions.explanation:
This scenario mirrors the famous "Peerless" case, Raffles v Wichelhaus. Where parties are at cross-purposes regarding a fundamental aspect of the subject matter (here, which specific car) and there is no objective means of determining which one was intended (the description "Archie's car" is ambiguous in context), there is no consensus ad idem (meeting of the minds). This is a mutual mistake that prevents the formation of a contract. The contract is void.
A is incorrect. This applies an objective test where only one meaning is possible. Here, the objective test fails because there are two poss...

questions.text: (Mistake - Unilateral Mistake as to Terms)

options.label: A

A unilateral mistake (one party mistaken, the other not) as to the terms of the contract can render the contract void if the non-mistaken party knew or should reasonably have known of the other's mistake. questions.text: (Undue Influence - Presumed from Relationship) An elderly man, Harold, in poor health, lives with his niece, Zoe, who manages all his finances. Harold signs a document, prepared by Zoe, gifting his £300,000 house to her. He receives no independent legal advice. Harold later regrets this and seeks to have the gift set aside. What is the likely legal presumption?

options.label: A
options.text: There is a presumption of undue influence arising from the relationship of trust and confidence between Harold and Zoe.

options.label: B
options.text: No presumption arises; Harold must prove actual undue influence or fraud.

options.label: C
options.text: The gift is void as Harold lacked mental capacity.

options.label: D
options.text: The presumption only arises if Zoe is Harold's solicitor or doctor.

options.label: E
options.text: The gift is voidable for misrepresentation, as Zoe likely misstated its effect.

questions.explanation: The correct option is A. This follows the principle from Royal Bank of Scotland plc v Etridge (No 2). Where a relationship of trust and confidence exists (e.g., between an elderly dependent and a carer relative managing their affairs), and a transaction is not readily explicable by the ordinary motives of ordinary people (a substantial gift), the law raises a presumption of undue influence. The burden then shifts to the recipient (Zoe) to prove the transaction was the free exercise of independent will, usually by showing the donor received independent legal advice. The relationship here is one...

questions.text: (Illegality - Contract to Commit a Crime) Alex, knowing that high-powered laser pointers are illegal to import without a licence, contracts with Boris to smuggle a shipment into the country. Alex pays Boris a deposit. Boris takes the deposit but fails to deliver the lasers. Alex sues Boris to recover his deposit. What is the likely outcome?

options.label: A
options.text: Alex succeeds; Boris is in breach of contract and must repay the deposit.

options.label: B
options.text: Alex fails; the contract is illegal as formed for the purpose of committing a crime, and the court will not assist him.

options.label: C
options.text: Alex succeeds in restitution, as Boris has been unjustly enriched.

options.label: D
options.text: Alex fails, but the police should be informed of the attempted crime.

options.label: E
options.text: The contract is void for mistake as to legality.

questions.explanation:
This is a straightforward application of the illegality doctrine. Where a contract is formed with the intention of committing an illegal act (here, smuggling), it is illegal as formed. The maxim ex turpi causa non oritur actio (no cause of action arises from a base matter) applies. The courts will not enforce such a contract or provide any remedies to either party, leaving them as they are. Alex cannot recover his deposit (Parkinson v College of Ambulance). This acts as a deterrent.
A is incorrect. The court will not enforce an illegal contract for the benefit of either party. To allow Alex to...

questions.text: (Misrepresentation - Inducement and Materiality) Before buying a restaurant, Chloe asks the seller, David, "Has the kitchen ever failed a health inspection?" David replies, "No, it's always passed with flying colours." Relying partly on this, Chloe buys the business. She later discovers the kitchen failed an inspection two years prior, but it passed a subsequent one just before the sale. Chloe claims she would have negotiated a lower price had she known, but admits she still would have bought it . Has David's misrepresentation induced the contract?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the information was not material; the current pass was more important.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because Chloe admits she still would have entered the contract, so the misrepresentation was not decisive.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because the statement was false and was one of the factors that induced her to contract on the terms she did.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because Chloe did not rely solely on David's statement; she conducted her own due diligence.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only if the failure was for a critical violation.

questions.explanation: The correct option is C. This reflects the principle from Edgington v Fitzmaurice and JEB Fasteners Ltd v Marks Bloom & Co. A misrepresentation need not be the sole inducement; it is sufficient if it is an inducement, even if not the only one. Furthermore, a misrepresentation can be actionable if it induces the claimant to contract on the terms they did (e.g., at a certain price), even if they would still have contracted. The key is that the false statement played a real and substantial part in the decision-making process. Chloe's admission she would have paid less is crucial evidence of induc...

questions.text: (Mistake - Mistake as to Quality vs Identity) Mr. A. buys a painting from a dealer for £100, believing it to be a minor work by a famous artist. Both believe it is authentic. It is later revealed to be a clever forgery worth only £10. The contract was for "the painting catalogued as item 27, 'Riverscape'." Mr. A. seeks to have the contract declared void for mistake. Is the contract void?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, this is a common mistake as to a fundamental quality that makes the thing essentially different from what was contracted for.

options.label: B
options.text: No, this is a mistake as to quality only, not rendering the contract void at common law. The contract was for that specific painting, which was delivered.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because the consideration has wholly failed.

options.label: D
options.text: No, but Mr. A. can rescind for misrepresentation if the dealer made a statement of attribution.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, because the value is radically different.

questions.explanation: The correct option is B.This scenario is a classic illustration of the principle from Bell v Lever Bros Ltd and Leaf v International Galleries. A common mistake as to the quality or value of the subject matter (e.g., its authenticity or attribution) is not sufficient to render the contract void at common law, provided the subject matter itself exists and is correctly identified. The contract was for that specific physical painting, item 27. The mistake does not relate to its existence or fundamental identity. questions.text: (Undue Influence - Actual Undue Influence) An elderly, wealthy widow, Edith, is pressured by her spiritual advisor, Reverend Stone, who tells her that God has instructed her to make a large donation to his religious organisation to secure her place in heaven. Feeling intense spiritual pressure and fear, Edith donates £200,000 from her savings. There is no presumption of undue influence from their relationship. Can Edith recover the donation?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, if she can prove actual undue influence

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: E
options.text: No, because she received a spiritual benefit in return.

questions.explanation:
This reflects the concept of actual undue influence, as seen in cases like Allcard v Skinner and Morley v Loughnan. Where a presumption of influence does not arise from the relationship type, the claimant can still succeed by proving that in fact, the defendant used undue influence, improper pressure, coercion, or persuasion that overbore the claimant's independent free will. Spiritual coercion is a classic example of such improper pressure. Edith would need to prove the Reverend's conduct amounted to such coercion.
A is incorrect. Donations are not immune from scrutiny. They can be set aside ...

questions.text: (Mistake - Document Signed by Mistake (Non Est Factum)) An elderly man with poor eyesight, who cannot read complex documents, is told by his trusted nephew that a document is a "letter to the council about his bin collection." He signs it. In fact, it is a deed transferring his house to the nephew for £1. The nephew immediately sells the house to a third party, who buys in good faith for market value. Can the elderly man have the transfer to the nephew set aside?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: E

This defence applies where a person signs a document fundamentally different in character from what they believed it to be, due to a trick or fraud, and they were not careless in signing. Here, the document's nature (a property transfer) is radically different from what was represented (a letter). The plea would succeed against the fraudulent nephew, rendering the transfer voidable (or even void) as against him. options.label: A

options.label: B

questions.text: (Termination by Expiry) Sofia entered into a two-year fixed-term contract to lease office space from Property Ltd, commencing on 1st January 2023. The contract stated it would terminate automatically on 31st December 2024. On 15th December 2024, Sofia emailed Property Ltd to confirm she would be vacating on the 31st. Property Ltd replied, "We acknowledge your notice and will conduct the exit inspection." Sofia vacated on 31st December. On 5th January 2025, Property Ltd invoiced Sofia for one additional month's rent, claiming her email was insufficient formal notice and that the contract had converted to a periodic tenancy. Is Property Ltd entitled to the additional rent?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because a fixed-term lease automatically becomes a periodic tenancy unless valid notice is given by either party before expiry.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the contract expressly provided for automatic termination on a specific date, so no notice was required to end it.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because Sofia's email constituted an offer to enter a new contract, which Property Ltd accepted by conducting the inspection.

options.label: D
options.text: No, but only if the contract contained an explicit 'break clause' which Sofia exercised.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, because commercial leases always require at least six months' notice to quit.

questions.explanation:
The correct option is B.  Where a contract is for a fixed term with a specified end date, it terminates automatically by effluxion of time on that date. No notice is required from either party to bring it to an end; it ends by operation of the original agreement. Any continuation thereafter would require the formation of a new contract, express or implied. Sofia's email was merely confirmatory, not a necessary notice.
Incorrect Options Explained:
A is incorrect. This rule applies to periodic tenancies (e.g., month-to-month). A fixed-term tenancy does not automatically roll over unless the cont...

questions.text: (Termination for Breach - Repudiatory Breach) XYZ Ltd contracted to supply and install a specialised, brand-new bottling machine at ABC Winery by 1st June, time being stated as "of the essence." On 25th May, XYZ's project manager told ABC, "We're having sourcing issues. The absolute earliest we can deliver is 30th July." ABC needs the machine for its summer production run. On 28th May, ABC informs XYZ it is treating the contract as terminated and will source a machine elsewhere. Which of the following best describes ABC's legal position?

options.label: A
options.text: ABC has wrongfully repudiated the contract; XYZ has not yet breached as the delivery date has not passed.

options.label: B
options.text: ABC can terminate on 28th May because XYZ's communication amounts to an anticipatory breach.

options.label: C
options.text: ABC must wait until 1st June; if the machine is not delivered then, it can terminate.

options.label: D
options.text: ABC can claim damages for late delivery but cannot terminate until the delay actually causes a serious loss.

options.label: E
options.text: ABC's termination is only valid if it gives XYZ a reasonable period to remedy the breach, which it has not done.

questions.explanation:
This is a clear case of anticipatory breach. Where one party, before the time for performance arrives, unequivocally indicates they will not perform (or will commit a repudiatory breach), the innocent party may elect to terminate the contract immediately. XYZ's statement that delivery will be two months late, when time is of the essence, is a renunciation of the contract, allowing ABC to accept the repudiation and terminate forthwith (Hochster v De La Tour).
A is incorrect. The breach is not in the failure to deliver, but in the renunciation of the obligation to deliver on time. ABC is accepti...

questions.text: (Frustration - Destruction of Subject Matter) Classic Car Hire Ltd agreed to rent a specific, vintage 1965 Aston Martin DB5 to James for his wedding on 1st July. The contract was signed on 1st June. On 20th June, the car was completely destroyed by a fire in Classic Car Hire's secure garage, through no fault of either party. James had to hire a different, more expensive car at short notice. What is the legal consequence?

options.label: A
options.text: Classic Car Hire is in breach of contract and must pay James damages for his extra hire costs.

options.label: B
options.text: The contract is frustrated. Both parties are discharged from future obligations, but James can claim restitution for any prepaid hire fee.

options.label: C
options.text: Classic Car Hire must provide a substitute vehicle of equivalent value; the contract is not discharged.

options.label: D
options.text: The contract is void ab initio for common mistake, as the car was already destroyed when they contracted.

options.label: E
options.text: James must pay the full hire charge as the risk of loss remained with him once the contract was signed.

questions.explanation:
This is frustration by impossibility of performance due to the destruction of a thing essential for performance (Taylor v Caldwell). The unforeseen, non-faulty destruction of the specific car, which was the core of the contract, makes further performance impossible. The contract is discharged from the moment of the fire. Any prepayment by James would be recoverable on the basis of total failure of consideration.
A is incorrect. Frustration operates to discharge the contract automatically. There is no breach because the failure to perform is due to an extraneous, supervening event for which nei...

questions.text: (Restitution - Recovery of Money on Termination for Breach) Thomas paid a £10,000 deposit to a builder, Dean, for a house extension. Dean commenced work but then abandoned the site without justification, having completed only £2,000 worth of preliminary groundwork. Thomas terminated the contract for repudiatory breach and hired a new builder. Thomas sues to recover his £10,000 deposit. What is Thomas entitled to recover?

options.label: A
options.text: The full £10,000 deposit, as Dean's breach means he is entitled to restitution of all money paid.

options.label: B
options.text: Nothing; the deposit is forfeited as a penalty for Dean's breach.

options.label: C
options.text: £8,000, being the deposit minus the value of the work actually done by Dean.

options.label: D
options.text: Only damages for the cost of completing the work, which may be more or less than the deposit.

options.label: E
options.text: Nothing at all

questions.explanation:
Upon termination for breach, the innocent party is entitled to recover money paid on the basis of a total failure of consideration. However, the failure of consideration is only total if the payer has received no part of the contracted-for benefit. Here, Thomas received £2,000 worth of work. Therefore, the consideration has partially failed. He can recover the deposit, but must give credit for the value of the benefit received (Rover International Ltd v Cannon Film Sales Ltd).
A is incorrect. Recovery of money paid requires a total failure of consideration. Since Thomas received some benefit (...

questions.text: (Frustration - Change in Law / Illegality) In 2023, a UK company contracted with a supplier in Country X to import a rare mineral for use in manufacturing. Performance was due in 2024. In early 2024, before delivery, the UK government imposed immediate and absolute sanctions, making it a criminal offence for UK persons to import any goods from Country X. The supplier is ready and willing to deliver. What is the effect on the contract?

options.label: A
options.text: The contract is unaffected; the supplier must deliver to a neutral country and the UK company can collect it from there.

options.label: B
options.text: The UK company is in anticipatory breach if it refuses to accept delivery.

options.label: C
options.text: The contract is frustrated. Performance has become illegal under after the contract was made.

options.label: D
options.text: The supplier is in breach for failing to deliver to the UK.

options.label: E
options.text: The contract is void for common mistake, as both parties assumed continued legality of trade.

questions.explanation:
The correct option is C. A supervening change in the law that makes performance illegal discharges the contract by frustration (Denny, Mott & Dickson Ltd v James B Fraser & Co Ltd). Here, the imposition of sanctions after the contract was formed renders the very act of importation a criminal offence, making performance impossible in the manner contemplated. The contract is discharged from the date the law changed.
A is incorrect. The contract was for import to the UK. Requiring the parties to perform in a fundamentally different way (ship to a third country) is not performance of the original ...

Given the minor and immaterial nature of the breach, the court would uphold this classification.
A is incorrect. The label 'warranty' typically denotes a term where the remedy for breach is damages alone. The right to terminate is reserved for conditions or serious breaches of innominate terms.
