questions.text: (Restitution - Quantum Meruit) Laura contracted with Ben, a carpenter, to make and fit custom bookshelves for £5,000. After Ben had completed the construction of the shelves in his workshop (but before delivery or installation), Laura wrongfully repudiated the contract without reason. Ben had spent £1,500 on materials and 50 hours of labour. The shelves, being bespoke, have a scrap value of only £200. Ben accepts Laura's repudiation and wishes to claim for the work done. What is Ben's best course of action?

options.label: A
options.text: Sue for the full contract price of £5,000.

options.label: B
options.text: Sue for damages for breach of contract, which would be his lost profit on the contract.

options.label: C
options.text: Bring a claim in reasonable value for the work done prior to termination.

options.label: D
options.text: Do nothing; he has no claim because the shelves were never delivered.

options.label: E
options.text: Insist on completing the work and then sue for the price.

questions.explanation:
Where a contract is terminated for the other party's breach, the innocent party has an election. They can either sue for damages for breach of contract, or they can sue in restitution on a quantum meruit for the reasonable value of the work they have done. Where the work is incomplete and/or the contractual price is not a good measure of the value of partial performance (as here with bespoke items), a quantum meruit claim is often advantageous (Planché v Colburn). It allows recovery for the benefit conferred.
A is incorrect. A claim for the full price generally requires that the claimant has c...

questions.text: (Frustration - Personal Service & Incapacity) Mohammed, a renowned violinist, was contracted to perform as the soloist at a prestigious concert on a specific date. A week before the concert, Mohammed was involved in a car accident, rendering him physically unable to play the violin for six months, as confirmed by medical reports. The concert organisers had to hire a replacement soloist at a higher fee. Is the contract with Mohammed frustrated?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because Mohammed's incapacity is a personal misfortune, not a supervening event affecting the contract itself.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because his incapacity makes performance of this personal service contract impossible and discharges it.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the organisers could have postponed the concert.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the contract contained a force majeure clause covering illness.

options.label: E
options.text: No, Mohammed is in breach of contract and liable for the organisers' extra costs.

questions.explanation:
The correct option is B. Contracts for personal services are frustrated by the permanent incapacity or death of the person who is to perform them (Condor v The Barron Knights Ltd). The foundation of the contract is the personal skill of the individual. A temporary incapacity that prevents performance on the crucial date has the same effect, as the contract is for performance on that specific date. The accident is an unforeseen, external event.
A is incorrect. Incapacity of a specific individual in a personal service contract is the classic example of a frustrating event. It goes to the root of...

questions.text: (Termination - Affirmation of Contract)

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because the breach was of a condition, giving an immediate right to reject.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because by using the goods for two weeks, the buyer affirmed the contract and lost the right to reject.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but only if the buyer pays for the two weeks of use.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because the right to reject is lost once the goods are incorporated into other products.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, because the buyer acted within a reasonable time of discovering the breach.

questions.explanation:
Even where a breach gives an immediate right to terminate, that right can be lost if the innocent party affirms the contract. Affirmation can be express or implied from conduct that is consistent only with treating the contract as still in force. Using the goods extensively in a business process, as opposed to merely inspecting them, is strong evidence of affirmation (Long v Lloyd). The right to reject is therefore lost.
Explanation
A is incorrect. While a breach of condition initially gives a right to reject, that right is not perpetual. It can be lost by affirmation, lapse of time, or other ...

questions.text: (Frustration - The Effect: The Law Reform (Frustrated Contracts) Act 1943) Under a contract governed by English law, a musician paid a theatre owner a £5,000 advance to hire the venue for a concert. Before the hire date, the theatre was compulsorily purchased and demolished by the local authority. The contract is frustrated. The theatre owner had incurred £800 in non-refundable administrative costs in preparing for the event. How does the Law Reform (Frustrated Contracts) Act 1943 allocate the financial losses?

options.label: A
options.text: All losses lie where they fall; the musician loses £5,000 and the theatre owner keeps it.

options.label: B
options.text: The musician recovers the £5,000 advance, and the theatre owner bears its own £800 costs.

options.label: C
options.text: The theatre owner may retain £800 from the £5,000 advance to cover expenses, and must return the balance of £4,200 to the musician.

options.label: D
options.text: The £5,000 must be split evenly between the parties to share the loss.

options.label: E
options.text: The theatre owner keeps the £5,000 as compensation for losing the booking.

questions.explanation:
The correct option is C. Section 1(2) of the Law Reform (Frustrated Contracts) Act 1943 provides that money paid before frustration is recoverable, but the payee may deduct expenses incurred in the performance of the contract. The court has a discretion to allow a larger deduction if just, but the basic position is recovery of the advance less provable expenses. Here, the theatre owner can retain £800 and return £4,200.
A is incorrect. This was the common law position ("loss lies where it falls") before the 1943 Act, which was passed to create a fairer, statutory scheme for adjustment.
B is in...

questions.text: (Anticipatory Breach - Election and Mitigation) On 1st March, a seller under a CIF contract for May shipment of wheat informed the buyer, "We will not be able to ship the wheat due to sourcing problems." This was an anticipatory breach. The market price for wheat was rising. The buyer did not respond immediately. On 15th March, the buyer confirmed it accepted the repudiation and would cover its needs elsewhere. By then, the price had risen further, increasing the buyer's cost of cover. Until what point can the buyer delay its election to accept the repudiation?

options.label: A
options.text: The buyer must accept the repudiation immediately or it is deemed to have affirmed the contract.

options.label: B
options.text: The buyer has a reasonable time to decide whether to accept the repudiation or affirm the contract.

options.label: C
options.text: The buyer can wait until the actual date for performance (May) before deciding.

options.label: D
options.text: The buyer's silence until 15th March constituted an automatic affirmation of the contract.

options.label: E
options.text: The buyer can delay indefinitely, as the repudiation gives a permanent right to terminate.

questions.explanation:
Upon an anticipatory breach, the innocent party has a reasonable time to elect whether to accept the repudiation (and terminate) or to affirm the contract. What is reasonable depends on the circumstances. The innocent party cannot unreasonably delay and "keep the contract alive" to speculate on the market at the repudiator's expense. A two-week delay in a volatile commodity market might be at the upper limit of reasonableness.
A is incorrect. The law allows a period for deliberation; an immediate response is not mandated.
C is incorrect. This would allow the innocent party to "wait and see" if...

questions.text: (Termination - Breach of Innominate Term)

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because any breach of a contractual term allows for termination.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the breach was trivial and did not deprive the charterer of substantially the whole benefit of the contract.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because the term related to the condition of the vessel, which is always a condition.

options.label: D
options.text: No, unless the charterer can prove it specifically requested a higher standard.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, because the term was part of the description of the service.

questions.explanation:
This is a classic application of the innominate term doctrine. Whether a breach of such a term justifies termination depends on the nature and consequences of the breach (Hongkong Fir Shipping Co Ltd v Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha Ltd). A trivial breach with no serious consequences only gives rise to a claim for damages, not a right to terminate. The charterer received the substantial benefit of the contract (a seaworthy ship and successful carriage).
A is incorrect. Termination is only available for repudiatory breach: breach of condition, breach of an innominate term with serious consequences, or r...

questions.text: (Restitution - Total Failure of Consideration) Clara paid £15,000 to a tour operator for a "luxury, all-inclusive 14-day holiday in Resort X" in July. In May, the tour operator went into liquidation and cancelled all holidays. No alternative was offered. Clara reclaimed the £15,000 from her credit card company under Section 75 of the Consumer Credit Act 1974. The credit card company, having reimbursed Clara, now seeks to recover the £15,000 from the liquidated tour operator. On what basis can the credit card company claim?

options.label: A
options.text: They cannot; the debt is extinguished by the liquidation process.

options.label: B
options.text: As damages for breach of contract suffered by Clara, which they have subrogated to.

options.label: C
options.text: In restitution, on the basis of a total failure of consideration for the payment.

options.label: D
options.text: As a penalty for the tour operator's failure to provide the service.

options.label: E
options.text: They cannot; Section 75 is a statutory protection for consumers, not a right of recourse for credit card companies.

questions.explanation:
Upon the tour operator's failure to provide any part of the holiday, the consideration for Clara's payment totally failed. The credit card company, having settled Clara's claim, is subrogated to her rights. One of those rights is a restitutionary claim to recover money paid for a consideration that has wholly failed (Fibrosa Spolka Akcyjna v Fairbairn Lawson Combe Barbour Ltd). This claim ranks as an unsecured debt in the liquidation.
A is incorrect. The debt is not extinguished; it is proved in the liquidation. The company may only pay pence in the pound, but the right to claim exists.
B is i...

questions.text: (Frustration - Foreseeability & Self-Induced)

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because the closure was unforeseeable and renders performance radically different.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the transport company could use alternative, albeit longer, routes.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because performance has become illegal.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because road closures are a foreseeable risk in the haulage business.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only if the contract specified the M1 route.

questions.explanation:
Frustration requires that performance be rendered impossible or radically different. Mere increase in cost, difficulty, or time is usually insufficient. The availability of an alternative route (even if much longer) means the contract's central obligation, transporting the goods, can still be performed. The event does not strike at the root of the contract (Davis Contractors Ltd v Fareham UDC).
A is incorrect. While the event may be unforeseeable, the critical question is its impact on performance. Radical change requires more than increased cost and delay; it must destroy the commercial purpo...

questions.text: (Termination - Consequences for Accrued Rights)

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, termination discharges all future obligations and nullifies all past ones.

options.label: B
options.text: No, termination is prospective only. Rights and obligations that have already accrued remain enforceable.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because the client's act of termination repudiates the entire contractual relationship.

options.label: D
options.text: No, but only if the contract expressly states that accrued rights survive termination.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, because the supplier's breach taints the entire contract, including past performance.

questions.explanation:
Termination for breach operates prospectively. It discharges the parties from future primary obligations to perform, but it does not undo the past. Rights and liabilities that have already accrued (e.g., a right to payment for services rendered, a right to damages for past breaches) remain intact and enforceable (Photo Production Ltd v Securicor Transport Ltd).
A is incorrect. This describes rescission ab initio (e.g., for misrepresentation or common mistake), which unwinds the contract entirely. Termination for breach is fundamentally different.
C is incorrect. Termination for breach is the a...

questions.text: (Damages - Remoteness of Loss)

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because the loss was a direct consequence of the late delivery.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the loss was an unusual consequence not within the reasonable contemplation of the parties at the time of contracting.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because Precision Parts knew the component was for a new production line, so all consequential losses are recoverable.

options.label: D
options.text: No, unless Assembly Line can prove Precision Parts acted fraudulently.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but the damages will be reduced by 50% due to Assembly Line's failure to find an alternative temporary component.

questions.explanation: The rule in Hadley v Baxendale limits recoverable damages to those arising naturally from the breach, or those that were in the reasonable contemplation of the parties at the time of the contract as the probable result of the breach. While Precision Parts knew the component was for a production line, the loss of a specific, highly lucrative contract with a third party is a type of loss that goes beyond ordinary business interruption. Unless Assembly Line had specifically informed Precision Parts about this particular contract and its dependence on timely delivery (Victoria Laundry v Newman), s...

questions.text: (Damages - Measure: Cost of Cure vs Diminution in Value) Mr. Lee contracted with "Posh Builders" to construct an extension to his house. The specification called for "Brand X" roof tiles, which were slightly more expensive and a particular shade of blue. Posh Builders, by mistake, used functionally identical "Brand Y" tiles of a marginally different hue. To replace them with Brand X tiles would require stripping the whole roof at a cost of £25,000. The difference in the market value of the house with Brand Y tiles is negligible (£500). Mr. Lee insists on the £25,000 cost of cure. Is Mr. Lee entitled to the cost of cure?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because a contracting party is entitled to be put in the position they would have been in had the contract been performed.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the cost of cure is wholly disproportionate to the benefit obtained, and damages will be limited to the diminution in value

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because Mr. Lee has a legitimate personal preference for Brand X tiles and the cost of cure is proportionate to the benefit.

options.label: D
options.text: No, unless Mr. Lee can prove he will actually spend the £25,000 to replace the tiles.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only if the contract expressly stated that the Brand X tiles were a condition of the agreement.

questions.explanation:
This scenario mirrors Ruxley Electronics and Construction Ltd v Forsyth. The House of Lords held that where the cost of rectifying a breach is disproportionate to the end result, and the innocent party has no genuine intention to undertake the work, damages may be limited to the difference in value (which may be nominal) plus possibly a modest sum for loss of amenity or pleasure. The court balances the claimant's desire for performance against the economic waste involved. Here, £25,000 vs £500 is stark disproportion.
A is incorrect. This states the general principle, but it is qualified by the...

questions.text: (Liquidated Damages vs Penalty)

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because the parties freely agreed to it.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because it is a penalty clause, being a sum disproportionate to any legitimate interest and intended to deter breach.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but only to the extent of the actual loss of £40,000.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because penalty clauses are always void at common law.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, because it is a genuine pre-estimate of the loss of goodwill from competition.

questions.explanation:
The modern test for a penalty, established in Cavendish Square Holding BV v Talal El Makdessi, is whether the clause is a secondary obligation imposing a detriment on the contract-breaker out of all proportion to any legitimate interest of the innocent party in enforcing the primary obligation. A clause designed purely to deter breach (a "terror" mechanism) without reference to a genuine pre-estimate of loss or other legitimate interest (like protecting the goodwill of the purchased business) is likely a penalty. A round number with no attempt at estimation is a classic indicator.
A is incorre...

questions.text: (Specific Performance - Adequacy of Damages) Anna entered into a contract to buy a rare, first edition of a 19th-century novel from a collector, Ben. The book is one of only five known copies. Ben refuses to complete the sale. Anna seeks an order for specific performance. Will the court likely grant specific performance?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because damages (the difference between contract and market price) are an adequate remedy.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because the subject matter is unique, and damages would not compensate Anna adequately.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because specific performance is a discretionary remedy and courts are reluctant to order it for chattels.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if Anna pays the purchase price into court first.

options.label: E
options.text: No, unless Anna can prove the book has special sentimental value to her.

questions.explanation:
Specific performance is an equitable remedy granted where damages are inadequate. For unique goods, such as rare books, works of art, or land, damages are typically considered inadequate because the claimant cannot go into the market and acquire an equivalent. The uniqueness of the chattel is a key factor in establishing inadequacy of damages.
A is incorrect. For generic goods, this is true. For unique items, the law recognises that market value does not compensate for the failure to receive the specific item.
C is incorrect. While discretionary, the discretion is exercised according to settle...

questions.text: (Duty to Mitigate - Reasonable Steps)

options.label: A
options.text: No, it was unreasonable to immediately accept a lower rate without waiting.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, it took reasonable steps by seeking a replacement charter promptly in a falling market (The Solholt).

options.label: C
options.text: No, the duty requires the charterer to find a charter at the same rate, even if it takes time.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but damages will be reduced because the charterer should have negotiated harder.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the new charter was for the same duration, locking in the loss.

questions.explanation:
The duty to mitigate requires the innocent party to take reasonable steps to minimise its loss. What is reasonable depends on the circumstances. In a volatile, falling market, taking prompt action to secure a replacement contract, even at a lower rate, is typically reasonable. Waiting in hope of a market recovery could be seen as failing to mitigate, as it speculates with the wrongdoer's money (The Solholt).
A is incorrect. In a falling market, waiting is often unreasonable as it increases the probable loss. The duty is to act reasonably, not to hold out for the best possible deal.
C is incorr...

questions.text: (Injunction - Prohibitory to Enforce Negative Covenant) An employee, Sarah, signed a contract with "Tech Innovators Ltd" containing a 12-month post-termination non-solicitation clause preventing her from soliciting its clients. She resigns and immediately contacts several key clients, persuading them to move their business to her new employer. Tech Innovators seeks an injunction to restrain her from further solicitation. Will the injunction likely be granted?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because injunctions are not granted to enforce contractual terms for personal service.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, this is a prohibitory injunction to prevent a breach of a clear negative covenant, and damages would be an inadequate remedy.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the employer's only remedy is damages for lost client revenue.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if Tech Innovators pays Sarah a sum of money to compensate her.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because an injunction would effectively force Sarah not to work, which is a positive obligation.

questions.explanation:
Prohibitory injunctions are commonly granted to enforce negative covenants in contracts, such as non-compete or non-solicitation clauses, where damages are an inadequate remedy. The loss of client goodwill and future business is notoriously hard to quantify. The court will grant the injunction if the clause is reasonable in scope and the applicant has acted promptly (Lumley v Wagner -the principle extends beyond theatrical performances).
A is incorrect. While courts are reluctant to grant specific performance (a positive order) for personal service contracts, they are willing to grant injuncti...

questions.text: (Indemnity - Nature and Breadth)

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the accident was due to the Landlord's own potential negligence as owner.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because the indemnity is widely worded to cover all claims arising from the Tenant's use.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because indemnity clauses are interpreted narrowly and only cover liabilities caused solely by the Tenant.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the court finds the Tenant 100% at fault.

options.label: E
options.text: No, unless the lease explicitly states the indemnity covers the Landlord's own negligence.

questions.explanation:
Indemnity clauses are construed strictly, but if the wording is clear and wide enough, they can cover liabilities incurred by the indemnified party (Landlord) even where they might also be at fault. The phrase "arising from the Tenant's use" is broad. If the visitor's claim can be linked to the Tenant's use (e.g., their failure to maintain the internal area they occupy), the indemnity is likely triggered. Courts require clear words to cover negligence, but "all claims... arising from use" can be sufficient (Canada Steamship Lines v The King principles).
A is incorrect. The existence of potenti...

questions.text: (Damages - Non-Pecuniary Loss: Loss of Amenity)

options.label: A
options.text: No, damages for mental distress are not recoverable in contract.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because the contract's major purpose was to provide pleasure, relaxation, and peace of mind.

options.label: C
options.text: No, they are limited to the difference in value (£4,000).

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if they suffered a diagnosable psychiatric injury.

options.label: E
options.text: No, unless the tour operator's conduct was deliberate or reckless.

questions.explanation:
The general rule is that damages for non-pecuniary loss (distress, disappointment) are not recoverable in contract. However, a major exception exists where the very purpose of the contract is to provide pleasure, relaxation, or peace of mind. Holiday contracts are the classic example (Jarvis v Swan's Tours). In such cases, damages for the spoiled enjoyment are recoverable.
A is incorrect. This is the general rule, but there is a well-established exception for contracts concerning comfort, pleasure, or peace of mind.
C is incorrect. The diminution in value is recoverable as pecuniary loss. The ...

questions.text: (Damages - Tax Element) An employee is wrongfully dismissed and wins a court award of £100,000 for lost earnings. Had he received the money as salary, it would have been subject to income tax at 40%. The award itself is not taxable under current UK rules. How should the court calculate the award?

options.label: A
options.text: £100,000 gross. The tax position of the parties is irrelevant.

options.label: B
options.text: Approximately £60,000, being the net sum after notional deduction of tax (British Transport Commission v Gourley).

options.label: C
options.text: £100,000, but the employer must pay the associated tax to HMRC.

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on whether the employee finds a new job quickly.

options.label: E
options.text: £100,000, because the Gourley principle only applies to personal injury cases.

questions.explanation:
The rule in British Transport Commission v Gourley states that where a damages award replaces income that would have been taxable, and the award itself is not taxable, the award should be reduced to reflect the net loss, to avoid over-compensating the claimant. The claimant should be put in the position they would have been in financially, which is the net position after tax.
A is incorrect. This would over-compensate the employee by giving him £100,000 net when his actual loss was £60,000 net.
C is incorrect. There is no mechanism for the employer to pay tax on an award of damages for breach ...

questions.text: (Liquidated Damages - Genuine Pre-Estimate)

options.label: A
options.text: No, because it includes an unquantifiable element for "public inconvenience," which makes it a penalty.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because it was a genuine pre-estimate of loss made at the time of contracting.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because LDs cannot include non-pecuniary losses like inconvenience.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only for the elements covering actual pecuniary loss (£2,500/week).

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the calculation was done by one party only.

questions.explanation:
A liquidated damages clause is a genuine pre-estimate of loss if it is a reasonable attempt to quantify the probable loss at the time of contracting, even if it is not precise. The inclusion of a figure for "public inconvenience" for a public library could be argued as a legitimate head of loss (e.g., loss of public amenity, reputational damage) which is difficult to quantify. As long as the overall figure is not extravagant or unconscionable compared to the greatest loss that could conceivably follow, it is likely enforceable (Dunlop Pneumatic Tyre Co Ltd v New Garage & Motor Co Ltd).
A is in...

questions.text: (Specific Performance - Discretion and Personal Service)

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because her unique talent makes damages inadequate.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the court will not order specific performance of a contract for personal services.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but only if she is paid an additional fee.

options.label: D
options.text: No, unless the contract expressly states that specific performance is available.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, because charity contracts are specially enforced.

questions.explanation:
Courts are inherently reluctant to order specific performance of contracts for personal services. This is based on practical difficulties of supervision, the undesirability of forcing a continuous personal relationship, and principles against involuntary servitude (De Francesco v Barnum). This applies even where the performer is unique.
A is incorrect. While uniqueness supports specific performance for sales of unique goods/land, the strong public policy against enforcing personal service contracts overrides this.
C is incorrect. Adding money does not overcome the fundamental objection to orde...

questions.text: (Indemnity vs Damages - Timing of Recovery) Under a contract containing a wide indemnity, Consultant Ltd becomes liable to pay a third party £100,000 due to a fault in its work for Client Corp. The third party's claim is settled. Consultant Ltd has insurance covering 80% of the loss. Client Corp is unquestionably liable under the indemnity. How much can Client Corp be required to pay under the indemnity?

options.label: A
options.text: £100,000 (the full liability), regardless of Consultant Ltd's insurance recovery.

options.label: B
options.text: £20,000 (the uninsured portion), to prevent double recovery.

options.label: C
options.text: Nothing, because Consultant Ltd has been indemnified by its insurer.

options.label: D
options.text: £100,000, but Consultant Ltd must account to Client Corp for the £80,000 insurance proceeds.

options.label: E
options.text: It depends on whether the insurance policy is one of indemnity.

questions.explanation:
An indemnity is an obligation to keep the indemnified party harmless from a specified loss. It creates a primary obligation to reimburse the amount of the loss incurred. The indemnified party's recovery from a third party (like an insurer) is generally irrelevant to the indemnifier's liability, unless the contract states otherwise. This is the principle of collateral benefits. The indemnity is not a damages claim for net loss.
B is incorrect. This applies the principle of mitigation or net loss to an indemnity, which is incorrect. An indemnity reimburses the gross loss.
C is incorrect. The ins...

questions.text: (Injunction - Mandatory to Restore Status Quo) Neighbour A builds a fence that encroaches 30cm onto Neighbour B's land, in breach of a boundary agreement. Neighbour B discovers this only after construction is complete. Neighbour B seeks a mandatory injunction requiring Neighbour A to demolish and remove the encroaching fence. Will the court grant a mandatory injunction?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, mandatory injunctions are granted as of right for trespass to land.

options.label: B
options.text: No, the court will only award damages representing the value of the land taken.

options.label: C
options.text: It is discretionary. The court will balance the hardship, considering the triviality of the encroachment against the cost of removal

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if Neighbour B pays half the cost of removal.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because Neighbour B delayed in bringing the action (discovering it after completion).

questions.explanation:
While prohibitory injunctions are more common, mandatory injunctions (ordering a party to take positive action) are discretionary and harder to obtain. The court conducts a balancing exercise, considering factors such as the triviality of the breach, the cost of compliance relative to the benefit to the claimant, and whether damages would be an adequate remedy (Jaggard v Sawyer). For a small encroachment where removal costs are high, the court may award damages in lieu (Shelfer v City of London Electric Lighting Co).
A is incorrect. Injunctions, especially mandatory ones, are equitable and dis...

questions.text: (Guarantee - Discharge by Variation of Principal Contract) Bank has a loan agreement with Borrower Ltd, guaranteed by Guarantor. The loan agreement allows the Bank, at its discretion, to grant an interest-only period. Without consulting Guarantor, the Bank agrees with Borrower Ltd to a 6-month interest-only period. Guarantor argues this discharges her from the guarantee. Is Guarantor discharged?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the variation is minor and within the Bank's contractual rights.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because any material variation of the principal contract without the guarantor's consent discharges the guarantor.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the guarantee probably contained a clause allowing variations.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the variation increases the risk to the Guarantor.

options.label: E
options.text: No, the Guarantor remains liable for the original obligation.

questions.explanation:
A guarantee is a contract of strict fidelity. If the creditor (Bank) agrees to a material variation of the terms of the principal contract with the debtor, without the consent of the guarantor, the guarantor is discharged (Holme v Brunskill).. This is because the guarantor agreed to answer for the debt on specific terms. Changing those terms, even if seemingly minor, alters the risk the guarantor undertook. Moving to interest-only is likely a material variation.
A is incorrect. The fact it is within the Bank's contractual rights vis-à-vis the Borrower is irrelevant to the Guarantor's separate ...

questions.text: (Damages - Reliance Loss)

options.label: A
options.text: No, because it cannot prove loss of profits (expectation loss).

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, it can recover the £50,000 fee as money paid for a total failure of consideration, and the £20,000 as reliance loss incurred in reasonable preparation for the contract

options.label: C
options.text: No, the £20,000 lease cost is a pre-contractual expense and irrecoverable.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only the £50,000 fee. Reliance losses are only recoverable if expectation loss is proven.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because Start-Up Ltd should have mitigated by sub-letting the office space.

questions.explanation:
Where expectation loss (lost profits) is too speculative, a claimant can elect to claim reliance loss: expenses wasted in reliance on the contract(Anglia Television Ltd v Reed).. This aims to put them in the position they would have been in had the contract not been made. The £50,000 fee is recoverable for total failure of consideration. The £20,000 lease, if entered into after the contract and in reasonable preparation for its performance, is a recoverable reliance loss. Pre-contractual expenses may also be recoverable if within the parties' contemplation.
A is incorrect. The inability to pro...

questions.text: (Liquidated Damages - Cap on Liability)

options.label: A
options.text: £120,000 (full actual loss).

options.label: C
options.text: £50,000 (the overall cap on liability).

options.label: D
options.text: £50,000, but only if the LD clause is deemed a penalty.

questions.explanation:
Contractual limitations and exclusions of liability are generally interpreted together. The LD clause quantifies damages for a specific breach (delay). The limitation clause sets a ceiling on all liability. The LD sum is a claim "arising under this contract," so it is subject to the £50,000 cap. Therefore, even if the calculated LDs are £100,000, recovery cannot exceed £50,000.
Incorrect Options Explained:
A is incorrect. The parties have contractually agreed to replace the common law measure of damages with their own regime (LDs subject to a cap).
B is incorrect. This ignores the overriding l...

questions.text: (Specific Performance - Contract Requiring Constant Supervision)

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because the unique nature of the gardens makes damages inadequate.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the contract requires continuous acts over a long period, and the court will not supervise such performance.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but only for the remainder of the current growing season.

options.label: D
options.text: No, unless the contract contains an arbitration clause for disputes about performance standards.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, because contracts relating to land are specifically enforceable.

questions.explanation:
A longstanding bar to specific performance is where the order would require constant supervision by the court to ensure compliance. Contracts for the continuous provision of services over a period of time fall into this category. The court will not put itself in the position of having to manage an ongoing relationship or adjudicate on whether each weekly task has been done properly.
A is incorrect. While inadequacy of damages is a prerequisite, it is not the only factor. The difficulty of supervision is an independent and decisive bar in such cases.
C is incorrect. The court does not typically...

questions.text: Omega Ltd contracts to sell a specialised industrial pump to Beta Manufacturing for £50,000. During negotiations, Omega’s sales director is told the pump is needed to replace a broken one in Beta’s main production line and that "any delay will cause production stoppages." The pump is delivered 4 weeks late due to Omega’s breach. During those 4 weeks, Beta loses its standard production output, worth £100,000. Furthermore, Beta misses the launch window for a new, specially marketed product line, losing a highly profitable one-off contract with a major retailer worth £500,000. Omega was unaware of this specific launch or retail contract. Which of the following best describes the recoverable losses?

options.label: A
options.text: Beta can recover £100,000 for lost standard production and £500,000 for the lost retail contract, as all losses were a direct result of the delay.

options.label: B
options.text: Beta can only recover £100,000. The loss of the specific retail contract was not within the reasonable contemplation of the parties as a probable result of the breach at the time of contracting.

options.label: C
options.text: Beta can recover £100,000 and a reasonable proportion of the £500,000, as the type of loss (lost production) was contemplated, even if the extent was not.

options.label: D
options.text: Beta cannot recover the £100,000 because it should have rented a temporary pump, but can recover the £500,000 as it was the largest loss.

options.label: E
options.text: Beta can recover nothing for lost production, as this is pure economic loss, but can recover for the lost retail contract as it was a consequential loss.

questions.explanation: This applies the rule in Hadley v Baxendale and its modern interpretation. Losses are recoverable if they arise naturally (first limb) or were within the reasonable contemplation of the parties as a probable result of the breach (second limb). Omega knew delay would stop general production, so lost standard output (£100,000) arises naturally. However, the specific, unusually lucrative retail contract was a special circumstance. For this loss to be recoverable under the second limb, Omega needed to have knowledge of those circumstances sufficient to make the loss a probable consequence of their...

questions.text: Achilles Ltd charters a ship from Troy Shipping under a voyage charter to carry cargo. The charterparty contains no unusual terms. Troy Shipping knows the cargo is perishable and that Achilles is a trader who will sell it on arrival. Due to Troy’s negligent handling, the cargo is damaged and arrives worthless. Achilles had already contracted to sell the cargo to a third party, Hector Ltd, at a profit. As a result of the breach, Achilles loses this profit. Furthermore, because Achilles fails to deliver to Hector, it breaches its contract with Hector and becomes liable to pay a contractual penalty of £50,000. Troy Shipping was unaware of the resale contract with Hector. Which of the following losses is Achilles likely to recover from Troy Shipping?

options.label: A
options.text: Both the lost profit on the sale to Hector and the £50,000 penalty liability.

options.label: B
options.text: Only the lost profit on the sale to Hector. The penalty liability to a third party is too remote.

options.label: C
options.text: Only the market value of the cargo at the port of shipment.

options.label: D
options.text: The loss of profit on the resale, but not the £50,000 penalty, unless Achilles can prove Troy Shipping had actual knowledge of the penalty clause.

options.label: E
options.text: Neither the lost profit nor the penalty, as these are indirect losses excluded by the remoteness rule.

questions.explanation: Under the first limb of Hadley v Baxendale, losses arising naturally from the breach are recoverable. In a commercial carriage contract where the carrier knows the charterer is a trader, loss of profit on a sub-sale is a normal, foreseeable type of loss (The "Pepsi 7"). However, liability to pay a penalty under a sub-sale contract is a special loss. For this to be recoverable under the second limb, the unusual term (the penalty clause) must have been communicated to the carrier so that liability for it was within the parties' contemplation as a probable result of the breach (The "Heron II" / K...

questions.text: Clara retained David, an accountant, to prepare and file her company’s annual accounts. David knew the accounts were needed to secure renewal of a crucial bank overdraft facility. Due to David’s negligence, the accounts were filed late. The bank, as a result, temporarily withdrew the overdraft facility. Clara’s company, unable to pay suppliers, lost a key long-term supply contract, leading to a severe downturn in business. Clara sues David for the loss of the supply contract and the resulting downturn. Which of the following is the strongest argument for David’s defence regarding the loss of the supply contract?

options.label: A
options.text: The bank’s decision to withdraw the facility was an independent, intervening act that broke the chain of causation.

options.label: B
options.text: Clara should have used her personal funds to pay the suppliers, so she failed to mitigate her loss.

options.label: C
options.text: The loss of the supply contract was not a probable consequence of late filing at the time the contract with David was made

options.label: D
options.text: David’s duty was only to prepare accounts with reasonable skill and care, not to ensure the overdraft was renewed.

options.label: E
options.text: The loss is purely economic and therefore not recoverable in a claim for professional negligence.

questions.explanation: This tests the application of Hadley v Baxendale to professional services. For David to be liable for the loss of the supply contract, that loss must have been within the reasonable contemplation of both parties as a probable result of his breach. While David knew the accounts were for the overdraft renewal, the chain of events from late filing to withdrawal of facility to inability to pay suppliers to loss of a specific contract involves several steps. The final loss (the supply contract) may be seen as a consequence of the bank’s commercial decision and Clara’s financial state, not a probabl...

questions.text: Builder Co contracted to renovate a historic theatre for Owner by a specific date. Builder Co knew the theatre was booked for a prestigious festival opening on that date. Due to Builder Co’s delay, the opening night had to be cancelled. Owner refunded all tickets, lost bar revenue, and also suffered a loss of future bookings because of the negative publicity. Furthermore, Owner had a side agreement with a documentary film crew granting them exclusive access to film the renovation; due to the delay, this contract was also cancelled, causing Owner to lose a £50,000 fee. Builder Co was aware of the festival but not the documentary contract. What can Owner recover?

options.label: A
options.text: All losses, including the documentary fee, as they all flow directly from the delay.

options.label: B
options.text: Only the losses related to the festival opening (ticket refunds, lost bar revenue, loss of future bookings), as these were within contemplation. The documentary fee is too remote.

options.label: C
options.text: Only the ticket refunds and lost bar revenue. Loss of future bookings and the documentary fee are both too remote.

options.label: D
options.text: Nothing for loss of future bookings, as this is speculative, but everything else is recoverable.

options.label: E
options.text: Only the difference between the contract price and the cost of hiring another builder, as this is the normal measure for delay.

questions.explanation:
Builder Co had special knowledge of the festival opening, bringing losses from its cancellation within the second limb of Hadley v Baxendale. This includes direct losses (refunds, bar revenue) and consequential losses that are a probable result (loss of reputation leading to lost future bookings, provided evidence is clear). However, the documentary contract was an unrelated, undisclosed venture. Without knowledge of it, the loss of the £50,000 fee was not a probable consequence of the delay in the minds of the parties at the time of contracting, making it too remote.
A is incorrect. It applie...

questions.text: Simon sold a specific, rare vintage car to Priya. The contract required Simon to keep the car insured until collection. Simon negligently failed to insure it, and the car was destroyed by vandals while in his garage before collection. The market value of the car was £80,000. Priya had planned to exhibit the car at a major classic car show where she had a guaranteed opportunity to sell it for £120,000 to a pre-identified collector. Simon was unaware of this planned sale. What damages is Priya entitled to?

options.label: A
options.text: £120,000, as this is the value of her lost opportunity.

options.label: B
options.text: £80,000, as the lost sale is too remote.

options.label: C
options.text: £80,000, and the £40,000 lost profit if she can prove Simon acted fraudulently.

options.label: D
options.text: Nothing, because the risk had not yet passed to Priya when the car was destroyed.

options.label: E
options.text: A sum between £80,000 and £120,000 at the court’s discretion, to reflect the chance of the sale.

questions.explanation:
Simon’s breach is the failure to insure. The direct loss is the value of the car. The lost profit on the planned sale is a consequential loss. For this to be recoverable, it must have been within the contemplation of the parties. Simon had no knowledge of the specific, lucrative resale opportunity. Therefore, the £120, sale price is too remote. Priya is entitled to be put in the position she would have been in had the contract been performed: she would have received the car, worth its market value of £80,000 (Hadley v Baxendale).
A is incorrect. It ignores the remoteness rule. The exceptional ...

questions.text: Farmer George contracted to sell his entire annual cherry harvest to SuperJuice Ltd. SuperJuice knew the cherries were to be used in its premium juice line. George failed to deliver because he sold the harvest to a higher bidder. SuperJuice, unable to source equivalent cherries at short notice, had to cancel production of the premium line, losing £50,000 in profit. It also had to breach contracts with several high-end supermarkets, incurring £20,000 in contractual penalties. SuperJuice had not told George about the supermarket contracts. What can SuperJuice recover from George?

options.label: A
options.text: £70,000 (both lost profit and penalties).

options.label: B
options.text: Only £50,000 (lost profit). The penalties are too remote.

options.label: C
options.text: Only the difference between the contract price and the market price for cherries.

options.label: D
options.text: £50,000 in lost profit and a reasonable proportion of the £20,000, as George knew the cherries were for commercial production.

options.label: E
options.text: Nothing, because SuperJuice should have mitigated by sourcing cherries from elsewhere.

questions.explanation:
George knew the cherries were for SuperJuice’s commercial production. Loss of profit on the planned premium juice line is a loss arising naturally from the breach in a commercial supply contract (first limb of Hadley). However, liability for penalties under downstream contracts with supermarkets is a special loss. For this to be recoverable, George needed knowledge of those specific contracts and their penal terms so that such liability was a probable consequence in his contemplation. Without that knowledge, the £20,000 is too remote.
A is incorrect. It fails to apply the remoteness rule to th...

questions.text: An architect, Maria, was hired to design a house for Leo. Maria knew Leo planned to build quickly and sell the property for a profit. Maria’s designs contained serious errors, leading to a stop-work notice from building control. Correcting the errors and re-starting construction caused a 6-month delay. Due to this delay, Leo sold the completed house a year later than planned. The housing market had fallen significantly in that year, and Leo received £150,000 less than he would have a year earlier. Leo claims this £150,000 from Maria. Is Leo likely to succeed?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because Maria’s breach directly caused the delay which led to the sale in a falling market.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the volatility of the housing market is an independent economic factor, and such a loss is too remote.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but only if Leo can prove Maria guaranteed the sale value of the house.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because Leo’s decision to sell was voluntary; he could have held the property.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but the damages will be reduced by the amount Leo saved in mortgage interest during the delay.

questions.explanation: This engages with the modern restatement of remoteness in Transfield Shipping Inc v Mercator Shipping Inc (The "Achilleas"). The question is whether the loss from a fall in the market is a type of loss for which the defaulting party assumed responsibility. In a professional contract for design, the architect assumes responsibility for the costs of rectification and associated delay costs, but not necessarily for the economic risk of market fluctuations affecting the client’s speculative sale profit. Such a loss is arguably outside the assumed responsibility, even if it is a direct factual cons...

questions.text: TechSoft licensed software to BankCorp for its trading floor, knowing it was critical for real-time transactions. The licence included a clause excluding liability for "loss of profits, revenue, or data." The software crashed for 3 hours due to a latent defect. During the crash, BankCorp’s traders could not execute deals, missing out on several profitable arbitrage opportunities. BankCorp calculated this lost chance profit as £2 million. BankCorp also had to pay £200,000 in regulatory fines for failing to maintain operational systems. Which loss is more likely to be recoverable despite the exclusion clause?

options.label: A
options.text: Both losses are excluded by the clear wording "loss of profits."

options.label: B
options.text: The £200,000 regulatory fine, as this may be construed as a liability not falling within loss of profits and may have been within the parties’ contemplation

options.label: C
options.text: The £2 million lost chance profit, as this is the most direct financial loss.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither loss; the exclusion clause is clear and covers all consequential financial loss.

options.label: E
options.text: Only the cost of repairing or replacing the software.

questions.explanation: This tests the interpretation of exclusion clauses in light of remoteness. The clause excludes "loss of profits, revenue, or data." The £2m for lost trading opportunities clearly falls within "loss of profits" and is excluded. A regulatory fine, however, is a different type of loss, it is a liability to a third party (the regulator) imposed as a penalty. It is not naturally described as "loss of profits" or "revenue." For it to be recoverable, it must also satisfy remoteness rules. In the context of mission-critical software for a regulated bank, regulatory fines for downtime are a foreseeable...

questions.text: Wellesley Partners LLP, a headhunting firm, engaged the law firm Withers LLP to draft a partnership agreement for a new joint venture in Asia. Wellesley made it clear that the agreement needed to be finalised with utmost urgency to capitalise on a specific and fleeting market opportunity, and that delayed completion would cause them to lose the entire venture. Withers negligently delayed the drafting by two months. By the time the agreement was ready, the market opportunity had vanished, and the potential partners withdrew. Wellesley sued for the loss of the expected multi-million-pound profits from the joint venture. Withers argued the loss was too remote, as the success of the venture was uncertain and dependent on many factors. Which of the following best describes the court's likely approach to remoteness in this professional negligence context?

options.label: A
options.text: The loss is too remote because it is pure economic loss and requires proof of a special relationship of proximity.

options.label: B
options.text: The loss is recoverable if it was within the reasonable contemplation of the parties as a probable result of the breach

options.label: C
options.text: The loss is only recoverable if Withers had assumed responsibility for the success of the joint venture, which they did not by merely agreeing to draft documents.

options.label: D
options.text: The loss is too remote because a solicitor's duty is to exercise skill and care in drafting, not to guarantee the commercial success of the client's ventures.

options.label: E
options.text: Wellesley must prove on the balance of probabilities that the joint venture would definitely have been profitable, which it cannot do, so only nominal damages are available.

questions.explanation: The case of Wellesley Partners LLP v Withers LLP reaffirmed the application of the Hadley v Baxendale remoteness test in contract claims for professional negligence. The test remains whether the loss was reasonably contemplated. The critical factor is the defendant's knowledge. Where a professional has been clearly informed of a specific, identifiable commercial opportunity that depends on their timely performance, the loss of that opportunity (and its associated profits) is within their reasonable contemplation as a probable result of delay. The court will assess this at the time the contract...

questions.text: In a contract for the sale of Brent crude oil, Seller knew Buyer was a trader who would on-sell the oil into the European market. Seller failed to deliver the cargo on the contracted date. As a result, Buyer had to go into the market to buy similar oil at a higher price to meet its commitments. Buyer claimed the difference between the contract price and the higher cover price (a loss of $500,000). Furthermore, due to the Seller's failure, Buyer missed a profitable opportunity to sell the oil during a brief, sharp price spike that occurred two days after the original delivery date. This lost opportunity was valued at $1 million. Seller was aware oil prices were volatile but had no specific knowledge of Buyer's particular trading strategy or the anticipated spike. Which of the following is correct regarding the $1 million lost opportunity claim?

options.label: A
options.text: It is recoverable because trading for profit was the very essence of the contract, so all trading losses are within contemplation.

options.label: B
options.text: It is not recoverable. While the $500,000 cover loss is a direct market loss, the $1m claim is for a loss on a collateral speculation, which was not within the parties' reasonable contemplation as a probable result of the breach.

options.label: C
options.text: It is recoverable but will be reduced by 50% due to the inherent uncertainty of market predictions.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only recoverable if Buyer can prove Seller acted in bad faith.

options.label: E
options.text: It is not recoverable because Buyer mitigated its loss by purchasing substitute oil, thus crystallising its loss at the cover price.

questions.explanation: This scenario deals with the boundary between direct market losses and speculative market losses. The case of Glencore Energy v Transworld Oil illustrates that in commodity trades, a defaulting seller can reasonably contemplate that a buyer will need to enter the market to cover a short position, making the difference between contract and cover price recoverable. However, a loss relating to a specific, missed profitable opportunity (like a fleeting price spike) is a different type of loss. For this to be recoverable, the seller would need knowledge of the buyer's specific trading intentions re...

areas.name: Correct. If a party does not attend trial, the court may proceed in their absence and decide the case on the evidence available.

questions.text: : Andrew brings a breach of contract claim against Benjamin in the County Court. After trial, Andrew succeeds on most issues, but the court reduces the damages claimed by 25%. Both parties argue they should recover their legal costs. What is the general rule the court will apply when deciding costs?

options.label: A
options.text: Each party bears their own costs

options.label: B
options.text: The losing party pays the winning party’s costs

options.label: C
options.text: Costs are always split equally

options.label: D
options.text: Costs follow the amount of damages awarded

options.label: E
options.text: Costs are never awarded in County Court cases

questions.explanation: B is Correct. The general rule is that costs follow the event, meaning the unsuccessful party pays the successful party’s costs, subject to the court’s discretion.Partial success may justify adjustment, but does not displace the general rule.

questions.text: : Charlotte sues Daniel for negligent advice. Charlotte wins the claim, but the court finds that she acted unreasonably by refusing to engage in settlement discussions and by breaching court directions during the proceedings. How may the court reflect Charlotte’s conduct when awarding costs?

options.label: A
options.text: The court must award Charlotte all her costs

options.label: B
options.text: The court may reduce or disallow Charlotte’s costs

options.label: C
options.text: The court must dismiss Charlotte’s claim

options.label: D
options.text: The court must order Daniel to pay indemnity costs

options.label: E
options.text: The court cannot consider conduct when awarding costs

questions.explanation:
B is Correct. The court has discretion to reduce or disallow costs based on unreasonable conduct, even if the party has won.Conduct is a key factor under CPR when deciding costs.
.

questions.text: : Emily succeeds in a fast-track trial against Frank. At the conclusion of the hearing, Emily asks the judge to assess costs immediately. Frank objects, stating that costs should be assessed later. Which approach to cost assessment is most likely?

options.label: A
options.text: Costs must always be assessed by detailed assessment

options.label: B
options.text: Costs must always be summarily assessed

options.label: C
options.text: The court is likely to carry out a summary assessment

options.label: D
options.text: Costs cannot be assessed until enforcement proceedings

options.label: E
options.text: Costs are assessed only on appeal

questions.explanation: C is Correct. In fast-track and short hearings, the court usually carries out a summary assessment of costs at the end of the hearing. Detailed assessment is more common for complex or high-value cases.

questions.text: : George brings a claim against Hannah and wins. Hannah’s conduct during proceedings is found to be unreasonable and obstructive. George applies for costs on the indemnity basis. What is the effect of awarding costs on the indemnity basis?

options.label: A
options.text: Costs are limited to fixed amounts

options.label: B
options.text: Any doubt as to reasonableness is resolved in favour of the paying party

options.label: C
options.text: Any doubt as to reasonableness is resolved in favour of the receiving party

options.label: D
options.text: Only court fees can be recovered

options.label: E
options.text: Costs are automatically doubled

questions.explanation: C is Correct. On the indemnity basis, doubts are resolved in favour of the receiving party, making it more generous than the standard basis.This is typically awarded where the losing party’s conduct is unreasonable.

questions.text: : Isabella brings a claim against Jacob for £100,000. Jacob makes a Part 36 offer of £80,000, which Isabella rejects. At trial, Isabella is awarded £75,000. What are the likely costs consequences?

options.label: A
options.text: Isabella recovers all her costs

options.label: B
options.text: Jacob must pay all costs because Isabella won

options.label: C
options.text: Isabella may have to pay Jacob’s costs from the expiry of the offer

options.label: D
options.text: Costs are split equally

options.label: E
options.text: The Part 36 offer has no effect

questions.explanation: C is Correct. If a claimant fails to beat a defendant’s Part 36 offer, the claimant may be ordered to pay the defendant’s costs from the date the offer expired.

questions.text: : Thomas claims £50,000 from Richard for defective goods. Richard makes a Part 36 offer of £45,000. Thomas rejects the offer. At trial, Thomas is awarded £46,000. What are the likely costs consequences under Part 36?

options.label: A
options.text: Thomas recovers all his costs from the start of proceedings

options.label: B
options.text: Richard recovers no costs because the claim partially succeeded

options.label: C
options.text: Thomas may have to pay Richard’s costs from the date the Part 36 offer expired

options.label: D
options.text: Costs are irrelevant in Part 36 cases

options.label: E
options.text: The judge may award costs on the indemnity basis automatically

questions.explanation:
C is Correct. If the claimant fails to beat a Part 36 offer, they may be liable for the defendant’s costs from the date the offer expired.
A is Incorrect. Partial success does not override Part 36 rules.
B is Incorrect. Part 36 allows cost consequences even if the claim is partially successful.
D is Incorrect. Costs are central to Part 36.
E is Incorrect. Indemnity basis is discretionary and not automatic.

questions.text: : Emma brings a multi-track claim for £250,000 against Nathan for breach of contract. The court hears complex expert evidence and procedural applications. After trial, Emma wins the claim but the court finds she acted unreasonably in refusing settlement discussions. How is the court likely to handle costs in a multi-track case with unreasonable conduct?

options.label: A
options.text: Full costs must be awarded to Emma regardless of conduct

options.label: B
options.text: Costs may be reduced or awarded partially due to Emma’s unreasonable conduct

options.label: C
options.text: Costs are always assessed on the indemnity basis in multi-track cases

options.label: D
options.text: Costs are irrelevant in multi-track claims

options.label: E
options.text: Costs must be split equally because of case complexity

questions.explanation:
B is Correct. In multi-track cases, the court has discretion to reduce or adjust costs based on unreasonable conduct, even if the party wins.
A is Incorrect. Conduct can affect costs.
C is Incorrect. Indemnity basis is discretionary and not automatic.
D is Incorrect. Costs are highly relevant in multi-track claims.
E is Incorrect. Costs are not automatically split due to complexity.
K- Appeals

questions.text: : Sophia loses her claim in the County Court. She believes the judge made an error in applying the law and wishes to challenge the decision. Which of the following is true regarding her right to appeal?

options.label: A
options.text: She has an automatic right to appeal any County Court decision to the Court of Appeal

options.label: B
options.text: She can appeal only if she obtains permission from the court

options.label: C
options.text: She cannot appeal County Court decisions under any circumstances

options.label: D
options.text: She can appeal directly to the Supreme Court

options.label: E
options.text: She can appeal without permission only if she disagrees with the judge’s findings of fact

questions.explanation:
B is Correct. Appeals from the County Court generally require permission, either from the lower court or the appellate court.
A is Incorrect. Appeals are not automatic.
C is Incorrect. Appeals are allowed, subject to permission.
D is Incorrect. Supreme Court hears only rare, high-value or public law cases.
E is Incorrect. Permission is needed regardless of whether the appeal concerns law or fact.

questions.text: : Liam loses a multi-track claim in the High Court. He wants to appeal to the Court of Appeal but has delayed notifying the court for three months. What is the usual time limit for filing an appeal from the High Court to the Court of Appeal?

options.label: A
options.text: 7 days from judgment

options.label: B
options.text: 14 days from judgment

options.label: C
options.text: 21 days from judgment

options.label: D
options.text: 28 days from judgment

options.label: E
options.text: 3 months from judgment

questions.explanation: D is Correct. The usual time limit is 28 days from the date of the judgment.

areas.name: C  are Incorrect. Too short; these do not reflect standard CPR rules.

questions.text: : Rachel wins a small-claims trial but disagrees with the judge’s decision on costs. She wants to appeal. What is the correct statement about appealing a small-claims decision?

options.label: A
options.text: She may appeal on any point, including factual findings, to the Court of Appeal

options.label: B
options.text: Appeals are limited; she can only challenge points of law

options.label: C
options.text: She may appeal to the Supreme Court directly

options.label: D
options.text: She may appeal on costs only if the amount exceeds £10,000

options.label: E
options.text: Appeals from small claims are prohibited

questions.explanation:
B is Correct. Small claims appeals are limited to points of law, not factual disputes.
A is Incorrect. Appeals on factual grounds are not permitted in small claims.
C is Incorrect. Supreme Court is not a first appellate court for small claims.
D is Incorrect. Appeal rights are not linked to costs amount.
E is Incorrect. Appeals are permitted but limited.

questions.text: : Emma sues Daniel in the County Court for breach of a construction contract. The County Court judge dismisses her claim, finding that the contract was not legally binding. Emma believes the judge made an error in law, particularly regarding how implied terms were interpreted. She wants to appeal the decision to the High Court. She is unsure whether she can automatically appeal or if she needs to request permission. What must Emma do to appeal this County Court decision?

options.label: A
options.text: She has an automatic right to appeal to the High Court

options.label: B
options.text: She must obtain permission to appeal from the County Court or High Court

options.label: C
options.text: She may appeal directly to the Court of Appeal

options.label: D
options.text: She cannot appeal because the case involves a contract

options.label: E
options.text: She can only appeal if the claim value exceeds £50,000

questions.explanation:
B is Correct. Appeals from the County Court generally require permission, either from the lower court (the County Court) or the appellate court (High Court).
A is Incorrect. No automatic right exists.
C is Incorrect. The Court of Appeal is not the first appellate stage for County Court cases.
D is Incorrect. Contract cases are appealable.
E is Incorrect. Appeal rights are not determined by the claim value.

questions.text: : Lucas loses a High Court multi-track trial against Henry involving a £150,000 claim. Lucas wishes to appeal the judgment to the Court of Appeal but realises that more than 28 days have passed since the judgment was handed down. Lucas considers applying for an extension of time. Henry objects, arguing that the time limit is strict and Lucas should have acted promptly. Lucas is uncertain how the court will treat his late application. What is the correct procedure regarding the time limit for appeal?

options.label: A
options.text: Appeals must be filed within 28 days; no extension is possible

options.label: B
options.text: Appeals can be filed at any time if the appellant has a good reason

options.label: C
options.text: The appellant may apply for an extension of time, and the court has discretion to allow it

options.label: D
options.text: The appellant can only appeal on the next business day

options.label: E
options.text: The appeal will automatically be struck out if late

questions.explanation:
C is Correct. The standard time limit for appealing a High Court decision is 28 days, but the court has discretion to allow a late appeal if there is a good reason.
A is Incorrect. Strict adherence without discretion is wrong.
B is Incorrect. Appeals cannot be filed at any time without court permission.
D is Incorrect. No “next business day” rule applies.
E is Incorrect. The court can extend time; automatic striking out is not required.

questions.text: Sophie wins a judgment against Michael in the County Court for £60,000. Michael appeals to the High Court. Sophie is concerned about whether she can enforce the judgment immediately or if the appeal prevents her from doing so. Michael argues that the appeal suspends the judgment automatically. Sophie wants to understand her options to recover her money pending the appeal. What is the effect of an appeal on the enforcement of a judgment?

options.label: A
options.text: The judgment is automatically suspended pending appeal

options.label: B
options.text: The judgment can be enforced immediately unless the appellate court orders a stay

options.label: C
options.text: Enforcement is prohibited until the Supreme Court decides

options.label: D
options.text: Enforcement is only possible if the appellant consents

options.label: E
options.text: The judgment is void during the appeal

questions.explanation:
B is Correct. Generally, a judgment can be enforced immediately unless the appellate court grants a stay of enforcement.
A is Incorrect. Appeals do not automatically suspend enforcement.
C is Incorrect. Enforcement is not dependent on the Supreme Court.
D is Incorrect. Consent is not required.
E is Incorrect. The judgment is valid unless stayed.

questions.text: : Nathan loses a fast-track claim in the County Court against Olivia for breach of contract. Nathan believes the judge misunderstood the applicable law on misrepresentation but does not dispute the facts found by the judge. Nathan considers appealing to the High Court. Olivia argues that appeals are not permitted on factual findings in fast-track cases and that Nathan can only challenge errors of law. Nathan is unsure whether he can appeal and what scope the High Court will consider. On what basis is Nathan likely able to appeal?

options.label: A
options.text: Nathan can appeal on any factual or legal point

options.label: B
options.text: Nathan can appeal only on points of law, not on factual findings

options.label: C
options.text: Nathan cannot appeal because the case is fast-track

options.label: D
options.text: Nathan can appeal on both fact and law if he obtains permission

options.label: E
options.text: Nathan can appeal only if the damages awarded exceed £50,000

questions.explanation:
B is Correct. In fast-track appeals, the appellate court generally considers points of law only, not factual disputes.
A is Incorrect. Appeals on factual findings are generally prohibited.
C is Incorrect. Fast-track cases can be appealed on law.
D is Incorrect. Permission does not allow appeals on fact.
E is Incorrect. Claim value does not determine appeal rights.
