options.text: No, because witnessing a Statutory Declaration is a reserved activity that can only be performed by a Notary Public.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because all solicitors with a practicing certificate have the powers of a Commissioner for Oaths.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because a solicitor is not permitted to charge a fee for legal services provided to a neighbor in an informal setting like a coffee shop.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the coffee shop is located within the same postal district as Noah’s registered office.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because "witnessing" is not a reserved legal activity, so Noah has no special authority to sign the document.

questions.explanation:
Under the Solicitors Act 1974, every solicitor who has a practicing certificate in force has the powers of a Commissioner for Oaths. This is one of the six reserved legal activities.
Why the other options are incorrect:
Option A: While Notaries can do this, solicitors have the same power for most domestic declarations.
Option C: Solicitors are entitled to the statutory fees for Oaths.
Option D: There is no geographical restriction on where a Commissioner for Oaths can exercise their power.
Option E: "Administration of oaths" (which includes statutory declarations) is a reserved activity

questions.text: : PII—The Minimum Terms and Conditions (MTCs) Partner A at a medium-sized firm is reviewing the firm’s Professional Indemnity Insurance (PII) policy. He notices a "Special Condition" inserted by the insurer which states: "The insurer shall not be liable to indemnify the firm for any claim arising from an act or omission that is deemed to constitute 'gross negligence' or 'reckless disregard' for the client's interests." The firm accepts this clause because it reduces their annual premium by 15%. Is this clause valid and enforceable under the SRA Indemnity Insurance Rules?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because PII is a commercial contract and insurers are free to limit their risk exposure to prevent "moral hazard."

options.label: B
options.text: No, because insurers are prohibited from excluding or limiting cover based on the degree of the solicitor's negligence.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, provided that the firm has specifically notified the SRA of this exclusion and the SRA has granted a "waiver of compliance."

options.label: D
options.text: No, because solicitors are professionals and the law presumes that they can never be "grossly" negligent, making the clause redundant.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, as long as the firm maintains a "negligence reserve fund" in its office account to cover any claims that fall into the "gross negligence" category.

questions.explanation:
The SRA Minimum Terms and Conditions (MTCs) are designed for public protection. They mandate a minimum level of "all-risks" civil liability cover. Insurers are not permitted to exclude a claim simply because the solicitor was "grossly" negligent or even reckless.
Incorrect Options:
A: While commercial insurance allows this, compulsory SRA insurance does not.
C: The SRA does not grant individual waivers that lower the protection of the MTCs.
E: A "reserve fund" is not a substitute for the mandatory insurance requirements.

questions.text: : Business Structures—The CILEX Manager Oliver is a Chartered Legal Executive (CILEX Fellow) with 15 years of experience in personal injury law. He wishes to open his own firm, "Oliver’s Injury Law Ltd." He intends to be the sole director and 100% shareholder. He applies to the SRA to have his firm regulated as a "Recognised Body." Can Oliver’s firm be regulated by the SRA?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the SRA only regulates firms where at least one manager or owner is a qualified solicitor of England and Wales.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because CILEX Fellows are "authorized persons" under the Legal Services Act and are eligible to be managers and owners of SRA-regulated firms.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the Legal Services Act 2007 requires CILEX members to be regulated exclusively by CILEX Regulation Ltd, not the SRA.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if Oliver hires at least one solicitor to act as the Compliance Officer for Legal Practice (COLP).

options.label: E
options.text: No, because CILEX Fellows are not permitted to perform reserved legal activities, so the firm could not provide full legal services.

questions.explanation:
A Recognised Body is a firm where all the managers and interest holders are "legally qualified" (authorized persons). This includes solicitors, RELs, and CILEX Fellows.
Incorrect Options:
A: The SRA regulates various "lawyer-led" firms, not just those led by solicitors.
C: Practitioners often have a choice of regulator (though there are currently discussions about merging CILEX regulation into the SRA).
D: A CILEX Fellow can be a COLP if they are a manager of the firm.
E: CILEX Fellows can perform certain reserved activities (like litigation or probate) if they have the appropriate practice ri...

questions.text: : Jacob is a dual-qualified professional. He is both a solicitor and a Notary Public. A client, Elena, asks him to notarize a Power of Attorney for her to sell a villa in Spain. Jacob checks her ID, witnesses her signature, and applies his official Notarial Seal. He charges a fee of £150 for this specific service. Which regulatory body is responsible for supervising Jacob’s conduct during this specific transaction?

options.label: A
options.text: The Solicitors Regulation Authority (SRA).

options.label: B
options.text: The Faculty Office of the Archbishop of Canterbury.

options.label: C
options.text: The Law Society of England and Wales.

options.label: D
options.text: The Bar Council.

options.label: E
options.text: The Spanish Ministry of Justice.

questions.explanation:
Notaries are one of the oldest branches of the legal profession. They are regulated by the Master of the Faculties through the Faculty Office. Even if the Notary is also a solicitor, the SRA only regulates their "solicitor" work.
Incorrect Options:
A: The SRA only regulates his work when he is acting as a solicitor.
C: The Law Society is a representative body, not a regulator.

questions.text: : Accounts Rules—Payments on Account Finn is a criminal defense solicitor. A new client, Leo, pays him £2,000 in cash as an "advance" for fees and anticipated expert witness costs for a trial that is scheduled for three months' time. No bill has been sent to Leo yet, and no work has been performed. How must Finn treat this £2,000 payment under the SRA Accounts Rules?

options.label: A
options.text: He must pay it into the Office Account immediately because it is "money received in connection with his business.

options.label: B
options.text: He must pay it into the Client Account because it is money held or received on account of costs for work not yet billed.

options.label: C
options.text: He has a choice: he can bank it in either account as long as he records it in the client ledger within 48 hours.

options.label: D
options.text: He must return the cash to the client and ask for a bank transfer, as solicitors are prohibited from accepting any cash payments over £1,000.

options.label: E
options.text: It is "Exempt Money" under Rule 2.2 because it is for a criminal matter.

questions.explanation:
Rule 2.1 of the SRA Accounts Rules defines Client Money as money held or received in respect of fees and any unpaid disbursements if held prior to the delivery of a bill.
Incorrect Options:
A: It only moves to the office account after a bill has been issued to the client.
D: While AML rules might suggest caution, there is no flat prohibition on £2,000 cash under the Accounts Rules; it just must be banked correctly.

questions.text: : Duty to the Regulator—The Dishonest Partner Grace is the junior partner in a two-partner firm. While reviewing the accounts for a quiet real estate quarter, she discovers that her senior partner, Arthur, has been "borrowing" money from the client account to pay his personal gambling debts. He has taken £50,000 over six months. When confronted, Arthur (who is Grace’s mentor) breaks down in tears, admits the theft, and promises to pay it all back from a pending inheritance next month. He begs her not to tell anyone, as it would destroy his 40-year career. What is Grace’s mandatory obligation under the SRA Code of Conduct?

options.label: A
options.text: She should wait 30 days to see if the inheritance arrives; if the money is replaced, no "loss" has occurred and no report is needed.

options.label: B
options.text: She must report the matter to the SRA promptly

options.label: C
options.text: She must report the matter to the Law Society’s "Practice Advice Service" and follow their non-binding recommendation.

options.label: D
options.text: She must ask the affected clients for permission to report the partner, as client confidentiality overrides the duty to the regulator.

options.label: E
options.text: She should tell Arthur to resign quietly for "health reasons" to avoid bringing the profession into disrepute.

questions.explanation:
Under Paragraph 7.7 of the Code of Conduct for Individuals, solicitors must report "promptly" any facts or matters they believe amount to a serious breach. Theft/misuse of client money is the highest category of serious breach.
Incorrect Options:
A: Delaying a report of dishonesty is itself a serious regulatory breach.
D: The duty to report a serious breach is an exception to the usual rules of confidentiality; you do not need client consent to report a crime/serious breach.
E: This would be a "cover-up," which is a separate breach of Principle 5 (Integrity).
B. overriding legal obligations & ...

questions.text: Christopher is a solicitor representing Matthew, who has severe visual impairment. Matthew is the claimant in a complex clinical negligence case. The firm’s standard procedure is to send all evidence bundles and witness statements via a secure digital portal in PDF format. Matthew informs Christopher that his screen-reading software cannot process the firm’s encrypted PDFs and requests that all documents be provided in a specific high-contrast, large-print physical format or an accessible Word document. Christopher’s senior partner, Peter, refuses, citing the high administrative cost and the firm’s "paperless" environmental policy. What is the firm’s legal obligation under the Equality Act 2010?

options.label: A
options.text: The firm has no obligation to change its format if the "paperless" policy is applied consistently to all clients regardless of disability.

options.label: B
options.text: The firm must provide the documents in the requested format as a reasonable adjustment, and the cost cannot be passed on to Matthew.

options.label: C
options.text: The firm must provide the documents but is entitled to charge Matthew an additional administrative fee to cover the printing and formatting costs.

options.label: D
options.text: The firm only needs to comply if Matthew can prove that the lack of accessible documents would lead to him losing the case.

options.label: E
options.text: Christopher should refer Matthew to a specialized firm for the blind, as this would be a "proportionate means of achieving a legitimate aim."

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Under s.20 of the Equality Act 2010, service providers (including law firms) have a duty to make reasonable adjustments for disabled persons. This includes changing the way things are done (procedural adjustments) and providing information in an accessible format. s.20(7) explicitly states that the person for whom the adjustment is made cannot be charged for the cost of that adjustment.
Why the other options are incorrect:
Option A: Neutral policies that put a disabled person at a substantial disadvantage trigger the duty to adjust.
Option C: Passing on the cost is strictl...

questions.text: Elizabeth is the Managing Partner of a law firm. She decides to implement a new "Saturday Morning Excellence" initiative, requiring all fee-earners to attend the office every Saturday from 9:00 AM to 12:00 PM for mandatory training and file reviews. John, an Orthodox Jewish associate, explains to Elizabeth that he cannot attend due to the Sabbath. Elizabeth tells John that the rule applies to everyone equally and that his career progression will be hindered if he does not attend like the other associates. Which form of discrimination is most likely occurring here?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct discrimination

options.label: B
options.text: Harassment

options.label: C
options.text: Indirect discrimination

options.label: D
options.text: Victimization

options.label: E
options.text: No discrimination, as the training is a legitimate business requirement applied to all staff.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. Indirect discrimination (s.19 Equality Act 2010) occurs when a rule or policy (PCP) is applied to everyone but has the effect of putting people with a protected characteristic (Religion) at a disadvantage compared to others, and the policy cannot be shown to be a "proportionate means of achieving a legitimate aim."
Why the other options are incorrect:
Option A: The rule isn't specifically about Jews; it's a general rule that affects them differently. That makes it indirect, not direct.
Option B: Harassment requires conduct related to a characteristic that violates dignity ...

questions.text: Andrew is a solicitor acting for Mark in a boundary dispute. Shortly before the trial, Mark shows Andrew a historical map he found in his attic which clearly shows the boundary is in the neighbor's favor, not his own. Mark tells Andrew: "I am going to destroy this map. You are my solicitor, so you must keep this quiet and win my case." What is Andrew’s overriding legal and professional obligation?

options.label: A
options.text: He must maintain confidentiality and proceed to trial, as the map is a privileged document.

options.label: B
options.text: He must follow Mark's instructions to destroy the map to ensure the best possible outcome for the client.

options.label: C
options.text: He must explain to Mark that he cannot mislead the court, and if Mark destroys the map or refuses to disclose it, Andrew must cease acting.

options.label: D
options.text: He must immediately call the neighbor's solicitor and disclose the existence of the map to ensure the court is not misled.

options.label: E
options.text: He must report Mark to the SRA for attempted fraud.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. Under the SRA Principles, the duty to uphold the "proper administration of justice" (Principle 1) and "Integrity" (Principle 5) overrides the duty to act in the "best interests of the client" (Principle 7). A solicitor cannot be a party to the destruction of evidence or the misleading of the court. If the client refuses to disclose a relevant document, the solicitor must withdraw from the case.
Why the other options are incorrect:
Option A: Privilege does not allow a solicitor to assist in a fraud or the suppression of disclosable evidence.
Option B: This would be a crimin...

questions.text: Sarah, a senior associate at a law firm, informs her supervisor, David, that she is pregnant. Two weeks later, David removes Sarah from a high-profile merger case, claiming that the late-night negotiations would be too stressful for an expectant mother and that it would be better for her to handle "quieter" administrative work until her maternity leave starts. Sarah wants to stay on the case and feels her career is being sidelined. Which of the following best describes David’s actions under the Equality Act 2010?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not discrimination because David is acting in Sarah’s best interest and fulfilling his duty of care.

options.label: B
options.text: It is indirect discrimination because the policy of removing stressed workers applies to everyone.

options.label: C
options.text: It is direct pregnancy and maternity discrimination

options.label: D
options.text: It is only discrimination if Sarah’s salary is reduced as a result of the move.

options.label: E
options.text: It is a "proportionate means of achieving a legitimate aim" regarding health and safety.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. Under s.18 Equality Act 2010, it is direct discrimination to treat a woman unfavorably because of her pregnancy. "Benevolent" discrimination (acting out of a misplaced sense of protection) is still discrimination if it results in unfavorable treatment, such as being removed from a career-enhancing project.
Why the other options are incorrect:
Option A: Motivation is irrelevant in direct discrimination.
Option B: This is a direct act based on the pregnancy, not a neutral policy.
Option D: Unfavorable treatment includes loss of opportunity, not just financial loss.
Option E:...

questions.text: Thomas is a solicitor specializing in probate. He regularly refers his clients to "Faithful Stones," a monumental masonry company, for headstones. Unknown to his clients, Thomas receives a 10% commission from "Faithful Stones" for every referral. Thomas justifies this by saying he spends a lot of time coordinating with them, and the referral helps his clients find a reliable service. Has Thomas breached his overriding legal obligations?

options.label: A
options.text: No, provided the masonry company provides a high-quality service to the clients.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because he is failing to act with independence and is not being transparent about his financial interests.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because solicitors are entitled to "referral fees" in all areas of law under the SRA Transparency Rules.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the headstone is more expensive because of his commission.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because this is a private commercial arrangement outside of the legal case.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Solicitors must act with Integrity and Independence. Under the SRA Code of Conduct (Para 5.1), solicitors must inform clients of any financial interest in a referral. Failing to disclose a commission is a breach of the duty to act in the client's best interest and undermines public trust.
Why the other options are incorrect:
Option A: Quality of service does not excuse a lack of transparency.
Option C: Referral fees are strictly prohibited in personal injury cases and must be disclosed in all others.
Option D: The breach is the secrecy and the conflict of interest, regardl...

questions.text: James, the Managing Partner of a law firm, introduces a policy that no one over the age of 65 can be a Senior Partner. He argues that this is necessary to allow "new blood" to move up the ranks and to ensure the long-term succession planning of the firm. Paul, who is 66 and highly productive, is forced to step down. Is this policy lawful under the Equality Act 2010?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because direct discrimination can never be justified.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because age is the only protected characteristic where direct discrimination can be objectively justified.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because the SRA requires firms to have succession plans.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because the policy should have a "grandfather clause" for existing partners.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, because retirement ages are exempt from the Equality Act.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Unlike other protected characteristics (Race, Sex, etc.), s.13(2) Equality Act 2010 allows for direct age discrimination if it is a "proportionate means of achieving a legitimate aim." Succession planning and "inter-generational fairness" have been recognized by courts as legitimate aims.
Why the other options are incorrect:
Option A: Age is the specific exception to the "direct discrimination cannot be justified" rule.
Option C: The SRA requires management, but doesn't mandate age-based removal.
Option D: A grandfather clause isn't a legal requirement for the policy to be...

questions.text: Martha is the COLP (Compliance Officer for Legal Practice) for a firm with 15 employees. She receives the SRA's biennial request to collect and publish diversity data. Martha decides not to do it, arguing that in such a small firm, the data would make it easy to identify individual staff members' religions or sexual orientations, which she believes would breach the GDPR. What is Martha’s regulatory obligation?

options.label: A
options.text: She is correct; GDPR overrides the SRA's request for diversity data in small firms.

options.label: B
options.text: She must collect the data and report it to the SRA, but she should not publish it if it risks identifying individuals.

options.label: C
options.text: She must ignore the SRA request as diversity data is a "voluntary" scheme for firms under 20 people.

options.label: D
options.text: She must publish everything regardless of GDPR because SRA rules take precedence over statutes.

options.label: E
options.text: She must only collect data on gender and age, as these are not "sensitive" under data law.

questions.explanation: Option B is correct. All SRA-regulated firms must collect and report diversity data to the SRA. However, for the publication requirement (making it public on the website), firms must ensure they don't breach data protection laws. If the firm is so small that publishing the data would identify individuals, they should report it to the SRA but may withhold or redact the public version.

questions.text: : Simon, a senior solicitor, frequently makes jokes about the "traditional roles of women" in the office kitchen. He often tells Mary, a trainee, that she shouldn't worry about her exam results because she’ll "just get married and leave anyway." Mary feels deeply uncomfortable and humiliated, but Simon says he is just joking and that Mary is "too sensitive." Does Simon’s conduct constitute harassment under the Equality Act 2010?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because he did not intend to cause offense.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, if the conduct had the purpose or effect of violating Mary’s dignity or creating an intimidating environment.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because "banter" is a recognized defense in employment tribunals.

options.label: D
options.text: Only if Mary formally complained to him in writing first.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because he didn't touch her or threaten her job.

questions.explanation: Option B is correct. Under s.26 Equality Act 2010, harassment occurs if a person engages in unwanted conduct related to a protected characteristic (Sex) which has the purpose or effect of violating dignity or creating an intimidating, hostile, degrading, humiliating or offensive environment. The "effect" is judged both subjectively (how Mary felt) and objectively (whether it was reasonable for her to feel that way). Therefore, A,C,D & E are incorrect.

questions.text: Rebecca gives evidence as a witness for a colleague who is suing the firm for racial discrimination. A month later, Rebecca is denied a bonus that she was clearly entitled to based on her billable hours. Her manager, Stephen, tells her: "We need team players here, not people who testify against the firm." What claim can Rebecca bring under the Equality Act 2010?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct discrimination based on race.

options.label: B
options.text: Indirect discrimination.

options.label: C
options.text: Victimization.

options.label: D
options.text: Harassment.

options.label: E
options.text: No claim, as bonuses are discretionary.

questions.explanation: Option C is correct. Under s.27 Equality Act 2010, victimization occurs when a person is treated badly (subjected to a detriment) because they have done a "protected act" (such as giving evidence in a discrimination claim).

questions.text: Ruth has severe hay fever during the summer months which makes her eyes swell and gives her headaches. She applies for a job at a law firm but is rejected. She later finds out the partners thought she would "take too much time off in June." Ruth wants to sue for disability discrimination. Does Ruth meet the definition of "disabled" under the Equality Act 2010?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because any medical condition is a disability.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because hay fever is excluded by the Equality Act 2010

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because it has a substantial effect on her ability to work.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because it is not a "permanent" condition (it only happens in summer).

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, provided she has a doctor's note.

questions.explanation: Option B is correct. Under the Equality Act 2010 (Guidance on the Definition of Disability), certain conditions are excluded. Hay fever is specifically listed as an excluded condition unless it aggravates another underlying disability.

questions.text: Timothy is a junior solicitor. He discovers that his supervisor, Philip, has been overcharging a client by £500 every month for "administrative fees" that do not exist. Timothy brings this to the attention of the Managing Partner, Isaac, who tells Timothy to "forget about it" because Philip brings in a lot of revenue. What is Timothy’s overriding obligation?

options.label: A
options.text: To follow the instructions of Isaac, as the Managing Partner.

options.label: B
options.text: To remain silent to protect his career prospects within the firm.

options.label: C
options.text: To report the matter to the SRA

options.label: D
options.text: To call the client and tell them to find another firm.

options.label: E
options.text: To write a letter to the Law Society for advice.

questions.explanation: See course materials.

questions.text: Gabriel is acting for Judith, an 85-year-old woman, in the sale of her house. Judith’s son, Samuel, is present at every meeting and speaks for her. Samuel wants the proceeds of the sale to be paid into his own bank account. Judith seems confused but nods when Samuel looks at her. What is Gabriel’s overriding legal obligation?

options.label: A
options.text: To follow the instructions of the son, as he is clearly the "caregiver."

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure the money goes where the son wants to save the client the stress of banking.

options.label: C
options.text: To see Judith alone to ensure she is not under undue influence and has the mental capacity to make the decision.

options.label: D
options.text: To refuse to act for anyone over the age of 80 to avoid risk.

options.label: E
options.text: To report the son to the police immediately.

questions.explanation: Option C is correct. A solicitor’s duty to act in the best interests of the client includes protecting them from undue influence. A solicitor must satisfy themselves that instructions are given freely, which usually requires seeing the client without family members present.

questions.text: "Green & Co" is a law firm located in a Grade II listed building with steep stone steps at the entrance and no lift. They specialize in "Wills and Probate." Mr. Thompson, who uses a wheelchair, calls to book an appointment. The receptionist tells him: "I'm sorry, we don't have a ramp and our office is on the second floor. You'll have to find a different firm that has modern facilities." The firm argues that as a small business, they cannot afford to install a lift in a protected historical building. Has the firm breached its obligations under the Equality Act 2010 and SRA Principles?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the Equality Act does not require small firms to make "unreasonable" structural changes to listed buildings.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because the firm has a duty to make reasonable adjustments.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the duty to make adjustments only arises once a client has signed a formal letter of engagement.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if Mr. Thompson offers to pay the extra costs associated with a home visit or a ground-floor meeting.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because "Wills and Probate" is not a public service, so the Equality Act doesn't apply.

questions.explanation:
The duty to make reasonable adjustments is anticipatory. Even if the building can't be changed (structural), the firm must provide "auxiliary services." Offering a home visit or meeting in an accessible local café would be a "reasonable adjustment."
Incorrect Options:
A: While a lift might be unreasonable, doing "nothing" is a breach.
C: The duty applies to "prospective" clients as well as current ones.
D: The law strictly forbids service providers from charging disabled people for the cost of making adjustments.
E: Private law firms are "service providers" and are fully covered by the Act.

questions.text: Thomas, a senior partner, repeatedly makes comments about the "attractiveness" of a junior trainee, Sarah, in front of other staff. He also sends her several late-night "unprofessional" text messages suggesting they go for drinks alone. Sarah complains to the firm's HR department. The firm argues that Thomas was acting on his own time and that his comments were intended as "compliments," and therefore the firm is not responsible for his "private" behavior. Which of the following is correct regarding the firm's liability?

options.label: A
options.text: The firm is not liable because the comments were not intended to be offensive (lack of "subjective intent").

options.label: B
options.text: Only Thomas is liable because his actions were "outside the course of his employment."

options.label: C
options.text: The firm is vicariously liable for the harassment unless it can show it took all reasonable steps to prevent such conduct.

options.label: D
options.text: Sarah cannot claim harassment unless she can prove that she suffered a clinical psychiatric injury.

options.label: E
options.text: The SRA cannot take action against the firm because harassment is an employment tribunal matter, not a regulatory one.

questions.explanation:
Under the Equality Act, an employer is liable for acts of harassment committed by employees "in the course of employment." This includes work-related social interactions. The only defense is the "all reasonable steps" defense (e.g., having clear policies, training, and enforcement).
Incorrect Options:
A: Harassment is defined by the effect on the victim and whether it was reasonable for them to feel that way; intent is not required.
B: Senior partners acting in the office or via work contacts are generally within the "course of employment."
D: Harassment covers "violating dignity" or creating ...

questions.text: Lucas is a high-performing associate applying for a promotion to Partner. During the interview, he mentions that his young son has recently been diagnosed with severe autism and that he (Lucas) will need to leave promptly at 5:00 PM twice a week to take his son to therapy. The promotion board decides not to promote Lucas, stating in their private notes: "Lucas is great, but his son's condition will make him unreliable in the long run. We need partners who are 100% focused on the firm." Lucas is not disabled himself. Does Lucas have a valid claim under the Equality Act 2010?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because Lucas himself does not possess a protected characteristic.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, this is direct discrimination by association

options.label: C
options.text: No, because "being a parent" is not a protected characteristic under the Act.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if he can prove that a female employee with a disabled child would have been promoted (an "Indirect Sex Discrimination" claim).

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the firm’s decision was based on "unreliability," which is a legitimate business reason.

questions.explanation:
Associative Discrimination occurs when a person is treated less favorably because of their relationship with someone who has a protected characteristic (in this case, his son's disability).
Incorrect Options:
A: The Act protects people "associated" with those who have protected characteristics in cases of direct discrimination and harassment.
C: While "parent" isn't a characteristic, "disability" is, and the association with it is what triggers the protection.
E: The "unreliability" was an assumption based directly on the child's disability, making it discriminatory.
C. Money laundering

questions.text: : Grace, a trainee solicitor, is working on a conveyancing matter for Daniel. She notices that the purchase funds are coming from a high-risk jurisdiction and Daniel cannot provide a clear source of wealth. What is the correct procedure for Grace to follow?

options.label: A
options.text: Submit a Suspicious Activity Report (SAR) directly to the National Crime Agency (NCA) via their online portal.

options.label: B
options.text: Make an internal disclosure to the firm’s Money Laundering Reporting Officer (MLRO) as soon as practicable.

options.label: C
options.text: Confront Daniel and ask him to explain the source of funds before taking any further steps.

options.label: D
options.text: Refuse to act and return the funds to Daniel immediately.

options.label: E
options.text: Report the matter to the Solicitors Regulation Authority (SRA) first.

questions.explanation:
Under POCA, employees in the regulated sector satisfy their legal obligation by reporting to their firm's nominated officer (the MLRO).
Incorrect Options: A is wrong because only the MLRO (or a sole practitioner) typically reports to the NCA. C and D risk "tipping off" or facilitating a money laundering offence. E is wrong; the NCA is the primary body for reporting suspicion of money laundering.

questions.text: : Hannah is acting for Samuel, who wants to buy a £2m property in London. Samuel is a 21-year-old student with no visible income, and the money has arrived in the client account from a third-party company in Panama. Hannah isn't sure if it's criminal property but feels uneasy. What is the legal threshold for "suspicion" under POCA 2002?

options.label: A
options.text: Certainty that the property is the proceeds of crime.

options.label: B
options.text: Beyond reasonable doubt that a crime has been committed.

options.label: C
options.text: A possibility which is more than fanciful that the property is the proceeds of crime.

options.label: D
options.text: Strong evidence that the client has a criminal record.

options.label: E
options.text: Any feeling of discomfort, regardless of the facts.

questions.explanation:
Following the case of R v Da Silva, the threshold for "suspicion" is low: it must be a possibility that is "more than fanciful."
Incorrect Options: A and B are too high (criminal standards). D is not required; suspicion relates to the property, not just the person. E is wrong because suspicion must have some subjective basis, even if low.

questions.text: Thomas, a solicitor, knows that his client Peter has made money from illegal drug trafficking. Peter asks Thomas to help him move the cash through the firm’s client account to buy several luxury cars. Thomas complies. Which principal offence has Thomas primarily committed?

options.label: A
options.text: Section 327: Concealing or transferring criminal property.

options.label: B
options.text: Section 330: Failure to disclose.

options.label: C
options.text: Section 333A: Tipping off.

options.label: D
options.text: Section 329: Acquisition, use, or possession.

options.label: E
options.text: Section 328: Arrangements.

questions.explanation:
Section 327 targets the act of moving or hiding the "criminal property" (the cash). By transferring it through the client account, Thomas is "transferring" or "converting" it.
Incorrect Options: While E (Arrangements) might also apply, A is the more direct fit for the act of moving funds. B and C are "secondary" or "regulated sector" offences, not the principal money laundering act itself.

questions.text: Isaac, a solicitor, receives £10,000 into the firm's office account for his legal fees. He suspects that the client, Luke, paid this from the proceeds of a fraud. What is Isaac’s best defense against a Section 329 charge?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of suspicion.

options.label: B
options.text: He did not "conceal" the money.

options.label: C
options.text: He acquired the property for adequate consideration.

options.label: D
options.text: He is a professional legal adviser.

options.label: E
options.text: The amount was below the "threshold amount."

questions.explanation:
Section 329(2)(c) provides a defense if the person acquired the property for "adequate consideration." This usually includes solicitors receiving money for or on account of their professional costs.
Incorrect Options: A is not a defense if he did suspect. B is irrelevant to s.329. D is not an automatic defense. E (threshold amount) generally refers to bank transactions under s.339A, not professional fees.

questions.text: Abigail, an associate in the corporate department, sees clear evidence of money laundering during a due diligence exercise. She decides not to report it to the MLRO because the deal is small and she doesn't want to "rock the boat." What is the maximum penalty Abigail faces for the offence of failure to Disclose?

options.label: A
options.text: An unlimited fine only.

options.label: B
options.text: 2 years' imprisonment and/or an unlimited fine..

options.label: C
options.text: 5 years' imprisonment and/or an unlimited fine.

options.label: D
options.text: 14 years' imprisonment.

options.label: E
options.text: Striking off the roll only.

questions.explanation:
For the s.330 "Failure to Disclose" offence (the objective test in the regulated sector), the maximum penalty is 5 years' imprisonment.
Incorrect Options: D (14 years) is the maximum for the principal offences (s.327–329). B is the maximum for "tipping off."

questions.text: Matthew is a solicitor who handles a transaction that is a textbook case of money laundering. He later claims he had "no idea" and "didn't suspect a thing" because he was busy. The prosecution argues that any reasonable solicitor in his position would have suspected. Can Matthew be convicted of failure to disclose under s.330?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the prosecution must prove subjective suspicion.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because the test is whether he had reasonable grounds for suspicion.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because busyness is a "reasonable excuse."

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if they prove he was "wilfully blind."

options.label: E
options.text: No, as solicitors are exempt from the objective test.

questions.explanation:
Section 330 applies an objective test for those in the regulated sector. You can be guilty if you should have suspected, even if you didn't.
Incorrect Options: A describes the test for the principal offences, not s.330. C is not a valid excuse. D is a higher standard than "reasonable grounds."

questions.text: Joshua (MLRO) has submitted a SAR to the NCA regarding his client, Paul. Paul calls Joshua asking why his transaction has been delayed for 5 days. Joshua tells Paul: "I can't tell you exactly, but I've had to file a report with the National Crime Agency and we're waiting for consent." What offence has Joshua likely committed?

options.label: A
options.text: Failure to disclose.

options.label: B
options.text: Arrangements.

options.label: C
options.text: Tipping off.

options.label: D
options.text: Prejudicing an investigation.

options.label: E
options.text: None, as he was telling the truth to a client.

questions.explanation:
Under s.333A, it is an offence in the regulated sector to disclose that a SAR has been made if that disclosure is likely to prejudice any investigation.
Incorrect Options: A and B are different offences. D (s.342) is a similar offence but applies where someone knows an investigation is being carried out, whereas tipping off (s.333A) relates specifically to the fact a SAR was filed.

questions.text: Rachel suspects a client's funds are criminal. She wants to proceed with the transaction. Her MLRO submits a SAR to the NCA requesting a "Defence Against Money Laundering" (DAML). When can Rachel safely proceed with the transaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately after the SAR is sent.

options.label: B
options.text: After 7 working days, if the NCA has not responded.

options.label: C
options.text: Only when she receives a written letter of absolute clearance from the police.

options.label: D
options.text: After 31 days, regardless of the NCA's response.

options.label: E
options.text: Never; once a suspicion is formed, the firm must stop acting.

questions.explanation:
The "notice period" is 7 working days. If the NCA does not refuse consent within that time, the firm has "deemed consent" to proceed.
Incorrect Options: A is premature (risk of committing a principal offence). D refers to the "moratorium period" if the NCA does refuse consent.

questions.text: Simon, a solicitor, suspects money laundering but is held at gunpoint by a client and told he will be killed if he makes a report to his MLRO. Simon does not report. Which defence is Simon most likely to rely on?

options.label: A
options.text: Adequate consideration.

options.label: B
options.text: Deemed consent.

options.label: C
options.text: Reasonable excuse.

options.label: D
options.text: Professional legal privilege.

options.label: E
options.text: Lack of suspicion.

questions.explanation:
Sections 327–329 and s.330 include a defence if the person had a "reasonable excuse" for not disclosing. Duress (threat of death or serious injury) is a classic example.
Incorrect Options: A relates to fees. B relates to NCA responses. D (LPP) does not apply if the lawyer is being used to further a crime (the crime/fraud exception).

questions.text: Rebecca is a solicitor. She suspects her client David is laundering money and has made a report. David asks why the deal is stuck. Rebecca says: "I cannot give you the details, but you should be aware of the Money Laundering Regulations and POCA. You might want to consider the legality of your source of funds." Why is Rebecca likely NOT guilty of tipping off?

options.label: A
options.text: She did not mention the word "NCA."

options.label: B
options.text: There is an exception for such disclosures

options.label: C
options.text: She has a "reasonable excuse."

options.label: D
options.text: The client already knew he was a criminal.

options.label: E
options.text: The Law Society said she could.

questions.explanation:
Section 333D(2) provides an exception for professional legal advisers if the disclosure is made to a client to dissuade them from criminal conduct.
Incorrect Options: A is a common misconception; the test is "likelihood to prejudice," not specific keywords.

questions.text: Timothy is acting for a new client, Catherine, who is the daughter of a foreign Minister of Defence. What is Timothy’s mandatory obligation under the MLR 2017?

options.label: A
options.text: Refuse to act because she is a Politically Exposed Person (PEP).

options.label: B
options.text: Carry out Standard Customer Due Diligence (CDD) only.

options.label: C
options.text: Apply Enhanced Due Diligence (EDD) and obtaining senior management approval.

options.label: D
options.text: Report her to the NCA immediately.

options.label: E
options.text: Charge a higher fee to cover the risk.

questions.explanation:
Family members of PEPs are themselves treated as PEPs and require EDD under Regulation 35.
Incorrect Options: A is "de-risking," which is discouraged. B is insufficient. D is only required if there is suspicion of crime, not just because she is a PEP.

questions.text: Elena, a solicitor, is instructed by Mr. Volkov, a wealthy businessman from a country currently on the UK’s "High-Risk Third Countries" list. He wants to buy a luxury flat in London for £5m. He provides a bank statement showing the £5m sitting in a reputable UK bank account, transferred from his personal account in his home country. He explains the money came from "successful business investments over the last decade." What is Elena’s mandatory obligation regarding "Source of Wealth" (SoW) under the MLR 2017?

options.label: A
options.text: Elena has satisfied her duties because the funds are already in a UK bank, which would have conducted its own AML checks.

options.label: B
options.text: Elena must verify the "Source of Funds" only; "Source of Wealth" is only required if the client is a Politically Exposed Person (PEP).

options.label: C
options.text: Elena must take reasonable steps to establish the "Source of Wealth" and the "Source of Funds"

options.label: D
options.text: Elena must refuse to act immediately because it is a criminal offence under POCA to act for any client from a high-risk third country.

options.label: E
options.text: Elena can use "Simplified Due Diligence" (SDD) because the money is held in a UK-regulated credit institution.

questions.explanation:
Regulation 33(1) mandates Enhanced Due Diligence (EDD) whenever a client is established in a high-risk third country. EDD specifically requires the solicitor to obtain information on both the Source of Funds (where the £5m for this deal came from) and the Source of Wealth (how the client accumulated their total net worth over time).
Difference: * Source of Funds: The specific bank statement showing the £5m transfer.
Source of Wealth: Evidence of the "business investments" (e.g., company accounts, dividends, or sale of shares from 10 years ago).

questions.text: Simon, a junior solicitor, is acting for a long-standing client in a divorce. The client mentions in passing that he has "stashed" £50,000 in cash in a safe at his mother’s house to ensure his wife doesn't get her share during the financial settlement. He asks Simon to draft a trust deed that effectively "gifts" this money to his mother retroactively to hide the trail. Simon suspects the money might be the result of tax evasion, but he drafts the deed anyway, thinking he is just following his client's instructions. Which criminal offence is Simon most likely at risk of committing under the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002?

options.label: A
options.text: Section 327: Concealing or disguising criminal property.

options.label: B
options.text: Section 328: Entering into an arrangement facilitates the acquisition of criminal property.

options.label: C
options.text: Section 333A: Tipping off.

options.label: D
options.text: No offence, because the "Ordinary Conduct of Litigation" exception applies to all family law matters.

options.label: E
options.text: Section 329: Acquisition, use, or possession of criminal property.

questions.explanation:
Section 328 POCA is the "professional's offence." It applies when a person becomes "concerned in an arrangement" which they know or suspect facilitates the retention or use of criminal property (tax-evaded money is criminal property). Drafting a deed to hide money is a classic "arrangement."
The "litigation exception" (s.328(3)) only applies to funds used for bona fide legal fees or court-ordered settlements, not for helping a client hide assets from the other party or the state.

questions.text: Firm A is instructed to act for a high-net-worth individual. Firm B (a reputable London law firm) has acted for this client for 10 years and tells Firm A: "We have all the CDD on file; you can just rely on our checks so you don't have to bother the client again." Firm A agrees and proceeds without seeing the client's passport. It later turns out the client was using a forged passport which Firm B failed to spot. What is the regulatory position of Firm A under Regulation 39 of the MLR 2017?

options.label: A
options.text: Firm A is protected because they "relied" on another regulated professional body.

options.label: B
options.text: Firm A is in breach because "Reliance" is only permitted between banks, not between two law firms.

options.label: C
options.text: Firm A is permitted to rely on Firm B, but Firm A remains legally liable for any failure to comply with CDD requirements.

options.label: D
options.text: Firm A should have asked the SRA for a "Reliance Waiver" before proceeding.

options.label: E
options.text: Firm B is solely liable for the fine because they provided the "faulty" due diligence.

questions.explanation:
Regulation 39 allows you to rely on a third party (who is also in the regulated sector) to carry out CDD. However, the ultimate responsibility stays with the firm that is currently acting. If the third party's checks were bad, you are the one who gets fined by the SRA. This is why most firms do not "rely" and instead insist on seeing the documents themselves.
D. Financial services

questions.text: Benjamin, a litigation solicitor, is representing Matthew in a dispute over a commercial contract. During a lunch break, Matthew mentions he has £50,000 to invest and asks Benjamin if he should buy shares in "Quantum Tech PLC." Benjamin, who has no FCA authorization, tells him it’s a "strong buy" based on a news article he read. Benjamin does not charge for this advice and it is the first time he has ever given investment advice. Has Benjamin breached the s.19 General Prohibition?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because "Advising on Investments" is a specified activity and shares are a specified investment.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because he did not charge a fee for the advice

options.label: C
options.text: No, because he only gave the advice once, and one-off acts are never regulated activities.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, because solicitors are always deemed to be acting "by way of business" regardless of the circumstances.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the advice was given during a lunch break and not in a formal office meeting.

questions.explanation:
For an activity to be regulated, it must be carried on "by way of business" (s.22 FSMA). Giving informal, unpaid advice to a client during a social break lacks the business element.
Incorrect Options:
A: While these are specified, the "business" element is missing.
C: There is no "one-off" rule in the statute; frequency is just one factor in the "business" test.
D: The law does not apply a blanket "deeming" rule to solicitors for informal social acts.
E: The location is irrelevant; the nature of the transaction (commercial vs. social/gratuitous) is what matters.

questions.text: : Elizabeth is acting for Samuel in the sale of his family business. Samuel asks whether he should reinvest the proceeds into (i) a portfolio of UK government bonds, (ii) a commercial warehouse to rent out, or (iii) a residential apartment in London. Which of these options involves a "Specified Investment" under the RAO 2001?

options.label: A
options.text: All three options.

options.label: B
options.text: Only the commercial warehouse and the residential apartment.

options.label: C
options.text: Only the UK government bonds.

options.label: D
options.text: Only the residential apartment.

options.label: E
options.text: None of them.

questions.explanation:
Under the Regulated Activities Order (RAO), government bonds (gilts) are specified investments. Physical land/property is NOT a specified investment.
Incorrect Options:
A, B, D: These incorrectly include land as a specified investment.
E: This incorrectly excludes government bonds.

questions.text: Andrew is a probate solicitor. The estate includes a portfolio of shares. Andrew advises the executors to sell the shares and reinvest in a high-interest savings account. The firm is not FCA authorized but is regulated by the SRA. Can Andrew rely on the s.327 exemption?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because advising on shares is a "mainstream" financial activity.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, provided the advice is incidental to his professional probate services.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because solicitors cannot advise on specific shares under any circumstances.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, because probate is a "reserved activity" under the Legal Services Act 2007.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because s.327 only applies to insurance products.

questions.explanation:
Under s.327 FSMA, solicitors can carry out regulated activities if they are incidental to the provision of professional legal services.
Incorrect Options:
A: Probate advice on shares is typically considered incidental, not mainstream.
C: They can, provided they meet s.327 criteria.
D: Reserved activities and FSMA are separate legal regimes; one doesn't exempt the other.
E: s.327 applies to most investments, including shares and debentures.

questions.text: : Sarah refers a client to a broker for a life insurance policy. The broker pays Sarah's firm a commission of £400. Sarah discloses the commission to the client but keeps it to cover the firm’s administrative costs for the referral. Has the firm met the conditions of the s.327 exemption?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because the commission was disclosed to the client.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the solicitor must account to the client for the commission.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, as long as the commission is less than 5% of the total premium.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because solicitors are prohibited from accepting any commissions.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, provided the client didn't ask for the money back.

questions.explanation:
s.327(3) explicitly requires that the firm must account to the client for any pecuniary reward (commission). Disclosure is not enough.
Incorrect Options:
A: Disclosure is a conduct requirement, but accounting for it is a condition of the exemption itself.
C: There is no "percentage" threshold.
D: They can accept it, but they must pass it to the client or offset it against the bill.
E: The obligation to account is proactive; the client doesn't need to request it.

questions.text: Thomas is acting for a corporate client buying 60% of the voting shares in a private company. Thomas advises on the merits of the deal and helps arrange the share transfer. Why is Thomas unlikely to need FCA authorization for this work?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the s.327 exemption always applies to corporate law.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the "Takeover Exclusion" (Article 70 RAO) for deals involving 50% or more of voting shares.

options.label: C
options.text: Because private company shares are not specified investments.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the buyer is a corporate entity and not an individual.

options.label: E
options.text: Because corporate law is not a "regulated activity."

questions.explanation:
Article 70 RAO excludes from regulation any activity (except insurance) relating to the sale of a body corporate where the shares consist of 50% or more of the voting rights.
Incorrect Options:
A: Exclusions (which take the act outside the perimeter) are different from exemptions.
C: All shares in companies (public or private) are specified investments.
D: The status of the buyer is irrelevant to this specific exclusion.
E: Corporate law involves shares; therefore, it is potentially regulated unless an exclusion applies.

questions.text: Hannah, a partner at a law firm, sends a newsletter to 500 clients stating: "Our firm has exclusive access to a new bond issue from GreenEnergy Ltd. We highly recommend you invest now for a 10% return." Is this a breach of s.21 FSMA?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because she is a solicitor and this is professional communication.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because it is an invitation to engage in investment activity

options.label: C
options.text: No, because it was sent to existing clients.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the bond issue is later found to be fraudulent.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because she didn't call them on the phone (cold calling).

questions.explanation:
s.21 restricts Financial Promotions. Unless authorized or approved by an authorized person, you cannot promote investments.
Incorrect Options:
A: Solicitors have no "general" permission to promote investments.
C: The fact they are clients does not provide an automatic exemption from s.21.
D: The breach occurs at the moment of communication, regardless of the bond's performance.
E: Promotion can be in writing, on a website, or via email.

questions.text: Isaac is a conveyancing solicitor. He regularly arranges indemnity insurance for clients where there are title defects. What is the status of Isaac’s firm on the FCA Register?

options.label: A
options.text: It must be listed as a "Fully Authorized Firm."

options.label: B
options.text: It must be listed as an "Exempt Professional Firm" (EPF).

options.label: C
options.text: It should not be on the register at all.

options.label: D
options.text: It must be listed as an "Appointed Representative."

options.label: E
options.text: It must be listed as a "Recognized Body."

questions.explanation:
Firms relying on the s.327 exemption are known as Exempt Professional Firms and must appear on the FCA’s Financial Services Register.
Incorrect Options:
A: EPFs are not "authorized"; they are "exempt."
C: If it's not on the register, it cannot legally carry out insurance distribution.
D: This is a different status for those who work under the umbrella of an authorized firm.
E: This is an SRA term, not an FCA Register category.

questions.text: : Luke, a litigator, is negotiating a settlement for a client. As part of the settlement, the defendant agrees to buy an annuity for the client. Luke advises on the terms of the settlement. Which exclusion is most likely to protect Luke?

options.label: A
options.text: The Takeover Exclusion.

options.label: B
options.text: The Necessary Exclusion

options.label: C
options.text: The s.327 Exemption.

options.label: D
options.text: The Trustee Exclusion.

options.label: E
options.text: The Land Exclusion.

questions.explanation:
Article 67 provides an exclusion where the regulated activity is a "necessary part" of other professional services (like litigation) and no separate fee is charged for that activity.
Incorrect Options:
A: Only applies to company share sales.
C: s.327 is an exemption, not an exclusion (exclusions are better as the act is "not regulated").
D: Only applies to trustees/PRs.
E: There is no "land exclusion" for annuities (which are insurance contracts).

questions.text: Martha is acting for a client who is lending money to his daughter to buy a flat. The loan is secured by a mortgage. The daughter will live in the flat as her main residence. Is this a "Regulated Mortgage Contract" under the RAO?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the lender is an individual and not a bank.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because it is a loan to an individual, secured by land, where at least 40% is used as a dwelling.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because it is a family transaction.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the interest rate is above 5%.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because it's a first-time purchase.

questions.explanation:
The definition of an RMC depends on the nature of the loan and the property (40% dwelling), not the professional status of the lender.
Incorrect Options:
A: Private individuals can enter RMCs, though they may not be "by way of business."
C: Family status does not change the definition of the contract type.
D: Interest rates are irrelevant to the classification.
E: First-time status is irrelevant.

questions.text: Samuel is a solicitor acting for the executor of a large estate. As part of the administration, the executor instructs Samuel to sell a portfolio of 1,000 shares in a London Stock Exchange listed company to raise funds for inheritance tax. Samuel contacts a registered stockbroker, provides the estate's details, and gives the instruction to execute the sale at the current market price. Samuel does not offer any advice on whether it is a good time to sell or which shares to pick. What regulated activity is Samuel performing by executing this instruction?

options.label: A
options.text: Managing Investments.

options.label: B
options.text: Dealing in Investments as Agent.

options.label: C
options.text: Advising on Investments.

options.label: D
options.text: Safeguarding and Administering Investments.

options.label: E
options.text: Arranging deals in investments.

questions.explanation:
Under Article 21 of the RAO, "Dealing as Agent" occurs when you buy, sell, or subscribe for a specified investment on behalf of another person. Samuel is acting as the intermediary to execute a transaction for the executor.
Incorrect Options:
A: Managing requires discretion (deciding what to buy/sell). Here, the executor gave the specific instruction.
D: This involves the physical or legal custody of assets (e.g., holding share certificates in a vault).
E: "Arranging" (Article 25) is a broader category that usually involves bringing two parties together; however, where a person actually execut...

questions.text: Peter is a property solicitor. His client, who has just sold a house for a significant profit, asks if Peter knows anyone who can help him invest the proceeds. Peter provides the client with the business card of an FCA-authorized Independent Financial Adviser (IFA) and says, "I’ve heard they are very good." Peter does not attend the meeting between the client and the IFA, nor does he receive any commission or follow-up on the investment. Why is Peter not considered to be carrying out a regulated activity?

options.label: A
options.text: Because solicitors have a general "right of introduction" under the Legal Services Act 2007.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the "Introducing" Exclusion (Article 33 RAO), which excludes mere introductions to an authorized person.

options.label: C
options.text: Because a business card is considered "marketing material" rather than a legal "communication."

options.label: D
options.text: Because the s.327 FSMA exemption applies automatically to all solicitor-client interactions.

options.label: E
options.text: Because he did not charge a specific "referral fee" for the introduction.

questions.explanation: Article 33 RAO provides a specific exclusion for "mere introductions." For this to apply, the introduction must be made to an authorized person (like the IFA) and the introducer must not take any further steps to assist in the conclusion of the deal.

questions.text: Sarah, a family law solicitor, is representing a client in a high-conflict divorce. The couple has significant joint credit card debt and a personal loan from a high-street bank. As part of the financial settlement negotiations, Sarah advises her client on the merits of consolidating these debts into a new low-interest loan and provides a step-by-step plan on how to liquidate the existing credit card balances. Is Sarah's advice a regulated activity under the FSMA regime?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because family law is a "non-financial" area of practice and is therefore outside the scope of FSMA.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, "Debt Counselling" is a regulated activity under the Regulated Activities Order.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because "Debt Counselling" only applies to commercial debt collection agencies, not professional legal advisers.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the debts in question are currently in "default" or are being handled by a bailiff.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because personal loans and credit cards are not "specified investments" like shares or bonds.

questions.explanation:
Under Article 39E RAO, Debt Counselling (giving advice to a borrower about the liquidation of a debt) is a regulated activity. Even though the debts themselves aren't "investments," they are "specified matters" under the consumer credit elements of the RAO.
Note: While Sarah is performing a regulated activity, she can likely rely on the s.327 exemption (Exempt Professional Firm status) because the advice is incidental to the "main" legal service (the divorce).

questions.text: Rachel is a conveyancing solicitor. She is advising two different clients: Client A is taking out a mortgage to buy a 3-bedroom house where they intend to live. Client B is taking out a mortgage to buy a commercial warehouse which will be used 100% for their logistics business. Which of these transactions involves a "Regulated Mortgage Contract" (a Specified Investment)?

options.label: A
options.text: Both Client A and Client B.

options.label: B
options.text: Neither, as land is never a "specified investment" under FSMA.

options.label: C
options.text: Only Client A’s mortgage.

options.label: D
options.text: Only Client B’s mortgage.

options.label: E
options.text: Only if the mortgage lender is a foreign bank.

questions.explanation:
For a mortgage to be a Regulated Mortgage Contract (RMC), it must meet three criteria: (1) The lender provides credit to an individual/trustee; (2) it is secured by a first legal mortgage on UK land; and (3) at least 40% of the land is used (or intended to be used) as a dwelling by the borrower or a "related person."
Comparison: Client B’s warehouse is 100% commercial (0% dwelling), so it is an unregulated mortgage.

questions.text: Sarah holds a physical share certificate for a client in the firm’s strongroom and collects the dividends on the client’s behalf. What regulated activity is Sarah performing?

options.label: A
options.text: Dealing as Agent.

options.label: B
options.text: Safeguarding and Administering Investments.

options.label: C
options.text: Managing Investments.

options.label: D
options.text: Arranging.

options.label: E
options.text: Advising.

questions.explanation: Holding the assets (safeguarding) and collecting the income (administering) is a combined regulated activity under the RAO.

questions.text: Mark, a partner at a law firm, has a close professional relationship with a high-net-worth client. He identifies a specific "Green Energy" bond that he believes would perfectly suit the client's stated ethical investment goals. Mark sends a single, highly personalized email to this one client, explaining the bond's features and suggesting the client consider investing. The firm is not FCA-authorized. Can Mark rely on an exemption from the s.21 FSMA restriction on "Financial Promotions"?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because s.21 FSMA creates a "strict liability" prohibition on any unauthorized person communicating an invitation to engage in investment activity.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, the "One-off" communication exemption applies to personalized, non-real-time communications.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because the email does not contain a "Buy" button, and therefore does not constitute an "inducement" or "invitation."

options.label: D
options.text: No, because the "One-off" exemption only applies to face-to-face oral conversations, not digital communications like email.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only if the client has already signed a "Sophisticated Investor" statement within the last 12 months.

questions.explanation: The Financial Promotion Order (FPO) contains an exemption for "One-off" communications. To qualify, the promotion must be made to only one recipient (or a small group), be uniquely tailored to them, and not be part of a generalized marketing campaign. This allows solicitors to mention specific investments to individual clients without needing FCA approval for the "advertisement."

questions.text: Luke is the Compliance Officer for Legal Practice (COLP) at an Exempt Professional Firm (EPF). A client submits a formal complaint alleging that the firm failed to disclose a commission they received from an insurer when the firm "arranged" an indemnity policy during a probate matter. Luke needs to ensure the firm follows the correct regulatory procedure for handling this specific financial services complaint. Where must Luke look for the specific rules governing the firm's conduct and disclosure requirements for this activity?

options.label: A
options.text: The FCA Handbook (specifically the PROD and COBS sourcebooks).

options.label: B
options.text: The SRA Financial Services (Conduct of Business) Rules.

options.label: C
options.text: The Legal Ombudsman’s (LeO) Technical Guidance notes only.

options.label: D
options.text: The Financial Ombudsman Service (FOS) Handbook, as they have primary jurisdiction over all insurance-related complaints.

options.label: E
options.text: The SRA Code of Conduct for Firms, as there are no specific rules for financial services.

questions.explanation:
When a firm uses the s.327 FSMA exemption, it moves out of FCA jurisdiction and into the SRA’s "designated professional body" (DPB) regime. The firm must then comply with the SRA Financial Services (COB) Rules, which mandate specific disclosures (e.g., that the firm is not FCA-authorized) and require firms to account for commissions.
Next Step for Luke: He must ensure the client was given the mandatory "Status Disclosure" in writing before the transaction, as required by Rule 2 of the SRA FS (COB) Rules.
E Funding options for legal services:

questions.text: "KiddiSafe" manufactures a popular children's backpack. The design includes a small, removable plastic whistle on the zipper pull. The whistle passes all mandatory toy safety regulations. Two years after the backpack's release, a leading consumer organisation publishes a report identifying that the whistle, if detached, presents a potential choking hazard for children under three. KiddiSafe immediately issues a press release and adds a warning label to new production, but does not recall existing stock. Leo, aged two, is given an old-stock backpack by his aunt. He detaches the whistle and chokes on it, suffering brain damage before his father can intervene. In a claim under the Consumer Protection Act 1987, which of the following is the most significant hurdle for Leo's claim?

options.label: A
options.text: The product complied with all relevant statutory safety regulations at the time of supply.

options.label: B
options.text: The aunt, not Leo, was the person to whom the product was supplied.

options.label: C
options.text: The hazard only became known after the product was put into circulation, invoking the development risks defence.

options.label: D
options.text: The whistle was removable, so the product was not defective when used as intended.

options.label: E
options.text: The choking was caused by Leo's father's failure to supervise adequately.

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. The CPA 1987 provides a defence under s.4(1)(e) (the "development risks" defence) where the state of scientific and technical knowledge at the time the product was supplied was not such that a producer of products of the same description might be expected to have discovered the defect. If the risk was unknown and undiscoverable according to the leading knowledge at the time of supply, this is a potent defence. The subsequent report highlights the defect was a later discovery.
Option A is incorrect. Compliance with regulations is a factor under s.3(2)(a) but is not conclusi...

questions.text: "GourmetGrill" manufactures a high-end electric barbecue. The user manual states in bold: "Always use on a flat, stable, non-flammable surface outdoors. Never use on a wooden deck." David purchases one and ignores the warning, setting it up on his treated pine decking. During a party, the grill tips over due to an uneven deck board. Flaming grease ignites the deck, causing a major fire that destroys David's garden furniture and damages his neighbour's fence. The investigation finds the grill's wheel locks were poorly designed and prone to slipping on smooth surfaces, contributing to the instability. In a claim under the Consumer Protection Act 1987 for the damage to David's garden furniture, which of the following is least relevant to determining if the grill was defective?

options.label: A
options.text: The clear and prominent warnings provided in the manual.

options.label: B
options.text: The expectations of the average consumer of an electric barbecue.

options.label: C
options.text: The compliance of the grill's electrical components with British Standards.

options.label: D
options.text: The fact that David used the grill on a wooden deck in direct contravention of the warning.

options.label: E
options.text: The existence of the design flaw in the wheel locks.

questions.explanation: Option D is the least relevant to the existence of a defect. Under s.3 CPA 1987, the safety persons are entitled to expect is assessed by considering all circumstances, including marketing, instructions, and what might reasonably be foreseen. David's misuse is highly relevant to causation and contributory negligence, but the initial question is whether the product itself, in its design/manufacture, was defective. The core issue is the safety expectation of the product when used as instructed, though foreseeable misuse is also considered. The defect (poor wheel locks) exists independently of Da...

questions.text: "TechGadgets Ltd" imports and sells "PowerMax" branded laptop chargers from a manufacturer in Country X. They apply their own UK compliance sticker and sell them through major retailers. A design flaw in the charger's circuitry causes it to overheat and melt, starting a house fire that destroys a customer's home office equipment, including a rare, antique desk valued at £25,000. The customer sues TechGadgets Ltd under the Consumer Protection Act 1987. Which of the following statements is correct regarding TechGadgets Ltd's potential liability?

options.label: A
options.text: They are not liable as they are not the "producer," only an importer of a finished product.

options.label: B
options.text: They are liable as the own-brander and can be sued as if they were the producer.

options.label: C
options.text: They are only liable if negligence on their part in the importing process can be proven.

options.label: D
options.text: Their liability is limited to damage to property ordinarily intended for private use, which excludes the antique desk.

options.label: E
options.text: They have a complete defence because the defect was a design flaw for which the foreign manufacturer is responsible.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. Under s.1(2)(b) CPA 1987, a "producer" includes any person who, by putting their name on the product or using a trademark, has held themselves out to be the producer. This is the "own-brander" provision. By applying their UK compliance sticker and selling under their brand involvement, TechGadgets Ltd has held itself out as the producer and assumes full producer liability.
Option A is incorrect. An importer into the EU (and under UK law post-Brexit, an importer into the UK) is also expressly defined as a "producer" under s.1(2)(c). So, even without the own-branding, they w...

questions.text: "FreshFare" sells pre-packaged salads. A batch of salad is contaminated with a novel strain of bacterium due to a one-off lapse at the washing facility of their vegetable supplier. The contamination is not detectable by any standard test available to FreshFare. Connor buys and eats the salad, suffering severe food poisoning. He successfully sues FreshFare under the Consumer Protection Act 1987. FreshFare had a contract with their vegetable supplier requiring the supplier to indemnify them for any liability arising from the supplier's negligence. Which of the following is the most accurate consequence of the indemnity clause?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides FreshFare with a defence against Connor's claim, as the fault lies with the supplier.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows FreshFare to seek full reimbursement from the vegetable supplier for the damages paid to Connor.

options.label: C
options.text: It is void as an attempt to exclude liability for personal injury caused by a defective product.

options.label: D
options.text: It means Connor must sue the vegetable supplier directly, as they are the original producer.

options.label: E
options.text: It has no effect because liability under the Act is several and not joint.

questions.explanation:
Option B is correct. An indemnity clause in a commercial contract is an agreement by one party (the supplier) to compensate the other (FreshFare) for loss or liability incurred. It is a separate contractual matter between them. FreshFare is strictly liable to Connor under the CPA 1987. After satisfying that liability, FreshFare can then turn to its supplier under the terms of the indemnity to recover its losses. This is a common risk-allocation tool in supply chains.
Option A is incorrect. The CPA 1987 imposes liability on the producer (which includes FreshFare as the seller of a finished food...

questions.text: "BuildRight" manufactures a premium "EverGrip" industrial adhesive. The adhesive works perfectly when used within a temperature range of 15-25°C, as stated in the technical data sheet. A construction company uses it to fix heavy cladding panels on a building site during a winter period where temperatures consistently fall to 5°C. The adhesive fails to cure properly, and six months later, a panel detaches, crashing onto and destroying a site supervisor's car. The supervisor sues BuildRight. In a common law negligence claim, what is the pivotal issue?

options.label: A
options.text: Whether the adhesive was "defective" within the meaning of the CPA 1987.

options.label: B
options.text: Whether BuildRight owed a duty of care to the supervisor, who did not purchase the product.

options.label: C
options.text: Whether BuildRight took reasonable care in the design and instruction for the product, given its foreseeable uses.

options.label: D
options.text: Whether the construction company's misuse of the product was the sole cause of the damage.

options.label: E
options.text: Whether the damage was to "consumer property."

questions.explanation:
Option C is correct. This is a classic negligence analysis. The manufacturer owes a duty to take reasonable care. Breach is determined by asking if they fell below the standard of the reasonable manufacturer. This encompasses product design, the adequacy of testing to discover its limitations, and the sufficiency of instructions/warnings to guide safe use. The key dispute will be whether using the adhesive in winter conditions was a foreseeable misuse that BuildRight should have guarded against (e.g., through clearer, more prominent warnings or a different formulation).
Option A is incorrect. ...

questions.text: "AutoInnovate" designs a revolutionary driver-assistance system, "SteadyGuide." Before launch, it conducts extensive simulations but, due to time pressures, omits real-world testing in heavy monsoon rain. The system is released. During a torrential downpour, the system's sensors malfunction, causing a car to swerve unexpectedly. The driver, Maya, regains control but collides with a central barrier, writing off her car.
