questions.text: During an argument in a pub, Noah says to Ethan, "I'm going to smash your face in tomorrow." Noah then picks up a beer glass and holds it threateningly but does not move towards Ethan. Ethan, terrified, steps backwards and trips over a bar stool, hitting his head and suffering a concussion. Noah is charged with assault occasioning actual bodily harm. Which of the following is the MOST accurate regarding the actus reus of assault?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no assault because Noah did not apply force.

options.label: B
options.text: There is an assault because Noah's words and holding the glass caused Ethan to apprehend immediate unlawful force.

options.label: C
options.text: There is no assault because the threat was of future violence ("tomorrow").

options.label: D
options.text: There is an assault only if Noah intended to cause Ethan to fear immediate violence.

options.label: E
options.text: There is no assault because Ethan's injury was caused by his own tripping, not by Noah.

questions.explanation:
An assault is committed when a person intentionally or recklessly causes another to apprehend immediate unlawful personal violence. Here, Noah's words ("I'm going to smash your face in tomorrow") alone might not be immediate, but coupled with the threatening act of holding a glass, it could cause an apprehension of immediate violence. The timing is a question of fact; the word "tomorrow" may be negated by the immediate threatening conduct. If Ethan feared that Noah was about to attack him then, there is an assault.
Option A is incorrect. Assault does not require force; it requires apprehension...

questions.text: Kai is driving his car when he is cut off by another driver, Leo. Kai becomes enraged and follows Leo to a car park. Kai gets out of his car, walks up to Leo's car, and punches the driver's side window. The window shatters, and glass cuts Leo's face, causing a deep laceration requiring stitches. Kai is charged with wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm. Which of the following is the most accurate regarding the mens rea for s.18?

options.label: A
options.text: Kai is guilty if he intended to cause some harm to Leo.

options.label: B
options.text: Kai is guilty if he intended to cause grievous bodily harm or was reckless as to whether grievous bodily harm would be caused.

options.label: C
options.text: Kai is guilty only if he intended to cause grievous bodily harm.

options.label: D
options.text: Kai is guilty if he was reckless as to whether some harm would be caused.

options.label: E
options.text: Kai is guilty if he intended to damage the window and grievous bodily harm was a foreseeable consequence.

questions.explanation:
Section 18 requires a specific intent to cause grievous bodily harm or to resist arrest. The mental element is intention (direct or oblique) to cause grievous bodily harm. Recklessness is not sufficient for s.18 (though it is for the underlying act of maliciously wounding/inflicting GBH under s.20). Here, Kai intended to punch the window, not necessarily to cause GBH to Leo. Therefore, he may not have the specific intent for s.18.
Option A is incorrect. Intention to cause some harm is the mens rea for s.20, not s.18.
Option B is incorrect. Recklessness as to GBH is not enough for s.18.

questions.text: During a heated argument, Zara pushes her colleague, Tom. Tom stumbles but does not fall. Unknown to Zara, Tom has a rare spinal condition that makes him extremely vulnerable to even minor force. The push causes a vertebral artery dissection, leading to a stroke. Tom suffers permanent paralysis. Zara is charged with inflicting grievous bodily harm. Which of the following is the MOST accurate regarding Zara's liability?

options.label: A
options.text: Zara is not guilty because she did not intend to cause serious harm.

options.label: B
options.text: Zara is guilty if she intended to cause some harm, and will take Tom as she finds him..

options.label: C
options.text: Zara is not guilty because the harm was unforeseeable.

options.label: D
options.text: Zara is guilty only if she was reckless as to causing grievous bodily harm.

options.label: E
options.text: Zara is not guilty because the push was not inherently dangerous.

questions.explanation:
For s.20, the mens rea is an intention to cause some harm or recklessness as to causing some harm. The defendant does not need to foresee the grievous (really serious) harm that actually occurs. The eggshell skull rule applies: the defendant takes the victim as they find them. If Zara intended to cause some harm (like the push) or was reckless as to causing some harm, she is liable for the full consequences, even if they are unexpectedly severe due to the victim's peculiar vulnerability.

questions.text: Ethan is a bouncer at a nightclub. He refuses entry to a group of men. One of them, Liam, becomes aggressive and shouts, "I'll come back and get you!" Later that night, Liam returns with a baseball bat and approaches Ethan. Ethan, seeing the bat, immediately punches Liam in the face, knocking him unconscious. Liam suffers a fractured jaw. Ethan is charged with assault occasioning actual bodily harm. At trial, Ethan raises self-defence. The prosecution argues that Ethan used excessive force. Which of the following directions to the jury is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Ethan has no defence because he should have retreated or called the police.

options.label: B
options.text: Ethan has a defence only if he believed he was in imminent danger and the force used was reasonable in the circumstances as he believed them to be.

options.label: C
options.text: Ethan has a defence only if his belief in the need for force was reasonable.

options.label: D
options.text: Ethan has a defence because he was acting in prevention of crime.

options.label: E
options.text: Ethan has no defence because he used pre-emptive force.

questions.explanation:
Self-defence requires (1) an honest belief (subjective) that force is necessary for defence, and (2) that the force used is reasonable (objective) in the circumstances as the defendant believed them to be. Ethan must have honestly believed he was about to be attacked with a baseball bat, and the response (a punch) must be proportionate to that perceived threat. The fact that he did not retreat is not fatal; there is no duty to retreat in English law.
Option A is incorrect. There is no duty to retreat; a person may stand their ground and use reasonable force.
Option C is incorrect. The belief d...

questions.text: Aisha and Ben are in a consensual sado-masochistic relationship. During a private session, Aisha, at Ben's request, whips him with a cane, causing bruising and welts that amount to actual bodily harm. Ben enjoys the activity and does not complain. A neighbour hears noises and calls the police. Aisha is charged with assault occasioning actual bodily harm. Which of the following is the MOST accurate statement based on R v Brown [1994]?

options.label: A
options.text: Aisha has a complete defence because Ben consented.

options.label: B
options.text: Aisha has no defence because consent is not valid for the infliction of actual bodily harm in sado-masochistic activities.

options.label: C
options.text: Aisha has a defence only if the activities were in private and for sexual pleasure.

options.label: D
options.text: Aisha has a defence because no permanent injury was caused.

options.label: E
options.text: Aisha has a defence if Ben consented and the harm was not serious.

questions.explanation:
In R v Brown, the House of Lords held that consent is not a defence to the infliction of actual bodily harm (or more serious harm) in the context of sado-masochistic activities, as such activities are not in the public interest. There are exceptions for recognised activities like sports, surgery, and tattooing, but sado-masochism is not an exception. Therefore, Aisha would have no defence.
Option A is incorrect. Consent is not a defence to ABH in this context.
Option C is incorrect. The fact that it was in private and for sexual pleasure does not make it lawful; Brown specifically involved pri...

questions.text: Chloe is a police officer. She arrests David for a suspected theft. During the arrest, David resists and tries to run away. Chloe uses a wrist lock to restrain him, causing a minor fracture to David's wrist. David is later found innocent of theft. He sues Chloe for assault occasioning actual bodily harm. Which of the following is the most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Chloe has no defence because the arrest was unlawful (as David was innocent).

options.label: B
options.text: Chloe has a defence if she used reasonable force in the circumstances as she believed them to be.

options.label: C
options.text: Chloe has a defence only if David was actually guilty of theft.

options.label: D
options.text: Chloe has no defence because the force used was excessive.

options.label: E
options.text: Chloe has a defence because police officers have immunity from prosecution.

questions.explanation:
Police officers (and anyone) may use reasonable force to effect a lawful arrest or to prevent crime. Under s.3 Criminal Law Act 1967 and common law, the force must be reasonable in the circumstances as the defendant believed them to be. If Chloe honestly believed she was arresting a suspect and used force that was reasonable to overcome resistance, she has a defence, even if the arrest was later found to be unjustified. The key is the honesty of her belief and the reasonableness of the force.
Option A is incorrect. The lawfulness of the arrest is judged at the time, based on the officer's reas...

questions.text: Ethan is playing a practical joke on his friend, Mia. He hides behind a door and jumps out shouting "Boo!" as she walks by. Mia, who has a heart condition, is so startled that she suffers a heart attack and dies. Ethan is charged with manslaughter. The prosecution's case is based on unlawful act manslaughter, with the underlying offence being assault. Which of the following is the most accurate regarding the assault?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no assault because Ethan did not intend to harm Mia.

options.label: B
options.text: There is an assault because Ethan intentionally caused Mia to apprehend immediate unlawful force.

options.label: C
options.text: There is no assault because the force was not applied.

options.label: D
options.text: There is an assault only if Ethan knew of Mia's heart condition.

options.label: E
options.text: There is no assault because the act was a joke.

questions.explanation:
An assault is the intentional or reckless causing of an apprehension of immediate unlawful force. Ethan intentionally jumped out and shouted, intending to startle Mia. This would likely cause an apprehension of immediate force (being touched or grabbed). The fact that it was a joke does not negate the actus reus or mens rea; it may go to dishonesty or intent to harm, but for assault, the mental element is intention or recklessness as to causing apprehension. Here, he intended to startle, which is essentially causing apprehension.

questions.text: Liam and Ben are engaged in a consensual boxing match at a licensed boxing club. During the match, Liam delivers a punch that is within the rules but with such force that Ben's nose is broken. Ben requires surgery. Liam is charged with assault occasioning actual bodily harm. Which of the following is the most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Liam has a defence of consent because boxing is a lawful sport.

options.label: B
options.text: Liam has no defence because he intended to cause harm.

options.label: C
options.text: Liam has a defence only if the punch was within the rules.

options.label: D
options.text: Liam has a defence because Ben consented to the risks.

options.label: E
options.text: Liam has no defence because the injury was serious.

questions.explanation:
Boxing is a lawful sport where participants consent to the application of force, including force that causes actual bodily harm, provided it is within the rules and spirit of the sport. This is a recognised exception to the rule that consent is not a defence to ABH. Therefore, Liam would have a defence.
Option B is incorrect. In lawful sports, the intent to cause harm within the rules is not criminal.
Option C is incorrect. The defence is not solely dependent on the punch being within the rules; it also depends on the context of a lawful sport.
Option D is incorrect. While true, it is not as p...

questions.text: Zara is walking her dog when the dog suddenly becomes aggressive and attacks a passer-by, Noah. Zara tries to pull the dog away but cannot. She then hits the dog with her lead to make it release Noah. In doing so, she accidentally hits Noah, causing a cut above his eye. Zara is charged with battery. Which of the following is the most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Zara is not guilty because she did not intend to hit Noah.

options.label: B
options.text: Zara is not guilty because she was acting to prevent crime.

options.label: C
options.text: Zara is guilty because she was reckless as to hitting Noah.

options.label: D
options.text: Zara is not guilty if she was acting in self-defence or defence of another.

options.label: E
options.text: Zara is guilty because she used excessive force.

questions.explanation:
Zara was using force to prevent the dog from attacking Noah, which is preventing crime (an offence under the Dangerous Dogs Act or common law assault). She may have a defence under s.3 Criminal Law Act 1967 if the force used was reasonable in the circumstances as she believed them to be. Accidentally hitting Noah while aiming at the dog may be considered reasonable if it was an inevitable consequence of her lawful action. This is similar to the doctrine of transferred malice but in the context of lawful force.
Option A is incorrect. Lack of intent is not a complete defence if she was reckless....

questions.text: Kai is a martial arts instructor. During a training session, he demonstrates a defensive move on his student, Mia. He applies a wrist lock with more force than necessary, causing a sprain. Mia had consented to the training but did not expect such force. Kai is charged with assault occasioning actual bodily harm. Which of the following is the most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Kai has a defence of consent because Mia consented to martial arts training.

options.label: B
options.text: Kai has no defence because he used excessive force beyond what was consented to.

options.label: C
options.text: Kai has a defence if he believed the force was necessary for training.

options.label: D
options.text: Kai has no defence because martial arts is not a recognised exception to the rule against consent to ABH.

options.label: E
options.text: Kai has a defence if the injury was accidental.

questions.explanation:
Consent to martial arts training is valid, but it is limited to the normal risks and force expected in training. If Kai intentionally or recklessly used excessive force beyond what was agreed or normally accepted, he may exceed the scope of consent, and the defence would not apply. The injury (sprain) may be ABH, and if the force was excessive, consent may be vitiated.
Option A is incorrect. Consent is not unlimited; it is to the normal contact of the activity.
Option C is incorrect. His belief may be relevant to mens rea, but if the force was objectively excessive, consent may not cover it.

questions.text: During a protest, a police officer, Ben, is hit on the head by a thrown bottle. He falls to the ground, dazed. Another officer, Chloe, sees a man, Noah, running away from the scene holding a bottle. She shouts, "Stop, police!" Noah continues running. Chloe tackles him to the ground, causing a broken collarbone. It is later discovered that Noah was not the thrower; he was merely running to catch a bus. Noah is charged with assault on an emergency worker, but also counter-sues for assault occasioning actual bodily harm against Chloe. Regarding Chloe's liability, which of the following is the most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Chloe is not liable because she was acting in the course of her duty.

options.label: B
options.text: Chloe is not liable if she honestly believed Noah was the offender and the force used was reasonable in the circumstances as she believed them to be.

options.label: C
options.text: Chloe is liable because Noah was innocent.

options.label: D
options.text: Chloe is not liable because she was preventing crime.

options.label: E
options.text: Chloe is liable because she used excessive force.

questions.explanation:
Police officers may use reasonable force to arrest a suspect or prevent crime. If Chloe honestly believed Noah was the offender (based on seeing him running with a bottle), and the force used (a tackle) was reasonable to apprehend him, she has a defence, even if she was mistaken. The reasonableness of the force is judged based on the circumstances as she believed them to be.
Option A is incorrect. Acting in the course of duty is not a blanket defence; the force must be reasonable.
Option C is incorrect. Mistake as to identity does not necessarily make the force unlawful if the belief was hones...

questions.text: Ethan is diagnosed with a highly contagious and serious disease. He is told by doctors to self-isolate. Ignoring this, he attends a party and knowingly has unprotected sexual intercourse with several partners without disclosing his condition. Two partners contract the disease and suffer serious health consequences. Ethan is charged with inflicting grievous bodily harm. Which of the following is the most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Ethan is not guilty because the partners consented to sexual intercourse.

options.label: B
options.text: Ethan is guilty if he intended to cause serious harm.

options.label: C
options.text: Ethan is guilty if he was reckless as to whether serious harm would be caused.

options.label: D
options.text: Ethan is not guilty because the transmission of disease is not inflicting GBH.

options.label: E
options.text: Ethan is guilty only if he directly assaulted the partners.

questions.explanation:
In R v Dica, it was held that reckless transmission of a serious disease can constitute inflicting grievous bodily harm under s.20. The mens rea is intention or recklessness as to causing some harm (here, the transmission of the disease). Consent to sexual intercourse does not include consent to the risk of infection if the defendant is aware of their condition and does not disclose it. Therefore, Ethan would be guilty if he was reckless (i.e., he foresaw the risk of transmission and went ahead).
Option A is incorrect. Consent to sex is not consent to the risk of infection if the defendant is ...

questions.text: Noah is a bouncer. He ejects a drunk customer, David, from a club. David becomes aggressive and swings a punch at Noah. Noah dodges and then punches David in the stomach, causing internal bleeding. David requires surgery. Noah is charged with wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm. At trial, Noah argues he acted in self-defence. The prosecution argues that the force was excessive because Noah could have restrained David without punching him. Which of the following directions to the jury is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Noah has no defence because he used excessive force.

options.label: B
options.text: Noah has a defence if he honestly believed he was in danger and the force used was reasonable in the circumstances as he believed them to be.

options.label: C
options.text: Noah has a defence only if he retreated first.

options.label: D
options.text: Noah has a defence because he was acting in prevention of crime.

options.label: E
options.text: Noah has no defence because he is a bouncer and should be trained to handle such situations without violence.

questions.explanation:
The law of self-defence applies equally to bouncers. The test is (1) honest belief in the need for force, and (2) that the force used is reasonable in the circumstances as believed. The jury must consider whether Noah's punch was a proportionate response to the threat (a punch from David). The fact that he could have restrained David is relevant to whether the force was reasonable, but it is not determinative. The jury must decide based on the circumstances as Noah believed them to be.
Option A is incorrect. Whether the force was excessive is a question for the jury, not a automatic bar.
Optio...

questions.text: Chloe and Emma are flatmates. They have an argument over chores. Chloe, in a fit of anger, throws a plate at Emma. The plate misses Emma but shatters against the wall. A shard of ceramic flies and cuts Emma's cheek, requiring stitches. Chloe is charged with wounding (s.20 OAPA 1861). Which of the following is the most accurate regarding the actus reus of wounding?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no wounding because the cut was caused indirectly.

options.label: B
options.text: There is wounding if the cut broke the continuity of the whole skin.

options.label: C
options.text: There is no wounding because Chloe did not directly cut Emma.

options.label: D
options.text: There is wounding only if the cut was serious.

options.label: E
options.text: There is wounding if the cut broke the dermis but not the epidermis.

questions.explanation:
Wounding requires a break in the continuity of the whole skin (both epidermis and dermis). The cut from the ceramic shard likely qualifies. The wounding can be caused indirectly (by a thrown object). The seriousness of the cut is not relevant to whether it is a wound; it only needs to break the skin. The mens rea for s.20 is intention or recklessness as to some harm, not specifically wounding.
Option A is incorrect. Wounding can be caused indirectly.
Option C is incorrect. Direct application of force is not required.
Option D is incorrect. The seriousness is not part of the definition of wound...

questions.text: Olivia and Jack are involved in a heated argument in a crowded pub. Jack, who is standing approximately two metres from Olivia, suddenly raises his fist and shouts, "I'm going to knock your head off right now!" He takes one aggressive step forward. Olivia, who is standing near the edge of a raised platform, instinctively flinches and steps backwards to avoid what she believes is an imminent punch. She loses her balance, falls off the platform, and fractures her wrist. Jack never actually moved to strike her and lowered his fist immediately after seeing her fall. Which of the following is the most accurate analysis?

options.label: A
options.text: Jack is not guilty of assault because he did not actually apply force to Olivia.

options.label: B
options.text: Jack is guilty of assault because his words and actions caused Olivia to apprehend immediate unlawful force.

options.label: C
options.text: Jack is not guilty of assault because his threat was conditional and not carried out.

options.label: D
options.text: Jack is guilty of battery because Olivia fell off the platform and fractured her wrist.

options.label: E
options.text: Jack is not guilty of assault because Olivia's reaction was unreasonable.

questions.explanation: The actus reus of assault (technical assault) is causing another person to apprehend the immediate application of unlawful force. The mens rea is intention or subjective recklessness as to causing that apprehension. Jack's aggressive gesture (raised fist) and words ("right now") likely created an apprehension of immediate force in Olivia. The fact that he did not actually strike her is irrelevant to assault, which is complete upon the creation of the apprehension. His intention to cause fear, or recklessness as to whether she would fear force, satisfies the mens rea. Olivia's fall and injury a...

questions.text: At a busy train station, Leo is rushing to catch his train. He bumps heavily into Sarah, a stranger, causing her to drop her suitcase. Leo does not stop or apologise and continues running. Sarah shouts after him, but he is gone. Sarah is unharmed but very shaken. Later, Sarah reports the incident to the police, who identify Leo from CCTV. He is charged with battery. Which of the following is the most accurate analysis of Leo's potential liability?

options.label: A
options.text: Leo is guilty of battery because he intentionally made contact with Sarah.

options.label: B
options.text: Leo is not guilty of battery if the contact was a result of mere recklessness in a crowded place.

options.label: C
options.text: Leo is guilty of battery only if he intended to harm Sarah.

options.label: D
options.text: Leo is not guilty of battery because the contact was incidental to everyday life.

options.label: E
options.text: Leo is not guilty of battery because Sarah suffered no injury.

questions.explanation:
Battery requires the application of unlawful force. In crowded public spaces, there is an implied consent to minor, non-hostile jostling that is an inevitable part of daily life (Collins v Wilcock). For battery to occur, the contact must go beyond this implied licence. Leo's bump, while perhaps careless, is likely within the scope of implied consent in a busy station, unless it was done with hostility or excessive force. The fact that he did not stop may indicate rudeness but does not necessarily transform the contact into a battery.
Option A is incorrect. While the contact was intentional in ...

questions.text: Liam and Ben are involved in a violent altercation outside a nightclub. Liam punches Ben once in the face, causing Ben to fall and hit his head on the kerb. Ben loses consciousness. Liam, fearing the consequences, flees the scene. A passer-by calls an ambulance, but Ben dies in hospital two days later from a severe brain injury. A pathologist confirms that the single punch caused the fatal injury. Liam is charged with murder. At trial, evidence is presented that Liam has a history of explosive anger disorder, which he was managing with medication, but he had not taken it that day. Which of the following is the mosst accurate statement regarding the potential for a partial defence to murder?

options.label: A
options.text: Liam may rely on diminished responsibility because his explosive anger disorder is a recognised medical condition.

options.label: B
options.text: Liam may rely on loss of control if he can show that Ben's conduct caused him to lose his self-control.

options.label: C
options.text: Liam cannot rely on any partial defence because he threw the first punch.

options.label: D
options.text: Liam may rely on diminished responsibility only if his disorder substantially impaired his ability to form a rational judgment or exercise self-control.

options.label: E
options.text: Liam may rely on loss of control if he can show that he feared serious violence from Ben.

questions.explanation: Diminished responsibility under s.2 of the Homicide Act 1957 (as amended) requires an abnormality of mental functioning arising from a recognised medical condition that substantially impairs one's ability to understand the nature of their conduct, form a rational judgment, or exercise self-control. Explosive anger disorder (Intermittent Explosive Disorder) could be a recognised medical condition. However, the defence only succeeds if the abnormality substantially impaired his mental responsibilities. The fact that he had not taken his medication may be relevant but does not automatically estab...

questions.text: Dr. Chen is an anaesthetist in a busy hospital. During a routine operation, he fails to notice that the oxygen supply to his patient, Mr. Adams, has become disconnected due to a faulty valve. The monitoring alarms are sounding, but Dr. Chen is distracted by a conversation with a colleague and dismisses them as false alarms. After 10 minutes, Mr. Adams suffers catastrophic brain damage due to oxygen deprivation and dies. An investigation reveals that the disconnection was obvious and the alarms were functioning correctly. Dr. Chen is charged with gross negligence manslaughter. In directing the jury, the judge should emphasise that for a conviction, the prosecution must prove:

options.label: A
options.text: Dr. Chen intended to cause harm to Mr. Adams.

options.label: B
options.text: Dr. Chen's conduct fell so far below the standard of a reasonable anaesthetist that it was criminal.

options.label: C
options.text: Dr. Chen was subjectively reckless as to the risk of death.

options.label: D
options.text: Dr. Chen owed no duty of care because the equipment was faulty.

options.label: E
options.text: Dr. Chen's distraction was a reasonable response in a busy hospital.

questions.explanation:
Gross negligence manslaughter (R v Adomako) requires: (1) a duty of care, (2) a breach of that duty that causes death, and (3) gross negligence, meaning the breach was so serious as to amount to a criminal act or omission. The test is objective: whether the defendant's conduct fell so far below the standard of a reasonable person (or professional) as to be characterised as gross and criminal. The key is the extreme nature of the negligence, not intention or subjective recklessness.
Option A is incorrect. Intention is not required for gross negligence manslaughter.
Option C is incorrect. Subjec...

questions.text: Kai is a drug dealer. He sells a batch of heroin to a known addict, Noah. Unknown to Kai, the heroin is unusually pure. Noah injects his usual dose and dies from an overdose. Kai is charged with unlawful act manslaughter. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding Kai's liability?

options.label: A
options.text: Kai is guilty because selling heroin is an unlawful act and it caused death.

options.label: B
options.text: Kai is not guilty because Noah voluntarily took the drug.

options.label: C
options.text: Kai is guilty only if he knew the heroin was unusually pure.

options.label: D
options.text: Kai is not guilty because the unlawful act (supplying drugs) is not inherently dangerous.

options.label: E
options.text: Kai is guilty only if he intended to cause harm to Noah.

Which of the following is the most accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Noah is guilty because he made a false representation about the service history, which was dishonest and intended to make a gain.

options.label: B
options.text: Noah is not guilty because he believed the car had been serviced regularly.

options.label: C
options.text: Noah is guilty only if he intended to cause loss to Olivia.

options.label: D
options.text: Noah is not guilty because the car was in good condition.

options.label: E
options.text: Noah is guilty only if Olivia suffered a financial loss.

questions.explanation:
Fraud by false representation requires a false representation, dishonesty, and an intention to make a gain or cause a loss. Noah’s statement about “full service history” is false because he knows the service book is lost. His belief about the car’s condition does not negate the falsity of the representation regarding documentation. If he was dishonest by ordinary standards (Ivey test) and intended to make a gain (the sale), he is guilty.
Option B is incorrect. His belief about the car’s condition does not make the representation about service history true.
Option C is incorrect. Intention to m...

questions.text: Patrick is a trader at a flea market. He sells a painting that he genuinely believes is a replica. He tells a customer, Quinn, “This is a beautiful painting.” Quinn, who is an expert, believes it is an original and buys it for a high price. It turns out to be an original worth ten times the price. Patrick is charged with fraud by false representation. Which of the following is the most accurate application of the Ivey test for dishonesty?

options.label: A
options.text: Patrick is guilty because he made a false representation about the painting being beautiful.

options.label: B
options.text: Patrick is not guilty because he did not know it was an original.

options.label: C
options.text: Patrick is guilty if, by the standards of ordinary decent people, his representation was dishonest given his belief that it was a replica.

options.label: D
options.text: Patrick is not guilty because he did not intend to cause loss to Quinn.

options.label: E
options.text: Patrick is guilty only if he intended to make a gain.

questions.explanation: The Ivey test for dishonesty has two stages: (1) ascertain the defendant’s actual knowledge or belief as to the facts, and (2) determine whether, given that knowledge or belief, the conduct was dishonest by the standards of ordinary decent people. Patrick believed the painting was a replica. If ordinary people would consider it dishonest to sell a painting without disclosing doubts about its authenticity (or to describe it as “beautiful” in a way that implies value), he may be guilty. However, if his statement was merely an opinion and he had no reason to believe it was original, he may not be...

questions.text: Rachel is the manager of a charity. She has authority to approve expenses. She submits an invoice for a training course that she did not attend, claiming the charity’s money. She believes she is entitled to the money because she works hard and is underpaid. She is charged with fraud by abuse of position under s.4 of the Fraud Act 2006. Which of the following is the most accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Rachel is guilty because she submitted a false invoice.

options.label: B
options.text: Rachel is not guilty because she believed she was entitled to the money.

options.label: C
options.text: Rachel is guilty if, by ordinary standards, her act was dishonest given her belief.

options.label: D
options.text: Rachel is not guilty because she was in a position of trust and could approve expenses.

options.label: E
options.text: Rachel is guilty only if the charity suffered a loss.

questions.explanation:
Fraud by abuse of position requires a person in a position of trust, a dishonest abuse of that position, and an intention to gain or cause loss. Rachel’s belief that she is entitled may be relevant to dishonesty under the Ivey test, but it is not a defence if ordinary people would consider her actions dishonest. The jury must determine her actual belief and then assess dishonesty objectively.
Option A is incorrect. Submitting a false invoice is not automatically fraud; dishonesty is required.
Option B is incorrect. Belief in entitlement is not a defence if the conduct is dishonest by ordinary ...

questions.text: Sam is selling his house. He knows that the basement occasionally floods after heavy rain, but he has never had major damage. The law requires sellers to disclose any material defects. Sam does not mention the flooding to the buyer, Tess, because he thinks it is not a big issue. Tess buys the house and later discovers the flooding. Sam is charged with fraud by failure to disclose information under s.3 of the Fraud Act 2006. Which of the following is the most accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Sam is guilty because he failed to disclose a material defect.

options.label: B
options.text: Sam is not guilty because he did not think the flooding was a big issue.

options.label: C
options.text: Sam is guilty only if he intended to cause loss to Tess.

options.label: D
options.text: Sam is not guilty because he did not make a false representation.

options.label: E
options.text: Sam is guilty if he was under a legal duty to disclose, dishonestly failed to disclose, and intended to make a gain.

questions.explanation:
Fraud by failure to disclose requires a legal duty to disclose, a failure to disclose, dishonesty, and an intention to gain or cause loss. Sam had a legal duty to disclose material defects. His belief that it was not a big issue is relevant to dishonesty but does not automatically negate it. The jury must apply the Ivey test to determine if his failure was dishonest by ordinary standards.
Option A is incorrect. Failure to disclose alone is not enough; dishonesty and intent are required.
Option B is incorrect. His personal opinion does not necessarily negate dishonesty.
Option C is incorrect. I...

questions.text: George is a waiter. He overcharges a customer, Hannah, by adding extra items to her bill. He does this because he wants the restaurant to make more money, and he hopes for a bonus. Hannah pays the bill without noticing. George is charged with fraud by false representation. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding “gain”?

options.label: A
options.text: George is guilty because he made a false representation (the bill).

options.label: B
options.text: George is not guilty because he did not intend to gain for himself.

options.label: C
options.text: George is guilty only if Hannah noticed the overcharge.

options.label: D
options.text: George is not guilty because the restaurant gained, not him.

options.label: E
options.text: George is guilty because he intended to cause a gain for another.

questions.explanation:
Fraud requires an intention to make a gain or cause a loss. “Gain” includes gaining for another. George intended the restaurant to gain, which is sufficient. His hope for a bonus is additional motivation but not necessary.
Option A is incorrect. The false representation alone is not enough; dishonesty and intent are required.
Option B is incorrect. Intention to gain for another is sufficient.
Option C is incorrect. The victim’s awareness is irrelevant.
Option D is incorrect. Gain for another is within the offence.

questions.text: Julia works in an office. She takes some office supplies home for her personal use. She believes that her manager would not mind because the supplies are inexpensive and the company is rich. She is charged with fraud by abuse of position. Which of the following is the most accurate application of the Ivey test?

options.label: A
options.text: Julia is guilty because she took supplies without permission.

options.label: B
options.text: Julia is not guilty because she believed her manager would consent.

options.label: C
options.text: Julia is guilty only if the supplies were valuable.

options.label: D
options.text: Julia is not guilty because she did not intend to cause loss.

options.label: E
options.text: Julia is guilty if, by ordinary standards, her conduct was dishonest given her belief.

questions.explanation:
The Ivey test requires ascertaining Julia’s actual belief (that the manager would consent) and then determining whether her conduct was dishonest by the standards of ordinary decent people. If ordinary people would consider it dishonest to take supplies without permission, even with a belief in consent, she may be guilty. The reasonableness of her belief is evidence but not determinative.
Option A is incorrect. Taking without permission is not automatically fraud; dishonesty is required.
Option B is incorrect. Belief in consent is not a defence if the conduct is dishonest by ordinary standards...

questions.text: Mike sets up an online auction account under a false name. He lists a non-existent luxury watch for sale. He receives payment from several buyers but never sends any watches. He is charged with fraud by false representation. Which of the following is the most accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Mike is guilty because he made false representations online regarding the existence of the watch.

options.label: B
options.text: Mike is not guilty because the buyers should have been more careful.

options.label: C
options.text: Mike is guilty only if the buyers suffered financial loss.

options.label: D
options.text: Mike is not guilty because he used a false name, so there was no representation to him.

options.label: E
options.text: Mike is guilty only if he intended to cause loss.

questions.explanation:
Listing a non-existent item for sale is a false representation. The offence is complete when the false representation is made dishonestly with intent to make a gain. The use of a false name does not negate the representation; it may be part of the fraud.
Option B is incorrect. The buyers’ carelessness is not a defence.
Option C is incorrect. Actual loss is not required.
Option D is incorrect. The representation is made to the buyers via the listing; the false name is irrelevant to the representation about the watch.
Option E is incorrect. Intention to make a gain is sufficient

questions.text: Paul is a financial advisor. He advises his client, Queen, to invest in a scheme that he knows is high-risk and likely to fail. He also advises another client, Richard, to invest in the same scheme, but he believes it is a good investment for Richard. The scheme fails, and both lose money. Paul is charged with fraud by false representation in relation to Queen and Richard. Which of the following is the most accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Paul is guilty in relation to Queen but not Richard because he was dishonest only towards Queen.

options.label: B
options.text: Paul is guilty in relation to both because he gave the same advice.

options.label: C
options.text: Paul is not guilty in relation to either because the investments were high-risk.

options.label: D
options.text: Paul is guilty only if the clients suffered loss.

options.label: E
options.text: Paul is guilty in relation to Queen if he was dishonest, and in relation to Richard if he was negligent.

questions.explanation:
Fraud requires dishonesty. For Queen, Paul knew the scheme was likely to fail, so his advice was dishonest. For Richard, he believed it was a good investment, so he was not dishonest. Therefore, he is guilty only for Queen. The same advice given with different states of mind leads to different outcomes.
Option B is incorrect. The advice may be the same, but the mental state differs.
Option C is incorrect. High-risk is not a defence if there is dishonesty.
Option D is incorrect. Loss is not required for fraud.
Option E is incorrect. Negligence is not sufficient for fraud; dishonesty is required

questions.text: Ethan, a financial advisor, convinces his elderly client, Mrs. Green, to invest £50,000 in a "guaranteed high-return" scheme. Ethan knows the scheme is speculative and high-risk, but he tells Mrs. Green it is "as safe as houses" and that he has invested his own mother's money in it. In fact, Ethan receives a 10% commission for every investment he secures. Mrs. Green invests and loses all her money when the scheme collapses. Ethan is charged with fraud by false representation.At trial, Ethan argues that he genuinely believed the scheme was a good investment and that his statements were mere "sales puffery." Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding dishonesty under the Ivey test?

options.label: A
options.text: Ethan is not dishonest because he believed the scheme would succeed.

options.label: B
options.text: Ethan is dishonest if he knew his statements were false or misleading and ordinary decent people would consider his conduct dishonest.

options.label: C
options.text: Ethan is not dishonest because he did not intend to cause loss.

options.label: D
options.text: Ethan is dishonest only if he intended to personally gain from the commission.

options.label: E
options.text: Ethan is not dishonest because the statements were opinions, not facts.

questions.explanation: The Ivey test for dishonesty has two stages: (1) ascertain the defendant's actual knowledge or belief as to the facts, and (2) determine whether, given that knowledge, the conduct was dishonest by the standards of ordinary decent people. Here, if Ethan knew the scheme was high-risk but described it as "as safe as houses," that is a false representation. The second stage asks whether ordinary decent people would consider it dishonest to make such a false representation to secure an investment and commission. His intention to gain (commission) is relevant but not necessary for dishonesty; the fo...

questions.text: Sophia is the director of a charity. She withdraws £10,000 from the charity's bank account to pay for her daughter's wedding, intending to repay the money with interest from her own funds within a month. She does not have authority to use charity funds for personal purposes. Before she can repay, the charity's auditor discovers the shortfall and reports it to the police. Sophia is charged with fraud by abuse of position. Which of the following is the most accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Sophia is not guilty because she intended to repay the money.

options.label: B
options.text: Sophia is guilty because she dishonestly abused her position as a director to make a gain for herself.

options.label: C
options.text: Sophia is not guilty because she did not cause a loss to the charity.

options.label: D
options.text: Sophia is guilty only if the charity suffered a permanent loss.

options.label: E
options.text: Sophia is not guilty because she believed the charity would have consented if asked.

questions.explanation: Fraud by abuse of position requires: (1) occupation of a position where one is expected to safeguard, or not act against, the financial interests of another, (2) dishonestly abusing that position, and (3) intending to make a gain or cause a loss. As a charity director, Sophia is in a position of trust. Using charity funds for personal purposes is an abuse. The dishonesty is judged by the Ivey test: if ordinary decent people would consider it dishonest to take charity money for a wedding, even with intent to repay, she may be found dishonest. The intention to repay is relevant to dishonesty but...

questions.text: Liam, who has a known allergy to nuts, attends a dinner party. The host, unaware of his allergy, serves a dish containing nuts. Liam consumes it and begins to experience a severe anaphylactic reaction. In a state of panic and confusion caused by the reaction, he smashes a valuable antique vase, believing it is a hallucinatory monster attacking him. He is charged with criminal damage. At trial, medical evidence confirms that the allergic reaction caused acute temporary psychosis. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding a potential defence?

options.label: A
options.text: Liam can rely on voluntary intoxication as he voluntarily consumed the food.

options.label: B
options.text: Liam can rely on involuntary intoxication as he was unaware the food contained nuts.

options.label: C
options.text: Liam has no defence because his actions were voluntary.

options.label: D
options.text: Liam can rely on the defence of insanity as he was suffering from a disease of the mind.

options.label: E
options.text: Liam can rely on self-defence as he honestly believed he was being attacked.

questions.explanation:
Involuntary intoxication occurs when a person ingests an intoxicating substance without their knowledge or consent. Here, Liam did not know the food contained nuts (the allergen) and had no reason to expect it would cause an intoxicating effect (psychosis). This constitutes involuntary intoxication. If the intoxication negated the mens rea for criminal damage (intention or recklessness as to damage), he must be acquitted. The temporary psychosis induced by the allergy may mean he lacked the necessary mental state.
Option A is incorrect. This is not voluntary intoxication as he did not knowingl...

questions.text: Chloe is in an abusive relationship with her partner, David. One evening, David tells Chloe he is going to kill her and reaches for a knife. Chloe, in terror, grabs a heavy lamp and hits David repeatedly on the head, killing him. At her murder trial, she raises the partial defence of loss of control. The prosecution argues that her response was disproportionate and that she could have run away. Which of the following jury directions is MOST accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: The defence will fail if the jury finds that Chloe could have safely retreated.

options.label: B
options.text: The defence will succeed only if Chloe's loss of control was sudden.

options.label: C
options.text: The defence may succeed if Chloe lost control due to a fear of serious violence from David, and a person of her sex and age, with a normal degree of tolerance, might have reacted in the same or a similar way.

options.label: D
options.text: The defence will fail because Chloe used a weapon, making her response disproportionate.

options.label: E
options.text: The defence will succeed because David's threat was a qualifying trigger of sexual infidelity.

questions.explanation:
Loss of control under the Coroners and Justice Act 2009 requires: (1) a loss of self-control (which need not be sudden), (2) a qualifying trigger (fear of serious violence is one), and (3) that a person of the defendant's sex and age, with a normal degree of tolerance and self-restraint, might have reacted in the same or a similar way in the defendant's circumstances. The fact that she could have retreated is not a statutory bar. The use of a weapon is a factor for the jury to consider in the objective test, but it is not automatically disqualifying.
Option A is incorrect. There is no requirem...

questions.text: Noah is a soldier suffering from severe Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) after multiple combat tours. One night, during a fireworks display, he experiences a vivid flashback and believes he is back in a combat zone. He sees a neighbour, Mr. Jones, and mistakes him for an enemy combatant. Noah attacks and kills Mr. Jones. He is charged with murder and raises diminished responsibility. Which of the following is the most  accurate statement regarding the defence?

options.label: A
options.text: The defence will fail because PTSD is not a recognised medical condition.

options.label: B
options.text: The defence will succeed because Noah was not in control of his actions.

options.label: C
options.text: The defence may succeed if the PTSD is a recognised medical condition that caused an abnormality of mental functioning which substantially impaired his ability to form a rational judgment

options.label: D
options.text: The defence will fail because the flashback was triggered by an external event (fireworks).

options.label: E
options.text: The defence will succeed only if Noah did not know the nature and quality of his act.

questions.explanation:
Diminished responsibility requires an abnormality of mental functioning arising from a recognised medical condition that substantially impairs one of the defendant's abilities: to understand the nature of his conduct, form a rational judgment, or exercise self-control. PTSD is a recognised medical condition. A flashback causing a delusional belief could substantially impair his ability to form a rational judgment. The trigger (fireworks) does not negate the defence; the focus is on the impairment caused by the condition.
Option A is incorrect. PTSD is a recognised medical condition.
Option B i...

questions.text: Kai is a member of a criminal gang. The gang leader, Vince, threatens to kill Kai's sister if he does not participate in a bank robbery. Under this threat, Kai drives the getaway car. The robbery is botched, and a security guard is shot and killed by Vince. Kai is charged with murder as a secondary party. He seeks to rely on the defence of duress. Which of the following is the most accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Duress is available as a defence to murder for a secondary party.

options.label: B
options.text: Duress is not available for any party to murder.

options.label: C
options.text: Duress is available only if Kai attempted to withdraw from the crime.

options.label: D
options.text: Duress is available if the threat was directed at Kai himself, not his sister.

options.label: E
options.text: Duress is available only if Kai reported the threat to the police.

questions.explanation:
Following R v Howe and affirmed in R v Hasan, duress is not available as a defence to murder, whether as a principal or secondary party. The law expects a person to sacrifice their own life or that of a loved one rather than commit murder. Therefore, Kai cannot plead duress to murder.
Option A is incorrect. Duress is not available for murder for any party.
Option C is incorrect. Withdrawal may affect liability but does not make duress available for murder.
Option D is incorrect. Even if the threat was to himself, duress is not a defence to murder.
Option E is incorrect. Reporting to the police...

questions.text: Sophia is a doctor who has been working 72 hours straight due to a hospital crisis. She is called to administer a drug to a patient. Exhausted, she misreads the dosage and administers ten times the correct amount. The patient dies. Sophia is charged with gross negligence manslaughter. At trial, she argues that her extreme fatigue should be taken into account. Which of the following is the most accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Sophia's fatigue is irrelevant because the test for gross negligence is objective.

options.label: B
options.text: Sophia's fatigue negates the duty of care.

options.label: C
options.text: Sophia's fatigue means she lacked the mens rea for any crime.

options.label: D
options.text: Sophia's fatigue is a complete defence under the principle of necessity.

options.label: E
options.text: Sophia's fatigue should be considered in determining whether her conduct was grossly negligent.

questions.explanation:
The test for gross negligence is objective: whether the defendant's conduct fell so far below the standard of a reasonable person in their position as to amount to a criminal breach. Personal circumstances like fatigue do not lower the standard; the question is what a reasonably competent doctor would have done. However, the context (e.g., a hospital crisis) might be relevant to what is reasonable, but personal exhaustion is not an excuse. The objective standard is applied strictly in professional contexts.
Option B is incorrect. Fatigue does not negate the duty of care; the duty arises from h...

questions.text: Ethan is at a pub where he consumes a large amount of alcohol. He gets into an argument with a stranger, Ben. Ethan, in his drunken state, picks up a bottle and hits Ben over the head, causing a fatal injury. Ethan is charged with murder. At trial, evidence shows that Ethan is normally a peaceful person and would not have acted violently if sober. His defence is that his intoxication prevented him forming the intent to kill or cause grievous bodily harm. Which of the following is the most accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Intoxication is a defence to murder if it negates specific intent.

options.label: B
options.text: Intoxication is never a defence to a crime of violence.

options.label: C
options.text: Intoxication is a defence only if it was involuntary.

options.label: D
options.text: Intoxication can reduce murder to manslaughter if it negates specific intent.

options.label: E
options.text: Intoxication is a complete defence if Ethan did not know what he was doing.

questions.explanation:
Murder is a specific intent crime (requiring intent to kill or cause GBH). Voluntary intoxication can be a defence to specific intent crimes if it prevents the defendant from forming the required intent. If the intoxication negates the specific intent for murder, the defendant may be convicted of the lesser offence of manslaughter (which is a basic intent crime where intoxication is not a defence). This is based on R v Majewski and subsequent cases.
Option A is incorrect. It is not a complete defence; it may reduce the charge to manslaughter.
Option B is incorrect. Intoxication can be relevant...

questions.text: Zara is walking home when she is attacked by a mugger, Leo. Leo pins her against a wall and demands her wallet. Zara manages to break free, grabs a nearby rock, and hits Leo on the head, killing him. She is charged with murder and raises self-defence. CCTV shows that after Zara broke free, Leo was turning to run away when she hit him. Which of the following jury directions is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Self-defence is not available because Leo was retreating.

options.label: B
options.text: Self-defence is available only if Zara honestly believed Leo was still an immediate threat.

options.label: C
options.text: Self-defence is not available because Zara used excessive force.

options.label: D
options.text: Self-defence is available because Zara was defending her property.

options.label: E
options.text: Self-defence is not available because Zara could have run away.

questions.explanation:
Self-defence requires an honest belief that force is necessary for defence, and that the force used is reasonable in the circumstances as believed. If Zara honestly believed that Leo was still an immediate threat (even if he was turning to run, she might have believed he was reaching for a weapon or would regroup), she may have a defence. The reasonableness of her belief is not required; it must be honest. The fact that he was retreating is evidence that the threat may have ended, but it is not determinative if she honestly believed otherwise.
Option A is incorrect. Retreat does not automatica...

questions.text: James is diagnosed with a brain tumour that causes him to experience sudden, uncontrollable violent outbursts. He is aware of the condition but has not yet started treatment. While in a supermarket, he has an outburst and attacks another shopper, causing grievous bodily harm. He is charged with wounding with intent. He raises the defence of insanity. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the defence of insanity?

options.label: A
options.text: Insanity is not available because James knew his actions were wrong.

options.label: B
options.text: Insanity may be available if the tumour is a disease of the mind that caused a defect of reason such that he did not know the nature and quality of his act.

options.label: C
options.text: Insanity is not available because the condition is physical, not mental.

options.label: D
options.text: Insanity is only available for murder, not for s.18.

options.label: E
options.text: Insanity is not available because James was aware of his condition.

questions.explanation:
The M’Naghten Rules define insanity as a defect of reason arising from a disease of the mind, such that the defendant either did not know the nature and quality of their act, or did not know it was wrong. A brain tumour can be considered a "disease of the mind" in legal terms if it affects mental functioning. The key question is whether it caused a defect of reason. The defence is available for any crime, not just murder.
Option A is incorrect. If he did not know the nature and quality of his act, it does not matter that he knew it was wrong; either limb of the M’Naghten Rules can be satisfied...

questions.text: Mia is coerced into smuggling drugs by a gang who have kidnapped her daughter. They threaten to kill her daughter if she does not comply. She is caught at the airport with the drugs and charged with possession with intent to supply. She raises the defence of duress. Which of the following is the most accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Duress is not available because the threat was not immediate.

options.label: B
options.text: Duress is available only if Mia reported the threat to the police before carrying out the crime.

options.label: C
options.text: Duress is available if the threat was of death or serious injury, was imminent, and a person of reasonable firmness would have succumbed.

options.label: D
options.text: Duress is not available for drug offences.

options.label: E
options.text: Duress is available only if the threat was directed at Mia herself.

questions.explanation:
Duress requires: (1) a threat of death or serious injury, (2) the threat must be imminent, (3) the defendant must have no safe avenue of escape, and (4) a person of reasonable firmness, sharing the defendant's characteristics, would have responded in the same way. The threat to her daughter qualifies. The defence is available for most crimes except murder, attempted murder, and some forms of treason.
Option A is incorrect. The threat can be imminent even if the harm will occur later if the defendant fails to comply. The key is that the threat is operating on the defendant's mind at the time of...

questions.text: David suffers from severe depression. He is prescribed medication but stops taking it, feeling it is not helping. During a deep depressive episode, he decides to end his life. He jumps from a bridge but lands on and kills a passer-by, Mr. Clark. David survives and is charged with murder. He raises diminished responsibility. Which of the following is the MOST accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Diminished responsibility is not available because David's act was not directed at Mr. Clark.

options.label: B
options.text: Diminished responsibility may be available if his depression is a recognised medical condition that substantially impaired his mental abilities.

options.label: C
options.text: Diminished responsibility is not available because David intended to kill himself, not Mr. Clark.

options.label: D
options.text: Diminished responsibility is only available if the abnormality of mental functioning is directed at the victim.

options.label: E
options.text: Diminished responsibility will fail because stopping medication was voluntary.

questions.explanation:
Diminished responsibility requires an abnormality of mental functioning arising from a recognised medical condition that substantially impairs the defendant's abilities in relation to the killing. The focus is on the defendant's mental state at the time of the act causing death. If his depression impaired his ability to understand his conduct, form a rational judgment, or exercise self-control in relation to the act that caused death (jumping), it may be relevant, even though the death was unintended. The condition need not be "directed" at the victim.
Option A is incorrect. The defence is con...

questions.text: Ben is at a party where he voluntarily consumes a large amount of alcohol and some illegal drugs. He becomes heavily intoxicated. He gets into a fight and punches another guest, causing a broken nose. He is charged with assault occasioning actual bodily harm. At trial, he argues that he was so intoxicated he did not know what he was doing. Which of the following is the most accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Intoxication is a defence to s.47 because it is a specific intent offence.

options.label: B
options.text: Intoxication is not a defence to s.47 because it is a basic intent offence.

options.label: C
options.text: Intoxication is a defence only if it was involuntary.

options.label: D
options.text: Intoxication can reduce the offence to common assault.

options.label: E
options.text: Intoxication is a complete defence if it negates mens rea.

questions.explanation:
Section 47 is a basic intent offence because the mens rea is the same as for assault or battery (intention or recklessness as to the application of force). For basic intent offences, voluntary intoxication is not a defence because the reckless taking of intoxicants supplies the necessary fault element (R v Majewski). Therefore, Ben cannot rely on his intoxication to negate mens rea.
Option A is incorrect. S.47 is a basic intent offence.
Option C is incorrect. Involuntary intoxication could be a defence, but here it was voluntary.
Option D is incorrect. Intoxication does not reduce the offence;...

questions.text: Sarah is a police officer. She arrests a suspect, Tom, for a violent assault. During the arrest, Tom resists and tries to grab Sarah's baton. Sarah uses a taser to subdue him. Tom has a hidden heart condition and dies from cardiac arrest triggered by the taser. Sarah is charged with manslaughter. She argues she used reasonable force in the course of her duty. Which of the following is the MOST accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Sarah has no defence because the force used was excessive.

options.label: B
options.text: Sarah has a defence if she honestly believed the force was necessary and it was reasonable in the circumstances as she believed them to be.

options.label: C
options.text: Sarah has no defence because she caused death.

options.label: D
options.text: Sarah has a defence only if Tom was actually guilty of the assault.

options.label: E
options.text: Sarah has a defence because police officers have immunity for actions during arrest.

questions.explanation:
Police officers may use reasonable force in the execution of their duty, including to effect an arrest or prevent crime. The test is the same as self-defence: an honest belief that force is necessary, and that the force used is reasonable in the circumstances as believed. The fact that Tom died due to a hidden condition (eggshell skull rule) does not automatically make the force unreasonable. The key is Sarah's honest belief and the proportionality of her response to the threat as she perceived it.
Option A is incorrect. Whether force was excessive is a question of fact based on the circumstan...

questions.text: Noah is diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia. He stops taking his medication. He becomes convinced that his neighbour, Mr. Lee, is a demon who must be destroyed. He attacks and kills Mr. Lee. At his murder trial, he raises the defence of insanity. Medical evidence confirms he did not know that killing Mr. Lee was wrong because he believed he was saving the world. Which of the following is the most accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Insanity is not available because Noah knew the nature and quality of his act (he knew he was killing a human).

options.label: B
options.text: Insanity is available if he did not know that what he was doing was wrong.

options.label: C
options.text: Insanity is not available because his condition was caused by not taking medication.

options.label: D
options.text: Insanity is only available if he did not know the nature and quality of his act.

options.label: E
options.text: Insanity is not available for murder.

questions.explanation:
The M’Naghten Rules provide two limbs: (1) not knowing the nature and quality of the act, or (2) not knowing that the act was wrong. Here, Noah may have known he was killing a human (nature and quality) but, due to his delusion, did not know it was legally or morally wrong. This satisfies the second limb and provides a defence of insanity. The fact that he stopped medication may be relevant but does not bar the defence if the disease of the mind exists.
Option A is incorrect. The second limb can be satisfied even if he knew the nature and quality.
Option C is incorrect. Failure to take medicat...

questions.text: Chloe is driving her car when she is carjacked by an armed man, Vince. Vince orders her at gunpoint to drive him to a location where he plans to commit a robbery. Fearing for her life, Chloe drives as instructed. During the robbery, Vince shoots and kills a security guard. Chloe remains in the car. She is charged with murder as a secondary party. She seeks to rely on duress. Which of the following is the MOST accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Duress is available because Chloe was under a threat of death.

options.label: B
options.text: Duress is not available for murder, even as a secondary party.

options.label: C
options.text: Duress is available only if Chloe attempted to escape.

options.label: D
options.text: Duress is available only for the robbery, not the murder.

options.label: E
options.text: Duress is not available because Chloe voluntarily drove the car.

questions.explanation:
As established in R v Howe and R v Wilson, duress is not a defence to murder, whether as a principal or secondary party. The law expects a person to sacrifice their own life rather than participate in a killing. Therefore, Chloe cannot plead duress to murder, even though she was under duress to participate in the robbery.
Option A is incorrect. While the threat existed, duress is not a defence to murder.
Option C is incorrect. Even if she attempted to escape, duress is not a defence to murder.
Option D is incorrect. Duress might be a defence to the robbery, but not to the murder charge.
Option...

questions.text: Daniel, who is obsessed with his former partner Chloe, decides to kill her. He purchases a lethal poison from an online marketplace, intending to slip it into her drink the next time they meet. He receives the poison in the post, carefully labels it "POISON – DEADLY," and places it in his kitchen cabinet alongside his other cooking ingredients. That evening, Chloe unexpectedly arrives at his flat to collect some belongings. Daniel invites her in, but before he can retrieve the poison, an argument erupts. Chloe storms out, and Daniel never retrieves the poison. He is later arrested when the online seller is investigated. Daniel is charged with attempted murder. Which of the following is the most accurate analysis of whether Daniel's actions amount to an attempt?

options.label: A
options.text: Daniel is guilty of attempted murder because he purchased the poison with the intent to kill.

options.label: B
options.text: Daniel is not guilty of attempted murder because his acts were merely preparatory

options.label: C
options.text: Daniel is guilty of attempted murder because he had the poison in his possession and Chloe was present.

options.label: D
options.text: Daniel is not guilty of attempted murder because he changed his mind when Chloe left.

options.label: E
options.text: Daniel is guilty of attempted murder because he had done everything he intended to do up to that point.

questions.explanation:
The actus reus of attempt requires an act that is "more than merely preparatory" to the commission of the offence. Purchasing and storing the poison are clear acts of preparation. The defendant must have begun to execute the plan, moving from preparation to perpetration. In R v Gullefer, the defendant's act was held to be merely preparatory. Here, Daniel had not taken any step towards administering the poison; he had not retrieved it, mixed it, or offered a drink. He was still in the planning stage when interrupted.
Option A is incorrect. Purchasing with intent is strong evidence of mens rea, ...

questions.text: Maya intends to steal a specific vintage watch from a museum display. She visits the museum several times to study security patterns. On the day she plans to take it, she enters the museum with a specialised glass cutter concealed in her sleeve. She approaches the display case, looks around to ensure no one is watching, and takes the glass cutter out, pressing it against the glass. At that moment, a security guard grabs her arm. She is charged with attempted theft. Which of the following best describes the legal threshold for the actus reus of attempt in this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: Maya is guilty because she had the glass cutter and was at the scene.

options.label: B
options.text: Maya is guilty because she had begun the actual process of breaking into the display case.

options.label: C
options.text: Maya is not guilty because she had not yet broken the glass or taken the watch.

options.label: D
options.text: Maya is not guilty because she was still surveying the scene, which is preparatory.

options.label: E
options.text: Maya is guilty only if she had successfully cut the glass.

questions.explanation:
The courts look for the point where the defendant has embarked on the crime itself. In R v Jones, pointing a loaded gun and pulling the trigger was held to be more than merely preparatory. Here, Maya has moved beyond reconnaissance and preparation. She has the tool in hand and has applied it to the case, beginning the process of breaking in. This is likely to be seen as an executional act, not merely preparatory.
Option A is incorrect. Presence with tools is still preparatory if she hasn't started the criminal act.
Option C is incorrect. The full offence need not be nearly complete; the attemp...

questions.text: Liam intends to defraud his insurance company by setting fire to his own business. He buys petrol and stores it in his garage. He then drives to his business premises late at night, parks nearby, and takes the petrol can from his car. As he walks towards the building, he is stopped by a police patrol who become suspicious. He is charged with attempted arson.. Which of the following is the most accurate direction to the jury?

options.label: A
options.text: You must decide whether Liam had reached the point where he was trying to commit the full offence.

options.label: B
options.text: You must decide whether Liam had done the last act he needed to do before the crime would be committed.

options.label: C
options.text: You must decide whether Liam's acts were more than merely preparatory to the commission of the offence.

options.label: D
options.text: You must decide whether Liam had a settled intention to commit the offence.

options.label: E
options.text: You must decide whether Liam had come very close to committing the full offence.

questions.explanation:
The statutory test under s.1(1) of the Criminal Attempts Act 1981 is whether the defendant did an act which is "more than merely preparatory" to the commission of the offence. This is the precise question for the jury. The other options are either incorrect statements of the law or previous common law tests that have been superseded. The "last act" test (Option B) is not the law; the defendant need not have done the last act.
Option A is incorrect. While this is a paraphrase, the statutory language is more precise and should be used.
Option B is incorrect. This was the old "last act" test from...

questions.text: Noah decides to rob a post office. He buys a balaclava, a toy gun that looks real, and plans the robbery in detail. On the day, he drives to the post office, parks nearby, and puts on the balaclava. He then walks towards the door of the post office, toy gun in his pocket. As he reaches for the door handle, an undercover police officer arrests him. He is charged with attempted robbery. Which of the following acts, if any, is likely to be considered "more than merely preparatory"?

options.label: A
options.text: Buying the balaclava and toy gun.

options.label: B
options.text: Driving to the post office.

options.label: C
options.text: Putting on the balaclava in the car.

options.label: D
options.text: Walking towards the door with the gun.

options.label: E
options.text: Reaching for the door handle.

questions.explanation:
The courts often look for the first act that is directly connected to the commission of the offence. In R v Boyle, approaching the door of a building with intent to burgle was held to be merely preparatory. However, reaching for the door handle could be seen as the first act of entering to commit the robbery, moving into the execution phase. It is a borderline case, but likely the strongest candidate from the options. Putting on the balaclava (C) and walking (D) are still preparatory; reaching for the handle is the point of entry.
Option A is incorrect. This is clearly preparation.
Option B is...

questions.text: Chloe intends to hack into her former employer's computer system to delete critical data. She accesses her home computer, launches specialist hacking software, and begins typing commands to bypass the firewall. She has successfully bypassed the first security layer when her internet connection fails. Frustrated, she gives up. Unknown to her, the company's system had been upgraded that day, and her method would have been ineffective anyway. She is later caught and charged with attempted unauthorised access to computer material with intent to impair operation (an offence under s.3 of the Computer Misuse Act 1990). Regarding the issue of impossibility, which of the following is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Chloe is not guilty because the crime was impossible to complete due to the system upgrade.

options.label: B
options.text: Chloe is guilty if she did an act that was more than merely preparatory, regardless of factual impossibility.

options.label: C
options.text: Chloe is not guilty because she voluntarily abandoned the attempt.

options.label: D
options.text: Chloe is guilty only if her method would have succeeded.

options.label: E
options.text: Chloe is not guilty because she did not actually access the system.

questions.explanation:
Under s.1(2) and (3) of the Criminal Attempts Act 1981, a person can be guilty of attempt even if the offence is impossible to commit, provided they did an act that is more than merely preparatory and they had the intent to commit the offence. Factual impossibility (the system upgrade) is no defence (R v Shivpuri). The key is her intent and her actions.
Option A is incorrect. Factual impossibility is not a defence to attempt.
Option C is incorrect. Voluntary abandonment is not a defence once the actus reus of attempt is complete. Her acts (bypassing the first layer) may have been more than mer...

questions.text: Ben plans to assassinate a politician. He obtains a high-powered rifle and takes up a position in a building opposite where the politician is due to give a speech. He loads the rifle, aims it through a window at the empty podium, and waits. Before the politician arrives, security officers storm the room and arrest him. He is charged with attempted murder. Which of the following best describes the mens rea for attempted murder in this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: Ben must have intended to kill the politician.

options.label: B
options.text: Ben must have intended to cause grievous bodily harm.

options.label: C
options.text: Ben must have been reckless as to whether death would occur.

options.label: D
options.text: Ben must have intended to cause some harm.

options.label: E
options.text: Ben must have known that death was a virtual certainty.

questions.explanation:
For attempted murder, the required mens rea is an intention to kill. This is a specific intent offence. The mens rea for the full offence of murder is intention to kill or cause GBH, but for the attempt, only intention to kill suffices (R v Whybrow). Intention to cause GBH is insufficient for attempted murder.
Option B is incorrect. This is sufficient for murder but not for attempted murder.
Option C is incorrect. Recklessness is never sufficient for attempt.
Option D is incorrect. Intention to cause some harm is the mens rea for offences like s.20 OAPA 1861, not attempted murder.
Option E is ...

questions.text: Zara, intending to steal any valuable jewellery she can find, breaks into a house at night. She searches the bedroom, opening drawers and wardrobes. Unknown to her, the owners have taken all their jewellery to a bank vault that day. She finds nothing of value and leaves empty-handed. She is caught on CCTV and charged with attempted theft. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding her mens rea?

options.label: A
options.text: Zara cannot be guilty of attempted theft because there was nothing to steal.

options.label: B
options.text: Zara is guilty of attempted theft because she had a conditional intent to steal anything valuable she found.

options.label: C
