options.text: Zara is not guilty because she did not find any property to appropriate.

options.label: D
options.text: Zara is guilty only if she intended to steal specific items she believed were in the house.

options.label: E
options.text: Zara is not guilty because she voluntarily left without taking anything.

questions.explanation:
A conditional intent (an intent to steal if there is anything worth stealing) is sufficient for the mens rea of attempted theft (Attorney General's References Nos 1 and 2 of 1979). The fact that there was nothing to steal is factual impossibility, which is no defence. Her acts of breaking in and searching are likely more than merely preparatory.
Option A is incorrect. Factual impossibility is no defence.
Option C is incorrect. Appropriation is not required for attempt; the intent to appropriate suffices.
Option D is incorrect. Specific intent as to particular items is not required; conditional...

questions.text: Kai intends to damage his neighbour's car by slashing the tyres. He takes a knife from his kitchen and walks to the neighbour's driveway. As he is about to bend down to slash the first tyre, he sees a child's toy in the car seat and has a change of heart. He puts the knife away and returns home. The neighbour later sees him on doorbell camera footage and reports him. Kai is charged with attempted criminal damage. Regarding the defence of withdrawal, which of the following is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Kai has a complete defence because he voluntarily abandoned the attempt.

options.label: B
options.text: Kai has no defence because he had already done an act that was more than merely preparatory.

options.label: C
options.text: Kai has a defence only if he abandoned the attempt before any criminal act was committed.

options.label: D
options.text: Kai has a defence because he did not actually damage the car.

options.label: E
options.text: Kai has a defence if his change of heart was due to a moral realisation.

questions.explanation:
Withdrawal is not a defence to attempt once the defendant has done an act that is more than merely preparatory. The offence of attempt is complete at that point. A later change of heart is irrelevant to liability (though may be mitigation in sentencing). The question is whether Kai's acts (taking the knife, walking to the car, about to bend down) were more than merely preparatory. If they were, then attempt is complete and withdrawal is no defence.
Option A is incorrect. Withdrawal is not a defence to a completed attempt.
Option C is incorrect. This is essentially correct as a statement of law...

questions.text: Ethan intends to commit fraud by falsely representing that a painting he owns is a lost masterpiece by a famous artist, hoping to sell it for millions. He creates forged documents of provenance and sends an email to an auction house attaching the documents and stating, "I believe this is a genuine [Artist's] work." Before the auction house can reply, an art expert who had seen the painting earlier informs the police it is a clear fake. Ethan is arrested and charged with attempting to commit fraud by false representation. Which of the following is the most accurate regarding the actus reus?

options.label: A
options.text: Ethan is guilty because he sent the email with forged documents.

options.label: B
options.text: Ethan is not guilty because the auction house did not rely on the representation.

options.label: C
options.text: Ethan is not guilty because the painting was a fake, making the fraud impossible.

options.label: D
options.text: Ethan is guilty only if the auction house had begun the selling process.

options.label: E
options.text: Ethan is not guilty because he only said "I believe," which is not a false representation.

questions.explanation:
The actus reus of attempt requires an act more than merely preparatory. Making the false representation (sending the email with forged documents) is likely the first act of executing the fraud, moving beyond preparation (forging documents) to communication. The full offence of fraud is complete when the false representation is made dishonestly with intent to gain or cause loss. Sending the email is arguably the attempt, as it is the act of making the representation.
Option B is incorrect. Reliance is not necessary for the full offence of fraud, nor for attempt.
Option C is incorrect. Factual i...

questions.text: Liam wants to kill his rival, Tom, by planting a car bomb. He constructs the bomb and attaches it to the underside of Tom's car while it is parked in a public car park. He sets the timer for 6 p.m., when Tom usually drives home. At 5:45 p.m., Liam has a crisis of conscience and returns to the car park to defuse the bomb. As he is crawling under the car, a police officer arrests him. The bomb is safely defused. Liam is charged with attempted murder. Regarding the defence of withdrawal, which of the following is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Liam has a defence because he voluntarily and completely renounced his criminal purpose.

options.label: B
options.text: Liam has no defence because he had already completed the actus reus of attempt when he planted and set the bomb.

options.label: C
options.text: Liam has a defence only if he successfully defused the bomb before arrest.

options.label: D
options.text: Liam has no defence because his return was part of the original plan.

options.label: E
options.text: Liam has a defence because he prevented the harm.

questions.explanation:
Once the defendant has done an act that is more than merely preparatory, the offence of attempt is complete. Withdrawal is not a defence. Planting and setting a live bomb is almost certainly an act more than merely preparatory; it is the execution of the plan. Therefore, his later change of heart does not absolve him of the completed attempt, though it may be mitigation.
Option A is incorrect. Withdrawal is not a defence to a completed attempt.
Option C is incorrect. Successful prevention of harm does not negate the completed attempt.
Option D is incorrect. The reason for return is irrelevant;...

questions.text: Noah attempts to smuggle a bag of white powder, which he believes to be cocaine, through airport security. The powder is actually plain flour, placed there by a friend as a prank. Noah is stopped at security and charged with attempting to possess a Class A drug with intent to supply. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding impossibility?

options.label: A
options.text: Noah is not guilty because the substance was not a controlled drug, so the full offence was impossible.

options.label: B
options.text: Noah is guilty if he did an act that was more than merely preparatory and he intended to possess cocaine.

options.label: C
options.text: Noah is not guilty because he was the victim of a trick.

options.label: D
options.text: Noah is guilty only if he knew the powder was flour.

options.label: E
options.text: Noah is not guilty because he did not have the requisite mens rea for the full offence.

questions.explanation:
Under s.1(2) and (3) of the Criminal Attempts Act 1981, a person can be guilty of attempt even if committing the full offence is impossible due to facts unknown to them, provided they have the intent to commit the offence and do an act that is more than merely preparatory. This is factual impossibility, which is no defence (R v Shivpuri).
Option A is incorrect. Factual impossibility is no defence.
Option C is incorrect. Being tricked does not negate his intent or his actions.
Option D is incorrect. His knowledge that it was flour would negate mens rea, but here he believed it was cocaine.
Opti...

questions.text: Chloe decides to blackmail her employer, Mr. Evans. She writes a letter demanding £50,000, threatening to reveal damaging information. She addresses the envelope, puts a stamp on it, and leaves it on her kitchen table to post the next morning. That night, her flatmate finds the letter, reads it, and calls the police. Chloe is arrested before posting it. She is charged with attempted blackmail. Which of the following acts is most likely to be considered merely preparatory?

options.label: A
options.text: Writing the letter.

options.label: B
options.text: Addressing the envelope.

options.label: C
options.text: Putting a stamp on it.

options.label: D
options.text: Leaving it on the table to post later.

options.label: E
options.text: All of the above are merely preparatory.

questions.explanation:
All the listed acts are preparatory to the commission of blackmail. The full offence of blackmail requires making an unwarranted demand with menaces. The demand is made when it is communicated to the victim. Therefore, any act before communication (such as writing, sealing, stamping) is preparatory. Posting the letter might be more than preparatory, as it sets the communication in motion, but leaving it on the table is not.
Option A is incorrect. Writing is preparation.
Option B is incorrect. Addressing is preparation.
Option C is incorrect. Stamping is preparation.
Option D is incorrect. Leav...

questions.text: Ben intends to commit burglary by entering a house to steal jewellery. He goes to the house at night and finds a window slightly ajar. He opens it wider and climbs halfway through the window, with his upper body inside the house. At that moment, a security light comes on and he panics, pulling himself back out and running away. He is caught by police. He is charged with attempted burglary. Which of the following is the MOST accurate analysis?

options.label: A
options.text: Ben is not guilty because he did not fully enter the building.

options.label: B
options.text: Ben is guilty because he had begun the act of entry, which is part of the actus reus of burglary.

options.label: C
options.text: Ben is not guilty because he changed his mind and withdrew.

options.label: D
options.text: Ben is guilty only if he had intended to steal specific items.

options.label: E
options.text: Ben is not guilty because he was interrupted by the light.

questions.explanation:
In R v Brown (a burglary case), putting a foot through a window was held to be an effective entry for burglary. For attempt, an act that is more than merely preparatory to burglary could include beginning the act of entry. Climbing halfway through the window is likely an act that is more than merely preparatory to burglary, as it is the commencement of the unlawful entry. Withdrawal after this point is not a defence to the completed attempt.
Option A is incorrect. Full entry is not required for attempt; beginning the entry may suffice.
Option C is incorrect. Withdrawal is not a defence once at...

questions.text: Zara attempts to shoot and kill her husband, David, with a rifle. She aims at him from a distance and pulls the trigger. The rifle fails to fire because, unknown to Zara, the safety catch is on. She is immediately apprehended. She is charged with attempted murder.Which of the following is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Zara is not guilty because the gun did not fire.

options.label: B
options.text: Zara is guilty because she did the last act she could do before the crime would be committed.

options.label: C
options.text: Zara is not guilty because the failure of the gun made the murder impossible.

options.label: D
options.text: Zara is guilty only if she knew the safety catch was off.

options.label: E
options.text: Zara is not guilty because she did not cause any harm.

questions.explanation:
In R v Jones, the defendant pointed a sawn-off shotgun at the victim's head and pulled the trigger, but the safety catch was on. This was held to be an act more than merely preparatory. The court stated that he had done the last act he intended to do to commit murder. This is a classic application of the law of attempt: the defendant has embarked on the execution of the crime, and a supervening event (safety catch) does not prevent liability for attempt.
Option A is incorrect. The gun's failure is irrelevant; the attempt is complete upon the act with intent.
Option C is incorrect. Factual impo...

areas.name: Rights of a suspect being detained by the police for questioning:

questions.text: Jonathan, aged 17, is arrested on suspicion of robbery at 10:00 on a Saturday morning. He is taken to the police station, where the custody officer informs him of his rights. Jonathan is scared and confused and asks repeatedly to speak to his mother. The custody officer tells him that he can call a solicitor now, but they cannot contact his mother until after the interview. The officer also notes that Jonathan appears agitated but does not arrange for an appropriate adult. The interview begins at 13:00 without a solicitor or any other adult present. During the interview, Jonathan makes significant admissions. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the lawfulness of the police actions?

options.label: A
options.text: The police acted lawfully because Jonathan was informed of his right to legal advice and chose not to exercise it.

options.label: B
options.text: The police acted unlawfully because of the time the interview commenced

options.label: C
options.text: The police acted unlawfully because they failed to secure an appropriate adult for a juvenile suspect before the interview.

options.label: D
options.text: The police acted lawfully because they allowed Jonathan to speak to a solicitor and his request for his mother was not a right under PACE.

options.label: E
options.text: The police acted unlawfully because they delayed Jonathan’s right to have someone informed without authorisation from an inspector.

questions.explanation: Under PACE Code C paragraph 3.13, upon the arrest of a juvenile, the police must inform a person responsible for their welfare (usually a parent/guardian) as soon as practicable. This is a separate duty from the suspect’s right under s.56 PACE to have someone informed of their arrest. However, the more serious breach here is the failure to secure an appropriate adult. Code C requires an appropriate adult for all juveniles during interviews and key procedures unless delay would involve immediate risk of harm or serious loss/damage to property. The absence of an appropriate adult renders the int...

questions.text: David is arrested for fraud at 14:00 on a Tuesday. He is taken to the police station, where the custody officer authorises his detention. David immediately requests a solicitor. At 15:30, the investigating officer, believing David’s co-conspirator might be alerted if David speaks to a solicitor, seeks authorisation from an inspector to delay David’s right to legal advice under Annex B of Code C. The inspector authorises a delay until 22:00. At 22:15, David is still not provided access to a solicitor. The interview begins at 22:30 without a solicitor present, during which David confesses. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the delay in legal advice?

options.label: A
options.text: The delay was lawful because an inspector authorised it based on a reasonable belief that alerting a co-conspirator would hinder the recovery of property.

options.label: B
options.text: The delay was unlawful because the grounds in Annex B only permit delay to prevent alerting other suspects, not to hinder recovery of property.

options.label: C
options.text: The delay was unlawful because it exceeded the authorised time.

options.label: D
options.text: The delay was lawful because the police can delay legal advice for up to 24 hours in serious fraud cases.

options.label: E
options.text: The delay was unlawful because only a superintendent can authorise delay of legal advice.

questions.explanation:
Under Code C Annex B, a delay in permitting legal advice can only be authorised by an officer of the rank of inspector or above, and only for specific grounds, such as risk of alerting other suspects. However, any delay must be strictly time-limited and must be ended as soon as the hazard no longer exists. If the inspector authorised delay until 22:00, the right should have been provided at or before that time. Continuing to deny access beyond 22:00 without further authorisation is a breach, potentially leading to exclusion of the confession under s.78 PACE.
Option A is incorrect. While alerti...

questions.text: Michael, who is profoundly deaf and communicates using British Sign Language (BSL), is arrested for assault. At the police station, the custody officer provides him with a written notice of rights. Michael indicates he cannot understand it. The police arrange for a family member who knows some BSL to interpret during the caution and interview. The family member is not a qualified interpreter. Michael makes admissions during the interview. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the adequacy of the interpreter arrangements?

options.label: A
options.text: The arrangements were adequate because a family member who knows BSL was present, ensuring communication.

options.label: B
options.text: The arrangements were inadequate because the police should have provided a written translation of the notice of rights.

options.label: C
options.text: The arrangements were inadequate because the police must secure a qualified, independent interpreter for a suspect with a hearing impairment.

options.label: D
options.text: The arrangements were adequate because the suspect’s right to an interpreter was met by having a family member assist.

options.label: E
options.text: The arrangements were inadequate because the custody officer should have read the notice aloud.

questions.explanation:
PACE Code C paragraph 3.12 requires the police to ensure that a suspect who has a hearing or speech impediment is provided with an interpreter capable of interpreting for them. This should be a qualified, independent interpreter, not a family member, to ensure accurate and impartial communication. Using an unqualified family member risks misunderstanding and unfairness, potentially leading to exclusion of evidence under s.78 PACE.
Option A is incorrect. Relying on a family member who is not a qualified interpreter does not meet the requirement for independent, competent interpretation.
Option ...

questions.text: Sophie is arrested for burglary at 09:00 on Wednesday. At the police station, the custody officer authorises detention. She requests legal advice and asks that her partner be informed of her arrest. The custody officer notes her requests. At 12:00, Sophie has still not spoken to a solicitor, and her partner has not been contacted. The custody officer reviews her detention and authorises further detention without charge. At 14:00, Sophie is interviewed without a solicitor present. She is asked about her right to legal advice and says she no longer wants it. She makes admissions. Which of the following is the MOST accurate statement regarding Sophie’s right to legal advice?

options.label: A
options.text: Sophie’s right was not breached because she later waived it voluntarily at 14:00.

options.label: B
options.text: Sophie’s right was breached because she was not provided with legal advice within a reasonable time after her request.

options.label: C
options.text: Sophie’s right was not breached because the custody officer reviewed her detention at 12:00, which is sufficient.

options.label: D
options.text: Sophie’s right was breached because she should have been provided with legal advice before the first review at 12:00.

options.label: E
options.text: Sophie’s right was not breached because she was informed of her right and chose to waive it after a delay.

questions.explanation:
Under s.58 PACE and Code C, the right to legal advice is absolute and should be provided as soon as practicable. A delay without proper authorisation under Annex B is a breach. Here, there was a 5-hour delay without any authorised reason. The fact that she later waived it does not cure the earlier breach. The interview following an unlawful delay may be rendered unfair under s.78 PACE.
Option A is incorrect. A waiver after an undue delay does not retrospectively legitimise the breach.
Option C is incorrect. A detention review does not substitute for providing legal advice.
Option D is incorrec...

questions.text: Thomas, aged 16, is arrested for criminal damage at 20:00 on a Friday. He is taken to the police station, where the custody officer contacts his mother, who lives 50 miles away. She says she cannot come until the next morning. The custody officer decides to proceed with the interview at 22:00 without an appropriate adult, noting that waiting would unreasonably delay the investigation. Thomas’s mother arrives at 10:00 on Saturday. Thomas has been detained overnight. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the detention time limits and appropriate adult provision?

options.label: A
options.text: The police acted lawfully because they contacted the parent and proceeded to avoid unreasonable delay.

options.label: B
options.text: The police acted unlawfully because they should have waited for the appropriate adult, regardless of delay.

options.label: C
options.text: The police acted lawfully because detention of a juvenile can last up to 24 hours without charge, so waiting was unnecessary.

options.label: D
options.text: The police acted unlawfully because an appropriate adult must be present for interview unless delay would involve immediate risk of harm or serious loss.

options.label: E
options.text: The police acted lawfully because Thomas was nearly 17 and could be treated as an adult.

questions.explanation:
Code C requires an appropriate adult for a juvenile during interview unless waiting would involve an immediate risk of harm to persons or serious loss of, or damage to, property. Inconvenience or investigation delay is not sufficient. Here, the offence was criminal damage, unlikely to meet that threshold. The interview without an appropriate adult was likely unlawful.
Option A is incorrect. “Unreasonable delay” is not a valid exception to the appropriate adult requirement.
Option B is incorrect. The rule is not absolute; there is a narrow exception for immediate risk, but it did not apply here...

questions.text: Emma is arrested for suspicion of causing grievous bodily harm with intent at 18:00pm. She is taken to the police station, where she requests legal advice and asks for her sister to be informed. The custody officer authorises detention. At 22:00pm, an inspector reviews the detention and authorises further detention without charge. At 02:00am, Emma is charged and held in custody to appear at court the next morning. At 09:00am, she is taken to court. Which of the following is the MOST accurate statement regarding the review of Emma’s detention?

options.label: A
options.text: The review at 22:00 was too late; the first review must be no later than 6 hours after detention begins.

options.label: B
options.text: The review at 22:00 was lawful; the first review must be no later than 6 hours after detention begins, and subsequent reviews every 9 hours.

options.label: C
options.text: No review was necessary because she was charged within 24 hours.

options.label: D
options.text: The review was unlawful because a superintendent should have conducted it after 24 hours.

options.label: E
options.text: The review was lawful because reviews are required every 9 hours until charge.

questions.explanation:
Under PACE s.40, the first review of detention must be no later than 6 hours after detention begins (here by 24:00, so 22:00 is fine). Subsequent reviews must be at intervals of not more than 9 hours. Emma was charged at 02:00, within 24 hours, so further reviews were not required. The timeline here complies with the law.
Option A is incorrect. The first review was within 6 hours (18:00 to 22:00 is 4 hours).
Option C is incorrect. Reviews are required until charge, regardless of whether charge occurs within 24 hours.
Option D is incorrect. A superintendent is required only for an extension bey...

questions.text: Chloe is arrested for theft at 15:00. She is taken to the station and requests legal advice. The duty solicitor is called but is busy. At 18:00, the custody officer, believing Chloe is likely to harm herself, authorises her detention under the Mental Health Act. At 20:00, a mental health professional assesses her and says she is fit for interview. The police interview her at 21:00 without a solicitor, arguing that the duty solicitor was unavailable and Chloe’ mental health required urgent questioning. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the denial of legal advice?

options.label: A
options.text: Legal advice was properly denied because Chloe’s mental health took priority.

options.label: B
options.text: Legal advice was improperly denied; the police should have waited for the duty solicitor or sought an alternative.

options.label: C
options.text: Legal advice was properly denied because the duty solicitor was unavailable.

options.label: D
options.text: Legal advice was improperly denied because only an inspector can authorise delay on mental health grounds.

options.label: E
options.text: Legal advice was properly denied because questioning was urgent.

questions.explanation:
The right to legal advice under s.58 PACE is fundamental. Unavailability of a particular solicitor does not justify denial; the police should try to secure another solicitor. Mental health concerns do not automatically override the right unless Annex B grounds exist (which they did not here). The breach may lead to exclusion of interview evidence under s.78.
Option A is incorrect. Mental health does not automatically negate the right to legal advice.
Option C is incorrect. Unavailability of one solicitor does not relieve the police of the duty to provide access to legal advice.
Option D is inc...

questions.text: Olivia is arrested for fraud at 10:00. She requests a solicitor and asks for her brother to be informed. The custody officer authorises detention. At 16:00, an inspector reviews detention. Olivia has not yet spoken to a solicitor because the duty solicitor is en route. The inspector authorises further detention. At 17:30, the solicitor arrives. The police interview Olivia at 18:00 with the solicitor present. At 22:00, Olivia is charged. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the detention timeline?

options.label: A
options.text: The review at 16:00 was unlawful because legal advice had not yet been provided.

options.label: B
options.text: The detention was unlawful because Olivia was not charged within 24 hours.

options.label: C
options.text: The review at 16:00 was lawful because it was within 6 hours of the last review.

options.label: D
options.text: The detention was lawful; all reviews occurred correctly, and charge was within 24 hours.

options.label: E
options.text: The detention was unlawful because the interview occurred more than 6 hours after arrest.

questions.explanation:
The first review was at 16:00 (6 hours after detention began at 10:00), complying with s.40 PACE. Charge at 22:00 is within 24 hours. The fact that legal advice was pending did not invalidate the review.
Option A is incorrect. Legal advice does not have to be provided before a review.
Option B is incorrect. Charge within 24 hours is permissible for an indictable offence like fraud.
Option C is incorrect. Reviews are calculated from the start of detention or previous review, not “within 6 hours of last review” arbitrarily. Here, the first review was at 6 hours, which is correct.
Option E is inc...

questions.text: Mark is arrested on suspicion of a street robbery that occurred two days ago. The victim, Mrs. Ellis, saw the suspect clearly for about 30 seconds during daylight and described him to the police as a tall, slim man in his 20s with a distinctive tattoo on his neck. Mark is 6'2", slim, 22 years old, and has a large neck tattoo. When interviewed, Mark admits he was in the area at the time but denies any involvement in the robbery. The investigating officer believes the victim’s description is a strong match and wishes to conduct a formal identification procedure. Mark’s solicitor argues that, because the description is so specific, a formal procedure is unnecessary and potentially prejudicial. In light of PACE Code D, which of the following is the most accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: A formal identification procedure is mandatory because Mark disputes his identification as the robber.

options.label: B
options.text: A formal identification procedure is not required because the suspect’s distinctive features match the description so closely that a procedure would be superfluous.

options.label: C
options.text: A formal identification procedure is not required because Mark admits being in the area, so identity is not in issue.

options.label: D
options.text: A formal identification procedure is mandatory unless the suspect is well known to the witness, which is not the case here.

options.label: E
options.text: A formal identification procedure is at the discretion of the police; they may proceed without one if they have a strong case.

questions.explanation: Under Code D paragraph 3.12, a formal identification procedure must be held if three conditions are met: (1) a suspect is available, (2) the suspect disputes their identification as the person involved in the offence, and (3) an eye-witness has identified the suspect or might be able to do so. Mark disputes being the robber, and the witness saw the offender. The specificity of the description does not remove the requirement; in fact, it makes a fair procedure more important to test the witness’s ability to pick the suspect out from similar individuals. The exception for when the suspect is wel...

questions.text: Sarah is suspected of committing a burglary. The only evidence linking her to the crime is that a neighbour, Mr. Clark, briefly saw a woman leaving the property from about 50 meters away at dusk. Mr. Clark did not see her face clearly but noted she had a particular gait and was wearing a red coat. Sarah owns a similar red coat. The police arrest Sarah and wish to conduct an identification procedure. Sarah’s solicitor argues that the witness’s view was so poor that any identification would be unreliable and a procedure should not be held. Which of the following is the most accurate statement with regards to identification procedure ?

options.label: A
options.text: An identification procedure must be held because the witness might be able to identify the suspect and Sarah disputes involvement.

options.label: B
options.text: An identification procedure is not required because the witness’s view was so poor that it would serve no useful purpose.

options.label: C
options.text: The decision rests with the identification officer, who may decide a procedure is not viable due to the poor quality of the witness’s observation.

options.label: D
options.text: An identification procedure is required, but it should be a confrontation due to the limited details available.

options.label: E
options.text: An identification procedure is not required because the witness did not see the suspect’s face.

questions.explanation: The obligation under Code D 3.12 is triggered if the witness saw the offender and the suspect disputes identification. The reliability of the potential identification is a matter for the trial court to consider, guided by the Turnbull guidelines. It is not for the police to decide that a witness’s view was too poor to justify a procedure. The purpose of the procedure is to test the witness’s ability, however limited. The “no useful purpose” exception in paragraph 3.13 generally relates to situations where identity is not in issue (e.g., suspect known to witness), not to the perceived weakness ...

questions.text: David is suspected of an assault in a crowded pub. The victim, Ben, states he had never seen the assailant before. The police obtain CCTV from the pub which clearly shows the assault. From the CCTV, Ben is able to point out the assailant to the police. David is later arrested. During interview, he admits being in the pub but says he was not involved in any assault. The police propose to conduct a video identification procedure using stills from the CCTV. David’s solicitor objects, arguing that Ben has already identified David from the CCTV, so a formal procedure is unnecessary and would be unfairly repetitive. In accordance with PACE Code D, which of the following is the most accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: A video identification procedure must be held because David disputes being the assailant and was identified from CCTV by a witness.

options.label: B
options.text: No identification procedure is required because the witness has already identified the suspect from CCTV, which is a form of visual media identification.

options.label: C
options.text: The police should proceed directly to a confrontation, as the witness has already seen the suspect on CCTV.

options.label: D
options.text: A procedure is only required if the suspect disputes being the person on the CCTV, which David does not.

options.label: E
options.text: The police have a discretion to hold a procedure, but it is not mandatory as the identification has already taken place.

questions.explanation:
Paragraph 3.12 of Code D states that a procedure must be held if a witness has identified a suspect “by having been shown photographs, or similar images, or by any other means.” Identification from CCTV falls within this. The fact that the witness has already seen the suspect on CCTV does not remove the requirement for a formal, fair procedure (like a video lineup) where the witness is asked to pick the suspect from among similar-looking individuals. This tests recognition rather than confirmation.
Option B is incorrect. Prior identification from CCTV triggers the requirement for a formal proc...

questions.text: Chloe is suspected of a theft from a shop. The store manager, Mr. Atkins, witnessed the theft. Chloe is a regular customer, and Mr. Atkins knows her by name. Upon arrest, Chloe admits taking the item but claims she intended to pay and it was a misunderstanding. The police do not intend to hold an identification procedure, as the witness knows Chloe. Chloe’s solicitor argues that because Chloe admits the physical act but raises a defence of lack of dishonest intent, identity is not in issue and a procedure is unnecessary. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the need for an identification procedure?

options.label: A
options.text: An identification procedure is not required because the witness knows the suspect well.

options.label: B
options.text: An identification procedure is required because Chloe disputes her identification as the person who committed the theft.

options.label: C
options.text: An identification procedure is not required because Chloe admits the physical act, so identity is not disputed.

options.label: D
options.text: An identification procedure is required because the offence is an either-way offence and a procedure is always needed.

options.label: E
options.text: An identification procedure is at the police’s discretion because the witness’s prior knowledge makes a procedure of limited value.

questions.explanation:
Paragraph 3.13 of Code D lists exceptions to the requirement for a formal procedure. One exception is where the suspect is “known to the witness” (Note 3A clarifies this means “known” in the sense of being personally familiar, not just known by name). Here, Mr. Atkins knows Chloe as a regular customer, so she is known to him. Furthermore, identity is not truly in dispute—Chloe admits being the person who took the item. The dispute is over mens rea, not identity.
Option B is incorrect. While Chloe disputes the offence, she does not dispute that she was the person Mr. Atkins saw. Identity is not...

questions.text: During an investigation into a series of street muggings, a witness, Ms. Patel, attends the police station. She is shown a series of twelve photographs on a computer screen (a “VIPER” system) by the identification officer. The images are presented one at a time. Ms. Patel views the first eight images and then states, “I’m sure number three is the man I saw.” The identification officer stops the procedure and records the identification. The suspect (image number three) is later arrested. His solicitor challenges the admissibility of the identification, arguing the procedure was flawed. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the conduct of the procedure?

options.label: A
options.text: The procedure was flawed because the witness was not shown all twelve images before making a decision.

options.label: B
options.text: The procedure was conducted correctly because the witness made a clear positive identification.

options.label: C
options.text: The procedure was flawed because the identification officer should have encouraged the witness to view all images.

options.label: D
options.text: The procedure was correct because the witness can stop at any time once a positive identification is made.

options.label: E
options.text: The procedure was flawed because a video identification should have been used, not a photographic array.

questions.explanation:
Code D Annex E paragraph 8 requires that in a video or photographic identification procedure, the witness must be told that the person they saw may or may not be in the images, and that they should not make a decision until they have seen all the images. Stopping the procedure after a positive identification but before all images are seen undermines this instruction and risks a “relative identification” (picking the person who looks most like the offender from a subset). The witness should be asked to view all images before confirming any identification.
Option B is incorrect. A clear positive...

questions.text: Following a nightclub assault, the suspect is described as a tall, muscular man with a shaved head. The police arrest Liam, who fits the description. The witness, who got a good look at the assailant, is asked to attend a video identification procedure. The identification officer compiles a video parade using images of Liam and eight foils. All nine individuals are tall and muscular with shaved heads. However, Liam has a large, distinctive tribal tattoo on his forearm clearly visible in the video, while none of the foils have any visible tattoos. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the fairness of the procedure?

options.label: A
options.text: The procedure is fair because the foils matched the general description; unique tattoos are not part of “general appearance”.

options.label: B
options.text: The procedure is likely unfair because the distinctive tattoo may draw the witness’s attention solely to the suspect,

options.label: C
options.text: The procedure is fair if the witness’s original description did not mention the tattoo.

options.label: D
options.text: The procedure is fair because the tattoo is not on the suspect’s face, so it does not affect identification.

options.label: E
options.text: The procedure is unfair only if the witness had previously mentioned the tattoo; otherwise, it is acceptable.

questions.explanation:
Code D Annex E requires that the foils should resemble the suspect in age, general appearance, and position in life. A distinctive feature like a large, visible tattoo that is not shared by any foil is likely to make the suspect stand out, rendering the procedure unfair. This breaches the requirement for a fair test of the witness’s ability to recognise the suspect. The fairness is judged objectively, not by whether the witness mentioned the feature.
Option A is incorrect. “General appearance” includes all visible, distinctive features that could influence selection.
Option C is incorrect. The...

questions.text: After a hit-and-run incident, a witness provides a partial vehicle registration. The police trace the car to Ben. Ben is arrested. The witness only saw the driver from behind through the rear window for a split second. The police arrange a group identification. They place Ben, without his knowledge, in a busy town square with an identification officer discreetly observing. The witness is taken past the square in a car and is asked if she can see the driver. She points to Ben. Ben’s solicitor later argues the procedure was unlawful. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the group identification?

options.label: A
options.text: The procedure was lawful as a covert group identification is permitted under Code D.

options.label: B
options.text: The procedure was unlawful because Ben did not consent to taking part.

options.label: C
options.text: The procedure was unlawful because the witness was in a car, which did not allow a proper view.

options.label: D
options.text: The procedure was lawful only if authorised by an inspector, which it was not.

options.label: E
options.text: The procedure was unlawful because group identifications must be overt, with the suspect’s consent.

questions.explanation:
Code D Annex C permits group identifications, which can be either covert or overt. Paragraph 2 of Annex C states that a suspect may be placed informally in a group without their knowledge or consent, provided it is done in a way that ensures the witness gets a fair view. The use of a car for the witness does not inherently breach the Code if it allows a fair view. The key is that the procedure is managed by an identification officer to ensure fairness.
Option B is incorrect. Consent is not required for a covert group identification.
Option C is incorrect. The method of the witness’s viewing is...

questions.text: An armed robbery occurs at a post office. The robber wore a mask, but a customer saw him without the mask for a few seconds in the car park beforehand. The customer gives a description. Two weeks later, police arrest Gary based on intelligence. They wish to hold an identification parade. Gary refuses to take part in any identification procedure. The identification officer informs Gary that if he refuses, the police may use other evidence, including a covertly obtained image of him for a video identification. Gary continues to refuse. The officer proceeds to create a video identification using a recent photograph taken of Gary in custody without his consent. According to Code D, is the officer permitted to do this?

options.label: A
options.text: No, using a custody photograph without consent for a video identification is never permitted.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, if a suspect refuses to cooperate, the police may use any available image to create a video identification.

options.label: C
options.text: No, the police must attempt a group identification first before using a custody image.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if authorised by an officer of the rank of inspector.

options.label: E
options.text: No, the police should proceed directly to a confrontation procedure.

questions.explanation:
Code D Annex E paragraph 4 clearly states that if a suspect refuses to cooperate with video identification, the identification officer has the authority to make arrangements for a video identification using any available image of the suspect (e.g., a custody photograph or a covertly obtained image). The suspect’s consent is not required in these circumstances. The procedure must still be conducted fairly, with appropriate foils.
Option A is incorrect. Code D expressly permits the use of such images when a suspect refuses to cooperate.
Option C is incorrect. There is no mandatory sequence requi...

questions.text: David is arrested for possession of Class A drugs with intent to supply. He is a heroin addict. During the consultation, he is visibly unwell, sweating, and says he is experiencing withdrawal symptoms. He tells his solicitor, “I just need to get out of here. If I say I was holding them for a friend, will they let me go?” The solicitor has received minimal disclosure, only that drugs were found in David’s pocket. The custody record shows he was arrested four hours ago and has not been seen by a healthcare professional. Which of the following is the solicitor’s most pressing concern and appropriate initial action?

options.label: A
options.text: Advise David to give a “no comment” interview immediately to avoid any admissions, as the case is weak.

options.label: B
options.text: Insist on an appropriate adult due to David’s potential mental vulnerability from withdrawal.

options.label: C
options.text: Request an immediate interview to get David’s account on record before his condition worsens.

options.label: D
options.text: Advise David that admitting to holding drugs for a friend is an admission of possession and should not be made.

options.label: E
options.text: Seek a delay in the interview and request a medical assessment to determine if David is fit to be interviewed.

questions.explanation:
Code C paragraph 9.13B of PACE requires the custody officer to call the police surgeon (or another healthcare professional) if a person brought to a station appears to be suffering from a mental disorder or is otherwise in need of medical attention. Withdrawal symptoms can impair a suspect’s ability to understand questions and give rational answers, potentially rendering any interview unreliable and inadmissible under s.76(2)(b) PACE (as in R v Goldenberg). The solicitor’s first duty is to ensure the client is fit to be interviewed. Advising on silence or admissions is secondary.
Option A is i...

questions.text: Thomas is arrested for assault after a fight in a pub. He has been drinking. At the station, he is borderline intoxicated. The custody officer decides he is fit for interview. Thomas tells his solicitor, “He started it, I just pushed him.” Disclosure indicates the victim has a broken nose. Thomas slurs his speech and is agitated. The solicitor is concerned about the admissibility of any interview conducted in this state. Which of the following is the solicitor’s BEST course of action regarding the interview and potential adverse inferences?

options.label: A
options.text: Allow the interview to proceed, as the custody officer has deemed him fit. Advise Thomas to give a prepared statement to avoid complex questioning.

options.label: B
options.text: Request that the interview be delayed until Thomas is sober.

options.label: C
options.text: Advise Thomas to refuse to answer any questions on the grounds that he is too intoxicated to understand them.

options.label: D
options.text: Proceed with the interview but advise Thomas to answer “no comment” to everything; his intoxication will be a reasonable excuse for silence.

options.label: E
options.text: Insist on an appropriate adult due to Thomas’s temporary vulnerability from intoxication.

questions.explanation:
Code C Note for Guidance 11C states that if a person is intoxicated, they should not be interviewed until fit to do so. An interview conducted while a suspect is under the influence of alcohol may be rendered inadmissible under s.76(2)(b) PACE (unreliable) or s.78 (unfair). If the interview is improperly conducted, any subsequent silence might also be protected from adverse inferences because the circumstances (intoxication) make it unreasonable to expect a coherent account. The solicitor should robustly seek a delay.
Option A is incorrect. Proceeding when the client is intoxicated is risky an...

questions.text: Fatima is arrested on suspicion of money laundering. She is a non-native English speaker but conversational. The custody officer provides an interpreter, but Fatima says she understands enough and waives the interpreter to “get things over with.” In consultation, her solicitor explains the caution and the serious nature of the allegations. Fatima seems to misunderstand key legal terms. She says, “If I say nothing, they will think I am guilty, so I will talk.” The solicitor is concerned she does not fully grasp the concept of adverse inferences. What must the solicitor do to ensure Fatima’s right to a fair trial is protected?

options.label: A
options.text: Accept Fatima’s waiver of the interpreter and proceed to advise on interview strategy, as she is conversational in English.

options.label: B
options.text: Insist that an interpreter is present for the consultation and interview.

options.label: C
options.text: Advise her to give a “no comment” interview, as any attempt to explain a complex matter in English risks confusion.

options.label: D
options.text: Explain the concepts more slowly and simply in English until she appears to understand, then proceed.

options.label: E
options.text: Tell the custody officer that Fatima is not fit for interview due to language difficulties.

questions.explanation:
Code C paragraph 3.12 requires that if a suspect has difficulty understanding English, the police must secure an interpreter. The solicitor has a parallel duty to ensure the client understands the legal advice. A waiver given without truly understanding the consequences is not valid. The solicitor should insist on an interpreter for the consultation and interview to ensure informed instructions and a fair process. Failure to do so could render any interview unfair under s.78 PACE.
Option A is incorrect. The solicitor must be satisfied that the waiver is informed and voluntary. Given her misund...

questions.text: James, aged 17, is arrested on suspicion of burglary. He is taken to the police station where the custody officer informs him of his rights. James appears confused and says very little. The custody officer contacts James's estranged father, who lives in another city and says he cannot attend until the next day. An hour later, the investigating officer, keen to proceed, asks the custody officer if an interview can begin. The custody officer authorises the interview to go ahead, noting that a delay would be unreasonable and that James is "streetwise." James is interviewed without a solicitor or any other adult present. During the interview, he makes significant admissions. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the lawfulness of the interview?

options.label: A
options.text: The interview was lawful because the custody officer reasonably decided that waiting for the father would cause unreasonable delay.

options.label: B
options.text: The interview was unlawful because an appropriate adult must be present for the interview of a juvenile.

options.label: C
options.text: The interview was lawful because James appeared streetwise and did not explicitly request an adult.

options.label: D
options.text: The interview was unlawful only if James had specifically asked for his father to be present.

options.label: E
options.text: The interview was lawful because the police attempted to contact a parent, fulfilling their duty.

questions.explanation:
PACE Code C paragraph 11.15 and paragraph 3.13 make it clear that an appropriate adult must be present for the interview of a juvenile. The only exception is if waiting for the adult would involve an immediate risk of harm to persons or serious loss of, or damage to, property. Convenience or avoiding delay in the investigation is not a valid exception. The custody officer's assessment that James was "streetwise" is irrelevant. The interview without an appropriate adult is a serious breach, likely rendering any admissions inadmissible under s.78 PACE.
Option A is incorrect. "Unreasonable delay"...

questions.text: Michael is arrested for fraud. At the police station, he requests a solicitor. The duty solicitor is called but informs the station they will be delayed by two hours due to traffic. The custody officer, after consulting with the investigating officer, decides to commence the interview without the solicitor. The officer tells Michael he has the right to legal advice but it will cause a significant delay, and asks if he is willing to proceed. Michael, who is anxious and wants to "get it over with," agrees. He is cautioned and interviewed, making several damaging admissions. An hour into the interview, the solicitor arrives and is allowed to join. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the conduct of the interview?

options.label: A
options.text: The interview was conducted lawfully because Michael voluntarily waived his right to legal advice after being informed of the delay.

options.label: B
options.text: The interview was unlawful because the police failed to provide Michael with access to a solicitor as soon as practicable.

options.label: C
options.text: The interview was lawful only for the period before the solicitor arrived; the admissions made after the solicitor joined are admissible.

options.label: D
options.text: The interview was unlawful because the police cannot begin an interview once a solicitor has been requested, regardless of delay.

options.label: E
options.text: The interview was lawful because a delay of two hours in a solicitor's arrival is a valid ground to proceed without one under Annex B of Code C.

questions.explanation: The right to legal advice under s.58 PACE is fundamental. Code C paragraph 6.5 states that a person must be allowed to consult a solicitor as soon as practicable. A delay of two hours for a solicitor to arrive is not, in itself, a ground to deny access. The police should have waited. The "waiver" obtained from Michael is highly suspect because it was sought in the context of an implied pressure (the suggestion of delay). The breach is likely to lead to the exclusion of the admissions under s.78 PACE. Annex B allows delay only in very specific, serious circumstances (e.g., risk of alerting othe...

questions.text: Sarah, a suspect with a diagnosed learning disability that affects her understanding of complex questions, is arrested for theft. Her social worker, Ms. Evans, is contacted to act as the appropriate adult. Ms. Evans attends the police station. During the pre-interview consultation, Sarah's solicitor explains the caution and the allegation in simple terms. In the interview, the police officer asks Sarah a series of rapid, compound questions. Sarah becomes distressed and gives inconsistent answers. Ms. Evans remains quiet throughout. Sarah's solicitor intervenes, saying, "My client is becoming distressed and the questions are too complex. Could you rephrase them simply, one at a time?" What is the most accurate assessment of the roles of the solicitor and the appropriate adult in this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: The solicitor's intervention was improper; it is the role of the appropriate adult to safeguard the suspect's welfare and facilitate communication.

options.label: B
options.text: The solicitor's intervention was correct; they have a duty to ensure the interview is conducted fairly and their client can participate effectively.

options.label: C
options.text: The appropriate adult, Ms. Evans, failed in her duty by remaining quiet and should have been the one to object to the questioning.

options.label: D
options.text: Both the solicitor and the appropriate adult failed in their duties; the solicitor should have objected sooner, and the appropriate adult should have intervened.

options.label: E
options.text: The police officer acted properly; it is for the suspect to indicate if they do not understand a question.

questions.explanation:
The defence solicitor's role is multifaceted. They must protect their client's legal interests, which includes ensuring the interview is conducted fairly and that their client can understand and respond to questions. Intervening to request clearer, simpler questioning for a vulnerable client is a core part of their duty. While the appropriate adult also has a role in facilitating communication (Code C paragraph 11.17), the solicitor's duty to ensure a fair process is paramount and they are not precluded from intervening on procedural fairness grounds.
Option A is incorrect. The solicitor has e...

questions.text: David, aged 16, is arrested for criminal damage. His mother is contacted and arrives at the station to act as the appropriate adult. David's mother has a history of being very strict and punitive with David. In the private consultation before the interview, David tells his solicitor he is terrified of what his mother will do if he says anything that sounds like an admission. The solicitor observes that David is reluctant to speak freely in his mother's presence. What is the most appropriate course of action for the solicitor?

options.label: A
options.text: Proceed with the interview with the mother present, as she is the obvious and lawful appropriate adult.

options.label: B
options.text: Inform the custody officer that the mother is not a suitable appropriate adult and request a different appropriate adult.

options.label: C
options.text: Advise David to remain silent ("no comment") throughout the interview to avoid any problems with his mother.

options.label: D
options.text: Ask the mother to wait outside during the consultation and interview, as her presence is counterproductive.

options.label: E
options.text: Tell David his fears are irrelevant and he must cooperate with the process with his mother present.

questions.explanation: An appropriate adult's role is to safeguard the interests of the juvenile and facilitate communication. If the appropriate adult's presence is likely to inhibit the juvenile from communicating freely or cause distress that undermines the fairness of the process, they are not suitable. Code C Note 1G states that if a parent is "implicated in the offence," "the victim," "a witness," or "involved in a significant way in the investigation," they should not be the appropriate adult. While David's mother is not implicated, the solicitor has reasonable grounds to believe her presence is antithetical ...

questions.text: During the interview of a suspect, the police officer repeatedly asks, "You did it, didn't you? Just admit it, it will be easier for you." The suspect's solicitor objects, stating the question is oppressive. The officer replies, "I'm just putting the case to him," and continues in the same manner. The suspect eventually says, "Alright, fine, I did it." Which of the following best describes the correct position on the interview?

options.label: A
options.text: The solicitor should have remained silent; challenging the officer's style during the interview is unprofessional.

options.label: B
options.text: The solicitor's objection was correct; the questioning was likely oppressive and the confession may be inadmissible.

options.label: C
options.text: The questioning was merely robust and not oppressive; the solicitor's objection was an overreaction.

options.label: D
options.text: The solicitor's only recourse was to make a formal complaint after the interview; intervention during the interview is not permitted.

options.label: E
options.text: The confession is admissible because the suspect ultimately admitted it voluntarily.

questions.explanation:
Oppression under s.76(2)(a) PACE includes "exercise of authority or power in a burdensome, harsh, or wrongful manner" (R v Fulling). Badgering a suspect with accusations and implying benefits from confession can constitute oppression. The solicitor has a duty to protect their client from unfair treatment and should intervene when questioning becomes improper. This intervention is a key part of their role. A confession obtained through such questioning is likely to be excluded under s.76 or s.78 PACE.
Option A is incorrect. The solicitor has a positive duty to intervene to prevent unfairness.
O...

questions.text: Thomas is charged with robbery, an indictable-only offence. He has a previous conviction for robbery five years ago, for which he served three years. At his first hearing in the magistrates' court, the prosecution opposes bail, arguing there are substantial grounds to believe that if released, Thomas would commit further offences. Thomas’s solicitor argues he has a stable job and lives with his partner and their child. The magistrates refuse bail. Thomas’s solicitor immediately applies to the Crown Court for bail, citing his strong community ties. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding Thomas’s bail position?

options.label: A
options.text: The magistrates were wrong to refuse bail because Thomas has strong community ties, which displace the risk of reoffending.

options.label: B
options.text: Thomas has an automatic right to apply to the Crown Court for bail, and the Crown Court judge will rehear the application afresh.

options.label: C
options.text: Thomas can only appeal to the Crown Court if the magistrates made an error of law; they did not, so the appeal will fail.

options.label: D
options.text: The Crown Court cannot hear a bail application until at least 48 hours have passed from the magistrates' decision.

options.label: E
options.text: Thomas should first make a renewed application to the magistrates' court; only if that fails can he go to the Crown Court.

questions.explanation:
Under s.16 of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, a person refused bail by a magistrates' court has an automatic right of appeal to a Crown Court judge. The appeal is a hearing de novo, meaning the judge considers the matter afresh based on the circumstances at the time of the appeal, not just reviewing the magistrates' decision for error. There is no requirement to wait 48 hours or to make a renewed application first, though renewed applications are also possible.
Option A is incorrect. Strong community ties are a factor but do not automatically displace a finding of substantial grounds to believe...

questions.text: Sarah is charged with assault occasioning actual bodily harm. She has no previous convictions. At her first hearing, the prosecution opposes bail, citing a risk she will interfere with witnesses, as the victim is her neighbour with whom she has had ongoing disputes. The magistrates grant bail but impose conditions: a curfew from 7 pm to 7 am, an exclusion zone prohibiting her from entering her own street, and a requirement to report to a police station daily. Sarah’s solicitor argues the conditions are excessively onerous. Which of the following is the MOST accurate statement regarding the conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: The conditions are unlawful because they effectively amount to house arrest and prevent Sarah from living at home.

options.label: B
options.text: The conditions are lawful if they are necessary to address the risk of witness interference and are proportionate.

options.label: C
options.text: The condition requiring daily reporting is unlawful because it is imposed without electronic monitoring.

options.label: D
options.text: The exclusion zone is unlawful as it infringes her right to respect for her home under Article 8 ECHR.

options.label: E
options.text: The conditions are unlawful because they were imposed without giving Sarah a chance to propose alternatives.

questions.explanation:
Under s.3(6) of the Bail Act 1976, conditions can be imposed if necessary to prevent absconding, further offences, or interference with witnesses. Conditions must be proportionate. An exclusion zone from the victim’s vicinity and a curfew are common conditions to prevent interference. The fact they are onerous does not make them unlawful if they are necessary and proportionate to the risk. The court does not have to accept defence alternatives.
Option A is incorrect. Conditions can be strict; a curfew and exclusion zone do not automatically constitute unlawful house arrest if justified.
Option...

questions.text: David is charged with burglary. He is granted bail with a condition to reside at his sister’s address and to observe a curfew from 10 pm to 6 am. Two weeks later, he is arrested for a new offence of theft allegedly committed at 2 pm. At a bail hearing following this arrest, the prosecution argues he has breached his bail by committing an offence while on bail, and he should now be remanded in custody. David denies the new theft allegation. Which of the following is the most  accurate statement regarding the court’s approach?

options.label: A
options.text: The court must refuse bail because David has breached his bail conditions by committing a further offence.

options.label: B
options.text: The court can only refuse bail on the grounds of committing further offences if David is convicted of the new offence.

options.label: C
options.text: The court can consider the allegation of a new offence as evidence supporting substantial grounds to believe he would commit offences if released.

options.label: D
options.text: The court must ignore the new allegation as it is not proven and David denies it.

options.label: E
options.text: The court should ignore the new allegation and grant bail but impose stricter conditions.

questions.explanation:
Under Schedule 1 to the Bail Act 1976, the court may refuse bail if there are substantial grounds for believing the defendant would commit an offence if released. A recent allegation of an offence committed while on bail is highly relevant to that assessment, even if not yet proven. The court does not need a conviction; it must make a judgment based on the information before it.
Option A is incorrect. Bail is not automatically refused; the court must still be satisfied there are substantial grounds for the belief.
Option B is incorrect. A conviction is not required; the court assesses risk bas...

questions.text: Chloe is charged with fraud, an either-way offence. At her first hearing, she indicates a not guilty plea. The prosecution does not oppose bail, and the magistrates grant unconditional bail. Two months later, at a pre-trial hearing, the prosecution applies for bail to be revoked, presenting new evidence that Chloe has contacted a key witness via social media, asking them to “forget what they saw.” Chloe admits sending the message but says it was an apology, not intimidation. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the revocation of bail?

options.label: A
options.text: The magistrates cannot revoke bail as it was already granted unconditionally; they can only add conditions now.

options.label: B
options.text: The magistrates can revoke bail if satisfied there are substantial grounds to believe Chloe would interfere with witnesses.

options.label: C
options.text: The magistrates must issue a warrant for arrest first, then hold a hearing within 24 hours to reconsider bail.

options.label: D
options.text: Only the Crown Court can revoke bail once it has been granted by the magistrates.

options.label: E
options.text: The magistrates can only revoke bail if Chloe is convicted of an offence of witness intimidation.

questions.explanation:
A court that has granted bail has the power to reconsider it at a subsequent hearing if new information arises. Under the Bail Act 1976 and the court’s inherent case management powers, if there is evidence of a risk of interference with witnesses (a condition under Schedule 1), the court can revoke bail and remand the defendant in custody. A formal arrest is not required if the defendant is already before the court.
Option A is incorrect. A court can vary bail conditions or revoke bail entirely if circumstances change.
Option C is incorrect. The procedure for arrest under s.7 for breach of con...

questions.text: Sophie is granted bail with a condition to surrender her passport. She gives her passport to her solicitor, who lodges it with the court. Two weeks later, Sophie is stopped at an airport attempting to board a flight to Spain using an old, expired passport she had forgotten about. She is arrested and brought before the court. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the consequences?

options.label: A
options.text: Sophie has not breached her bail condition because she surrendered the passport specified; the old passport was not covered.

options.label: B
options.text: Sophie has committed the offence of absconding under s.6 Bail Act 1976.

options.label: C
options.text: Sophie has breached her bail condition, and the court must now remand her in custody.

options.label: D
options.text: Sophie’s attempt to leave the jurisdiction is a breach of her bail, likely leading to remand in custody.

options.label: E
options.text: No breach has occurred because she did not succeed in leaving the country.

questions.explanation:
The condition to surrender her passport is designed to prevent her from leaving the jurisdiction. Using another passport (even expired) to attempt to leave is a clear breach of the spirit and purpose of that condition. It demonstrates an intention to abscond. The court will view this very seriously and is highly likely to remand her in custody. It may not be the specific offence of absconding under s.6 (which relates to failure to surrender), but it is a blatant breach of bail.
Option A is incorrect. The condition is intended to prevent international travel; using any passport to attempt to le...

questions.text: Daniel is charged with drug supply. He is granted bail with a condition to reside at a hostel approved by the probation service. After a week, the hostel manager reports that Daniel has not been staying there overnight. The police arrest him for breach of bail. At the hearing, Daniel says the hostel was noisy and he stayed with a friend instead. The prosecution urges the court to remand him in custody. Which of the following is the most accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: The court must remand Daniel in custody because he has breached a bail condition.

options.label: B
options.text: The court must grant bail again but with a more suitable residence condition.

options.label: C
options.text: The court has a discretion to grant bail again, but the breach significantly weakens Daniel’s position.

options.label: D
options.text: The court cannot consider the breach because Daniel was arrested without a warrant.

options.label: E
options.text: The court should impose a financial penalty for the breach but continue bail.

questions.explanation:
A breach of bail conditions is a serious matter, but it does not automatically lead to remand in custody. The court has a discretion to reconsider bail under s.7 of the Bail Act. The breach, however, undermines the court’s trust in the defendant and makes it much harder to persuade the court that conditions will be obeyed. The court may decide that only custody will now manage the risk.
Option A is incorrect. Remand in custody is not automatic; it is a discretionary decision.
Option B is incorrect. Granting bail is not automatic. It is at the court’s discretion.
Option D is incorrect. The arre...

questions.text: Emma is convicted of theft in the magistrates' court. The magistrates adjourn for a pre-sentence report, indicating that a custodial sentence is likely. The prosecution opposes bail pending sentence. Emma’s solicitor argues she has a stable job and cares for her elderly mother. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the presumption of bail after conviction?

options.label: A
options.text: The presumption of bail continues, and the prosecution must show substantial grounds to refuse it.

options.label: B
options.text: There is no presumption of bail after conviction; the court need not grant it if a custodial sentence is probable.

options.label: C
options.text: Bail must be granted unless the court is satisfied there is a significant risk of her committing further offences.

options.label: D
options.text: Bail can only be refused if she is committed to the Crown Court for sentence.

options.label: E
options.text: The magistrates must grant bail because they have not yet passed sentence.

questions.explanation:
Schedule 1, Part II of the Bail Act 1976 applies after conviction. The presumption in favour of bail is effectively reversed. The court need not grant bail if it is satisfied that it is probable that the defendant will receive a custodial sentence. The threshold is lower than the “substantial grounds” test for unconvicted defendants.
Option A is incorrect. The strong presumption applies before conviction, not after.
Option C is incorrect. This is one of the grounds in Part II, but the primary ground here is the probability of a custodial sentence.
Option D is incorrect. Bail can be refused eve...

questions.text: John is charged with violent disorder. He is refused bail by the magistrates. John is distraught by the magistrate’s decision and feels it’s unfair. His solicitor wants to appeal to the Crown Court. The refusal was on a Friday afternoon. His solicitor is considering lodging the notice of appeal the next day. What is the time limit for lodging the appeal?

options.label: A
options.text: The notice of appeal must be lodged with the Crown Court within 24 hours of the magistrates' decision,  excluding weekends and public holidays..

options.label: B
options.text: The notice of appeal must be lodged within 48 hours, excluding weekends and public holidays.

options.label: C
options.text: The appeal must be heard within 48 hours of the decision.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no strict time limit, but it should be done as soon as practicable.

options.label: E
options.text: The notice of appeal must be lodged within 3 days including weekends but excluding public holidays.

questions.explanation:
Under the Criminal Procedure Rules, rule 14.8, an appeal to the Crown Court against a magistrates' bail decision must be lodged with the Crown Court and served on the prosecution within 48 hours of the magistrates' decision. This period excludes weekends and public holidays. So, if refused on Friday afternoon, the deadline would typically be Tuesday afternoon.
Option A is incorrect. The limit is 48 hours, not 24.
Option C is incorrect. The hearing must be as soon as practicable, but the lodging has the 48-hour deadline.
Option D is incorrect. There is a strict deadline for lodging the appeal.
...

questions.text: Ben is granted bail with a condition not to contact his ex-partner, the complainant. A week later, the ex-partner provides the police with voicemails from Ben begging her to drop the charges. Ben is arrested for breach of bail. At the hearing, Ben says he was emotional and just wanted to apologise. What is the legal consequence of this breach?

options.label: A
options.text: Ben has committed the separate offence of witness intimidation, which must be charged separately.

options.label: B
options.text: The court must remand Ben in custody for the breach.

options.label: C
options.text: The court may remand Ben in custody and can also take the breach into account as evidence of guilt at his trial.

options.label: D
options.text: The court can only impose a more stringent condition, such as electronic tagging.

options.label: E
options.text: The breach is irrelevant because it was an attempt at reconciliation.

questions.explanation:
Breach of a non-contact condition is a serious matter, showing disregard for court orders and potential interference. The court may well remand in custody. Furthermore, under the rules of evidence, this breach (attempting to persuade a witness to drop charges) may be admissible at trial as evidence of a "guilty mind" or consciousness of guilt.
Option A is incorrect. While it could be witness intimidation, it is primarily a bail breach. The police may investigate a separate offence, but that’s not the direct consequence at the bail hearing.
Option B is incorrect. The court has a discretion, tho...

questions.text: David is on bail for burglary. He fails to attend court on the morning of his trial. He is arrested later that day. At a hearing, he explains that his car broke down on the motorway, and he was stranded for hours without phone signal. He provides a recovery truck invoice timed for that morning. In relation to the offence of absconding (s.6 Bail Act 1976), which is the MOST accurate statement?

options.label: A
options.text: David likely has a defence of reasonable cause, which he must prove on the balance of probabilities.

options.label: B
options.text: David is guilty of the offence because he failed to surrender; his excuse is a mitigation matter only.

options.label: C
options.text: The prosecution must prove David had no reasonable cause for his failure; his excuse raises a reasonable doubt.

options.label: D
options.text: David cannot rely on the defence because he should have anticipated car trouble and left earlier.

options.label: E
options.text: David likely has a defence of reasonable cause, which he must prove beyond reasonable doubt.

questions.explanation:
Under s.6(1) of the Bail Act, it is an offence to fail to surrender without reasonable cause. If the defendant raises evidence of a reasonable cause (e.g., a genuine emergency), the legal burden shifts to them to prove it on the balance of probabilities. A broken-down car with contemporaneous evidence could constitute reasonable cause, but it is for David to prove it.
Option B is incorrect. Reasonable cause is a statutory defence, not just mitigation.
Option C is incorrect. The legal burden of proving reasonable cause is on the defendant, not the prosecution to disprove it.
Option D is incorre...

questions.text: Kevin is charged with perverting the course of justice. He applies for bail. The prosecution opposes, citing a risk he will interfere with witnesses, as the case involves allegations he pressured witnesses in a previous trial. The magistrates refuse bail. Kevin’s solicitor believes the magistrates misapplied the law by treating the risk of interference as automatic given the charge, without considering specific conditions that could mitigate it. What is the MOST appropriate next step?

options.label: A
options.text: Apply to the Crown Court immediately under s.16 CJA 2003 for a fresh hearing.

options.label: B
options.text: Apply to the High Court for judicial review of the magistrates' decision.

options.label: C
options.text: Make a renewed application to the magistrates within 24 hours, arguing a change of circumstances.

options.label: D
options.text: Wait for the case to be sent to the Crown Court and apply there.

options.label: E
options.text: Complain to the Legal Ombudsman about judicial misconduct.

questions.explanation:
The fastest and most effective remedy for a defendant refused bail by magistrates is the automatic right of appeal to a Crown Court judge under s.16. This is a rehearing. Judicial review to the High Court is a last resort for errors of law or irrationality and is slower and more complex. A renewed application to magistrates is also possible, but the appeal route is specifically designed for this situation.
Option B is incorrect. Judicial review is not the primary route; it is for exceptional cases where the decision is arguably unlawful in a public law sense.
Option C is incorrect.There is no ...

areas.name: First hearings before the magistrates’ court & Plea before Venue

questions.text: Benjamin is arrested and charged with an offence under section 18 of the Offences Against the Person Act 1861 (causing grievous bodily harm with intent). He is brought before the magistrates’ court for his first hearing. Benjamin has no previous convictions and intends to plead not guilty.
