Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the procedural steps that will occur at this first hearing?

options.label: A
options.text: The magistrates will conduct a plea before venue hearing, and if Benjamin indicates a not guilty plea, they will hold a mode of trial hearing to decide if the case is suitable for summary trial.

options.label: B
options.text: The magistrates will take a formal plea from Benjamin. If he pleads not guilty, they will set a trial date in the magistrates’ court.

options.label: C
options.text: The magistrates’ role is limited to a sending hearing; they will not take a plea and will send the case directly to the Crown Court.

options.label: D
options.text: The magistrates will ask Benjamin to indicate a plea. If he indicates guilty, they will commit him to the Crown Court for sentence. If he indicates not guilty, they will send the case to the Crown Court for trial.

options.label: E
options.text: The magistrates will conduct a plea before venue hearing, and regardless of Benjamin’s plea, they must send the case to the Crown Court because it is an either-way offence.

questions.explanation:
Section 18 GBH with intent is an indictable-only offence. Under the Crime and Disorder Act 1998 s.51, the magistrates’ court’s function at the first hearing for an indictable-only offence is purely administrative: to confirm the defendant’s details and send the case to the Crown Court. No plea is taken (unless it is a guilty plea and the magistrates are asked to commit for sentence, which is rare). The case does not go through plea before venue or mode of trial procedures.
Option A is incorrect. Plea before venue and mode of trial apply only to either-way offences, not indictable-only offences...

questions.text: Chloe is charged with theft of a bicycle valued at £150. She appears at the magistrates’ court for her first hearing. She is 25, unemployed, and receives Universal Credit. She wishes to apply for legal aid. The duty solicitor helps her complete the application form. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding her application for a Representation Order?

options.label: A
options.text: Chloe will automatically pass the means test because she is on Universal Credit, and she will automatically pass the interests of justice test because theft is an imprisonable offence.

options.label: B
options.text: Chloe will pass the means test due to being on benefits, but she must also satisfy the interests of justice test, which she will likely do as she is at risk of a custodial sentence.

options.label: C
options.text: Chloe will fail the means test because theft is not a serious enough offence to qualify for legal aid.

options.label: D
options.text: The application must be refused because she is unemployed and cannot contribute to the cost.

options.label: E
options.text: The magistrates will decide on the spot whether to grant legal aid based on her oral submission.

questions.explanation:
The grant of a Representation Order under the Legal Aid, Sentencing and Punishment of Offenders Act 2012 (LASPO) requires both a means test and an “interests of justice” (merits) test. Receipt of a qualifying benefit like Universal Credit means she passes the means test automatically. However, she must also satisfy at least one of the criteria in Schedule 1 of LASPO. Theft is an either-way offence with a maximum sentence of 7 years, so she is at risk of a custodial sentence, which satisfies the “loss of liberty” criterion. It is not automatic, but it is very likely to be met.
Option A is incor...

questions.text: Sophia stole at a supermarket and is charged with low-value shoplifting (goods worth £180). At her first hearing, she indicates a not guilty plea. Her solicitor advises her that she can elect to have her trial in the Crown Court. Is the solicitor’s advice correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because shoplifting is an either-way offence, and she has a right to elect trial by jury.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, but only if the magistrates decline jurisdiction after a mode of trial hearing.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because low-value shoplifting is a summary-only offence for mode of trial purposes.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because, any offence with the subject matter less than £200 is to be tried in the magistrate court

options.label: E
options.text: It depends on whether she has any previous convictions; if she does, she can elect Crown Court trial.

questions.explanation:
Section 22A of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 creates a special category for low-value shoplifting (goods not exceeding £200). For the purposes of mode of trial, it is treated as a summary-only offence. This means the defendant has no right to elect trial by jury. The case must be dealt with in the magistrates’ court. The solicitor’s advice is therefore incorrect.
Option A is incorrect. While theft is generally an either-way offence, the low-value shoplifting provision removes the either-way status for mode of trial.
Option B is incorrect. The magistrates do not hold a mode of trial hearing ...

questions.text: At a magistrates’ court first hearing, Eleanor is charged with burglary of a dwelling place (an either-way offence). She indicates a guilty plea during plea before venue. The magistrates hear the facts and decide their sentencing powers (maximum 6 months) are insufficient. What is the correct procedural next step?

options.label: A
options.text: The magistrates must sentence Eleanor themselves, as she pleaded guilty.

options.label: B
options.text: The magistrates must commit Eleanor to the Crown Court for sentencing.

options.label: C
options.text: The magistrates must offer Eleanor the choice of being sentenced in the magistrates’ court or the Crown Court.

options.label: D
options.text: The magistrates must send the case to the Crown Court for trial, as the guilty plea is not binding.

options.label: E
options.text: The magistrates must adjourn for a pre-sentence report before deciding whether to commit for sentence.

questions.explanation:
When a defendant indicates a guilty plea to an either-way offence in the magistrates’ court, the case remains there for sentencing unless the magistrates consider their sentencing powers inadequate. Under section 3 of the PCC(S)A 2000, if the offence(s) are “so serious that greater punishment should be inflicted than the court has power to impose,” they may commit the defendant to the Crown Court for sentence. This is a discretionary but common step for serious either-way offences like dwelling burglary.
Option A is incorrect. They have the power to decline to sentence if they believe their po...

questions.text: David and Leo are co-defendants charged with joint possession of a Class A drug with intent to supply. At their first hearing, David indicates a guilty plea. Leo indicates a not guilty plea and, when the magistrates accept jurisdiction, elects trial by jury in the Crown Court. What is the likely outcome for David?

options.label: A
options.text: David will be sentenced immediately in the magistrates’ court.

options.label: B
options.text: David’s case will be sent to the Crown Court alongside Leo’s, and he will be sentenced there.

options.label: C
options.text: David will be given the choice of being sentenced in the magistrates’ court or the Crown Court.

options.label: D
options.text: David’s guilty plea will be vacated, and both will be tried together in the Crown Court.

options.label: E
options.text: The magistrates court will immediately sentence David with a one-third reduction.

questions.explanation:
When co-defendants are charged together and one elects Crown Court trial, the general rule is that all defendants are sent to the Crown Court to be tried together (under s.51(1) of the Crime and Disorder Act 1998 for either-way offences linked with an indictable-only or sent under s.50A for either-way offences). The guilty plea of one defendant does not prevent this. David’s case will be sent to the Crown Court. He will likely be sentenced there, often after the trial of the co-defendant, so the sentencing judge has a full picture of the joint enterprise.
Option A is incorrect. The magistrates...

questions.text: At a first hearing, the magistrates are dealing with a defendant charged with common assault (a summary offence). The defendant indicates a not guilty plea. The prosecutor informs the court that the victim, a key witness, is abroad for three months. What is the most likely procedural step the court will take?

options.label: A
options.text: Dismiss the case due to the witness’s unavailability.

options.label: B
options.text: Immediately list the case for trial in two weeks’ time.

options.label: C
options.text: Adjourn the case for trial to a date after the witness’s return and give case management directions.

options.label: D
options.text: Send the case to the Crown Court where more robust witness summons powers exist.

options.label: E
options.text: Direct the prosecution to proceed without that witness.

questions.explanation:
For summary offences, once a not guilty plea is entered, the case is set down for trial in the magistrates’ court. The court has an active duty to manage the case under the Criminal Procedure Rules. If a key witness is unavailable, the court will adjourn the case to a realistic trial date and give directions for the service of witness availability and evidence. The case cannot be dismissed simply due to witness unavailability at this stage.
Option A is incorrect. The court will not dismiss a viable case because of a temporary witness absence; it will manage the listing.
Option B is incorrect. ...

questions.text: Micheal damaged his neighbor’s property in revenge for a prior altercation he had with his neighbor. He is charged with criminal damage valued at £4,500 and appears for a first hearing. His solicitor has advised him that the mode of trial procedure is governed by section 22A of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980. What advice should the solicitor give regarding trial venue?

options.label: A
options.text: “You have the right to elect trial by jury in the Crown Court because criminal damage is an either-way offence.”

options.label: B
options.text: “The magistrates will decide if the case is suitable for summary trial. If they accept jurisdiction, you can choose between magistrates’ and Crown Court trial.”

options.label: C
options.text: “This offence is treated as summary-only for mode of trial, so it must be heard in the magistrates’ court. You have no right to elect Crown Court trial.”

options.label: D
options.text: “Because the value is high, the case will automatically be sent to the Crown Court.”

options.label: E
options.text: “You can only go to the Crown Court if you plead guilty and the magistrates decide to commit you for sentence.”

questions.explanation:
Section 22A MCA 1980 applies to low-value criminal damage (value of loss or damage not exceeding £5,000). For mode of trial purposes, it is treated as a summary-only offence. This means the defendant has no right to elect trial by jury. The case must be dealt with in the magistrates’ court (unless it is linked to a related either-way or indictable-only offence). The solicitor’s advice must reflect this removal of the defendant’s choice.
Option A is incorrect. This is the general rule for either-way criminal damage, but section 22A removes that right for low-value cases.
Option B is incorrect. ...

areas.name: Allocation, Case management and pre-trial hearings

questions.text: Sarah and Chloe are co-defendants charged with joint possession with intent to supply Class A drugs, an either-way offence. At the plea before venue hearing, Sarah indicates a guilty plea. Chloe indicates a not guilty plea. The magistrates accept jurisdiction for summary trial. Chloe elects trial by jury in the Crown Court. What is the correct procedural outcome for Sarah?

options.label: A
options.text: Sarah will be sentenced immediately in the magistrates’ court.

options.label: B
options.text: Sarah’s case will be sent to the Crown Court alongside Chloe.

options.label: C
options.text: The magistrates will sentence Sarah after obtaining a pre-sentence report, as her guilty plea is unrelated to Chloe’s election.

options.label: D
options.text: Sarah will be given the choice of being sentenced in the magistrates’ court or the Crown Court.

options.label: E
options.text: Sarah’s guilty plea will be vacated, and both will be tried together in the Crown Court.

questions.explanation: Section 50A of the Crime and Disorder Act 1998 provides for the sending to the Crown Court of an either-way offence which is related to an indictable-only offence, or, crucially, where it is related to another either-way offence for which a co-defendant is sent for trial. Here, Chloe’s election for Crown Court trial means her either-way offence is “sent” to the Crown Court. Under s.50A(3)(b), the court must also send any related either-way offence charged against another person (Sarah). Sarah’s guilty plea does not prevent this; she will be sentenced in the Crown Court, often after Chloe’s tri...

questions.text: David is charged with criminal damage valued at £4,800. He has no previous convictions. At the first hearing, his solicitor advises him on the mode of trial procedure. Which of the following statements by the solicitor is correct in light of section 22A of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980?

options.label: A
options.text: “This is an either-way offence, so the magistrates will decide if it’s suitable for summary trial. If they accept, you can choose between the magistrates’ court and the Crown Court.”

options.label: B
options.text: “Because the damage is under £5,000, this offence is treated as summary-only for mode of trial. It must be dealt with in the magistrates’ court, and you have no right to elect Crown Court trial.”

options.label: C
options.text: “The value is high, so the case will automatically go to the Crown Court for trial.”

options.label: D
options.text: “You can elect Crown Court trial, but if you do, you risk a higher sentence if convicted.”

options.label: E
options.text: “The mode of trial depends on whether you plead guilty or not guilty.”

questions.explanation:
Section 22A MCA 1980 applies to low-value criminal damage (value of loss or damage not exceeding £5,000). For mode of trial purposes, it is treated as a summary-only offence. This means the standard either-way procedure (magistrates deciding suitability, then defendant election) does not apply. The case must be dealt with in the magistrates’ court, and the defendant has no right to elect trial by jury. The solicitor’s advice must reflect this.
Option A is incorrect. This is the standard either-way procedure, which is displaced by s.22A for low-value criminal damage.
Option C is incorrect. The ...

questions.text: At a Plea and Trial Preparation Hearing (PTPH) in the Crown Court for a case of fraud, the judge asks the defence advocate to identify the issues in the case. The advocate states, “The defendant’s case is a complete denial; he says he was not involved.” The judge presses for more detail, asking if there are any specific evidential disputes. What is the primary purpose of the judge seeking this information at the PTPH?

options.label: A
options.text: To decide whether there is a case to answer.

options.label: B
options.text: To formulate final  judicial directions for the jury.

options.label: C
options.text: To ensure efficient case management.

options.label: D
options.text: To determine the admissibility of hearsay evidence.

options.label: E
options.text: To assess the strength of the prosecution case for the purpose of plea bargaining.

questions.explanation:
The PTPH is a crucial case management hearing under the Criminal Procedure Rules. Its purpose is to ensure the efficient progression of the case to trial. This includes identifying the real issues in dispute, which informs what disclosure is needed, which witnesses are required, the estimated trial length, and the need for any pre-trial rulings. A “blanket denial” is unhelpful for case management; the court expects the defence to specify the factual and legal issues.
Option A is incorrect. A submission of no case is made at trial, not at the PTPH.
Option B is incorrect. While the judge may sta...

questions.text: In a magistrates’ court case management hearing for a trial of assault, the defence solicitor has not yet served a Defence Statement. The prosecutor has provided initial disclosure. The legal adviser asks the defence solicitor for an update on the Defence Statement. Under the Criminal Procedure and Investigations Act 1996, which of the following is the most  accurate statement regarding the Defence Statement?

options.label: A
options.text: The defence must serve a Defence Statement within 14 days of the prosecution’s initial disclosure.

options.label: B
options.text: A Defence Statement is optional in the magistrates’ court and is only required if the defence wishes to make an application to exclude evidence.

options.label: C
options.text: The defence is not required to serve a Defence Statement until the prosecution has served all its evidence.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no requirement for a Defence Statement in summary-only offences.

options.label: E
options.text: The defence must serve a Defence Statement within 28 days of the prosecution’s initial disclosure

questions.explanation:
Under the CPIA 1996 (as amended), the defence must normally serve a Defence Statement on the court and prosecution within 14 days of the prosecution complying with its initial disclosure duty (s.5 CPIA). This applies in the magistrates’ court for either-way offences tried there. Failure to do so, or setting out a different defence at trial, can allow the court to draw adverse inferences under ss.6E and 11 CPIA.
Option B is incorrect. It is a mandatory requirement in relevant cases, not optional.
Option C is incorrect. The trigger is prosecution initial disclosure, not service of all evidence.
...

questions.text: Elijah is charged with assault and is granted unconditional bail by the magistrates. At a later case management hearing, the prosecution informs the court that the Elijah has been arrested for a new, unrelated offence of criminal damage. The prosecution applies for bail to be revoked. On what basis can the magistrates revoke bail at this hearing?

options.label: A
options.text: They cannot; bail can only be revoked if the defendant is convicted of the new offence.

options.label: B
options.text: They can, if satisfied there are now substantial grounds to believe the defendant would commit further offences if released.

options.label: C
options.text: They cannot, because the new offence is unrelated and the defendant is presumed innocent of it.

options.label: D
options.text: They can only add conditions, such as a curfew; they cannot revoke bail entirely.

options.label: E
options.text: They must issue a warrant for arrest under section 7 of the Bail Act first.

questions.explanation:
The court has the power to reconsider bail at any hearing where the defendant is present. New information, such as an arrest for another offence, is highly relevant to the risk of committing further offences (one of the Schedule 1 grounds). The court can revoke bail if satisfied there are substantial grounds for that belief. A conviction is not necessary.
Option A is incorrect. The court acts on information available, not just convictions.
Option C is incorrect. The relationship of the offences is not decisive; the key is the assessment of risk.
Option D is incorrect. The court has the power t...

questions.text: In a Crown Court case, the defence serve a Defence Statement that is very brief: “The defendant denies the offence. He says he was not there.” The prosecution apply for an order under section 6E of the CPIA 1996, arguing the statement is inadequate. What must a Defence Statement contain to be adequate?

options.label: A
options.text: It must set out the nature of the defence, indicate the matters on which issue is taken with the prosecution, and set out the reasons for taking issue.

options.label: B
options.text: It is adequate if it contains a simple denial, as the burden of proof remains on the prosecution.

options.label: C
options.text: It must disclose all defence witnesses and their evidence.

options.label: D
options.text: It must be signed by the defendant personally.

options.label: E
options.text: It must be approved by the trial judge before service.

questions.explanation:
Section 6A of the CPIA 1996 sets out the requirements for a Defence Statement. It must set out the nature of the defence, indicate any points of issue with the prosecution, and give reasons for those issues. A mere denial is insufficient and may lead to adverse inferences under s.11 CPIA if a different or more detailed defence is advanced at trial. The purpose is to assist in identifying the real issues and ensuring proper disclosure.
Option B is incorrect. A simple denial does not meet the statutory requirements.
Option C is incorrect. While details of alibi witnesses are required, a general ...

questions.text: In a complex fraud trial, the defence case is that the defendant, a company director, acted on legal advice throughout the relevant transactions. The defence serves a detailed Defence Statement to this effect. The prosecution has in its possession two categories of unused material: (1) Handwritten, unsigned meeting notes taken by a junior solicitor at the law firm, which record the solicitor advising the defendant that a proposed transaction "carries a high risk of being viewed as dishonest." (2) An internal police email between the Senior Investigating Officer and the CPS prosecutor, discussing the strengths and weaknesses of the case, in which the prosecutor writes: "The defendant's reliance on legal advice is the strongest part of his defence. If the jury believe he genuinely followed advice, we lose." Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the prosecution's duty to disclose these two items?

options.label: A
options.text: Neither item needs to be disclosed. Item (1) is subject to legal professional privilege and Item (2) is internal prosecution work product.

options.label: B
options.text: Only Item (1) must be disclosed because it contains direct evidence of the advice given, which is central to the defence.

options.label: C
options.text: Only Item (2) must be disclosed because it reveals the prosecution's own assessment of a key weakness in its case.

options.label: D
options.text: Both items must be disclosed because they both meet the disclosure test.

options.label: E
options.text: Item (1) must be disclosed, but Item (2) is protected by litigation privilege and need not be disclosed.

questions.explanation:
Both items meet the objective test for disclosure under section 3 CPIA 1996: they might reasonably be considered capable of undermining the prosecution case or assisting the defence.
Item (1): While the notes may be subject to legal professional privilege (LPP), this does not automatically prevent disclosure. If the material is in the prosecution's possession, the disclosure test still applies. The fact it contains a record of advice directly relevant to the defendant's state of mind and defence makes it highly capable of assisting the defence. The prosecution cannot hide behind LPP if it has ...

questions.text: During a police interview under caution for theft, David exercises his right to silence and gives a “no comment” interview on the advice of his solicitor, as disclosure was minimal. At his trial, his defence is that he believed he had the owner’s permission to take the item. The prosecution seeks to invite the jury to draw an adverse inference under section 34 of the Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994 (CJPOA). The defence objects, arguing the inference is not permitted because David acted on legal advice. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the drawing of an adverse inference in these circumstances?

options.label: A
options.text: An adverse inference cannot be drawn because David was following legal advice to remain silent.

options.label: B
options.text: An adverse inference can be drawn unless the legal advice was clearly justified.

options.label: C
options.text: An adverse inference can always be drawn if a fact is later relied on that was not mentioned in interview; legal advice is irrelevant.

options.label: D
options.text: An adverse inference can never be drawn from silence in interview.

options.label: E
options.text: The jury must be directed that they cannot draw an adverse inference if the solicitor’s advice was reasonable.

questions.explanation: The leading case of R v Argent [1997] 2 Cr App R 27 established that legal advice is one of the circumstances the court considers when deciding if it was “reasonable” for the defendant to have mentioned the fact later relied on. However, the mere fact of legal advice is not an absolute bar. The jury may still draw an inference if they conclude the defendant remained silent not because of the advice, but because he had no innocent explanation to give at the time. The judge must direct the jury to consider the reasonableness of the advice in the circumstances (e.g., lack of disclosure may make s...

questions.text: During a trial for burglary, the prosecution seeks to adduce evidence that the defendant, when arrested two days after the offence, had in his pocket a distinctive gold cigarette lighter. The victim had reported that a similar lighter was stolen during the burglary. The defendant made no comment when asked about it. The defence argues this evidence is irrelevant and prejudicial. What is the BEST argument for its admissibility?

options.label: A
options.text: It is evidence of the defendant’s bad character, admissible under gateway (d) of the CJA 2003 to show propensity.

options.label: B
options.text: It is relevant circumstantial evidence connecting the defendant to the crime scene.

options.label: C
options.text: It is hearsay evidence of the victim’s description, admissible under the res gestae exception.

options.label: D
options.text: It is inadmissible because it is evidence of a previous alleged theft, which is prejudicial.

options.label: E
options.text: It is only admissible if the defendant gives evidence and is cross-examined about it.

questions.explanation:
The possession of an item matching one reported stolen is directly relevant circumstantial evidence. It does not, in itself, constitute “bad character” evidence (which relates to misconduct or disposition). It is simply a fact from which the jury may, if they choose, draw an inference of involvement. Relevance is the primary test for admissibility. The judge may exclude it under s.78 PACE if its prejudicial effect outweighs its probative value, but it is prima facie admissible as relevant evidence.
Option A is incorrect. This is not evidence of bad character (previous misconduct or disposition...

questions.text: In a trial for possession of a firearm with intent to endanger life, the defendant was found by police hiding in a garden shed near where shots were fired. When asked by the arresting officer, “What are you doing here? Shots were fired from this area,” the defendant said nothing. The prosecution seeks an adverse inference under section 37 of the CJPOA 1994. What must the prosecution establish for such an inference to be permissible?

options.label: A
options.text: That the defendant was arrested at the time the offence was committed.

options.label: B
options.text: That the defendant’s presence at the place at the time of the offence is attributable to his participation in it.

options.label: C
options.text: That the officer informed the defendant in ordinary language of the officer’s belief, what he was being asked to account for, and that a court may draw an adverse inference from a failure.

options.label: D
options.text: That the defendant later gives an account of his presence at his trial.

options.label: E
options.text: Both B and C are required.

questions.explanation: Section 37 mirrors the structure of section 36. For an inference from failure to account for presence, the conditions are: (1) the defendant was arrested at a place at or about the time the offence was committed; (2) a constable reasonably believes that the defendant’s presence at that place at that time may be attributable to his participation in the offence; (3) the constable informs the defendant of that belief and requests an explanation; (4) the constable warns the defendant in ordinary language that a court may draw an adverse inference from a failure or refusal. Both the reasonable beli...

questions.text: At a trial for theft, the only evidence is the testimony of a shop security guard who says he saw the defendant take an item. The guard had a clear, unobstructed view for 10 seconds from 5 meters away. The defendant does not testify. The judge sums up to the jury but omits to give any specific warning about the dangers of identification evidence. What is the most likely consequence of this omission?

options.label: A
options.text: The conviction will be safe if the jury found the witness credible.

options.label: B
options.text: The conviction will be unsafe and will be quashed on appeal.

options.label: C
options.text: The omission is only a material irregularity if the defence had requested a Turnbull direction.

options.label: D
options.text: The omission is irrelevant because the defendant did not testify.

options.label: E
options.text: The Court of Appeal will apply the proviso if satisfied the jury would have convicted anyway.

questions.explanation:
Where the prosecution case depends wholly or substantially on the correctness of identification evidence, a Turnbull direction is mandatory. Failure to give such a direction is a material misdirection in law and will usually render a conviction unsafe, resulting in it being quashed on appeal. The strength of the evidence is irrelevant to the requirement for the direction. The Court of Appeal is highly unlikely to apply the proviso (that no miscarriage of justice occurred) in the absence of a Turnbull direction.
Option A is incorrect. The safety of the conviction is judged by the fairness of th...

questions.text: In a murder trial, the defendant’s case is alibi. He claims he was at a cinema at the time. He did not mention this alibi in his police interview, on his solicitor’s advice, because the solicitor felt the disclosure was inadequate. At trial, the prosecution cross-examines him: “You never mentioned this alibi to the police, did you? Why not?” The defendant replies, “My solicitor told me not to say anything.” How should the judge direct the jury regarding this exchange?

options.label: A
options.text: Tell the jury to ignore the exchange entirely, as it is prejudicial.

options.label: B
options.text: Direct the jury that they must not draw any adverse inference from the failure to mention the alibi because the defendant was following legal advice.

options.label: C
options.text: Direct the jury that they may draw an adverse inference if they are sure the only reason for silence was that the defendant had no alibi to mention at the time.

options.label: D
options.text: Direct the jury that they must draw an adverse inference because alibi defences should be disclosed at the earliest opportunity.

options.label: E
options.text: Tell the jury that the defendant’s answer is irrelevant and they should focus only on the evidence of the alibi.

questions.explanation: This is the correct direction following R v Argent and R v Condron. The jury must be directed on the conditions for drawing a section 34 inference. They should consider: (1) Did the defendant fail to mention a fact later relied on? (2) Could he reasonably have been expected to mention it? In considering reasonableness, they should consider all circumstances, including the legal advice and its reasonableness (e.g., was lack of disclosure a valid reason for the advice?). If they are sure the defendant remained silent not because of the advice, but because he had no explanation to give, they may ...

questions.text: The prosecution seeks to adduce a confession made by a defendant with a significant learning disability. An appropriate adult was present during the interview. The defence applies to exclude the confession, arguing that despite the presence of the appropriate adult, the defendant’s disability meant he could not properly understand the questions or the implications of his answers. What is the correct legal test for the judge to apply in deciding admissibility under section 76(2)(b) of PACE?

options.label: A
options.text: Whether the police acted in bad faith or intentionally exploited the defendant’s disability.

options.label: B
options.text: Whether, in the circumstances existing at the time, the confession was likely to be unreliable.

options.label: C
options.text: Whether the confession is corroborated by other evidence.

options.label: D
options.text: Whether the defendant now alleges the confession is untrue.

options.label: E
options.text: Whether the interview breached Code C of PACE.

questions.explanation:
Section 76(2)(b) focuses on the circumstances and their likely effect on the reliability of any confession the defendant might make. The defendant’s learning disability is a key circumstance. The presence of an appropriate adult is a factor that may mitigate concerns, but does not automatically guarantee reliability. The judge must consider all circumstances and decide, on the balance of probabilities, whether they were likely to render any confession unreliable. If so, the confession must be excluded. This is an objective test focused on potential unreliability, not police misconduct.
Option ...

questions.text: At a trial for dangerous driving, the prosecution case is that the defendant was driving at twice the speed limit. The only evidence is from a single witness, Mr. Jones, who was standing on the pavement. The defence challenges the reliability of this identification, noting that Mr. Jones was 100 meters away and it was dusk. The judge rules the evidence admissible. In his summing up, the judge says: "Members of the jury, you have heard Mr. Jones's evidence. If you believe him, you may convict. If you do not believe him, you must acquit. There is no other evidence." Which of the following is the most accurate assessment of the judge's direction?

options.label: A
options.text: It is correct; it accurately reflects the state of the evidence.

options.label: B
options.text: It is incorrect because it fails to give the specific warning required by the Turnbull guidelines.

options.label: C
options.text: It is incorrect because the judge should have withdrawn the case from the jury due to the poor quality of the identification evidence.

options.label: D
options.text: It is incorrect because the judge should have directed the jury that they need corroboration.

options.label: E
options.text: It is correct because the witness's estimate of speed is not technically "identification evidence" within the meaning of Turnbull.

questions.explanation:
The Turnbull guidelines apply wherever the case depends wholly or substantially on the correctness of identification evidence. Here, the witness is identifying the defendant as the driver and estimating his speed—this is classic visual identification evidence. The judge's direction, while logically sound, omitted the mandatory elements of a Turnbull warning: the special need for caution, the reason for caution, and a detailed examination of the circumstances of the identification (distance, lighting, etc.). This omission constitutes a material misdirection.
Option A is incorrect. While the dir...

questions.text: Daniel is on trial for robbery. He has two previous convictions for theft from five and three years ago. The prosecution applies to admit these previous convictions as bad character evidence under gateway (d) of section 101(1) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, arguing they show a propensity to commit offences of dishonesty. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the admissibility of this evidence?

options.label: A
options.text: The convictions are automatically admissible because they are for offences of a similar category to the charge.

options.label: B
options.text: The judge must admit the evidence if it is relevant to an important matter in issue.

options.label: C
options.text: The judge must exclude the evidence because the convictions are too old and not sufficiently similar.

options.label: D
options.text: The convictions are inadmissible because they are for theft, not robbery, and are therefore not relevant.

options.label: E
options.text: The evidence can only be admitted if Daniel attacks the character of a prosecution witness.

questions.explanation: Gateway (d) permits evidence of a defendant's bad character if it is relevant to an "important matter in issue between the defendant and the prosecution." Propensity to commit offences of the kind charged is explicitly listed in section 103(1)(a) as such a matter. The judge's role is not automatic; they must conduct a two-stage test: (1) Is the evidence admissible through a gateway? (Yes, gateway (d) is potentially open). (2) Even if admissible, should the evidence be excluded under section 101(3) because its admission would have such an adverse effect on the fairness of the proceedings that i...

questions.text: In a trial for assault occasioning actual bodily harm, the defendant, Marcus, gives evidence. Under cross-examination, he is asked: "Isn't it true that you were dismissed from your job last year for making violent threats to a colleague?" Marcus denies this. The prosecution seeks to call Marcus's former manager to prove the dismissal for violent threats. Under which gateway of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 is this evidence MOST likely to be admissible?

options.label: A
options.text: Gateway (a): All parties agree to the evidence being admissible.

options.label: B
options.text: Gateway (d): It is relevant to an important matter in issue, namely, Marcus's propensity to be untruthful.

options.label: C
options.text: Gateway (f): It is evidence to correct a false impression given by the defendant.

options.label: D
options.text: Gateway (g): The defendant has made an attack on another person's character.

options.label: E
options.text: Section 100: It is important explanatory evidence.

questions.explanation:
Gateway (f) applies where the defendant has given a false impression about their own character. If Marcus, through his evidence or conduct, has created a false impression of good character (e.g., by presenting himself as a peaceful person), the prosecution may adduce evidence to correct that impression. The question in cross-examination that elicits a denial is the first step. If he denies the dismissal, the prosecution can then call evidence to prove it, correcting the false impression. This gateway is designed to prevent a defendant from misleading the jury about their true character.
Option...

questions.text: During a trial for possession of a knife in a public place, the defendant, Liam, testifies. In his evidence, he says, "I'm not a violent person. I've never been in trouble with the police before." In fact, Liam has a previous conviction for common assault from four years ago. The prosecution did not initially apply to admit this conviction. What is the MOST appropriate course of action for the prosecution?

options.label: A
options.text: Apply to admit the previous conviction to correct the false impression given by Liam.

options.label: B
options.text: Do nothing; the prosecution cannot reopen the issue once the defendant has finished his evidence.

options.label: C
options.text: Cross-examine Liam on his previous conviction, as he has put his character in issue.

options.label: D
options.text: Make a submission to the judge that Liam is lying, but no further evidence can be called.

options.label: E
options.text: Apply to admit the conviction under gateway (g), as Liam has attacked the character of the police.

questions.explanation:
Gateway (f) allows evidence to correct a false impression given by the defendant. By stating "I've never been in trouble with the police before," Liam has clearly given a false impression of good character. The prosecution can apply to admit evidence (the previous conviction) to correct this. The proper procedure is for the prosecution to seek the judge's leave. If granted, they can cross-examine Liam on it or call evidence to prove it.
Option B is incorrect. The prosecution can apply to admit bad character evidence even after the defendant has testified, especially if the false impression was...

questions.text: During a trial for sexual assault, the defendant, Jude, does not testify. The prosecution applies to admit evidence of his previous conviction for a sexual offence against a different victim. The defence objects, arguing the prejudicial effect is overwhelming. What is the primary consideration for the judge when deciding whether to exclude the evidence under section 101(3) of the CJA 2003?

options.label: A
options.text: Whether the defendant is testifying.

options.label: B
options.text: Whether the previous conviction is for an offence of an identical nature.

options.label: C
options.text: Whether the admission of the evidence would have such an adverse effect on the fairness of the proceedings.

options.label: D
options.text: Whether the jury is likely to be able to follow a direction to use the evidence only for propensity.

options.label: E
options.text: Whether the prosecution has other strong evidence.

questions.explanation:
Section 101(3) provides the court with a specific power to exclude bad character evidence even if it is admissible through a gateway. The test is: "The court must not admit evidence under subsection (1)(d) or (g) if... it appears to the court that the admission of the evidence would have such an adverse effect on the fairness of the proceedings that the evidence ought not to be admitted." This is a fairness-based test, requiring the judge to balance the probative value of the evidence against its prejudicial effect. This is the primary statutory safeguard.
Option A is incorrect. Whether the de...

questions.text: Paul, a defendant, is charged with theft. The prosecution evidence is weak. To bolster its case, the prosecution applies to admit evidence that the defendant was convicted of shoplifting 15 years ago. The defence argues this is irrelevant and prejudicial. Which of the following arguments for the defence is most likely to succeed under the CJA 2003?

options.label: A
options.text: The conviction is for a summary offence, which cannot be used as bad character evidence.

options.label: B
options.text: The conviction is too old and has minimal probative value; its admission would be unfairly prejudicial.

options.label: C
options.text: The conviction is inadmissible because it is not for an offence of the same description.

options.label: D
options.text: The prosecution cannot use bad character evidence to bolster a weak case.

options.label: E
options.text: The conviction is inadmissible because the defendant has not put his character in issue.

questions.explanation:
Age of a previous conviction is a key factor in the section 101(3) balancing exercise. A 15-year-old conviction for a relatively minor offence may have very low probative value regarding current propensity, while the risk of unfair prejudice ("once a thief, always a thief") is significant. The defence's strongest argument is that admitting such stale evidence would have an adverse effect on the fairness of the proceedings. The judge has the power to exclude it on this basis.
Option A is incorrect. The category of the offence (summary vs. indictable) does not determine admissibility; relevance ...

questions.text: During a police interview for an alleged assault, the suspect was not cautioned for the first 30 minutes of questioning. During this time, he made several incriminating statements. The rest of the interview, after the caution, was conducted properly. The defence applies to exclude all the interview evidence under section 78 of PACE. What is the key factor the court will consider?

options.label: A
options.text: Whether the police acted in bad faith.

options.label: B
options.text: Whether the incriminating statements made before the caution are likely to be true.

options.label: C
options.text: Whether the admission of the evidence would have such an adverse effect on the fairness of the proceedings that it ought not to be admitted.

options.label: D
options.text: Whether the defendant was legally represented at the time.

options.label: E
options.text: Whether the breach of Code C was minor or technical.

questions.explanation:
This is the precise wording of the test under section 78(1) of PACE 1984. The court has a discretion to exclude prosecution evidence if its admission would affect the fairness of the proceedings. The court will consider the seriousness of the breach (failure to caution is a significant breach of Code C), the effect it had on the defendant, whether the evidence would have been obtained anyway, and the importance of the evidence to the case. The court might exclude the pre-caution statements, or possibly the entire interview if the breach tainted the whole process.
Option A is incorrect. Bad fai...

questions.text: In a complex fraud trial, the prosecution failed to disclose a crucial email to the defence until the morning of the trial. The email could be used by the defence to cross-examine a key prosecution witness. The defence applies to exclude the prosecution witness's evidence in its entirety under section 78 due to the late disclosure. What is the judge most likely to do?

options.label: A
options.text: Exclude the witness's evidence as a sanction for the prosecution's failure.

options.label: B
options.text: Refuse the application and allow the trial to proceed, as the email has now been disclosed.

options.label: C
options.text: Adjourn the trial to allow the defence time to consider the email, and only consider exclusion if the prosecution refuses the adjournment.

options.label: D
options.text: Direct the jury to draw an adverse inference against the prosecution.

options.label: E
options.text: Stay the proceedings as an abuse of process.

questions.explanation: The primary remedy for late disclosure is usually an adjournment to allow the defence to digest the new material and prepare, not the exclusion of crucial evidence. Exclusion under section 78 is a last resort for serious breaches that cannot be remedied. The judge's first step will be to assess whether an adjournment can cure the prejudice. If the prosecution opposes a necessary adjournment, or if the lateness is so egregious that it undermines the fairness of the trial irreparably, exclusion or a stay may be considered. The case of R v H and C emphasises the continuing duty of disclosure and ...

questions.text: During a murder investigation, police interviewed a vulnerable suspect with a significant learning disability. An appropriate adult was present. However, during a crucial part of the interview, the appropriate adult briefly left the room to use the toilet, and during this 5-minute period, the suspect made a key admission. The interview was otherwise conducted properly and was fully recorded. The defence applies to exclude the entire confession under section 78. Which of the following best reflects the key consideration for the court?

options.label: A
options.text: The confession must be excluded because it was obtained in breach of Code C, which requires the appropriate adult to be present at all times.

options.label: B
options.text: The court should admit the confession because the breach was minor and the appropriate adult's absence did not cause the admission.

options.label: C
options.text: The court must assess whether, in all the circumstances, the admission of the evidence would affect the fairness of the proceedings.

options.label: D
options.text: The evidence is admissible only if the prosecution can prove the admission would have been made even if the appropriate adult had been present.

options.label: E
options.text: The appropriate adult's failure is a matter for civil action against them, not for exclusion of evidence.

questions.explanation: Section 78 requires a holistic assessment of fairness. The breach of Code C (absence of the appropriate adult) is serious, particularly for a vulnerable suspect. The court will consider: the duration and context of the absence; whether the suspect was questioned during that time; the susceptibility of the suspect; and whether the admission appears causally linked to the absence. The judge might exclude the specific admission made during the absence, or potentially the whole interview if the breach tainted its overall integrity. There is no automatic rule; it is a discretion based on the impact...

questions.text: At a trial for assault occasioning actual bodily harm, the defendant, Leo, testifies. During his evidence-in-chief, his barrister asks him: "Mr. Smith, the victim, has a history of violence, doesn't he?" Leo replies, "Yes, he's known for starting fights." The prosecution had not previously adduced any evidence about Smith's character. The prosecution now applies to admit Leo's previous conviction for assault from two years ago. Through which gateway is Leo's previous conviction MOST likely admissible?

options.label: A
options.text: It is important explanatory evidence.

options.label: B
options.text: It is relevant to an important matter in issue between the defendant and the prosecution, namely, Leo's propensity for violence.

options.label: C
options.text: The defendant has made an attack on another person's character (the victim, Mr. Smith).

options.label: D
options.text: It is evidence to correct a false impression given by the defendant.

options.label: E
options.text: It has substantial probative value in relation to the victim's credibility.

questions.explanation: Gateway (g) of section 101(1) allows evidence of the defendant's bad character to be admitted if "the defendant has made an attack on another person's character." An "attack on another person's character" is defined in section 106(1) as evidence adduced by the defendant, or a question asked by him (or on his behalf), which is likely to undermine the witness's credibility, or which imputes misconduct on his part (other than evidence relating to the alleged facts of the offence). By stating that the victim is "known for starting fights," Leo (through his counsel) has imputed misconduct (a propen...

questions.text: In a magistrates’ court trial for common assault, the defendant, Mark, is representing himself. The prosecutor is a young solicitor, Chloe. During her examination-in-chief of the victim, Chloe asks, "You saw Mark raise his fist and punch you, didn't you?" The legal adviser interrupts and advises Chloe that her question is improper. Why is this question likely to be considered improper at this stage of the trial?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it calls for an opinion from the witness, not a fact.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a leading question, which is generally prohibited during examination-in-chief.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is argumentative and assumes facts not yet in evidence.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a leading question, which is generally prohibited during examination-in-chief with no exceptions.

options.label: E
options.text: Because it is a question that the witness is not competent to answer.

questions.explanation: The rule against leading questions is a fundamental rule of evidence during examination-in-chief. A leading question is one that suggests the desired answer within the question itself (e.g., "He punched you, didn't he?"). During examination-in-chief, the party calling the witness must generally use open, non-leading questions to allow the witness to give their evidence in their own words, without being led. This ensures the evidence is the witness's own account. The prohibition is relaxed for non-controversial introductory matters or to help a struggling witness, but for a central, disputed fa...

questions.text: At a Crown Court trial for fraud, the defendant's wife, Sarah, is called as a witness for the prosecution. Sarah is reluctant to testify. The prosecution applies for a witness summons to compel her attendance. Is Sarah a compellable witness for the prosecution in these circumstances?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, the spouse of a defendant is always a compellable witness for the prosecution.

options.label: B
options.text: No, a spouse is never compellable for the prosecution as it would undermine marital harmony.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but only if the offence involves an assault on, or a sexual offence against, a person under 16.

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on the offence. She is compellable for the prosecution only for specified offences.

options.label: E
options.text: No, she is competent but not compellable, as she could incriminate herself.

questions.explanation: The compellability of a spouse is governed by section 80 of PACE 1984. The general rule is that the spouse of a defendant is a competent witness for the prosecution but is not compellable. However, there are key exceptions where the spouse is compellable. These are listed in section 80(3) and include, among others: where the offence charged involves an assault on, or injury or threat of injury to, the spouse or a person under 16; or a sexual offence alleged to have been committed against a person under 16. For fraud, which does not fall into these categories, Sarah would likely not be a compel...

questions.text: During a Crown Court trial for robbery, the prosecution calls a witness, Liam, who is 14 years old. Defence counsel objects, arguing that Liam is not competent to give evidence due to his age. The judge decides to conduct a preliminary inquiry. What is the correct legal test for determining the competence of a child witness?

options.label: A
options.text: The child must understand the solemnity of the oath and the difference between truth and lies.

options.label: B
options.text: The child is presumed competent. The test is whether the child can understand questions put to them and give answers that can be understood.

options.label: C
options.text: The child must be able to provide a coherent and consistent account of the events.

options.label: D
options.text: The child is only competent if a child psychologist confirms their cognitive ability.

options.label: E
options.text: The child must be over the age of 10, as per the doli incapax rule.

questions.explanation:
Section 53 of the Youth Justice and Criminal Evidence Act 1999 establishes that all persons are presumed competent to give evidence regardless of age. The presumption can be rebutted if it appears to the court that the witness is unable to (a) understand questions put to them as a witness, and (b) give answers that can be understood. This is a low threshold focused on basic communication, not intelligence, consistency, or understanding of the oath. For a child, the judge will conduct a simple conversation to assess this.
Option A is incorrect. This was part of the old common law test for takin...

questions.text: In a magistrates' court trial for driving without insurance, the defendant, David, is representing himself. The prosecutor is a trainee solicitor, Anna. Anna, in her closing speech, says to the magistrates: "You must find the defendant guilty because he has produced no evidence to show he was insured. The burden is on him to prove he was insured, and he has failed to do so." What is the most accurate statement regarding the legal burden of proof in this context?

options.label: A
options.text: Anna is correct; for this strict liability regulatory offence, the legal burden shifts to the defendant to prove he was insured.

options.label: B
options.text: Anna is incorrect; the legal burden of proving all elements of the offence, including the lack of insurance, remains on the prosecution throughout.

options.label: C
options.text: Anna is partially correct; the defendant bears an evidential burden to raise the issue of insurance, but the legal burden of disproving it remains on the prosecution.

options.label: D
options.text: Anna is incorrect; the defendant bears no burden whatsoever, evidential or legal.

options.label: E
options.text: The burden depends on whether the defendant testifies.

questions.explanation: The golden thread of English criminal law, established in Woolmington v DPP [1935] AC 462, is that the prosecution bears the legal (persuasive) burden of proving every element of the offence beyond reasonable doubt. For the offence of driving without insurance, the prosecution must prove the defendant was driving and that he was not insured. There is no common law or statutory exception that reverses the legal burden for this offence. The defendant may choose to provide evidence of insurance, but he is not obliged to do so, and his failure to do so does not relieve the prosecution of its burde...

questions.text: At the start of a Crown Court trial, the jury has been sworn in. The defendant's barrister, Mr. Collins, needs to address the judge to raise a legal point in the absence of the jury. He begins, "Judge, if I may..." What is the correct mode of address for a Circuit Judge in the Crown Court?

options.label: A
options.text: "My Lord"

options.label: B
options.text: "Your Honour"

options.label: C
options.text: "Sir" or "Madam"

options.label: D
options.text: "Your Worship"

options.label: E
options.text: "Judge"

questions.explanation:
In the Crown Court, a Circuit Judge is addressed as "Your Honour." A High Court Judge is addressed as "My Lord" or "My Lady." In the magistrates' court, lay magistrates are addressed as "Your Worships" and a District Judge as "Sir" or "Madam." Using the correct mode of address is a fundamental aspect of courtroom etiquette and demonstrates respect for the court.
Option A is incorrect. This is for a High Court Judge.
Option C is incorrect. This is for a District Judge in the magistrates' court.
Option D is incorrect. This is for lay magistrates.
Option E is incorrect. While sometimes used collo...

questions.text: During a trial for burglary, the prosecution calls a security guard, Ben. In examination-in-chief, the prosecutor asks, "What did you see when you entered the storage room?" Ben replies, "I saw a man running out. I couldn't see his face." The prosecutor then asks, "That man was the defendant, wasn't it?" Defence counsel objects. What is the best ground for the objection?

options.label: A
options.text: The question is irrelevant.

options.label: B
options.text: The question calls for hearsay.

options.label: C
options.text: The question is leading.

options.label: D
options.text: The witness has already said he couldn't see the face, so he is not competent to answer.

options.label: E
options.text: The question is compound.

questions.explanation:
This is a clear leading question. The witness has given no evidence identifying the defendant. The question "That man was the defendant, wasn't it?" directly suggests the desired answer (that it was the defendant). This is prohibited during examination-in-chief, especially on a central and disputed issue like identity. The prosecutor should ask open questions such as, "Did you recognise the man?" or "Can you describe the man?"
Option A is incorrect. The identity of the man is highly relevant.
Option B is incorrect. The question does not call for an out-of-court statement; it calls for the witn...

questions.text: In a trial for witness intimidation, the prosecution wishes to call the defendant's 12-year-old daughter, Chloe, to give evidence about a conversation she overheard at home. The defence strongly objects, arguing it would be traumatising for her and that she is too young. What is the court's first step in determining whether Chloe can give evidence?

options.label: A
options.text: To order a psychological assessment to determine if she is fit to testify.

options.label: B
options.text: To presume she is competent and proceed unless she appears unable to understand questions and give understandable answers.

options.label: C
options.text: To refuse to allow her to testify due to her age and the potential familial conflict.

options.label: D
options.text: To require her evidence to be given by video-link with a screen.

options.label: E
options.text: To hold a voir dire where she is cross-examined by both advocates on her understanding.

questions.explanation:
As per section 53 of the Youth Justice and Criminal Evidence Act 1999, all persons are presumed competent regardless of age. The burden is on the party challenging competence to rebut this presumption. The court will conduct a preliminary inquiry, usually by the judge asking the child simple, non-threatening questions about unrelated matters (e.g., their age, school, a favourite TV show) to assess if they can understand questions and give intelligible answers. This is a low threshold.
Option A is incorrect. A psychological assessment is not the first step and is only ordered in exceptional cir...

questions.text: In a Crown Court trial, the prosecution calls an expert witness, Dr. Evans, to give evidence on DNA analysis. During examination-in-chief, the prosecutor asks, "Doctor, based on your analysis, is it your opinion that the DNA on the knife matches the defendant's?" What type of question is this, and is it permissible?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a leading question and is permissible because it is examination-in-chief of an expert.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a non-leading question and is permissible.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a leading question and is generally not permissible in examination-in-chief.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a hypothetical question and is not permissible without a proper foundation.

options.label: E
options.text: It is a compound question and should be broken down.

questions.explanation:
The question is leading because it suggests the desired answer ("matches the defendant's"). The general rule is that leading questions are not allowed in examination-in-chief. This rule applies to all witnesses, including experts. The proper form would be an open question such as, "What were the results of your DNA analysis?" or "What is your opinion regarding the DNA found on the knife?" There are limited exceptions to the rule against leading questions (e.g., on introductory, non-contentious matters), but the central conclusion of an expert is contentious and should not be led.
Option A is i...

questions.text: Thomas is on trial in the Crown Court for grievous bodily harm. His defence is that he was acting in self-defence. He wishes to call his wife, Eleanor, to give evidence that the victim had a reputation for violence in their neighbourhood and that she heard the victim threaten Thomas the week before. Thomas’s barrister informs the court that Eleanor is reluctant to testify because she fears it will damage her marriage. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding Eleanor’s competence and compellability?

options.label: A
options.text: Eleanor is competent but not compellable for the defence.

options.label: B
options.text: Eleanor is both competent and compellable for the defence.

options.label: C
options.text: Eleanor is competent but not compellable due to the evidence's nature.

options.label: D
options.text: Eleanor is not competent to give opinion evidence.

options.label: E
options.text: Eleanor is not compellable as her evidence is not directly relevant.

questions.explanation:
Under section 80 of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act (PACE) 1984, the spouse or civil partner of a defendant is competent and compellable to give evidence for the defendant. This is a clear rule. Her reluctance is irrelevant to compellability; if she is subpoenaed, she must attend and give evidence, and can be held in contempt if she refuses. Her evidence about the victim’s reputation and threats is relevant to the defence of self-defence (to support the defendant’s state of mind and reasonableness of his actions).
Option A is incorrect. A spouse is compellable for the defence. It is for t...

questions.text: During a trial in the magistrates’ court for theft, the defendant, Michael, represents himself. While cross-examining the security guard who detained him, Michael becomes agitated and shouts, “You’re a liar! You’re only saying this because you’re racist!” The lay bench of three magistrates is presided over by a legally qualified justice’s clerk. The prosecutor rises to object. What is the correct mode of address for the prosecutor to use when addressing the bench?

options.label: A
options.text: “Your Worships”

options.label: B
options.text: “My Lord”

options.label: C
options.text: “Sir”

options.label: D
options.text: “Your Honour, I object.”

options.label: E
options.text: “Madam Chairman.”

questions.explanation:
The correct collective form of address for a bench of lay magistrates is “Your Worships.” The defendant, even when unrepresented, must conduct himself appropriately. The appropriate immediate judicial response is to assert control by giving a firm warning about proper conduct and the importance of respectful questioning. .
Option B is incorrect. The mode of address “My Lord” is for Crown Court judges.
Option C is incorrect. The mode of address “Sir” is too informal.
Option D is incorrect. “Your Honour” is for a District Judge not a lay bench.
Option E is incorrect. “Your Worships” is the stand...

questions.text: Sophia pleads guilty to three separate offences: (1) assault occasioning actual bodily harm (ABH) on a stranger in a pub fight (category 2, starting point 1 year); (2) theft of a phone from a bag during the same incident; (3) criminal damage to a shop window committed a week later. The judge sentences her to 12 months for the ABH, 3 months for the theft, and 2 months for the criminal damage. Which of the following principles is the judge most likely to apply when deciding whether these sentences should run concurrently or consecutively?

options.label: A
options.text: All sentences should run concurrently as they arose from a single incident.

options.label: B
options.text: Sentences for offences arising from the same incident should be concurrent; sentences for unrelated offences should be consecutive.

options.label: C
options.text: Sentences should always be consecutive to reflect the totality of offending.

options.label: D
options.text: Sentences should be concurrent if the offences are of a similar type.

options.label: E
options.text: The judge has complete discretion; there is no guiding principle.

questions.explanation:
The general principle is that sentences for offences arising out of the same incident or single transaction should be concurrent, as they represent one course of criminal conduct. Sentences for offences arising from separate incidents should be consecutive, as they represent distinct offending. Here, the ABH and theft arose from the same pub incident and should be concurrent. The criminal damage occurred a week later and is a separate incident, so a consecutive sentence is appropriate. The judge must then apply the totality principle to ensure the overall sentence is just and proportionate.
Op...

questions.text: Daniel, aged 19 with no previous convictions, pleads guilty to robbery. The guideline indicates a starting point of 5 years’ custody. In mitigation, his barrister argues he acted under the influence of an older co-defendant, has shown genuine remorse, and has a promising future. The judge decides to impose a sentence of 3 years’ detention in a young offender institution but suspends the sentence for 2 years. Which of the following is a LEGAL prerequisite for imposing a suspended sentence order?

options.label: A
options.text: The sentence must be between 14 days and 2 years.

options.label: B
options.text: The offender must have no previous convictions.

options.label: C
options.text: The judge must be satisfied that the circumstances are so exceptional that custody can be suspended.

options.label: D
options.text: The offence must not be one specified in the Sentencing Code as being ineligible for suspension.

options.label: E
options.text: A pre-sentence report must recommend suspension.

questions.explanation: Under section 189 of the Sentencing Code, a suspended sentence order can be imposed for a custodial sentence of between 14 days and 2 years (inclusive). The threshold for imposing a custodial sentence must first be met (the offence is “so serious that neither a fine alone nor a community sentence can be justified”). If that threshold is met and the custodial term is within the 14-day to 2-year range, the court may suspend it if it is “in the interests of justice” to do so. There is no requirement for exceptional circumstances, though suspension is not automatic. Previous convictions are a fact...

questions.text: Emma is convicted after trial of fraud. The prosecution version is that she orchestrated a complex scam over six months. Emma’s basis of plea is that she played a minor role for only two weeks under duress. The prosecution does not accept her version. The judge is unsure which version to believe for sentencing purposes. What is the correct procedural step for the judge to take?

options.label: A
options.text: Sentence on the prosecution version, as the defendant was convicted by the jury.

options.label: B
options.text: Sentence on the defendant’s version, as she is entitled to the benefit of the doubt.

options.label: C
options.text: Hold a Newton hearing to determine the facts on the balance of probabilities.

options.label: D
options.text: Impose an average sentence between the two potential outcomes.

options.label: E
options.text: Hold a Newton hearing to determine the facts beyond reasonable doubt.

questions.explanation: Where there is a dispute about facts material to sentence that was not resolved by the jury’s verdict, and the prosecution does not accept the defendant’s version, the judge should hold a Newton hearing (R v Newton (1982)). This is a fact-finding hearing where the judge hears evidence from both sides and decides, on the balance of probabilities, which version to accept. The defendant has the right to give evidence. Sentencing on the prosecution’s untested assertions (A) or an arbitrary compromise (D) is wrong. The defendant is not automatically entitled to the benefit of the doubt on sentencin...

questions.text: David, aged 40, is convicted after trial of a s.20 GBH. The guideline indicates a category 2 offence with a starting point of 2 years 6 months and a range of 1 year 9 months to 3 years 6 months. He has several similar previous convictions. The judge sentences him to 3 years’ imprisonment. What is the maximum discount David would have received for a guilty plea entered at the first stage of proceedings?

options.label: A
options.text: One-third

options.label: B
options.text: One-quarter

options.label: C
options.text: One-tenth.

options.label: D
options.text: No discount

options.label: E
options.text: The judge has discretion to award any discount up to one-third.

questions.explanation: Under the Sentencing Council’s Guilty Plea guideline, the maximum reduction is one-third, applied where the plea was indicated at the first stage of proceedings. The reduction is applied to the sentence determined after assessing seriousness and before considering totality. If David had pleaded guilty at the first opportunity, his sentence of 3 years (post-trial) would have been reduced by one-third, likely to 2 years. Since he was convicted after trial, he receives no discount (D), but the question asks for the maximum discount he would have received.

questions.text: Which of the following is a legitimate aim of sentencing that a judge must have regard to under the sentencing code?

options.label: A
options.text: The rehabilitation of offenders.

options.label: B
options.text: The appeasement of public opinion.

options.label: C
options.text: Retribution as the primary aim.

options.label: D
options.text: The financial cost to the state of different sentences.

options.label: E
options.text: Setting an example to co-defendants.

questions.explanation: Section 57 of the Sentencing Code sets out the five purposes of sentencing: (a) punishment, (b) reduction of crime (including deterrence), (c) reform and rehabilitation, (d) protection of the public, and (e) making reparation. The court must have regard to these. Rehabilitation is one of them..

questions.text: An offender is convicted of three separate burglaries of commercial premises. He is sentenced to 18 months for each. The judge orders that the sentences for Burglary 1 and Burglary 2 run consecutively (total 3 years), and the sentence for Burglary 3 run concurrently with the others. The total sentence is therefore 3 years. What principle is the judge applying by making the third sentence concurrent?

options.label: A
options.text: The parity principle.

options.label: B
options.text: The totality principle.

options.label: C
options.text: The principle of concurrent sentences.

options.label: D
options.text: The principle that the maximum aggregate sentence for multiple either-way offences in the magistrates’ court is 12 months.

options.label: E
options.text: The judge has made an error; all three should be consecutive.

questions.explanation:
The totality principle requires the total sentence to be just and proportionate. By making the third 18-month sentence concurrent rather than consecutive, the judge has reduced the total from 4.5 years to 3 years, likely because 4.5 years was deemed excessive for the overall criminality. This “stepping back” to adjust the totality is the correct application of the principle.
Option A is incorrect. Parity relates to co-defendants.
Option D is incorrect. This is a Crown Court sentence; the 12-month magistrates’ limit is irrelevant.
Option E is incorrect. The judge’s approach is a standard method...

questions.text: In a Newton hearing, who bears the burden of proving the disputed facts, and to what standard?

options.label: A
options.text: The prosecution must prove its version beyond reasonable doubt.

options.label: B
options.text: The defence must prove its version on the balance of probabilities.

options.label: C
options.text: The judge decides on the balance of probabilities, with the burden on the party asserting a fact.

options.label: D
options.text: The prosecution must prove its version on the balance of probabilities.

options.label: E
options.text: The judge decides on the beyond reasonable doubt threshold , with the burden on the party asserting a fact.

questions.explanation:
In a Newton hearing, the judge decides factual disputes on the balance of probabilities. The general rule is that the party asserting a fact (e.g., the prosecution asserting an aggravating fact, or the defence asserting a mitigating fact) bears the evidential burden to raise it, and if raised, the judge decides. There is no fixed legal burden on one party; it is an inquisitorial process where the judge hears evidence.
Option A is incorrect. The beyond reasonable doubt standard applies to proving guilt, not sentencing facts.
Option B is incorrect. The burden is not always on the defence; if the...

questions.text: Jane Smith is convicted for theft, and a suspended sentence order (SSO) is imposed with a custodial term of 18 months, suspended for 2 years, and a rehabilitation requirement. During the operational period, Jane Smith commits a new offence of theft. What is the likely consequence for the SSO?

options.label: A
options.text: The suspended sentence is automatically activated in full.

options.label: B
options.text: The court must activate the suspended sentence unless it would be unjust to do so.

options.label: C
options.text: The court may extend the operational period or impose more onerous requirements.

options.label: D
options.text: The suspended sentence is irrelevant as a new offence has been committed.

options.label: E
options.text: The court must activate the sentence and order it to run consecutively to any sentence for the new offence.

questions.explanation:
Under Schedule 16 of the Sentencing Code, where an offender commits a new offence during the operational period of an SSO, the court must activate the suspended sentence (in whole or in part) unless it would be unjust to do so in view of all the circumstances, including the facts of the subsequent offence. There is a strong presumption in favour of activation. The activated sentence can be ordered to run concurrently or consecutively to the new sentence, with consecutively being the norm unless unjust.
Option A is incorrect. The court has a discretion not to activate if unjust.
Option C is inc...

questions.text: Mark was convicted of common assault in the magistrates' court. His solicitor, Mr Peter,  believes the magistrates misinterpreted the law on self-defence. He wants a higher court to review the legal ruling, but he does not want a complete rehearing of all the evidence. Which of the following is the most appropriate appeal route for Mark?

options.label: A
options.text: Appeal to the Crown Court against conviction and sentence.

options.label: B
options.text: Appeal to the High Court by way of case stated.

options.label: C
options.text: Apply for judicial review of the magistrates' decision.

options.label: D
options.text: Appeal directly to the Court of Appeal (Criminal Division).

options.label: E
options.text: Request a retrial in the magistrates' court.

questions.explanation: An appeal by way of case stated under section 111 of the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980 is the correct route where the challenge is solely on a point of law or that the magistrates acted in excess of jurisdiction. The magistrates are asked to state a case for the opinion of the High Court, which then reviews the legal issue without rehearsing the facts. A Crown Court appeal (A) is a full rehearing on the facts and law. Judicial review (C) is for procedural impropriety, not a mistaken interpretation of law on the facts. The Court of Appeal (D) only hears appeals from the Crown Court.

questions.text: Sophia is convicted of theft and given a community order by the magistrates' court. She wishes to appeal against both conviction and sentence. What is the procedure for lodging her appeal?

options.label: A
options.text: She must apply to the Crown Court for leave (permission) to appeal within 21 days.

options.label: B
options.text: She has an automatic right of appeal and must serve a notice of appeal on the magistrates' court and the prosecution within 21 days.

options.label: C
options.text: She must appeal to the High Court by lodging an appellant's notice within 28 days.

options.label: D
options.text: She has an automatic right of appeal and must serve a notice of appeal on the magistrates' court and the prosecution within 28 days..

options.label: E
