options.text: She can only appeal if she obtains leave from the Magistrates' Court.

questions.explanation: Under section 108 of the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980, a person convicted by a magistrates' court may appeal to the Crown Court against conviction and/or sentence. The appeal is as of right; no permission is required. The time limit is 21 days, (not 28 days) from the date of sentence (CrimPR 34.2). Notice must be given to the magistrates' court (which then transfers it to the Crown Court) and the prosecution. Leave is not required (A, E). The High Court routes (C) are for different types of challenge.

questions.text: David appeals to the Crown Court against his magistrates' court conviction for assault. At the Crown Court hearing, the judge sits with two magistrates. After hearing all the evidence again, they find David guilty and, considering his previous convictions, impose a sentence of 6 months' imprisonment. The original magistrates had given him a community order. Which of the following statements about the Crown Court's powers is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The Crown Court acted unlawfully; it cannot increase the sentence on appeal.

options.label: B
options.text: The Crown Court can impose any sentence that the magistrates' court could have imposed, which can be more severe than the original.

options.label: C
options.text: The Crown Court can only increase the sentence if the prosecution cross-appeals on the grounds of undue leniency.

options.label: D
options.text: The Crown Court can only vary the sentence if it quashes the conviction and then convicts on a different basis.

options.label: E
options.text: The Crown Court should have remitted the case back to the magistrates for resentencing.

questions.explanation: Upon an appeal from the magistrates' court, the Crown Court has the power under section 48 of the Senior Courts Act 1981 to "make any order that the magistrates' court could have made." This includes imposing a more severe sentence than the original one, which acts as a deterrent against frivolous appeals. This is sometimes called the "dismissal of frivolous appeals" power. There is no requirement for a prosecution cross-appeal.

questions.text: The Court of Appeal (Criminal Division) allows an appeal against conviction. It quashes the conviction but considers that a retrial is in the interests of justice. What is the Court's power in this situation?

options.label: A
options.text: It must order a retrial unless it is satisfied a fair trial is no longer possible.

options.label: B
options.text: It can order a retrial  if it is in the interests of justice.

options.label: C
options.text: It can only order a retrial for indictable offences.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no power to order a retrial; the defendant must be acquitted.

options.label: E
options.text: It can only order a retrial if the prosecution applies for one.

questions.explanation: Under section 7 of the Criminal Appeal Act 1968, if the Court of Appeal allows an appeal against conviction, it may order a retrial if it appears to the Court that the interests of justice so require. This power is not limited to indictable offences, nor is a prosecution application required. The court must consider all circumstances, including the time elapsed and fairness.

questions.text: On an appeal to the Crown Court against sentence only, what is the nature of the hearing?

options.label: A
options.text: A complete rehearing of the case, including the evidence of the offence.

options.label: B
options.text: A review of the sentencing decision based on the papers from the magistrates' court.

options.label: C
options.text: A rehearing on the question of sentence only; the conviction is not revisited.

options.label: D
options.text: A hearing where the defendant can only argue that the sentence was wrong in law.

options.label: E
options.text: An oral hearing only if the Crown Court judge grants permission.

questions.explanation: On a sentence-only appeal to the Crown Court, the appeal is confined to the sentence. The conviction is not reopened. The hearing is a rehearing on sentence, meaning the Crown Court hears submissions and evidence relevant to sentence (e.g., mitigation, antecedents) and can impose any sentence the magistrates could have imposed. It is not a full rehearing of the case (A) nor a paper review (B).

questions.text: Which of the following is a valid ground of appeal against conviction from the Crown Court to the Court of Appeal?

options.label: A
options.text: The conviction is "unsafe."

options.label: B
options.text: The verdict was "perverse."

options.label: C
options.text: The jury was biased.

options.label: D
options.text: New evidence has emerged that might prove innocence.

options.label: E
options.text: All of the above.

questions.explanation: Under section 2 of the Criminal Appeal Act 1968, the sole ground for allowing an appeal against conviction is that the conviction is "unsafe." All the scenarios listed (B, C, D) are specific instances that could render a conviction unsafe. "Unsafe" is a broad term encompassing errors of law, misdirections, procedural unfairness, fresh evidence, and, in rare cases, perversity.

questions.text: Samuel is convicted of fraud in the crown court and sentenced to 3 years in Belmarsh prison. Mr Adam Johnson, the Attorney General is not satisfied with this sentence and then refers the sentence to the Court of Appeal as unduly lenient under section 36 of the Criminal Justice Act 1988. What is the Court of Appeal's power if it agrees?

options.label: A
options.text: It may increase the sentence to one it considers appropriate.

options.label: B
options.text: It must order a retrial on sentence.

options.label: C
options.text: It can only issue a declaration that the sentence was unduly lenient.

options.label: D
options.text: It can vary the sentence but not to a term longer than the original sentencing judge could have imposed.

options.label: E
options.text: It can only increase the sentence only if the offender is present in court.

questions.explanation: On an Attorney General's Reference, if the Court of Appeal agrees the sentence was unduly lenient, it may quash the sentence and substitute any sentence the Crown Court could have imposed (which may be more severe), provided it is not greater than the statutory maximum. The offender's presence is generally required, but the court can proceed in absence in certain circumstances . The power is to resentence, not just declare.

questions.text: Mathew is convicted for manslaughter in the Crown Court and sentenced to 15 years in His Majesty’s prison. Mathew’s solicitor, Mr Peter, wants to appeal his conviction. What is the time limit for applying for leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal against conviction from the Crown Court?

options.label: A
options.text: 21 days from the date of conviction.

options.label: B
options.text: 28 days from the date of conviction.

options.label: C
options.text: 28 days from the date of sentence.

options.label: D
options.text: 21 days from the date of sentence

options.label: E
options.text: There is no strict time limit, but delay requires explanation.

questions.explanation: Under CrimPR 39.2, a defendant must serve an application for leave to appeal against conviction or sentence within 28 days of the date of the conviction (if appealing conviction) or the date of sentence (if appealing sentence, or conviction and sentence). In practice, for conviction appeals, the 28 days runs from the date of sentence, as that is the final disposal.

questions.text: Peter was convicted of robbery and sentenced to six years' imprisonment. He appealed against his sentence to the Court of Appeal (Criminal Division) on the grounds that it was manifestly excessive. The Court of Appeal heard the case, but the judges dismissed the appeal, upholding the original sentence. Peter’s solicitor, Sarah, believes the Court of Appeal made a significant error of law regarding the interpretation of sentencing guidelines that could affect many other cases. Peter now wishes to appeal this decision to the Supreme Court. Can Peter appeal to the Supreme Court?

options.label: A
options.text: No, there is no further appeal from the Court of Appeal on sentence.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, with leave from the Court of Appeal or the Supreme Court, if the Court of Appeal certifies a point of law of general public importance.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, with leave from the Court of Appeal only, if the Court of Appeal certifies a point of law of general public importance.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the Attorney General supports the appeal.

options.label: E
options.text: No, the Supreme Court only hears appeals on conviction, not sentence.

questions.explanation: A further appeal from the Court of Appeal (Criminal Division) to the Supreme Court is possible under section 33 of the Criminal Appeal Act 1968. The Court of Appeal must certify that a point of law of general public importance is involved, and either the Court of Appeal or the Supreme Court must grant leave to appeal. This applies to both conviction and sentence appeals.

questions.text: David was charged with assault (a summary-only offence). He pleaded not guilty and was tried in the Magistrates' Court. At the trial, David’s solicitor, Lucy, focused the defense on self-defence. David was convicted and sentenced to a community order. David decides to appeal his conviction to the Crown Court. While preparing for the appeal, a new witness, Samuel, comes forward. Samuel was standing across the street during the incident and claims he saw the "victim" strike David first. Samuel was not known to David and did not give evidence at the original trial. At the appeal hearing in the Crown Court, David’s counsel, Clare, informs the court that she intends to call Samuel to give oral evidence. Is this permitted?

options.label: A
options.text: No, fresh evidence is not allowed on a Crown Court appeal.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, the Crown Court appeal is a rehearing, and fresh evidence is generally admissible.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but only with the leave of the Crown Court judge.

options.label: D
options.text: No, the appeal is confined to the evidence that was before the magistrates.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only if the witness was unavailable at the original trial.

questions.explanation:
An appeal to the Crown Court is a rehearing (a trial de novo). The Crown Court hears the case afresh. Parties are not restricted to the evidence that was before the magistrates; they can call new witnesses and introduce new evidence. There is no requirement for leave or a test of unavailability.

questions.text: James, aged 16, is charged with robbery. He has no previous convictions. The victim was threatened but not physically injured. The Youth Court is considering whether to retain jurisdiction or send the case to the Crown Court under the "grave crimes" provisions. Which of the following is the correct legal test the Youth Court must apply when deciding whether to send the case to the Crown Court?

options.label: A
options.text: The Youth Court must send the case to the Crown Court because robbery is a "grave crime".

options.label: B
options.text: The Youth Court may send the case to the Crown Court only if it is of the opinion that, it ought to be possible to sentence the young person to a term of detention exceeding 2 years.

options.label: C
options.text: The Youth Court must send the case to the Crown Court

options.label: D
options.text: The Youth Court should always retain jurisdiction unless the young person is jointly charged with an adult.

options.label: E
options.text: The Youth Court may send the case to the Crown Court if the offence is so serious that only a custodial sentence of at least 4 years would be appropriate.

questions.explanation: The "grave crime" procedure is governed by section 24 of the Magistrates' Courts Act 1980. A youth court may send a case to the Crown Court if the offence is one for which an adult could be sentenced to 14 years or more, and the court is of the opinion that if the young person is found guilty, it ought to be possible to sentence them to a term of detention exceeding 2 years (the maximum the youth court can impose). This is a discretionary test based on the likely sentence, not automatic. The court must consider the specific facts and the Sentencing Council's guideline, "Sentencing Children and...

questions.text: Sophia, aged 15, is charged with actual bodily harm (ABH) under section 47 of the OAPA 1861 (maximum sentence for an adult is 5 years). She is charged jointly with her 22-year-old brother, Mark. They are alleged to have assaulted a neighbour together. They appear together at the adult magistrates' court for a first hearing. What is the MOST likely procedural outcome regarding venue for Sophia's trial?

options.label: A
options.text: Both Sophia and Mark will be tried together in the adult magistrates' court.

options.label: B
options.text: Both Sophia and Mark will be sent to the Crown Court for trial together.

options.label: C
options.text: Mark must be sent to the Crown Court and Sophia will be sent back to the youth court to be tried separately.

options.label: D
options.text: The magistrates must decide if it is in the interests of justice for them to be tried together; if so, Sophia can be sent to the Crown Court with Mark.

options.label: E
options.text: Sophia must be tried in the youth court; Mark must be tried in the adult magistrates' court.

questions.explanation:
The general rule is that youths should be tried in the youth court. However, when jointly charged with an adult, the court has a discretion under section 29 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1963. The magistrates can send the youth to the Crown Court to be tried with the adult if it is "in the interests of justice" to do so. The starting point is to send the youth back to the youth court, but the court must consider factors such as avoiding separate trials, the gravity of the offence, and the youth's age and maturity.
Option A is incorrect. Youths are not typically tried in the adult magis...

questions.text: Chloe, aged 16, is appearing before the Youth Court for the first time. She has been charged with assault occasioning actual bodily harm (ABH) following a physical altercation at her college. This is Chloe's first criminal offence, and she enters a guilty plea at the first available opportunity. The court reviews a pre-sentence report prepared by the Youth Offending Team (YOT). The report indicates that Chloe is deeply remorseful and has a supportive family environment. Which of the following is the most appropriate sentence for the court to impose on Chloe?

options.label: A
options.text: Absolute Discharge

options.label: B
options.text: Referral Order

options.label: C
options.text: Youth Rehabilitation Order (YRO)

options.label: D
options.text: Detention and Training Order (DTO)

options.label: E
options.text: Fines and Parental Binding Over

questions.explanation:
For a youth offender appearing in court for the first time who has pleaded guilty, a Referral Order is mandatory unless the court proposes to deal with them by way of an absolute discharge or a custodial sentence (s.22 Sentencing Act 2020).
Option A is incorrect because the scenario states the court has already decided an absolute discharge is not appropriate given the harm caused.
Option C is incorrect because a Youth Rehabilitation Order (YRO) is a community sentence used when a Referral Order is not mandatory (e.g., if the defendant pleaded not guilty and was convicted, or has previous conv...

questions.text: James, aged 15, appears before the Youth Court for sentencing. He previously pleaded not guilty to robbery, but was convicted after a trial. James has a long record of previous convictions, including multiple counts of theft and battery. He is currently subject to a Youth Rehabilitation Order (YRO), which he has breached three times. The Youth Offending Team (YOT) report states that James is at high risk of reoffending and has refused to engage with community-based interventions. The Magistrates determine that the offence is so serious that neither a fine nor a community sentence can be justified. Which of the following is the most appropriate sentence for the court to impose on James?

options.label: A
options.text: Referral Order

options.label: B
options.text: Youth Rehabilitation Order (YRO)

options.label: C
options.text: Detention and Training Order (DTO)

options.label: D
options.text: Section 250 Detention

options.label: E
options.text: Absolute Discharge

questions.explanation:
A Detention and Training Order (DTO) is the standard custodial sentence for young offenders aged 12–17. It is appropriate here because James has been convicted of an imprisonable offence (robbery), the "custody threshold" has been passed (the offence is so serious a community order isn't justified), and he is a "persistent offender" who has failed to engage with previous community orders.
Option A is incorrect because Referral Orders are generally for first-time guilty pleas; James pleaded not guilty and has a prior record.
Option B is incorrect because the court has already determined the cus...

questions.text: Luke, aged 17, is appearing for sentencing in the Youth Court. He pleaded guilty to possession of a blade in a public place and assault occasioning actual bodily harm (ABH). The facts of the case show that Luke used a knife to threaten a group of teenagers and caused a deep wound to one victim’s arm. Although Luke has only one previous caution, the Magistrates are alarmed by the level of violence and the use of a weapon. The legal advisor confirms that the offence is "manifestly serious" and that the safety of the public is a primary concern. The court concludes that the only appropriate way to address the risk is a period of incarceration. Which of the following is the most appropriate sentence for the court to impose on Luke?

options.label: A
options.text: Referral Order

options.label: B
options.text: Youth Rehabilitation Order (YRO)

options.label: C
options.text: Detention and Training Order (DTO)

options.label: D
options.text: Conditional Discharge

options.label: E
options.text: Attendance Centre Order

questions.explanation:
Even though a Referral Order is often mandatory for first-time guilty pleas, there is a specific exception: the court is not required to make a Referral Order if it intends to impose a custodial sentence (DTO). Because Luke’s offence involved a knife and significant harm, the court can find that the custody threshold is met, making a DTO (which ranges from 4 months to 2 years) the appropriate choice.
Option A is incorrect because the court’s intention to impose custody overrides the mandatory referral order rule.
Option B is incorrect as a YRO is a community-based sentence, and the court has d...

questions.text: Tom, aged 17, is charged with manslaughter (a "grave crime"). The Youth Court decides to send him to the Crown Court for trial. He is convicted. The Crown Court judge is determining sentence. Which of the following sentences is the Crown Court judge NOT able to impose?

options.label: A
options.text: A Detention and Training Order (DTO).

options.label: B
options.text: A Youth Rehabilitation Order (YRO).

options.label: C
options.text: A sentence of detention for a term up to the adult maximum for manslaughter.

options.label: D
options.text: A Referral Order.

options.label: E
options.text: A sentence of long-term detention for life.

questions.explanation:
A Referral Order is only available in the youth court. It cannot be imposed by the Crown Court. The Crown Court can impose a DTO (up to 24 months), a YRO (with different requirements), detention under section 250 (for grave crimes where a DTO is insufficient), and in the most serious cases (like manslaughter), a life sentence under section 250.
Option A is incorrect. The Crown Court can impose a DTO.
Option B is incorrect. The Crown Court can impose a YRO.
Option C is incorrect. This is the standard sentence for a grave crime where a DTO is insufficient.
Option E is incorrect. A life sentence ...

questions.text: In the Youth Court, a 12-year-old, Amy, is found guilty of theft. She has no previous convictions. The court is considering a Referral Order. Her parents are present. What is the role of Amy's parents in the Referral Order process?

options.label: A
options.text: They must consent to the order being made.

options.label: B
options.text: They must attend the meetings of the Youth Offender Panel.

options.label: C
options.text: They have no formal role; the process is solely between the YOT and the young person.

options.label: D
options.text: They can be bound over to ensure her good behaviour instead of a Referral Order being made.

options.label: E
options.text: They are legally liable to pay any financial compensation ordered by the panel.

questions.explanation:
A key feature of the Referral Order process is the involvement of parents. They are legally required to attend the Youth Offender Panel meetings unless the court excuses them for a good reason. Their involvement is considered crucial to the rehabilitative process.
Option A is incorrect. Consent is not required from parents for the order itself.
Option C is incorrect. Parents have a formal, required role.
Option D is incorrect. Binding over a parent is a separate order that can be made alongside or instead of other sentences, but it does not replace the mandatory nature of a Referral Order for ...

questions.text: Ethan, aged 15, appeared before the Youth Court for sentencing after pleading guilty to a charge of robbery. Ethan has a significant history of violent offending and had recently failed to comply with the requirements of a Youth Rehabilitation Order (YRO). The Magistrates concluded that the custody threshold was clearly passed due to the level of force used. Ethan was sentenced to a 12-month Detention and Training Order (DTO). Ethan has now completed exactly six months of his sentence in a Secure Training Centre. What happens during the second half of the DTO?

options.label: A
options.text: He is released on licence subject to supervision by the Youth Offending Team.

options.label: B
options.text: He is released unconditionally.

options.label: C
options.text: He serves the remainder under home detention curfew (tagging).

options.label: D
options.text: He is transferred to an open prison for the remainder of the term.

options.label: E
options.text: The second half is remitted if his behaviour in custody is good.

questions.explanation:
A DTO is split equally. The first half is served in a secure youth detention centre. The second half is served under supervision in the community by the YOT. If the offender breaches the supervision, they can be recalled to serve the remainder in custody.
Option B is incorrect. Release is conditional on supervision.
Option C is incorrect. Home detention curfew is an adult provision.
Option D is incorrect. The youth estate is separate from the adult prison system.
Option E is incorrect. The term is not remitted; the structure is fixed by statute.
L- Preliminary considerations for the use of the...

questions.text: Gareth is charged with theft and will stand trial in the Crown Court sitting in Cardiff. His first language is Welsh, and he informs his solicitor that he wishes to have his entire trial (including all evidence and legal submissions) conducted in Welsh. The solicitor makes a formal request to the court. The listing officer is concerned about the availability of a Welsh-speaking judge and the cost of simultaneous translation for any non-Welsh speaking participants. What is the fundamental legal principle governing Gareth's request?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of Welsh is a matter for the court's discretion.

options.label: B
options.text: Any party or witness in legal proceedings in Wales has the absolute right to use the Welsh language.

options.label: C
options.text: The defendant has a right to a trial in Welsh, but this is conditional on the court's resources.

options.label: D
options.text: The right to use Welsh is limited to oral submissions by the defendant

options.label: E
options.text: The defendant can require the jury to be composed solely of Welsh speakers

questions.explanation: The Welsh Language Act 1993 and the Welsh Language (Wales) Measure 2011 establish the principle of equality between Welsh and English in the conduct of public business in Wales, including the courts. The Practice Direction (Welsh Language) [2022] sets out that any party or witness in criminal proceedings in Wales has the right to use Welsh. It imposes a duty on the court to make the necessary arrangements (interpreters, translation of documents, a Welsh-speaking judge if possible) to give full effect to this right. This right is not discretionary or contingent on resources, though practical ar...

questions.text: During a plea and trial preparation hearing (PTPH) at Merthyr Tydfil Crown Court, the defendant, Rhys, who is representing himself, addresses the judge in Welsh. The judge, who does not speak Welsh, states, "Mr. Rhys, this is an English-speaking court. You must speak in English so that I and the other participants can understand you. An interpreter can be provided to translate your English into Welsh if you need assistance." Is the judge's direction correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, the judge must be able to understand proceedings directly

options.label: B
options.text: No, the defendant has the right to speak Welsh

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, but only if the judge orders it in the interests of expediting the trial.

options.label: D
options.text: No, but the defendant must provide and pay for his own interpreter to translate his Welsh into English for the court.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, because the defendant is representing himself

questions.explanation:
Under the Welsh Language Scheme for HM Courts and Tribunals Service and the relevant Practice Direction, a party has the right to use Welsh. If the judge or other participants do not understand Welsh, the court has a duty to arrange for competent simultaneous interpretation into English. The cost is borne by the court, not the defendant. The judge cannot compel the defendant to speak English.
Option A is incorrect. It directly contradicts the statutory right to use Welsh.
Option C is incorrect. Expediency is not a valid reason to deny the right.
Option D is incorrect. The duty and cost of inte...

questions.text: At a preliminary hearing for a case to be tried at Mold Crown Court, the defendant, a Welsh speaker, informs the court that he wishes to waive his right to a trial in Welsh and proceed in English. His solicitor confirms this instruction. The judge is fluent in Welsh and would prefer to conduct the trial in Welsh. Can the judge override the defendant's waiver and order that the trial be conducted in Welsh?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, if the judge believes conducting the trial in Welsh would be in the overall interests of justice, particularly given the location of the court.

options.label: B
options.text: No, the choice of language is a personal right of the defendant, which he can waive..

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because the judge has control over the proceedings

options.label: D
options.text: No, unless the prosecution also agrees to proceed in Welsh.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only if all other participants agree to use Welsh.

questions.explanation:
The right to use Welsh is a right vested in the parties and witnesses, not the court. It is a right that can be waived by the person who holds it. If a defendant clearly and voluntarily waives the right to proceed in Welsh, the court must respect that choice and conduct the proceedings in English. The judge's personal preference or the location of the court is irrelevant.
Option A is incorrect. The "interests of justice" do not trump the defendant's personal waiver of his own right.
Option C is incorrect. The judge's control over procedure does not extend to compelling a party to use a languag...

questions.text: In a magistrates' court in Swansea, the defendant, Gwyneth, indicates that she wishes to have her trial conducted entirely in Welsh. She is represented by a solicitor who only speaks English. The prosecution is ready to proceed. The legal adviser informs the court that listing a Welsh-language trial will require a bilingual judge or magistrate and a Welsh-speaking clerk, causing a three-month adjournment. What is the court's primary obligation in this situation?

options.label: A
options.text: To refuse the request to avoid delay, as the defendant's solicitor can translate for her.

options.label: B
options.text: To proceed in English because the defendant has legal representation in English.

options.label: C
options.text: To adjourn the case and make the necessary arrangements to conduct the trial in Welsh.

options.label: D
options.text: To proceed in English as that is the official court language

options.label: E
options.text: To ask the defendant to choose between a speedy trial in English or a delayed trial in Welsh.

questions.explanation:
The defendant's right under Section 22 of the Welsh Language Act 1993 is to use Welsh in all stages of criminal proceedings. If she elects for a Welsh-language trial, the court is under a duty to facilitate this, which includes ensuring a bilingual tribunal and supporting staff. An adjournment to make these arrangements is a necessary consequence of upholding this statutory right. The court cannot compel her to proceed in English for convenience.
Option A is incorrect. The right cannot be refused to avoid delay, and a solicitor is not a suitable interpreter for court proceedings.
Option B is i...

questions.text: In 2023, Theo granted Zoe the right to walk across a paved path on his land to access her adjacent cottage. The agreement was in writing and signed by both, but not executed as a deed. Theo has now sold his land to Imogen, who wishes to block the path. Zoe claims her right is binding on Imogen. Which of the following best describes the nature of Zoe’s right and its enforceability against Imogen?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a legal easement created in writing, binding on Imogen under s.52 LPA 1925.

options.label: B
options.text: It is an equitable easement created by a valid contract, binding on Imogen if protected by notice.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a mere licence, personal to Zoe and not binding on Imogen.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a legal profit à prendre, requiring a deed, and is void for lack of formality.

options.label: E
options.text: It is an equitable lease, binding if Zoe is in actual occupation.

questions.explanation:
An easement requires a deed to be legal (s.52 LPA 1925). A written agreement signed by both parties satisfies s.2 LP(MP)A 1989 for a contract to grant an easement, creating an equitable easement. For it to bind a purchaser (Imogen) in registered land, it must be protected by a notice.
A is incorrect because a deed is required for a legal easement. C is incorrect as the right, if intended to be proprietary, is more than a licence. D is incorrect as it is not a profit. E is incorrect as it is not a lease.

questions.text: Liam owns a freehold house. He installs a large, ornate Victorian greenhouse in the garden. It rests on its own weight on concrete pads but is not fixed to the ground. It is connected to mains water for irrigation. Liam sells the house to Noah. The contract is silent on the greenhouse. On completion, Noah claims the greenhouse is a fixture and included in the sale. Liam argues it is a chattel he can remove. Applying the two-stage test from Holland v Hodgson, which of the following is the MOST decisive factor in determining the greenhouse’s status?

options.label: A
options.text: The fact it is connected to mains water.

options.label: B
options.text: The degree of annexation.

options.label: C
options.text: The purpose of annexation.

options.label: D
options.text: The value of the greenhouse relative to the house.

options.label: E
options.text: The size

questions.explanation: In the two-stage test, the purpose of annexation is the decisive consideration (Holland v Hodgson; Chelsea Yacht). The court asks whether the item was attached to enhance the land (fixture) or for the better use of the item itself (chattel). B (degree) is the first stage but not decisive. A is a factor under degree/purpose but not the most decisive. D and E are incorrect.

questions.text: Ava owns a freehold field. In 2022, she orally agreed with Ben that he could extract sand from a pit on the field for his pottery business for 5 years, in return for £1000 per annum. Ben has paid and taken sand for two years. Ava now sells the field to Chloe, who discovers Ben’s activities and seeks to stop him. What is the nature of Ben’s right and is it binding on Chloe?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a legal profit à prendre for a term of years, granted orally, and binding on Chloe as an overriding interest.

options.label: B
options.text: It is an equitable profit à prendre, created by a valid oral contract, but void against Chloe for lack of registration.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a licence, revocable by Ava, and not binding on Chloe.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a legal lease of the sand pit, created orally for less than 3 years, and binding on Chloe.

options.label: E
options.text: It is a restrictive covenant, requiring a deed, and is void.

questions.explanation:
A profit à prendre is a legal interest in land requiring a deed (s.52 LPA 1925). An oral agreement may create a valid contract under s.2 LP(MP)A 1989 if all terms are in writing and signed, but here it is oral, so it may be a valid equitable interest if supported by part performance/estoppel. However, as an equitable interest, to bind a purchaser (Chloe) in unregistered land, it must be registered as a land charge (Class C(iv)). It is not a licence (C) as it grants a proprietary right to take soil.
A is incorrect as a legal profit requires a deed. D is incorrect as it is not a leasehold estate...

questions.text: Daniel owns a registered freehold title to "The Paddock." He enters into a written contract with Eva, signed by both, to sell The Paddock to her for £200,000. Completion is set for two months later. Before completion, Daniel purports to grant a legal mortgage over The Paddock to FastBank plc by deed. FastBank registers its charge at HM Land Registry. Eva completes the purchase and applies to register her title. What is the priority of interests between Eva and FastBank?

options.label: A
options.text: FastBank’s registered charge takes priority because it was registered first.

options.label: B
options.text: Eva’s equitable interest under the contract takes priority under the doctrine in Walsh v Lonsdale.

options.label: C
options.text: FastBank’s charge is void because Daniel had no power to grant it after contracting to sell.

options.label: D
options.text: Eva takes free of the charge because her legal estate, once registered, will take priority over a charge registered against her predecessor.

options.label: E
options.text: The charge is valid but postponed to Eva’s interest because her contract was an estate contract which should have been protected by notice.

questions.explanation: Upon exchange of contracts, Eva acquired an equitable interest (estate contract) under Walsh v Lonsdale. Daniel remained legal owner and could grant a mortgage, but it would be subject to Eva’s prior equitable interest. For registered land, Eva should have protected her estate contract by a notice. FastBank, as a registered chargee for value, may take free of unprotected equitable interests. However, if Eva’s interest constitutes an overriding interest due to actual occupation (not stated), it could bind FastBank. The best answer is E: the charge is valid, but the unprotected prior equitable i...

questions.text: Felix is the freehold owner of a detached house. He builds a solid brick garden shed, bolted to a concrete base. He also hangs a valuable tapestry in the living room using specialist picture hooks that can be removed without damaging the fabric of the wall. He sells the house to Grace. The contract excludes "all curtains, carpets, and removable furnishings." Who owns the shed and the tapestry?

options.label: A
options.text: Both are fixtures and pass with the house.

options.label: B
options.text: The shed is a fixture; the tapestry is a chattel..

options.label: C
options.text: The shed is a chattel as it could be dismantled; the tapestry is a fixture as it is attached.

options.label: D
options.text: Both are chattels as they are not integral to the structure.

options.label: E
options.text: The contract’s exclusion clause overrides the common law test, so both are chattels.

questions.explanation:
Applying the two-stage test: The shed is firmly annexed (bolted) and likely for permanent improvement, a fixture. The tapestry, though attached, is for ornamentation and can be removed without damage to the wall or itself. In Leigh v Taylor, tapestries fixed for enjoyment as chattels were held not to be fixtures. The contract excludes specific items, but the tapestry is not listed, so common law applies.
A is incorrect for the tapestry.
C is incorrect for the shed.
D is incorrect for both.
E is incorrect; the clause does not mention these specific items.

questions.text: Hannah grants an option to purchase her unregistered freehold farm to Isaac for £500,000. The option agreement is in writing and signed by both parties. It states the option may be exercised anytime within the next 10 years. Hannah later sells the farm to Jacob, who registers his title. Isaac later tries to exercise the option against Jacob. What is the nature of Isaac’s right and its enforceability against Jacob?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a legal estate contract, binding on Jacob as it was created by deed.

options.label: B
options.text: It is an equitable estate contract, which is void against Jacob for lack of registration as a Class C(iv) land charge.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a mere personal right (licence), not binding on Jacob.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a restrictive covenant, requiring registration as a Class D(ii) land charge to bind Jacob.

options.label: E
options.text: It is an equitable easement, binding if Isaac was in actual occupation.

questions.explanation: An option to purchase is an estate contract, an equitable interest (s.2 LP(MP)A 1989). For unregistered land, it must be registered as a Class C(iv) land charge under the LCA 1972 to bind a purchaser for value. As Hannah’s land was unregistered at the grant, and Jacob is a purchaser, failure to register renders it void against him. A is incorrect; it is not a legal estate. C is incorrect; it is a proprietary equity. D is incorrect; it is not a restrictive covenant. E is incorrect; it is not an easement.

questions.text: Katherine owns a freehold building. She leases the top-floor flat to Leo for 5 years by a written agreement signed by both, but not as a deed. Leo pays rent monthly and moves in. Katherine then grants a legal mortgage over the whole building to SecureBank plc by deed. SecureBank registers its charge. Leo claims his lease is binding on SecureBank. Is he correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because his lease is a legal lease under s.54(2) LPA 1925 as it is for less than 3 years.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the agreement is in writing.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because his equitable lease is an overriding interest

options.label: D
options.text: No, because leases cannot bind mortgagees.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, because the mortgage was granted after the lease, so the mortgage is subject to it.

questions.explanation: A lease for 5 years requires a deed to be legal (s.52 LPA 1925). The written agreement creates an equitable lease (if it satisfies s.2 LP(MP)A 1989). Leo is in actual occupation. Under Sch.3, para 2 LRA 2002, an interest belonging to a person in actual occupation is an overriding interest and binds a registered chargee, provided it is obvious on inspection (which occupation is). Therefore, C is correct. A is incorrect as the term is 5 years, not ≤3. B is incorrect. D is incorrect. E is incorrect as it states the outcome but for the incorrect reason (it’s not the chronology but the overriding i...

questions.text: Oliver owns a freehold house. He agrees in a detailed written contract, signed by both, to sell the house to Penelope. The contract includes all terms. Before completion, Oliver dies. His sole heir, Quentin, obtains probate. Penelope demands completion from Quentin. Which of the following is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The contract is void due to Oliver’s death.

options.label: B
options.text: Quentin holds the legal estate on a constructive trust for Penelope

options.label: C
options.text: Penelope only has a claim against Oliver’s estate for damages, not specific performance.

options.label: D
options.text: The contract was personal to Oliver and cannot bind his heir.

options.label: E
options.text: Penelope’s equitable interest is void against Quentin as he is a purchaser for value.

questions.explanation: A valid contract for the sale of land creates an equitable interest in the purchaser (Walsh v Lonsdale). On the vendor’s death, the legal estate vests in his personal representative (Quentin), who holds it subject to the existing equitable interest. Quentin is bound to complete the contract; he holds the legal estate on a constructive trust for Penelope. A and D are incorrect; the benefit and burden of the contract pass. C is incorrect; specific performance is available against the estate. E is incorrect; Quentin is not a purchaser for value but a successor in title.

questions.text: Rachel owns a freehold title to a plot of land. She signs a document purporting to grant Simon a "999-year lease" at a peppercorn rent. The document is labelled "Deed" and is signed by Rachel in the presence of one witness, but it is not delivered to Simon. Simon takes possession and builds a house. What is the status of Simon’s interest?

options.label: A
options.text: He has a legal lease because the term is certain and he is in possession.

options.label: B
options.text: He has an equitable lease due to the absence of a deed.

options.label: C
options.text: He has no proprietary interest because the deed was not delivered.

options.label: D
options.text: He has a licence because the rent is nominal.

options.label: E
options.text: He has a legal freehold by virtue of adverse possession.

questions.explanation: For a lease over 3 years, a deed is required (s.52 LPA 1925). Under s.1 LP(MP)A 1989, a deed must be in writing, clear that it is a deed, signed, witnessed, and delivered. Delivery is an essential formalities requirement (Shaw v Foster). Without delivery, it is not a valid deed and cannot create a legal estate. Therefore, C is correct. B is incorrect because  the scenario does not mention a contract complying with s.2. A is incorrect due to lack of deed. D is incorrect; nominal rent does not preclude a lease. E is incorrect; adverse possession requires 12 years.

questions.text: Tara is the registered proprietor of a freehold house. She orally agrees with her cousin, Umar, that he can live in the granny flat attached to the house rent-free for as long as he wishes. Umar moves in. Two years later, Tara sells and transfers the house to Violet by deed. Violet is unaware of Umar’s occupancy as he is on holiday at the time of her inspection. On his return, Umar claims a right to occupy. What is the nature of Umar’s right and is it binding on Violet?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a life interest, requiring a deed, and is void.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a lease for life, which is not a term of years absolute and is void.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a contractual licence, which is not proprietary and does not bind Violet.

options.label: D
options.text: It is an equitable lease, which may be an overriding interest due to actual occupation, binding Violet.

options.label: E
options.text: It is a tenancy at will, which determines when Tara sold the house.

questions.explanation: An oral agreement for occupation for an uncertain period (as long as he wishes) at no rent is a classic bare licence. It is personal, not proprietary, and does not create an interest in land. It is therefore not binding on a purchaser, Violet (Street v Mountford). A and B are incorrect as no life interest or lease is created due to lack of certainty and formality. D is incorrect; there is no equitable lease without a valid contract. E is incorrect because the facts suggest a licence, not a tenancy at will.

questions.text: William grants a right of way over his unregistered land to his neighbour, Xanthe, "for her lifetime." The grant is contained in a deed. Xanthe uses the right for 5 years. William then sells his land to Yvonne. Yvonne blocks the path. What is the nature of Xanthe’s right and its enforceability against Yvonne?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a legal easement for a term equivalent to a life interest, which is not a legal estate under s.1 LPA 1925 and is void.

options.label: B
options.text: It is an equitable easement for life, binding on Yvonne if registered as a land charge.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a legal easement in perpetuity (fee simple), as easements are not limited to the two legal estates, and binds Yvonne.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a profit à prendre, requiring registration.

options.label: E
options.text: It is a mere licence, personal to Xanthe.

questions.explanation: An easement can be granted for a term equivalent to a life interest. However, under s.1(1) LPA 1925, the only legal estates are fee simple absolute in possession and term of years absolute. A legal easement is a legal interest (s.1(2)(a)), but it must be created for a duration equivalent to a legal estate. An easement for life is not a legal interest but an equitable interest (s.1(3)). It was created by deed, so it is a valid equitable easement. To bind Yvonne (a purchaser of unregistered land), it must be registered as a Class D(iii) land charge (equitable easement). Therefore, B is correct. ...

questions.text: Zara owns a freehold field. She enters into a written agreement with Adam, signed by both, to sell him the field for £100,000, completion in 6 months. The agreement includes all terms. The next day, Zara signs a written agreement, but not a deed, granting her brother Ben a right to park his car on the field every weekend. Ben starts using the right. Adam completes the purchase 6 months later and is registered as proprietor. He erects a fence, preventing Ben from parking. Ben claims his right is binding. Which of the following is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Ben has a legal easement created in writing, binding Adam.

options.label: B
options.text: Ben has an equitable easement, which is void against Adam as it was not protected by a notice on the register.

options.label: C
options.text: Ben has an equitable easement, which is an overriding interest due to his regular use (actual occupation) and binds Adam.

options.label: D
options.text: Ben has a licence, which is not binding on Adam.

options.label: E
options.text: Ben has a proprietary estoppel claim, which may bind Adam.

questions.explanation: A right to park can be an easement (Moncrieff v Jamieson). It requires a deed to be legal (s.52). A written agreement signed by both satisfies s.2 LP(MP)A 1989 for a contract to grant an easement, creating an equitable easement. For registered land, an equitable easement should be protected by a notice to bind a purchaser (s.32 LRA 2002). It is not an overriding interest under Sch.3 (equitable easements are not listed; only legal easements may override). Ben’s regular use does not constitute "actual occupation" of the field for parking rights in this context (London & Blenheim Estates). Theref...

questions.text: Chloe owns a freehold house. She signs a document granting her friend David "a right to store his canoe in my garden shed for the next 15 years." The document is not witnessed. David pays Chloe £50. David stores his canoe. Two years later, Chloe sells the house to Eve. Eve removes the canoe. What is David’s best argument regarding the nature of his right?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a legal lease of the shed, created by deed, binding Eve.

options.label: B
options.text: It is an equitable easement, created by a valid contract, binding Eve if protected.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a licence coupled with a grant (profit à prendre), binding Eve.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a restrictive covenant, requiring registration.

options.label: E
options.text: It is a mere personal licence

questions.explanation: A right to store chattels can be an easement if it satisfies the Re Ellenborough Park tests (dominant/servient tenements, accommodates dominant land, etc.). Here, David likely has no dominant land, so it may fail. However, if construed as a right for David personally, it is a licence. The best proprietary argument is an equitable easement if the written agreement (signed) is a valid contract under s.2. The payment of £50 suggests consideration. It would need protection to bind a purchaser. A is incorrect; no deed for a 15-year term. C is incorrect; not a profit. D is incorrect. E is incorrect.

questions.text: Fred is the registered proprietor of a freehold flat. He grants a 2-year assured shorthold tenancy to Gemma by a written agreement, signed by both, at a market rent. Gemma moves in. Fred then grants a legal charge over the flat to QuickLoan Bank by deed. QuickLoan registers its charge. Gemma’s tenancy is not noted on the register. Gemma claims her tenancy binds QuickLoan. Is she correct?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because her tenancy is an equitable lease and is void against a registered chargee.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because her tenancy is a legal lease and is an overriding interest

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the bank’s charge takes priority as a registered disposition.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if she was in actual occupation at the time of the charge.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because leases must always be registered to bind third parties.

questions.explanation: A 2-year lease at a market rent, granted in possession, can be a legal lease without a deed under s.54(2) LPA 1925. Under Sch.3, para 1 LRA 2002, a lease for 7 years or less is an overriding interest and binds a registered chargee, whether or not the chargee has notice. Therefore, B is correct. D is incorrect. actual occupation is not required for this category of overriding lease. A is incorrect; it is a legal lease. C is incorrect; registered dispositions are subject to overriding interests. E is incorrect for leases ≤7 years.

questions.text: Ian is the freehold owner of a workshop. He orally agrees with his employee, Jess, that she can use a designated parking space behind the workshop "for as long as you work here." Jess uses it daily for 3 years. Ian sells the freehold to Kevin. Kevin fires Jess and revokes the parking permission. Jess claims she has a permanent right. What is the nature of Jess’s right?

options.label: A
options.text: An easement by prescription.

options.label: B
options.text: An equitable easement by estoppel.

options.label: C
options.text: A lease for life.

options.label: D
options.text: A contractual licence, terminable on reasonable notice.

options.label: E
options.text: A profit à prendre.

questions.explanation: The right is linked to employment (personal) and for an uncertain duration. It lacks the necessary characteristics of an easement (no dominant tenement) or a lease (no certain term, exclusive possession questionable). It is a classic contractual licence, terminable when the condition (employment) ends or on reasonable notice. B in incorrect as it (proprietary estoppel) is possible if there was a representation and detriment, but the facts do not strongly support it. A is incorrect as it requires 20 years’ use. C is incorrect. E is incorrect.

questions.text: Laura owns a freehold house. She signs a document stating, "I grant to my son, Mike, the right to live in my house for the next 25 years, rent-free." The document is signed and witnessed but not described as a deed. Mike moves in. Laura later tries to sell the house. What is the status of Mike’s interest?

options.label: A
options.text: A legal lease for 25 years, requiring registration with the Land Registry.

options.label: B
options.text: An equitable lease, arising from a valid contract..

options.label: C
options.text: A licence for life, not an interest in land.

options.label: D
options.text: A fee simple absolute, as it is a gift of possession.

options.label: E
options.text: A tenancy at will.

questions.explanation: A grant of exclusive possession for a term certain (25 years) creates a leasehold estate. It requires a deed to be legal (s.52). The written document, signed, could constitute a contract for a lease if it contains all terms (parties, property, term, rent (zero), signed). This would satisfy s.2 LP(MP)A 1989, creating an equitable lease under Walsh v Lonsdale. Therefore, B is correct. A is incorrect; no deed. C is incorrect; it is for a term certain, not life. D is incorrect. E is incorrect.

questions.text: Nigel owns a freehold plot. He grants an "option to renew a lease" to his current tenant, Olivia, who holds under a 5-year legal lease. The option agreement is contained in a side letter signed by both. Nigel sells the freehold to Penny. Olivia’s lease expires and she tries to exercise the option against Penny. What is the key issue regarding the option’s enforceability?

options.label: A
options.text: Whether options are capable of being proprietary interests.

options.label: B
options.text: Whether the option was created by deed.

options.label: C
options.text: Whether the option was registered as a land charge or protected by notice at the time Penny purchased.

options.label: D
options.text: Whether the option is a positive covenant, which does not run with the land.

options.label: E
options.text: Whether Olivia was in actual occupation at the time of Penny’s purchase.

questions.explanation: An option to renew a lease is an estate contract, an equitable interest. To bind a purchaser of the freehold (Penny), it must be protected. If the land was unregistered at the grant, it must be registered as a Class C(iv) land charge. If registered, it should be protected by a notice. Its enforceability hinges on this registration/protection. A is settled; they are proprietary. B is relevant for a legal option, but equitable options are common. D is incorrect; it’s not a freehold covenant. E is not directly relevant for an option.

questions.text: Quentin owns a freehold manor house with extensive grounds, including a private chapel. He sells the house and grounds to Rachel but retains the chapel and a right of way to it across the sold land. The conveyance is by deed and expressly reserves "a right of way on foot for Quentin, his heirs and assigns, to the retained chapel." This reservation is contained in the deed. Quentin later sells the chapel to Sam. Sam claims the right of way. Rachel objects, arguing the right was personal to Quentin. Is the right enforceable by Sam?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the right was expressed to be for Quentin, his heirs and assigns, but assigns do not include purchasers.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because the right was expressly made for assigns and is a legal easement created by deed, binding successors.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because you cannot reserve an easement for the benefit of land you are retaining; it must be granted by the purchaser.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if Sam registers the right as a land charge.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because positive covenants (rights of way) do not run with the land.

questions.explanation:
An easement can be created by reservation in a conveyance. The wording "for Quentin, his heirs and assigns" shows an intention for the benefit to run with the retained land (chapel). It was created by deed, so it is a legal easement (s.52). As a legal interest, it binds successors in title to the servient land (Rachel) automatically. Therefore, Sam, as successor to the dominant land (chapel), can enforce it. B is correct.
A is incorrect; "assigns" includes purchasers.
C is incorrect; reservation is a valid method.
D is incorrect; legal easements do not require land charge registration (though ...

questions.text: Tom grants his daughter, Uma, "the right to take timber from the oak trees on my land for the purpose of fueling her fireplace, for the next 10 years." The grant is in a deed. Uma takes some timber. Tom sells the land to Victor. Uma demands more timber. Victor refuses. What is the nature of Uma’s right?

options.label: A
options.text: A legal profit à prendre for a term of years, binding Victor.

options.label: B
options.text: An equitable profit à prendre, requiring registration.

options.label: C
options.text: A licence, personal to Uma.

options.label: D
options.text: A restrictive covenant.

options.label: E
options.text: A lease of the oak trees.

questions.explanation:
A right to take timber (a natural product) from another’s land is a profit à prendre. It was granted by deed for a fixed term (10 years), so it is a legal interest (s.1(2)(a) LPA 1925). As a legal interest, it binds successors in title to the servient land (Victor). Therefore, A is correct. B is incorrect; it is legal.
C is incorrect; it is proprietary.
D is incorrect.
E is incorrect; it is not a leasehold estate.

questions.text: Wendy owns a freehold building. She grants a 99-year lease of the ground floor to Xavier by deed. The lease contains a covenant by Xavier not to use the premises for any noisy trade. Wendy sells the freehold reversion to Yvonne. Xavier starts operating a music studio. Yvonne seeks to enforce the covenant. Which of the following is correct regarding the enforceability of this covenant against Xavier?

options.label: A
options.text: Yvonne cannot enforce because there is no privity of contract between her and Xavier.

options.label: B
options.text: Yvonne can enforce because the covenant touches and concerns the land and there is privity of estate between her and Xavier.

options.label: C
options.text: Yvonne can only enforce if the benefit of the covenant was expressly assigned to her.

options.label: D
options.text: Yvonne cannot enforce because restrictive covenants in leases do not bind assignees of the reversion.

options.label: E
options.text: Yvonne can enforce only if the covenant was registered as a land charge.

questions.explanation:
This is a leasehold covenant. The burden of a covenant that "touches and concerns" the land runs with the leasehold estate due to privity of estate. When Wendy sold the reversion to Yvonne, Yvonne stepped into Wendy’s shoes as landlord. There is now privity of estate between Yvonne (landlord) and Xavier (tenant in possession). Therefore, Yvonne can enforce the restrictive covenant. B is correct.
A is incorrect; privity of estate suffices.
C is incorrect; assignment is not needed for leasehold covenants running with the estate.
D is incorrect; they do bind.
E is incorrect; registration is not r...

questions.text: Amelia is the registered proprietor of a freehold house, "Greenacre." Her elderly aunt, Beatrice, has lived in the self-contained annexe at Greenacre for 15 years. There is no formal agreement, but Amelia told Beatrice she could live there "for as long as she needed." Beatrice receives all her post there, is on the electoral roll, and has her own front door key. Amelia decides to sell Greenacre. The buyer, Charles, inspects the property. Beatrice is away visiting friends, so the annexe appears unoccupied. Charles completes the purchase and is registered as the new proprietor. On moving in, he finds Beatrice and demands she leaves. Beatrice claims she has a right to occupy that binds Charles. Which of the following is the strongest basis for Beatrice's claim?

options.label: A
options.text: She has a legal lease under s.54(2) LPA 1925, which is an overriding interest.

options.label: B
options.text: She has an equitable interest under a constructive trust, which is an overriding interest due to her actual occupation.

options.label: C
options.text: She has a contractual licence, which is a personal right that does not bind Charles.

options.label: D
options.text: She has a beneficial interest protected by a restriction on the register, which Charles would have seen.

options.label: E
options.text: She has an interest under a resulting trust, but as it was not protected by a notice, it does not bind Charles.

questions.explanation: Beatrice's long-term residence, with intention and objective signs (post, electoral roll, key), likely gives rise to an equitable interest under a constructive trust based on common intention or estoppel (see Stack v Dowden principles). This equitable interest is capable of being an overriding interest under Sch.3, para 2, LRA 2002 if she was in "actual occupation" at the relevant time (the date of Charles's purchase/disposition). The fact she was temporarily absent does not necessarily negate actual occupation if there is a degree of permanence and continuity (Link Lending v Bustard). As her ...

questions.text: In 2015, David sold part of his unregistered freehold land, "Field A," to Eleanor. The conveyance contained a covenant by Eleanor "not to build any structure on Field A." The covenant was not registered as a land charge. In 2024, Eleanor sells Field A to Finn. Finn begins to lay foundations for a barn. David seeks an injunction. Is the restrictive covenant enforceable against Finn?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because the burden of a restrictive covenant runs in equity under the rule in Tulk v Moxhay.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the covenant is positive in substance (not to build implies an obligation to maintain as open land).

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because Finn had constructive notice of the covenant as it was in the 2015 conveyance, which he should have investigated.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because the covenant was not registered as a Class D(ii) land charge and is void against Finn

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only if David had retained adjacent land capable of benefiting from the covenant.

questions.explanation: For unregistered land, a restrictive covenant created after 1925 is an equitable interest registrable as a Class D(ii) land charge under the LCA 1972. By virtue of s.4 of that Act, if such a land charge is not registered, it is void against a purchaser of the land for money or money's worth. Finn is such a purchaser. Therefore, the covenant is unenforceable against him. A is incorrect as the rule in Tulk v Moxhay is subject to the statutory registration regime. B is incorrect; a covenant "not to build" is classic restrictive covenant. C is incorrect; in unregistered land, the doctrine of notic...

questions.text: Grace is the sole registered proprietor of "Hillside," a freehold house. She holds the legal title on trust for herself and her brother, Henry, in equal shares under an express declaration of trust made in 2020. The trust is not noted on the register. In 2024, Grace forges Henry's signature on a transfer deed and sells Hillside to Ian, who pays the market price. Ian is registered as the new proprietor. Henry discovers the fraud and claims his beneficial interest. Which of the following best describes the status of Henry's interest?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an overriding interest under Sch.3 LRA 2002 due to his actual occupation, and therefore binds Ian.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a minor interest which should have been protected by a restriction; as it was not, Ian takes free of it.

options.label: C
options.text: It is overreached because the capital money (purchase price) was paid to a sole trustee, Grace.

options.label: D
options.text: It is an equitable interest defeated by Ian's status as a bona fide purchaser for value without notice.

options.label: E
options.text: It remains binding on Ian because forgery renders the entire transaction void ab initio.

questions.explanation: Henry's beneficial interest under a trust of land is a minor interest. The appropriate form of protection on the register is a restriction (to prevent a disposition by a sole trustee) or possibly a notice. As it was unprotected, and Ian is a registered purchaser for value, Ian takes free of the interest under the principles of registered conveyancing (ss. 26 & 29 LRA 2002). A is incorrect; while actual occupation can create an overriding interest, Henry's occupation is not mentioned in the facts. C is incorrect; overreaching requires capital money to be paid to at least two trustees or a trust...

questions.text: Jasmine owns an unregistered freehold estate, "The Orchard." She grants a 10-year lease of The Orchard to Kyle in 2020 by deed. In 2023, Jasmine contracts to sell the freehold to Liam. Liam's solicitor investigates title. Which of the following documents would constitute a valid 'root of title' for the purposes of proving Jasmine's ownership?

options.label: A
options.text: The 2020 lease to Kyle.

options.label: B
options.text: A certified copy of the 2023 contract for sale to Liam.

options.label: C
options.text: A conveyance of The Orchard to Jasmine dated 2008.

options.label: D
options.text: A will dated 1995 devising The Orchard to Jasmine.

options.label: E
options.text: A land charge search certificate from 2023.

questions.explanation: A 'root of title' is a document which deals with the legal estate, describes the property sufficiently, and shows no obvious defects. It must be at least 15 years old for unregistered land (though older is common). A conveyance on sale is a classic root. The 2008 conveyance meets these requirements. A is incorrect; a lease is a disposition of a lesser interest, not proof of the freehold title. B is incorrect; a contract does not prove legal title, only an agreement to transfer it. D is incorrect. E is not a document of title.

questions.text: Maya is in the process of buying an unregistered freehold house from Noah. Noah's solicitor provides an epitome of title tracing ownership back to a conveyance dated 2005. Maya's lender requires a search in the Land Charges Register. Which of the following interests, if discovered, would be void against Maya if not registered?

options.label: A
options.text: A legal easement granted in 1990.

options.label: B
options.text: A restrictive covenant created in 2010.

options.label: C
options.text: A lease for 21 years granted in 2000.

options.label: D
options.text: A mortgage created by deed in 2015.

options.label: E
options.text: A right of way acquired by prescription before 1926.

questions.explanation:
In unregistered land, a restrictive covenant created after 1925 is a Class D(ii) land charge. Under s.4 LCA 1972, if unregistered, it is void against a purchaser of the land for money.
A is incorrect; legal easements are legal interests and bind the world automatically, though they might be discoverable by inspection.
C is incorrect; a legal lease for over 7 years might be an estate contract if equitable, but a legal lease binds automatically. More importantly, leases are not generally registrable as land charges.
D is incorrect; a legal mortgage by deed is a puisne mortgage, registrable as a ...

questions.text: Oscar has been in adverse possession of an unregistered plot, "Plot B," for 14 years. The paper title owner, Patricia, has taken no action. Oscar now contracts to sell Plot B to Quentin. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding Oscar's ability to sell?

options.label: A
options.text: Oscar can give a good title because his 14 years of adverse possession has extinguished Patricia's title under the Limitation Act 1980.

options.label: B
options.text: Oscar can only sell his equitable interest; he must first apply to be registered as proprietor after 12 years of adverse possession.

options.label: C
options.text: Oscar has no title to sell because adverse possession does not confer ownership until the title is registered.

options.label: D
options.text: Oscar can sell, but Quentin's title will be subject to Patricia's right to bring a possession action for another two years.

options.label: E
options.text: Oscar can sell a fee simple, but must first obtain a vesting order from the court.

questions.explanation: Under the Limitation Act 1980, after 12 years of adverse possession of unregistered land, the paper owner's right to recover the land is extinguished (s.15). However, the legal estate does not automatically vest in the squatter. Instead, the squatter is deemed to have acquired a title based on possession, but the old owner is treated as holding the legal estate on trust for the squatter. The squatter's title is equitable. To deal with the land effectively (especially to give a legal title to a purchaser), the squatter should apply for first registration based on adverse possession. Therefore, ...

questions.text: Rachel is the registered proprietor of a freehold house. She grants an equitable lease of the house to Sam for 7 years (by a valid contract complying with s.2 LP(MP)A 1989). Sam moves in. Rachel then sells the freehold to Tanya. Tanya's solicitor fails to discover Sam's occupancy. After completion, Tanya is registered as proprietor and seeks to evict Sam. Which of the following is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Sam's lease is void against Tanya because it was not a legal lease.

options.label: B
options.text: Sam's lease is binding on Tanya as an overriding interest under Sch.3, para 1, LRA 2002.

options.label: C
options.text: Sam's lease is binding on Tanya as an overriding interest due to his actual occupation.

options.label: D
options.text: Sam's lease should have been protected by a notice; as it was not, Tanya takes free of it.

options.label: E
options.text: Sam's lease binds Tanya because it was granted before the sale.

questions.explanation:
Sam has an equitable lease (a minor interest). For it to bind a purchaser, it must either be protected by an entry on the register (a notice) or be an overriding interest. Under Sch.3, para 2, an interest belonging to a person in actual occupation of the land is an overriding interest. Sam is in actual occupation. Therefore, C is correct.
A is incorrect; equitable interests can bind via overriding status. B is incorrect; Sch.3, para 1 applies to legal leases for 7 years or less. Sam's lease is equitable.
D is incorrect; while protection by notice is advisable, the lack of it is not fatal if th...

questions.text: United Bank holds a legal charge over Tara's unregistered freehold house, granted by deed in 2020. The charge was never registered as a land charge. Tara sells the house to Victor in 2023. Victor pays the market price and completes the purchase, unaware of the bank's charge. Victor now applies for first registration. What is the status of United Bank's charge?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a valid legal mortgage binding on Victor because it was created by deed.

options.label: B
options.text: It is void against Victor because it was not registered as a Class C(i) land charge.

options.label: C
options.text: It is an overriding interest that will bind Victor's registered title because it is a legal interest.

options.label: D
options.text: It does not remain enforceable against Tara personally

options.label: E
options.text: It is valid but will be postponed to Victor's registered title.

questions.explanation:
For unregistered land, a legal mortgage not protected by deposit of title deeds is a "puisne mortgage" and must be registered as a Class C(i) land charge under the LCA 1972. By s.4 of that Act, if unregistered, it is void against a purchaser of the land for money. Victor is such a purchaser. Therefore, B is correct.
A is incorrect; the creation by deed makes it legal as between Tara and the bank, but it loses priority against a purchaser for lack of registration.
C is incorrect; overriding interests under the LRA 2002 generally apply to registered land. At the point of first registration, cert...

questions.text: When a person applies for first registration of title voluntarily under s.3 LRA 2002, which of the following is an advantage of doing so?

options.label: A
options.text: It triggers compulsory registration for all future dispositions of the land.

options.label: B
options.text: It guarantees an absolute title will be granted.

options.label: C
options.text: It automatically extinguishes all existing overriding interests.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows the proprietor to avoid paying stamp duty land tax.

options.label: E
options.text: It simplifies the process by not requiring documentary evidence of title.

questions.explanation:
Once land is registered, all future dispositions (e.g., transfers, leases over 7 years, charges) must be completed by registration to have legal effect (s.27 LRA 2002). This is a key benefit, bringing the land into the modern, transparent system.
B is incorrect; the class of title granted (absolute, possessory, qualified) depends on the strength of the evidence submitted.
C is incorrect; overriding interests are not extinguished by registration; they remain but should be noted on the register if discovered.
D is incorrect; SDLT is based on the transaction value, not registration.
E is incorrec...

questions.text: Xavier owns a registered freehold title. He grants a legal easement (right of way) to his neighbour, Yvonne, by deed. Yvonne uses the right immediately. What must Yvonne do to ensure her easement is fully protected and binding on future buyers of Xavier's land?

options.label: A
options.text: Nothing; as a legal easement, it is automatically an overriding interest under Sch.3 LRA 2002.

options.label: B
options.text: Enter a notice in the charges register of Xavier's title.

options.label: C
options.text: Enter a restriction in the proprietorship register of Xavier's title.

options.label: D
options.text: Register her own new title for the easement at the Land Registry.

options.label: E
options.text: Register the deed as a land charge at the Land Charges Registry.

questions.explanation:
A legal easement expressly granted is a registrable disposition under s.27(2)(d) LRA 2002. Although some legal easements can be overriding interests (Sch.3, para 3), an expressly granted legal easement is not overriding if it is created by deed and is intended to be a registrable disposition. The safe practice and statutory requirement is for it to be completed by registration, i.e., by entering a notice in the charges register of the servient title (Xavier's). Therefore, B is correct.
A is incorrect for expressly created easements; Sch.3, para 3 primarily covers easements that are not express...

questions.text: Zara is buying a registered freehold property from Adam. Adam's title is subject to a restriction which states: "No disposition of the registered estate by the proprietor of the registered estate is to be registered without a certificate signed by [XYZ Solicitors] that the terms of a trust dated 1 January 2010 have been complied with." What is the primary legal effect of this restriction?

options.label: A
options.text: It guarantees that Zara will take free of any beneficial interests under the trust.

options.label: B
options.text: It gives XYZ Solicitors a beneficial interest in the property.

options.label: C
options.text: It prevents the Land Registry from registering Zara's transfer unless the required certificate is provided.

options.label: D
options.text: It makes any disposition that breaches the restriction void as between Adam and the beneficiaries.

options.label: E
options.text: It is unenforceable because it is not in the prescribed form.

questions.explanation: Under s.40 LRA 2002, a restriction regulates the circumstances in which a disposition of a registered estate may be registered. The Land Registry will not register a disposition (like the transfer to Zara) unless the condition in the restriction (here, production of the certificate) is satisfied. This is its primary, mechanical effect. A is incorrect; the restriction protects beneficial interests but does not guarantee overreaching. B is incorrect; the restriction does not confer an interest on the solicitors. D is incorrect as it describes a potential consequence in equity, but the primary st...

questions.text: Before 2020, Brian owned an unregistered freehold in fee simple. In 2020, he granted a 25-year lease to Carla by deed. In 2024, Brian sells the freehold reversion to David. What is the trigger for compulsory first registration of title under s.4 LRA 2002?

options.label: A
options.text: The grant of the 25-year lease in 2020.

options.label: B
options.text: The sale of the freehold reversion to David in 2024.

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B are triggering events.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither A nor B, because the land is still unregistered.

options.label: E
options.text: Only if David applies for a mortgage.

questions.explanation:
Under s.4 LRA 2002, compulsory first registration is triggered by specific events affecting unregistered land. One key trigger is the transfer of a qualifying estate (e.g., a freehold) for valuable consideration (s.4(1)(a)). The sale to David in 2024 is such a transfer. The grant of the lease in 2020 was also a potential trigger (s.4(1)(c),  grant of a lease for more than 7 years), but as that event has passed without registration, the land remains unregistered. The new trigger in 2024 imposes the obligation on David to apply for first registration within 2 months. Therefore, B is correct.
C i...

questions.text: Elena is the registered proprietor. She grants Fiona an option to purchase the property for £300,000 anytime in the next 5 years. The option agreement is a valid contract under s.2 LP(MP)A 1989. How should Fiona protect this interest to ensure it binds a future buyer of the property?

options.label: A
options.text: By entering a notice in the charges register.

options.label: B
options.text: By entering a restriction in the proprietorship register.

options.label: C
options.text: By applying for first registration of her option.

options.label: D
options.text: No protection is needed as it is a legal interest.

options.label: E
options.text: By registering a Class C(iv) land charge.

questions.explanation:
An option to purchase is an estate contract, which is an equitable interest. In registered land, the appropriate method of protecting such a minor interest is by entering a notice in the charges register (s.32 LRA 2002). This ensures it binds successors.
