B is incorrect; restrictions are used to control how a proprietor deals with the land, not to note third-party rights.
C is incorrect; options are not separate titles. D is incorrect; options are equitable unless created by deed (rare). E is incorrect; land charges are for unregistered land.

questions.text: George has been in adverse possession of a registered freehold plot for 9 years. The registered proprietor, Hannah, has been aware of this but has taken no action. Which of the following is George able to do at this point?

options.label: A
options.text: Apply to be registered as the proprietor in place of Hannah.

options.label: B
options.text: Serve a caution against first registration.

options.label: C
options.text: Apply for a restriction to be entered on Hannah's title.

options.label: D
options.text: Nothing; he must wait until 12 years have passed.

options.label: E
options.text: Apply for an injunction to prevent Hannah from disturbing him.

questions.explanation:
For registered land, the rules on adverse possession were significantly changed by the LRA 2002. An application to be registered as proprietor can only be made after 10 years of adverse possession (Sch.6, para 1(1)). After 9 years, George cannot yet apply. Therefore, D is correct.
A is incorrect; it's too early.
B is incorrect; cautions against first registration apply to unregistered land.
C is incorrect; a person in adverse possession has no right to enter a restriction.
E is incorrect; he could potentially defend a possession claim, but he cannot proactively seek an injunction.

questions.text: When investigating title in unregistered land, a purchaser's solicitor discovers a conveyance dated 1980 that contains a covenant restricting the use of the property to a "single private dwelling house." The covenant is not registered as a land charge. The seller is the current owner, who purchased the property in 2010. Which of the following best describes the status of this covenant?

options.label: A
options.text: It is enforceable against the seller and any purchaser because it is a restrictive covenant touching and concerning the land.

options.label: B
options.text: It is void against the seller because it was not registered when he purchased in 2010.

options.label: C
options.text: It is enforceable against the seller due to privity of contract, but may be void against a new purchaser if not registered.

options.label: D
options.text: It is automatically void because it is more than 20 years old.

options.label: E
options.text: It is a positive covenant and does not run with the land.

questions.explanation: The original covenantor (the buyer in 1980) remains personally liable due to privity of contract. The burden of a restrictive covenant, however, can only pass to successors in title in equity (under Tulk v Moxhay) if it is registered as a Class D(ii) land charge. The covenant was not registered. When the seller bought in 2010, he was a purchaser for value. The unregistered covenant was void against him (s.4 LCA 1972). Therefore, the burden did not pass to him. He is not bound by it as a successor, but remains liable if he was the original covenantor (which he is not). For a new purchaser, the ...

questions.text: Imogen is buying a registered freehold house from Jake. She carries out an official copy of the register. The property register describes the land and states it is freehold. The proprietorship register shows Jake as proprietor with absolute title. The charges register is blank. On moving in, Imogen discovers an old, paved footpath crossing the garden, used by the neighbour for decades. This was not mentioned in the register or disclosed by Jake. Does this footpath bind Imogen?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because it was not noted in the charges register.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because it is a legal easement that is an overriding interest if it is obvious on a reasonably careful inspection.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because Jake gave no express grant, so it is a licence.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the neighbour registers a notice against Imogen's title within 2 months.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because Imogen is a bona fide purchaser for value without notice.

questions.explanation:
A right of way acquired by long use (prescription) is a legal easement. Under Sch.3, para 3, LRA 2002, a legal easement which is not registered can still be an overriding interest if, at the time of the disposition, it is either (i) within the actual knowledge of the purchaser, or (ii) it would have been obvious on a reasonably careful inspection of the land. A paved footpath may be "obvious." Therefore, B is correct.
A is incorrect; overriding interests bind despite not being on the register.
C is incorrect; long use can generate a proprietary easement.
D is incorrect; the easement, if overri...

questions.text: Kiran grants a legal mortgage over his registered freehold house to LoanBank plc by deed. The charge is registered at HM Land Registry. Two years later, Kiran falls behind on payments. LoanBank appoints Luka as a receiver under the powers in the mortgage deed. Luka collects rent from a tenant and pays himself a fee. Who is Luka acting as an agent for?

options.label: A
options.text: Kiran, the mortgagor.

options.label: B
options.text: LoanBank, the mortgagee.

options.label: C
options.text: The tenant.

options.label: D
options.text: The court.

options.label: E
options.text: He is a principal in his own right.

questions.explanation: A receiver appointed under a power in a mortgage deed, or under s.101(1)(iii) LPA 1925, is deemed to be the agent of the mortgagor (Kiran) for some purposes (e.g., liability for rates), but this is a statutory fiction. In reality, and for the purpose of determining who he acts for in managing the property and to whom he owes duties, he is the agent of the mortgagee who appointed him (LoanBank). This was established in cases like Barrow v Cross. Therefore, B is correct.

questions.text: Under the Land Registration Act 2002, the register can be rectified to correct a mistake. However, there is a statutory exception preventing rectification against a proprietor in possession. In which of the following situations is the proprietor NOT considered "in possession" for these purposes?

options.label: A
options.text: The proprietor lives in the property but is on a 3-month holiday abroad.

options.label: B
options.text: The proprietor has let the property on a 2-year assured shorthold tenancy.

options.label: C
options.text: The property is an empty plot of land visited by the proprietor monthly.

options.label: D
options.text: The proprietor lives in one half of a house and lets the other half.

options.label: E
options.text: The property is a commercial warehouse operated by the proprietor's company.

questions.explanation: Schedule 4, para 5(2) LRA 2002 states that for the purposes of rectification, a proprietor is not in possession if the land is subject to a lease (unless the proprietor is the tenant under that lease). If the proprietor has let the property, the tenant is in possession, not the proprietor. Therefore, B is correct. A, C, D, and E are incorrect as they all describe situations where the proprietor (or someone on their behalf) has a sufficient degree of physical control or use to be considered in possession.

questions.text: Naomi contracts to sell her unregistered freehold to Oliver. Between contract and completion, Naomi grants a legal easement to her neighbour, Penny. Oliver completes the purchase. Which of the following is correct regarding Penny's easement?

options.label: A
options.text: It is void against Oliver because it was granted after the contract.

options.label: B
options.text: It is binding on Oliver if Penny was in actual occupation of the easement.

options.label: C
options.text: It is binding on Oliver because Naomi remained legal owner until completion.

options.label: D
options.text: It is void against Oliver unless it was registered as a land charge before completion.

options.label: E
options.text: It is binding on Oliver only if he had notice of it.

questions.explanation: Between contract and completion, the seller (Naomi) remains the legal owner and holds the estate on a constructive trust for the buyer (Oliver). However, she retains a limited power to grant interests that will bind the buyer if they are consistent with the contract (e.g., not in derogation of grant). A legal easement granted by deed is a legal interest. As legal owner, Naomi could grant it, and it would be binding on the world, including Oliver, unless the contract expressly prohibited it. The doctrine of bona fide purchaser for value without notice applies to equitable interests, not legal i...

questions.text: The Land Registry makes an error in registering Quinn as proprietor of a piece of land, when in fact the land belonged to Rosa. Rosa applies for rectification. Quinn has built a house on the land. In deciding whether to order rectification, which of the following is a factor the court must consider under Sch.4 LRA 2002?

options.label: A
options.text: The length of time Quinn has been registered.

options.label: B
options.text: Whether Quinn acted in good faith.

options.label: C
options.text: The fact that Quinn is a registered proprietor in possession.

options.label: D
options.text: The relative wealth of Quinn and Rosa.

options.label: E
options.text: Whether Rosa's title was registered or unregistered.

questions.explanation: Under Sch.4, para 3(2) LRA 2002, the court must exercise its power to order rectification so as to not affect the title of a proprietor in possession unless one of the exceptions in para 3(3) applies (e.g., fraud, lack of proper care). Therefore, the proprietor's possession is a critical, mandatory factor. B is a relevant factor under para 3(3), but not the one the court must consider in all cases. A, D, and E are not statutory factors.

questions.text: Anna and Ben, an unmarried couple, buy a house in 2020. The transfer deed states the property is transferred to "Anna and Ben as joint tenants." Anna provides 80% of the deposit and pays 75% of the mortgage. Ben does the DIY and gardening. They separate in 2024. Ben claims a 50% beneficial share. What is the starting point for determining their beneficial interests?

options.label: A
options.text: They hold the legal and beneficial interests as joint tenants in equal shares.

options.label: B
options.text: They hold the legal estate as joint tenants, but the beneficial interest is held as tenants in common in shares reflecting their financial contributions.

options.label: C
options.text: They hold the beneficial interest as joint tenants, but Ben's share is reduced due to his lesser financial contribution.

options.label: D
options.text: The court will impute an intention that they hold as tenants in common in equal shares, as they are a cohabiting couple.

options.label: E
options.text: The absence of an express declaration of trust means a resulting trust arises, giving Anna a 75% share.

questions.explanation: Where a property is transferred into joint names for joint occupation, and the deed contains an express declaration of the beneficial interests (as here: "as joint tenants"), that declaration is conclusive in the absence of fraud, mistake, or a claim for rectification (Goodman v Gallant; Pettitt v Pettitt). The court will not look behind it to examine financial contributions. Therefore, the starting point (and likely the end point) is that they are beneficial joint tenants entitled to equal shares. B, C, D, and E are incorrect as they seek to circumvent the conclusive nature of the express dec...

questions.text: Chloe and David are registered as joint proprietors of a freehold house. They hold the beneficial interest as joint tenants. Chloe wishes to sever the joint tenancy. She writes a letter to David stating, "I intend to sever our joint tenancy next year." She posts it by recorded delivery. David receives and reads it. Has severance been effected?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because written notice was given and received.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the notice must indicate an immediate intention to sever.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because any written communication expressing a wish to sever is sufficient.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because severance requires a mutual agreement or course of dealing.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because notice must be served on all other joint tenants, and here there are only two.

questions.explanation: Severance by written notice under s.36(2) LPA 1925 requires the notice to indicate an immediate intention to sever. A notice expressing a future intention is ineffective (Harris v Goddard). Therefore, B is correct. A is incorrect due to the flawed nature of the notice. C is incorrect as the notice must be clear and immediate. D is incorrect; notice is a unilateral statutory method. E is incorrect; serving the only other joint tenant is sufficient.

questions.text: Eve and Finn, business partners, buy a freehold shop as an investment. The transfer to them is silent on the beneficial interest. Eve contributes £120,000 and Finn contributes £80,000 towards the £200,000 purchase price. They hold the legal estate as joint tenants. How will the equitable interests most likely be held?

options.label: A
options.text: As joint tenants, because equity follows the law.

options.label: B
options.text: As joint tenants, because they are business partners and partnership law presumes equality.

options.label: C
options.text: As tenants in common in equal shares, because the property was bought for investment.

options.label: D
options.text: As tenants in common in shares proportionate to their contributions.

options.label: E
options.text: As joint tenants, but subject to a resulting trust in favour of Eve for the extra £40,000.

questions.explanation:
In a commercial context, where property is purchased as an investment with unequal contributions, the courts readily infer a common intention to hold as tenants in common in shares reflecting their financial input. This rebuts the presumption that equity follows the law. Therefore, D is correct. A is the default presumption but is rebutted here.
B is incorrect; partnership law does not automatically dictate ownership of property. C is incorrect; while a tenancy in common is likely, the shares will reflect contributions, not be equal.
E is incorrect as it misstates the effect; a resulting trust...

questions.text: Grace and Hugo are beneficial joint tenants of a house. Hugo, without Grace's knowledge, executes a valid deed purporting to transfer his entire interest in the property to his brother, Ian. What is the effect of this transaction?

options.label: A
options.text: It is void because a joint tenant cannot unilaterally transfer their interest.

options.label: B
options.text: It severs the joint tenancy, and Hugo and Grace thenceforth hold as tenants in common in equal shares.

options.label: C
options.text: It severs the joint tenancy, and Ian and Grace become beneficial joint tenants of the whole.

options.label: D
options.text: It is effective, and Ian steps into Hugo's shoes as a beneficial joint tenant with Grace.

options.label: E
options.text: It has no effect on the beneficial interest, but creates an equitable charge in favour of Ian.

questions.explanation:
One of the methods of severance is an "act operating on one's own share," such as a purported transfer of the equitable interest (Williams v Hensman). The act severs the joint tenancy. Upon severance, the parties hold as tenants in common. The size of the shares is determined by the number of co-owners at severance. Here, there were two, so they hold in equal shares. The transfer to Ian may be valid as between Hugo and Ian, but Ian would acquire Hugo's severed 50% share as a tenant in common with Grace. Therefore, B is correct.
A is incorrect; a joint tenant can alienate their equitable intere...

questions.text: Isla and Jack hold the legal estate of a house on trust for themselves as beneficial tenants in common, Isla with a 70% share and Jack with 30%. They appoint their friend, Liam, as a second trustee. The trustees then sell the house to a buyer, Mia. The purchase money is paid to Isla and Liam as trustees. What is the effect of this sale on Jack's beneficial interest?

options.label: A
options.text: Jack's interest is overreached; it is transferred to the proceeds of sale held by the trustees.

options.label: B
options.text: Jack's interest is overreached only if he consented to the sale.

options.label: C
options.text: Jack's interest is not overreached because the money was paid to Isla, who is also a beneficiary.

options.label: D
options.text: Jack's interest binds Mia because it was a tenancy in common, and she should have investigated the trust.

options.label: E
options.text: Jack's interest is extinguished because the legal owners have sold the property.

questions.explanation:
Overreaching occurs where trustees exercise a trust power (like sale) and the capital money (purchase price) is paid to at least two trustees or a trust corporation (s.27 LPA 1925; s.2(1) LPA 1925). The beneficial interests are detached from the land and attach to the proceeds. This applies regardless of the consent of the beneficiaries. The fact that Isla is a beneficiary does not prevent overreaching; the key is the number of trustees receiving the money. Therefore, A is correct.
B is incorrect; consent is not required for overreaching.
C is incorrect; payment to two trustees is sufficient.
...

questions.text: Katherine and Leo, a married couple, are the registered proprietors of their home. No restriction is entered on the register. Katherine forges Leo's signature on a transfer deed to sell the house to Mark, who pays the market price. Mark is registered as proprietor. Leo had been working away and was not in occupation. Can Leo claim his beneficial interest against Mark?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because the transfer was a forgery and is void.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because Leo is in actual occupation.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because Leo is a beneficiary in actual occupation, so his interest is an overriding interest.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because Leo is not in actual occupation, and his unprotected minor interest is defeated.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, because the sale by one trustee cannot overreach the beneficial interests.

questions.explanation:
Leo has a beneficial interest under a trust of land. In registered land, the preferred method of protecting such an interest is by a restriction (to prevent a disposition by a sole trustee). As it was unprotected, and Mark is a registered purchaser for value, Mark takes free of it under the normal priority rules (ss. 28 & 29 LRA 2002). Leo's absence means his interest cannot claim overriding status via actual occupation. Therefore, D is correct.
A is incorrect; although a forgery, Mark's registration is effective until rectification (s.58 LRA 2002). B is incorrect. C is incorrect as Leo was no...

questions.text: Under the Trusts of Land and Appointment of Trustees Act 1996 (TOLATA), trustees have a duty to consult beneficiaries. In which of the following scenarios is this duty not engaged?

options.label: A
options.text: Before selling the trust property.

options.label: B
options.text: Before granting a lease of the trust property for 5 years.

options.label: C
options.text: Before mortgaging the trust property to raise money for the beneficiaries' education.

options.label: D
options.text: Before deciding which of two beneficiaries with a right to occupy should be asked to pay an occupation rent.

options.label: E
options.text: Before carrying out essential repairs to the roof.

questions.explanation: The duty to consult under s.11 TOLATA 1996 applies to the exercise of any function relating to the land by the trustees. However, case law suggests that day-to-day management decisions, such as essential repairs, may not trigger the formal duty to consult, whereas major decisions like sale, mortgage, or lease generally do. While not absolute, E is the best answer as it describes a routine management issue. A, B, and C are incorrect as they are clear examples of functions requiring consultation. D are incorrect as it involves regulating occupation, which is a key function likely requiring consu...

questions.text: Nina and Ollie are beneficial joint tenants of a cottage. Nina sends Ollie a text message saying, "I think we should split everything 50/50 if we break up." Ollie does not reply. Three months later, Nina dies. What is the effect on the beneficial interest?

options.label: A
options.text: The joint tenancy is severed by course of dealing, so Nina's share passes under her will.

options.label: B
options.text: The joint tenancy is severed by mutual agreement, so Nina's share passes under her will.

options.label: C
options.text: The text message is a valid written notice of severance under s.36(2) LPA 1925.

options.label: D
options.text: The joint tenancy remains unsevered, so Ollie takes the whole by survivorship.

options.label: E
options.text: The joint tenancy is severed because Ollie's silence constitutes agreement.

questions.explanation: Severance requires a clear, unequivocal act. A text message expressing a thought about the future ("I think we should... if we break up") is neither an immediate intention to sever (for s.36(2)) nor a concluded mutual agreement. It is insufficient for severance by any method (Burgess v Rawnsley). Therefore, the joint tenancy remains intact, and the right of survivorship operates on Nina's death. D is correct. A, B, and E are incorrect as there is no clear agreement or course of dealing. C is incorrect as the text lacks the requisite immediacy.

questions.text: Priya and Quinn, cohabitees, buy a house. The legal title is in Priya's sole name. Quinn contributes 30% of the deposit and pays half the mortgage. There is no express trust. What is the nature of Quinn's interest in the property?

options.label: A
options.text: He has no interest because the legal title is solely in Priya's name.

options.label: B
options.text: He has an interest under a resulting trust, proportionate to his financial contribution.

options.label: C
options.text: He has an interest under a constructive trust, based on the common intention inferred from his contributions.

options.label: D
options.text: He has a licence to occupy, which may become an interest by proprietary estoppel.

options.label: E
options.text: He is a beneficiary under an implied trust, but his share will be fixed at 50% due to their relationship.

questions.explanation:
In the context of the family home, the modern approach uses the constructive trust framework (Stack v Dowden, Jones v Kernott) to determine beneficial interests. This looks at the parties' common intention, actual, inferred, or imputed, taking into account all conduct, not just financial contributions. While a resulting trust (B) might be the starting point, the courts favour the more flexible constructive trust analysis in domestic cases. Therefore, C is the best answer.
A is incorrect. B is incorrect and an older approach for domestic contexts. D is incorrect; his payments suggest a propriet...

questions.text: Rohan and Sasha are trustees of land holding for their three adult children as beneficiaries. The trust deed requires the trustees to obtain the written consent of all beneficiaries before selling. The trustees wish to sell, but one beneficiary refuses consent. What can the trustees do?

options.label: A
options.text: They cannot sell because the requirement for consent is absolute.

options.label: B
options.text: They can sell regardless, as trustees have all the powers of an absolute owner under s.6 TOLATA 1996.

options.label: C
options.text: They can apply to the court under s.14 TOLATA 1996 for an order authorising the sale despite the lack of consent.

options.label: D
options.text: They must appoint a new trustee to break the deadlock.

options.label: E
options.text: The requirement for consent is void as it contradicts the trustees' statutory powers.

questions.explanation: While trustees have the powers of an absolute owner (s.6 TOLATA 1996), those powers can be limited by the trust instrument. Here, the deed imposes a consent requirement. If a beneficiary unreasonably withholds consent, the trustees can apply to the court under s.14 TOLATA 1996 for an order relating to the exercise of their functions, which could include authorising a sale despite the lack of consent. Therefore, C is correct. A is incorrect; the court can intervene. B is incorrect because the statutory power is subject to the terms of the trust. D is incorrect; appointing a new trustee wouldn't...

questions.text: Two sisters, Tia and Uma, inherit a freehold house from their mother. The assent to them states they are to hold "as joint tenants." Years later, they have a falling out. Tia writes a letter to Uma saying, "I hereby give you notice that I sever our joint tenancy." She leaves the letter on the kitchen table. Uma finds it a week later. Is the joint tenancy severed?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because notice must be served in accordance with the provisions for service in s.196 LPA 1925.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because leaving a letter on a table does not constitute valid service.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because the notice was in writing and clear, and it was brought to Uma's attention.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because severance requires a mutual agreement.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only from the date Uma actually read the letter.

questions.explanation: Severance by written notice under s.36(2) LPA 1925 does not prescribe a specific method of service. The key is that the notice is brought to the attention of the other joint tenant(s). Leaving it in a place where it is likely to be found (the kitchen table of the shared house) and the fact Uma found it would likely be sufficient to effect severance from the time it was received (i.e., when she found it). Therefore, C is correct. A is incorrect; s.196 provides deemed methods but does not exclude other effective methods. B is incorrect; service can be informal. D is incorrect. E is incorrect,  t...

questions.text: Victor and Wendy, an unmarried couple, buy a house. Victor provides the entire deposit. The mortgage is in both names, and they agree to pay it equally. The transfer deed states they hold as "joint tenants." They later separate. In determining the beneficial shares, what is the significance of their agreement to share mortgage repayments equally?

options.label: A
options.text: It is irrelevant because the express declaration of joint tenancy is conclusive.

options.label: B
options.text: It is powerful evidence of a common intention to share the beneficial interest equally, supporting the express declaration.

options.label: C
options.text: It only creates a personal obligation to pay the mortgage, not an interest in the property.

options.label: D
options.text: It suggests a resulting trust in Victor's favour for the deposit amount.

options.label: E
options.text: It indicates they intended a tenancy in common from the outset.

questions.explanation: In cases like Stack v Dowden and Jones v Kernott, the courts look at the whole course of dealing. An agreement to share mortgage repayments equally, when combined with a joint mortgage and joint legal title, is strong evidence of a common intention to share the beneficial interest equally, reinforcing the express declaration of joint tenancy. Therefore, B is correct. A is incorrect and too absolute; while the declaration is very strong, the courts can look at conduct to see if it supports or contradicts it. Here, it supports it. C is incorrect and underestimates the evidential value. D is inco...

questions.text: Xavier, Yara, and Zane are trustees of land holding for a group of beneficiaries. They wish to sell the land. One beneficiary, aged 17, objects to the sale. Under s.11 TOLATA 1996, what is the extent of the trustees' duty to consult this beneficiary?

options.label: A
options.text: They have no duty to consult her because she is a minor.

options.label: B
options.text: They must consult her, but need not give effect to her wishes.

options.label: C
options.text: They must consult her if she is beneficially entitled to an interest in possession in the land.

options.label: D
options.text: They must consult her guardian or parent.

options.label: E
options.text: They must obtain her consent before proceeding.

questions.explanation: Section 11(1) TOLATA 1996 states the duty to consult beneficiaries applies to "each of the beneficiaries of full age beneficially entitled to an interest in possession in land subject to the trust." A 17-year-old is not of full age. Therefore, the statutory duty does not apply to her. A is correct. C is incorrect. It would have been correct if she were 18. D is incorrect and not stipulated by the statute. B and E are incorrect regarding minors.

questions.text: Arthur and Beatrice hold a freehold property as beneficial joint tenants. Arthur commits a murder and is convicted. Subsequently, Arthur dies in prison. What is the effect on the beneficial interest?

options.label: A
options.text: The joint tenancy is severed at the moment of the crime.

options.label: B
options.text: The right of survivorship applies, so Beatrice takes all.

options.label: C
options.text: The forfeiture rule prevents Arthur's estate from benefiting, so his share passes as on intestacy.

options.label: D
options.text: The joint tenancy is severed, and Arthur's share is held on trust for the Crown.

options.label: E
options.text: The entire property passes to Beatrice, but she holds Arthur's share on constructive trust for his estate.

questions.explanation: The forfeiture rule (common law and Forfeiture Act 1982) prevents a person who has unlawfully killed another from acquiring a benefit from that person's death. This applies to survivorship under a joint tenancy. Arthur is deemed to have predeceased Beatrice. Therefore, the joint tenancy is severed in equity at the moment of death, and Arthur's share does not pass to Beatrice by survivorship but forms part of his estate. Thus, C is correct. A is incorrect; severance occurs at death, not at the crime. B is incorrect due to the forfeiture rule. D is incorrect; the share goes to his estate, not au...

questions.text: Elena and Felix, beneficial joint tenants, are in the process of divorcing. They have lengthy negotiations about selling the house and splitting the proceeds 60/40 in Elena's favour, but no agreement is signed. Felix then unexpectedly dies. What is the effect on the beneficial interest?

options.label: A
options.text: The negotiations constitute a course of dealing severing the joint tenancy, so Felix's share passes under his will.

options.label: B
options.text: The negotiations are an unenforceable agreement to sever, so the joint tenancy remains and Elena takes all by survivorship.

options.label: C
options.text: The negotiations sever the joint tenancy by mutual agreement, so Felix's share passes under his will.

options.label: D
options.text: The joint tenancy is severed only if the negotiations resulted in a legally binding contract.

options.label: E
options.text: The joint tenancy is intact, but Elena holds Felix's share on constructive trust for his estate due to the unfinished negotiations.

questions.explanation: For severance by mutual agreement, there must be a concluded agreement, not merely negotiations (Burgess v Rawnsley). Here, there were negotiations but no final agreement. Therefore, severance did not occur, and the right of survivorship operates. B is correct. A and C are incorrect as there was no concluded agreement. D is incorrect and sets too high a standard; a binding contract is not necessary, but a clear mutual agreement is. E is incorrect and not a recognised outcome.

questions.text: Under TOLATA 1996, a beneficiary with a right to occupy may be excluded by the trustees. Which of the following is not a condition the trustees may impose when excluding one of two beneficiaries?

options.label: A
options.text: Requiring the occupying beneficiary to pay compensation to the excluded beneficiary.

options.label: B
options.text: Requiring the occupying beneficiary to pay all outgoings on the property.

options.label: C
options.text: Requiring the occupying beneficiary to forfeit their beneficial interest.

options.label: D
options.text: Imposing reasonable conditions on the occupying beneficiary.

options.label: E
options.text: Making the exclusion for a limited period only.

questions.explanation: Under s.13 TOLATA 1996, trustees may impose "reasonable conditions" on occupying beneficiaries, including requiring them to pay compensation (s.13(5)) or outgoings. However, they cannot require a beneficiary to forfeit or surrender their beneficial interest in the property as a condition of occupation or exclusion. That would be an unreasonable fetter on their proprietary right. Therefore, C is the correct answer as it is NOT a condition they may impose. A, B, D, and E are within their powers.

questions.text: George and Harriet are beneficial joint tenants. George writes to Harriet: "I sever our joint tenancy." He posts the letter by ordinary post. It is delivered to her address but is lost in a pile of post and she never reads it. Harriet dies a month later. Is the joint tenancy severed?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because Harriet never had actual notice of the letter.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because service is effective upon delivery to the recipient's address, not upon reading.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because ordinary post is not a reliable method of service.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if George can prove the letter was delivered.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because severance by notice requires acknowledgment of receipt.

questions.explanation: Following Kinch v Bullard, severance by written notice under s.36(2) is effective when the notice is delivered to the other joint tenant's address, not when it is read. The risk of non-delivery or loss after delivery lies with the recipient. Therefore, B is correct. A, C, and E are incorrect based on this authority. D is incorrect and states a practical evidential point, but the legal principle is that delivery suffices.

questions.text: Ivan and Jasmine, trustees of land for their family, wish to mortgage the property to raise funds for Jasmine's business. The beneficiaries object. In considering an application under s.14 TOLATA 1996, which of the following would the court be least likely to consider?

options.label: A
options.text: The intentions of the person who created the trust.

options.label: B
options.text: The welfare of a minor beneficiary who lives in the property.

options.label: C
options.text: The personal financial circumstances of Ivan.

options.label: D
options.text: The interests of any secured creditor of a beneficiary.

options.label: E
options.text: The purposes for which the property is held.

questions.explanation: Section 15 TOLATA 1996 sets out the matters the court must have regard to, including: (a) the intentions of the settlor, (b) the purposes of the trust, (c) the welfare of any minor occupying the property, and (d) the interests of any secured creditor. The personal financial circumstances of a trustee (Ivan) is not a listed factor. The court considers the circumstances of beneficiaries, not trustees per se. Therefore, C is the least likely to be considered and is the correct answer.

questions.text: In 2015, Alistair sold the western half of his farmland, "West Field," to Beatrice. The transfer deed was silent on rights of way. To access West Field, Beatrice had always used a farm track that ran across the eastern half of Alistair's land ("East Field") to the public road, as this was the only practical route. Alistair had also used this track for his own farming operations on West Field before the sale. In 2024, Alistair sells East Field to Charles. Charles erects a gate, locking Beatrice out. Beatrice claims she has a right of way. Charles argues the deed to Beatrice contained no such grant. Which of the following provides Beatrice's strongest legal argument for a right of way?

options.label: A
options.text: An easement of necessity.

options.label: B
options.text: An easement under section 62 of the Law of Property Act 1925.

options.label: C
options.text: An easement under the rule in Wheeldon v Burrows.

options.label: D
options.text: An easement by prescription.

options.label: E
options.text: A contractual licence.

questions.explanation: C is correct. The rule in Wheeldon v Burrows implies a grant of an easement on the sale of part of land where a quasi-easement has been used by the common owner for the benefit of the part sold, provided it is continuous, apparent, and necessary for the reasonable enjoyment of that part. Here, Alistair used the track for West Field's benefit before the sale, making it a quasi-easement. It was apparent (a visible track) and necessary for reasonable enjoyment. A (necessity) is incorrect as the right, while the only practical route, might not meet the strict test of absolute necessity for basic u...

questions.text: Grace owns two adjacent freehold properties, No. 1 and No. 2 High Street. She lives in No. 1 and runs a bakery from No. 2. For years, the staff from No. 2 have used the back door of No. 1 as a shortcut to take deliveries, with Grace's permission. In 2022, Grace sells No. 2 to Hamid. The transfer deed, executed as a deed, is silent about any rights of way. Hamid's staff continue to use the back door of No. 1. Grace now objects. Hamid claims he has an implied easement. Under which principle is Hamid most likely to succeed?

options.label: A
options.text: The rule in Wheeldon v Burrows.

options.label: B
options.text: Section 62 of the Law of Property Act 1925.

options.label: C
options.text: An easement of necessity.

options.label: D
options.text: An easement by common intention.

options.label: E
options.text: An easement by prescription.

questions.explanation: B is correct. Section 62 LPA 1925 operates on a "conveyance" of land (which includes a transfer by deed). It converts any "privilege, easement, right, or advantage" enjoyed with the land at the time of conveyance into a legal easement. Here, at the time of sale, Hamid's staff were using the back door of No. 1 with Grace's permission. This permissive use was a "privilege... enjoyed with" No. 2. Section 52 can convert such a precarious licence into a full legal easement upon a conveyance by deed. A is incorrect because Wheeldon v Burrows applies to quasi-easements (rights used by the seller over...

questions.text: For over 25 years, residents of "Cliffside Cottages" have crossed a strip of land belonging to the "Manor Estate" to access a private beach. The use has been open, without force, and without the Estate's explicit permission. The Estate's land agent was aware but never challenged it. The Manor Estate is now sold to a property developer, who fences off the path. The residents seek a declaration that they have a right of way. Which of the following is the most appropriate method for the residents to claim an easement?

options.label: A
options.text: Common law prescription (since time immemorial).

options.label: B
options.text: Prescription under the doctrine of lost modern grant.

options.label: C
options.text: Prescription under the Prescription Act 1832.

options.label: D
options.text: An implied easement under section 62 LPA 1925.

options.label: E
options.text: An easement by necessity.

questions.explanation: C is correct. The Prescription Act 1832 provides a statutory basis for claiming an easement after 20 years of uninterrupted use "as of right" (nec vi, nec clam, nec precario). The facts describe 25 years of open, uninterrupted use without permission, which fits. The Act is the most common and practical method. A is incorrect because common law prescription (since 1189) is theoretically possible but practically very difficult as any evidence of interruption since 1189 defeats it. B is incorrect. Lost modern grant is a fallback doctrine used where the statutory period is met but there has been s...

questions.text: In a 1990 conveyance of Blackacre, the seller reserved "a right to pass and repass on foot over the driveway shown edged blue on the plan for the purposes of accessing the seller's retained land." The right was for the seller "his heirs and assigns." The driveway has been used ever since. In 2023, the owner of the retained land (the original seller's successor) sells part of that retained land to a new owner, who claims the benefit of the right of way. The owner of Blackacre (the servient land) objects, arguing the right was personal to the original seller. Is the right enforceable by the new owner of the part of the retained land?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the right was reserved only for the original seller.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because the words "heirs and assigns" show an intention for the benefit to run with the retained land.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the benefit of an easement cannot be assigned.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the new owner's part of the retained land is the whole of the original dominant tenement.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the right was not registered as a land charge.

questions.explanation:
B is correct. The wording "for the seller his heirs and assigns" in a reservation clause demonstrates an intention that the benefit of the easement is attached to the land retained by the seller (the dominant tenement) and is intended to pass to subsequent owners of that land. The benefit of an easement can run with the dominant land if it is annexed to it, either expressly (as here) or by implication.
A is incorrect; the wording rebuts a personal intention.
C is incorrect; the benefit of an easement can run with the land.
D is incorrect; the benefit can pass even if only part of the original ...

questions.text: Leo owns a freehold house with a cellar. For 40 years, Leo's cellar has been supported by the foundations of his neighbour Mia's house. This state of affairs was created when the two houses were built as a pair in 1880. There is no deed granting a right of support. Mia decides to demolish her house to build a block of flats, which requires deep excavations that would remove the support for Leo's cellar. Leo seeks an injunction to prevent the removal of support. What is the nature of Leo's right, if any?

options.label: A
options.text: A natural right of support for land in its natural state, which does not extend to buildings.

options.label: B
options.text: An easement of support, which can be acquired by long use (prescription).

options.label: C
options.text: A restrictive covenant preventing Mia from altering her property.

options.label: D
options.text: A licence for support, revocable by Mia.

options.label: E
options.text: A right under the rule in Rylands v Fletcher.

questions.explanation: B is correct. While land has a natural right of support from neighbouring land in its natural state, support for buildings is an artificial right that must be acquired as an easement. An easement of support can be acquired by prescription (long use) under the Prescription Act 1832. Forty years of uninterrupted use would establish such a right. A is incorrect because, while true for natural support, Leo needs the artificial right for his building. C is incorrect; there is no promise or covenant here. D is incorrect; the long, uninterrupted use suggests a proprietary right, not a revocable licen...

questions.text: In 2005, Noah sold a plot of land, "Plot A," to Pippa. The transfer deed expressly granted Pippa "a right of way for all purposes over the road known as Oak Drive on the seller's retained land." Oak Drive was a made-up road. In 2023, Noah's successor in title sells the retained land, which includes Oak Drive, to Quinn. Quinn wishes to gate Oak Drive at its entrance to control security but Pippa objects. The grant in the 2005 deed was never noted on the register (the land was and remains unregistered). Is Pippa's right enforceable against Quinn?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because it is a legal easement created by deed.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because it is an equitable easement and void against Quinn for non-registration as a land charge.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because Quinn had constructive notice of the right from the title deeds of Plot A.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because the right is too wide ("for all purposes") and is therefore invalid.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only if Pippa has been in actual occupation of Oak Drive.

questions.explanation: A is correct. The easement was expressly granted by deed. In unregistered land, a legal easement created by deed binds the world automatically. It is a legal interest, not an equitable one. It does not need to be registered as a land charge. Therefore, it binds Quinn. B is incorrect; it is a legal, not equitable, easement. C is true but unnecessary; legal interests bind irrespective of notice. D is incorrect; a right of way "for all purposes" is valid, provided the use is within the general character of an easement. E is irrelevant for a legal easement.

questions.text: For 15 years, Raj has openly used a shortcut across his neighbour's field, "The Meadow," to reach his own property. He believed he had a right to do so. The owner of The Meadow, Sarah, knew of this use but did nothing as Raj was a friend. Last year, Sarah sold The Meadow to Tariq. Before the sale, Raj told Tariq he used the path. Tariq bought the land and has now blocked the path. Raj claims an easement by prescription. Which of the following will be Tariq's strongest defence?

options.label: A
options.text: Raj's use was not for 20 years.

options.label: B
options.text: Raj's use was with Sarah's permission.

options.label: C
options.text: Raj's use was secretive.

options.label: D
options.text: Raj's use was for recreational purposes only.

options.label: E
options.text: Raj did not register his claim as a land charge.

questions.explanation: B is correct. For prescription, use must be "as of right," meaning without permission (nec precario). If Raj's use was with Sarah's permission, even if tacit or implied from their friendship and her acquiescence, it cannot found a prescriptive claim. The belief in a right is irrelevant if permission was given. A is incorrect because 15 years, while insufficient under the Prescription Act 1832 (which requires 20), could support a claim under the doctrine of lost modern grant, but the permission defence is fatal regardless of time. C is incorrect; the use was open. D is not stated; the use was a...

questions.text: In 2018, Vanessa, the freehold owner of "The Coach House," granted her neighbour William "the right to park one car in the designated space numbered 3 within the Coach House's courtyard." The grant was by a written agreement signed by both, but not executed as a deed. William has parked there daily since. In 2024, Vanessa sells The Coach House to Xena. The agreement with William is not mentioned in the sale documents or on the register. Xena tells William to leave. What is the status of William's right?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a legal easement, binding Xena as it was created by a written instrument.

options.label: B
options.text: It is an equitable easement, which may bind Xena if protected by a notice on the register.

options.label: C
options.text: It is an equitable easement, but void against Xena as it was not protected by a notice.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a short lease.

options.label: E
options.text: It is a lease of the parking space, requiring registration.

questions.explanation: B is correct. A right to park can be a valid easement (Moncrieff v Jamieson). However, to be a legal easement, it must be granted by deed (s.52 LPA 1925). Here, it was by a signed written agreement, which likely constitutes a valid contract to grant an easement (complying with s.2 LP(MP)A 1989), creating an equitable easement. In registered land, an equitable easement should be protected by a notice on the servient title's register (s.32 LRA 2002) to bind a purchaser. If unprotected, it may still bind if it qualifies as an overriding interest (e.g., if William was in actual occupation of the p...

questions.text: When Alex bought "The Barn" in 2000, the seller told him, "Of course, you can use the water from the well on my field next door, we all have." There was nothing in the deed. Alex connected a pipe and has drawn water for his household ever since, openly and without paying. In 2024, the field is sold to Beth, who disconnects the pipe. Alex claims an easement. What is the strongest argument for Alex?

options.label: A
options.text: An express grant by deed in 2000.

options.label: B
options.text: An easement implied by common intention in 2000.

options.label: C
options.text: An easement under section 62 LPA 1925 on the 2000 conveyance.

options.label: D
options.text: An easement by prescription.

options.label: E
options.text: An easement by necessity

questions.explanation: D is correct. The facts describe over 20 years of open, continuous use without permission (the seller's statement was an acknowledgment of an existing arrangement, not necessarily a revocable permission). This fits prescription under the Prescription Act 1832. The use is for a profit à prendre (water) or possibly an easement, and the long use "as of right" is key. A is incorrect; no deed. B (common intention) is incorrect as it requires a shared understanding that the right was necessary for the intended use of the land; possible but less certain than 24 years of use. C is incorrect; section 6...

questions.text: In a 1975 conveyance of "Greenfield," the seller reserved "a right of way for the seller and the tenants of the adjoining Redhouse over the track on Greenfield." Redhouse was a block of four flats owned by the seller. The right was used by the Redhouse tenants. In 2020, the owner of Redhouse (the original seller's successor) converted it into a single, large family home. The owner of Greenfield objects to the single household using the track, arguing the right was limited to use by tenants of multiple flats. Is the right still exercisable?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the character of the dominant tenement has changed substantially.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the right was personal to the tenants of the flats.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because the right is attached to Redhouse, regardless of its internal layout.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the current use is not excessive compared to the original use.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the right was not registered as a land charge.

questions.explanation:
C is correct. The easement is attached to the dominant tenement (Redhouse). The fact that the building's internal layout has changed from four flats to one house does not, in itself, extinguish the easement. The key question is whether the use of the right has increased so as to overburden the servient land. A mere change in the identity or number of occupants is not a change in the dominant tenement itself.
A is incorrect; the physical property (Redhouse) remains the same; its internal division does not change the dominant tenement for the purpose of the easement's existence.
B is incorrect; ...

questions.text: Felix grants an easement of light to Gina for the south-facing windows of her art studio. The grant is by deed. Twenty years later, Felix builds a permanent sculpture in his garden that partially blocks the light to Gina's studio. The light level is now just sufficient for general office work but is too poor for the detailed painting Gina does. Gina claims the easement has been infringed. What is the likely outcome?

options.label: A
options.text: Gina will succeed, as any reduction in light infringes an easement of light.

options.label: B
options.text: Gina will fail, because the easement only protects light for ordinary purposes.

options.label: C
options.text: Gina will succeed if she can prove the reduction materially affects her enjoyment.

options.label: D
options.text: Gina will fail, because Felix has a right to develop his own land.

options.label: E
options.text: Gina will succeed only if the blockage is malicious.

questions.explanation: B is correct. The test for infringement of a right to light is whether the obstruction deprives the dominant owner of so much light as to render the occupation of the building uncomfortable according to the ordinary notions of mankind, or to prevent the ordinary use of the rooms. The right is to sufficient light for ordinary purposes. A specially sensitive use, like detailed artistic work requiring exceptional light levels, is not protected. The fact that there is still enough light for general office work suggests the ordinary use test is not met. A is incorrect; some reduction is permissible...

questions.text: Owen has a right of way over his neighbour's land to reach a private road. The right is exercised by a defined gravel track. The neighbour erects a gate across the track but provides Owen with a key. The gate is kept locked. Owen claims the gate is a substantial interference with his easement. Is Owen likely to succeed?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the gate does not prevent passage; it merely regulates it.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because any obstruction placed on the route is an interference.

options.label: C
options.text: It depends on whether the gate causes unreasonable inconvenience or expense to Owen.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because the neighbour has a right to secure his property.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only if the gate was erected maliciously.

questions.explanation: C is correct. The law balances the servient owner's right to use their land with the dominant owner's right of way. A locked gate can be a substantial interference if it causes inconvenience (e.g., needing to stop and unlock) or expense. However, if the gate is reasonable for the servient owner's security and the key is provided, it may be permissible. The test is one of reasonableness and whether it substantially interferes with the convenient use of the right of way. A is incorrect and too absolute; some gates can be an interference. B is too absolute; minor obstructions may be acceptable. D...

questions.text: In 1970, a deed granted a right of way "to the owners and occupiers of the dominant tenement, their families, guests, and invitees." The dominant tenement was a large country house. In 2020, the house was converted into a boutique hotel. The hotel's guests and delivery vehicles now use the right of way frequently. The servient owner claims this is an excessive use outside the scope of the grant. What is the key legal issue?

options.label: A
options.text: Whether the easement was abandoned when the house became a hotel.

options.label: B
options.text: Whether the phrase "guests and invitees" extends to commercial patrons of a hotel.

options.label: C
options.text: Whether the increase in use amounts to a change in the character of the dominant tenement.

options.label: D
options.text: Whether the servient owner is entitled to payment for the increased use.

options.label: E
options.text: Whether the easement is a profit à prendre.

questions.explanation: C is correct. The core issue is whether the change from a private residence to a commercial hotel constitutes such a change in the character of the dominant tenement that the increased and different use of the right of way is outside the scope of the original grant. This is a question of degree. The grant to "guests and invitees" of a private house might be construed in that context; scaling it up to a hotel's constant traffic may be excessive. A is incorrect; there's no intention to abandon. B is incorrect, it is a sub-issue within the broader question of scope and character change. D is inco...

questions.text: In January 2024, Leo invited his friend Maya to live in the self-contained basement flat of his house. They signed a document titled "Licence Agreement," which stated Maya would pay £600 per month, had her own front door, and could exclude Leo and others from the flat. The term was stated as "from 1 February 2024 for a period of 12 months." The agreement was signed by both but was not executed as a deed. In June 2024, Leo decided to sell the house. The buyer, Nathan, is told Maya is a licensee. Maya claims she has a tenancy with security of tenure. Which of the following is the most accurate description of Maya’s legal position?

options.label: A
options.text: She has a legal lease because she has exclusive possession for a term certain.

options.label: B
options.text: She has an equitable lease because the agreement satisfies s.2 LP(MP)A 1989.

options.label: C
options.text: She is a licensee because the document is labelled a licence and the parties' intention governs.

options.label: D
options.text: She has a periodic tenancy arising from the payment and acceptance of rent.

options.label: E
options.text: She has no proprietary interest as the agreement was not by deed.

questions.explanation:
A is correct. The substance of the agreement is determinative (Street v Mountford). Maya has exclusive possession (own front door, right to exclude) for a term certain (12 months) at a rent. These are the hallmarks of a lease, regardless of the label "licence." A lease for a term not exceeding three years can be legal without a deed if it takes effect in possession at the best rent (s.54(2) LPA 1925). Here, the 12-month term meets this, so it is a legal lease.
B is incorrect; while the agreement may satisfy s.2, creating an equitable lease, that is only necessary for terms over three years. Fo...

questions.text: In 2020, Olivia granted a tenancy of a shop to Paolo "for the duration of the Covid-19 pandemic, but subject to termination by three months' notice by either party." Paolo paid a monthly rent and had exclusive possession. In 2023, with the pandemic officially declared over, Olivia served three months' notice to quit. Paolo refused to leave, arguing the tenancy continued until he chose to end it. What is the status of Paolo’s occupancy?

options.label: A
options.text: A lease for a fixed term of three years, now expired.

options.label: B
options.text: A periodic tenancy, terminable by reasonable notice.

options.label: C
options.text: A lease for a term of years absolute, which is still ongoing.

options.label: D
options.text: A licence, as the term was uncertain.

options.label: E
options.text: A tenancy at will.

questions.explanation: D is correct. A lease must have a certain maximum duration at the outset (Lace v Chantler). A term defined by the duration of the pandemic is uncertain. The presence of a break clause does not save it if the outer limit is unknown. Therefore, the agreement cannot create a leasehold estate. It is a licence, which can be terminated in accordance with its terms (three months' notice). A is incorrect; the term was not fixed at three years. B is incorrect; a periodic tenancy arises when the term is certain (e.g., week to week). Here, the initial term is void for uncertainty, so no periodic tenancy ...

questions.text: Tara granted a 10-year lease of a warehouse to Ben in 2018. The lease required Ben to keep the premises in "good and substantial repair and condition." In 2023, part of the roof collapsed due to latent defects present at the start of the lease, which were unknown to both parties. Ben argues the repair obligation does not extend to putting the property into a better state than it was at the start of the tenancy and refuses to pay for the full reconstruction. Is Ben correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, a tenant is only liable to keep the premises in the state they were in at the start of the lease.

options.label: B
options.text: No, a full repairing covenant obliges the tenant to put and keep the property in repair, which may include remedying inherent defects.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, latent defects are the landlord's responsibility under the common law rule of non-derogation from grant.

options.label: D
options.text: No, but only if the lease expressly includes a schedule of condition limiting the tenant's obligations.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, because the collapse was due to a defect existing at the grant, making it a landlord's repair under s.11 Landlord and Tenant Act 1985.

questions.explanation: B is correct. Under a full repairing covenant, the tenant's obligation to "keep" in repair includes an obligation to "put" into repair if the property is out of repair at the start of the lease (Proudfoot v Hart). This can extend to remedying inherent or latent defects, unless the covenant expressly excludes them. The phrase "good and substantial repair" reinforces this. A is incorrect; the covenant requires putting into repair if necessary. C is incorrect; non-derogation from grant prevents the landlord from rendering the property unfit for the contracted use, but it doesn't override express ...

questions.text: In 2019, Chloe granted a 15-year lease of an office to David. The lease contained a covenant prohibiting assignment without the landlord's consent, "such consent not to be unreasonably withheld." In 2024, David found a prospective assignee, Empire Ltd, a company with a strong financial covenant. Chloe withheld consent on the grounds that Empire Ltd intended to use the office for a call centre, which Chloe felt would devalue the building. The lease's user clause permits "office use (Class E)." A call centre falls within Use Class E. Has Chloe unreasonably withheld consent?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because a landlord can withhold consent for any reason connected with their property interest.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because the proposed use complies with the lease's user clause.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the landlord's subjective concern about devaluation is always reasonable.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if David can prove that Chloe acted maliciously.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the Landlord and Tenant Act 1988 does not apply to commercial leases.

questions.explanation:
B is correct. Under s.19(1A) of the Landlord and Tenant Act 1927 (as amended), in a lease with a qualified covenant against assignment, consent cannot be unreasonably withheld. The landlord must show reasonable grounds connected with the landlord’s interest as landlord. A dislike of a permitted use is not a reasonable ground. If the proposed use is within the lease's user clause, withholding consent based on that use is likely unreasonable (International Drilling Fluids Ltd v Louisville Investments (Uxbridge) Ltd).
A is incorrect; the right to withhold is subject to a test of reasonableness.
C...

questions.text: In 2017, a 10-year lease was granted to Felix. The lease contained a tenant's covenant to pay rent quarterly in advance. In 2023, Felix fell into arrears. The lease contained a proviso for re-entry "if the rent is 21 days in arrears, whether formally demanded or not." The landlord, Grace, wanted to forfeit the lease. She instructed her agent to verbally demand the rent from Felix. After 21 days of non-payment from the due date, Grace changed the locks while Felix was away. Is the forfeiture valid?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because Grace did not serve a formal written demand under s.210 of the Common Law Procedure Act 1852.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because the lease waived the requirement for formal demand.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because Grace did not obtain a court order for possession.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, because the rent was more than 21 days in arrears and Grace effected peaceable re-entry.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because forfeiture for non-payment of rent requires a section 146 notice.

questions.explanation:
D is correct. For non-payment of rent, a landlord may forfeit by peaceable re-entry without a court order, provided the lease contains a proviso for re-entry and the right has arisen. Here, the lease expressly waived the need for formal demand ("whether formally demanded or not"). The rent was 21 days in arrears, triggering the right. Peaceable re-entry (changing locks when the tenant is absent) is permissible if no force is used.
A is incorrect; the lease clause effectively waives the formal demand requirement. B is correct in outcome but D is more complete as it references the peaceable re-e...

questions.text: In 2020, a 5-year business lease was granted to "TechStart Ltd," a company owned by Mr. Khan. Mr. Khan signed the lease as director. The lease contained a covenant against altering the premises without consent. In 2023, TechStart Ltd went into administration. The administrators, without obtaining landlord's consent, removed partitioning to make the space more marketable for a sale of the business. The landlord claims this is a breach of covenant. Who is liable for this breach?

options.label: A
options.text: Only TechStart Ltd, as the tenant.

options.label: B
options.text: Only Mr. Khan personally, as he signed the lease.

options.label: C
options.text: The administrators personally, as they carried out the works.

options.label: D
options.text: Both TechStart Ltd and the administrators.

options.label: E
options.text: No one, as the company is in administration and the lease is disclaimed.

questions.explanation:
A is correct. The tenant is TechStart Ltd, the corporate entity that is party to the lease. The liability for breach of covenant rests with the tenant company. Directors or administrators acting on behalf of the company are not usually personally liable for the company's breaches, unless they have assumed personal responsibility, which is not indicated here.
B is incorrect; signing as a director does not create personal liability for lease covenants.
C is incorrect; administrators are officers of the court/company and are generally protected from personal liability when acting properly in thei...

questions.text: In 2018, landlord Lara granted a 7-year lease of a flat to tenant Tom. The lease was a formal deed and was registered at the Land Registry. In 2022, Tom orally agreed with his friend Uma that she could live in the flat for 18 months, paying Tom rent directly. Uma moved in. Tom later fell into arrears with Lara. Lara discovered Uma was in occupation and served a section 146 notice on Tom for breach of the covenant against parting with possession. Lara now seeks possession against Uma. What is Uma's status?

options.label: A
options.text: She is a lawful sub-tenant and is protected under the lease.

options.label: B
options.text: She is an assignee of Tom's lease.

options.label: C
options.text: She is a licensee whose interest terminates if Tom's lease is forfeited.

options.label: D
options.text: She has a tenancy by estoppel binding on Lara.

options.label: E
options.text: She is a tenant with direct privity of estate with Lara.

questions.explanation:
C is correct. Tom has granted a sub-lease (or more likely, given the oral agreement and lack of deed, an equitable sub-lease or licence). Uma's interest is derivative, carved out of Tom's leasehold estate. If the head lease (Tom's) is forfeited, the derivative interest (Uma's) is also destroyed, subject to the court's discretion to grant relief.
A is incorrect; she may be a sub-tenant, but she is not "protected" from the consequences of the head lease forfeiture.
B is incorrect; an assignment transfers the whole of the remaining term; an 18-month agreement is a sub-lease.
D is incorrect; a ten...

questions.text: In a 15-year lease granted in 2010, the original tenant, Alpha Ltd, assigned the lease to Beta Ltd in 2015 with the landlord's consent. In 2020, Beta Ltd assigned to Gamma Ltd, again with consent. The lease is an "old lease" (pre-1996). Gamma Ltd has now gone into liquidation, having failed to pay rent for six months. The landlord wishes to recover the arrears from Alpha Ltd. Can the landlord recover the arrears from Alpha Ltd?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because Alpha Ltd's liability ended when it assigned to Beta Ltd.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because under privity of contract, the original tenant remains liable for the duration of the lease.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the landlord consented to the assignments, releasing the prior tenants.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if Alpha Ltd entered into an Authorised Guarantee Agreement (AGA) on the assignment to Beta Ltd.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the Landlord and Tenant (Covenants) Act 1995 releases original tenants automatically.

questions.explanation:
B is correct. For leases granted before 1 January 1996 ("old leases"), the original tenant remains liable under privity of contract for the whole term, regardless of assignment, unless released by deed. The landlord's consent to assignment does not in itself release the original tenant.
A is incorrect for old leases. C is incorrect; consent does not equate to release. D is incorrect; AGAs are a creature of the Landlord and Tenant (Covenants) Act 1995, which applies to new leases (post-1996). For old leases, the original tenant's liability is automatic, not dependent on an AGA. E is incorrect; ...

questions.text: In 2022, a 10-year lease was granted containing a tenant's covenant "not to cause a nuisance or annoyance to the landlord or other tenants." The tenant plays loud music every night between 11 pm and 2 am. Other tenants complain. The lease contains a proviso for re-entry for any breach of covenant. The landlord wants to forfeit the lease. What is the first step the landlord must take?

options.label: A
options.text: Serve a section 146 notice specifying the breach and requiring remedy.

options.label: B
options.text: Apply immediately to the court for a possession order.

options.label: C
options.text: Serve a notice to quit.

options.label: D
options.text: Peaceably re-enter the premises.

options.label: E
options.text: Obtain an injunction to stop the nuisance first.

questions.explanation:
A is correct. For breaches of covenant other than non-payment of rent, a landlord must, before forfeiting, serve a notice under s.146 of the Law of Property Act 1925. The notice must specify the breach, require remedy (if remediable), and require compensation. The breach here (nuisance) is likely remediable (by stopping the noise). B is incorrect; a s.146 notice is a prerequisite to court proceedings for forfeiture for this type of breach.
C is incorrect; a notice to quit is for ending periodic tenancies, not forfeiting a fixed-term lease.
D is incorrect; peaceable re-entry is generally only p...

questions.text: In 2022, Zachary granted a legal charge over his registered freehold house, "Willow Cottage," to PrimeBank plc to secure a loan of £300,000. The charge was registered at HM Land Registry. In 2024, Zachary fell into arrears. PrimeBank appointed a receiver, Mr. Adams, under the powers in the charge deed. Mr. Adams collected rent from a tenant in the cottage, paid the ground rent and insurance, and then paid the surplus to PrimeBank to reduce the mortgage debt. Zachary claims Mr. Adams should have paid the surplus to him, as the receiver is his agent. Who is Mr. Adams acting as an agent for, and to whom does he owe his primary duty?

options.label: A
options.text: He is the agent of Zachary, the mortgagor, and owes him a duty of care.

options.label: B
options.text: He is the agent of PrimeBank, the mortgagee, and owes his primary duty to them.

options.label: C
options.text: He is an agent of the court, owing duties to both parties equally.

options.label: D
options.text: He is an independent fiduciary, acting in the best interests of the property itself.

options.label: E
options.text: He is the agent of the tenant, ensuring rent is collected properly.

questions.explanation: B is correct. A receiver appointed under a power in a mortgage deed, or under s.101 LPA 1925, is deemed by statute (s.109(2) LPA 1925) to be the agent of the mortgagor for the purpose of liability for acts and omissions. However, this is a statutory fiction for protecting third parties. In reality, and for the purpose of determining to whom he owes his primary duties (e.g., to maximise recovery for the loan), he is the agent of the mortgagee who appointed him (Barrow v Cross). His primary duty is to the mortgagee, though he also owes a duty to the mortgagor to act in good faith and with due ca...

questions.text: In 2020, Elara granted a first legal mortgage over her unregistered freehold farm, "Oaklands," to CountyBank by deed. The mortgage was never registered as a land charge. In 2023, Elara sold Oaklands to Finn for full market value. Finn was unaware of the mortgage. He applied for and obtained first registration of his title with absolute freehold. CountyBank now seeks to enforce its mortgage against Finn. What is the status of CountyBank’s mortgage?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a valid legal mortgage binding on Finn because it was created by deed.

options.label: B
options.text: It is void against Finn as it was not registered as a Class C(i) land charge.

options.label: C
options.text: It is an overriding interest binding on Finn because it is a legal interest.

options.label: D
options.text: It remains enforceable against Elara personally but does not bind the land in Finn’s hands.

options.label: E
options.text: It is void because the land was unregistered at the time of creation, requiring registration at the Land Registry.

questions.explanation: B is correct. For unregistered land, a legal mortgage not protected by the deposit of title deeds with the lender is a "puisne mortgage" and must be registered as a Class C(i) land charge under the Land Charges Act 1972 (LCA 1972). By virtue of s.4 of the LCA 1972, if such a land charge is not registered, it is void against a purchaser of the land for money or money's worth. Finn is such a purchaser. The fact that Finn later obtained first registration does not revive the void charge. A is incorrect because while it was valid between Elara and CountyBank, it loses priority against a purchaser ...

questions.text: MetroBank held a first legal charge over a registered freehold house. The borrowers defaulted. MetroBank exercised its power of sale. It instructed one estate agent, placed two online advertisements, and accepted an offer from its employee’s cousin at 20% below the latest professional valuation, completing the sale within a week. The borrowers sued, alleging MetroBank breached its duty in the sale. Which of the following best describes the nature of the duty breached?

options.label: A
options.text: A duty to obtain the best price reasonably possible, regardless of the speed of sale.

options.label: B
options.text: A duty to act in good faith, which it did by selling to a willing buyer.

options.label: C
options.text: A duty to take reasonable care to obtain the true market value at the time of sale.

options.label: D
options.text: A duty to consult the borrower before accepting any offer.

options.label: E
options.text: A duty to advertise the property for a minimum statutory period.

questions.explanation:
C is correct. A mortgagee exercising its power of sale owes a duty to take reasonable care to obtain the true market value of the property at the time of sale (Cuckmere Brick Co Ltd v Mutual Finance Ltd). This is not a duty to obtain the "best" price at all costs, but to take reasonable steps. The facts suggest a failure to take reasonable steps: using only one agent, minimal advertising, and a quick sale at a significant undervalue to a connected party.
A is incorrect; the duty is one of reasonable care, not an absolute duty to achieve the best price.
B is incorrect; good faith is required bu...

questions.text: In 2018, Mr. and Mrs. Chen granted a joint legal charge over their home to SecureHome Bank to secure a loan for their business. Mrs. Chen’s signature was forged by Mr. Chen. The bank’s clerk witnessed the signature without checking Mrs. Chen’s identity. The charge was registered. The business failed, and the bank sought possession. Mrs. Chen defended, arguing the charge was invalid due to the forgery. Is the charge valid and enforceable against Mrs. Chen?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because a forgery renders the charge void ab initio.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because the charge has been registered, and the register is conclusive under s.58 LRA 2002.

options.label: C
options.text: No, but the bank may have a claim in negligence against the clerk who witnessed it.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, because Mrs. Chen is estopped from denying the signature as she benefited from the loan.

options.label: E
options.text: It depends on whether the bank was a purchaser in good faith for value without notice of the forgery.

questions.explanation:
B is correct. Under the Land Registration Act 2002, once a person is registered as the proprietor of a charge, they acquire that legal estate (s.58). This is true even if the underlying disposition (the charge) was forged. The forgery makes the registration potentially liable to rectification, but until rectification occurs, the registered charge is valid and effective. Mrs. Chen’s remedy is to apply for rectification of the register and/or claim an indemnity.
A is incorrect; in registered land, the effect of registration can cure certain flaws.
C is incorrect. It does not answer the enforceab...

questions.text: In 2021, Sarah granted Bank A a legal charge over her registered freehold house to secure a £200,000 loan. The charge was registered. In 2023, Sarah needed more money and, with Bank A’s written agreement (contained in the original charge deed), took a further advance of £50,000 from Bank A, increasing the secured debt. Later in 2023, Sarah granted a second legal charge over the same property to Bank B for £75,000. Bank B’s charge was registered. Sarah defaulted on all loans. The property sells for £250,000. What is the order of priority for the proceeds?

options.label: A
options.text: Bank A gets £200,000, then Bank B gets £50,000.

options.label: B
options.text: Bank A gets £250,000, then Bank B gets nothing.

options.label: C
options.text: Bank A gets £200,000, Bank B gets £50,000, and the further £50,000 advance from Bank A.

options.label: D
options.text: Bank A gets £250,000 (including the further advance), and Bank B’s charge is postponed.

options.label: E
options.text: It depends on whether Bank B had notice of Bank A’s further advance clause.

questions.explanation: D is correct. This concerns "tacking" of further advances.
