Under s.49 of the Land Registration Act 2002, a registered chargee (Bank A) making a further advance has priority over any later registered charge (Bank B) if: (a) the earlier charge makes provision for further advances, AND (b) the later chargee did not serve a notice protecting their charge at the time of the further advance. Here, the original charge deed provided for further advances. There is no mention of Bank B serving a notice. Therefore, Bank A can "tack" its further advance (£50k) onto its original priority, meaning its entir...

questions.text: Delta Ltd, a company, granted a floating charge over "its present and future stock-in-trade" to FinanceCorp in 2022. The charge was registered at Companies House. In 2023, Delta Ltd bought a specific, valuable consignment of electronic components using a loan from TechBank. As part of that loan agreement, Delta Ltd granted TechBank a fixed charge over that specific consignment. TechBank’s charge was also registered. Delta Ltd is now insolvent. Which charge has priority over the consignment of electronic components?

options.label: A
options.text: FinanceCorp’s floating charge, as it was created first in time.

options.label: B
options.text: TechBank’s fixed charge, as fixed charges generally rank ahead of floating charges.

options.label: C
options.text: FinanceCorp’s floating charge, as it crystallises upon insolvency, catching all assets.

options.label: D
options.text: TechBank’s fixed charge, but only if it took possession of the components.

options.label: E
options.text: They rank equally and share the proceeds proportionately.

questions.explanation: B is correct. A fixed charge attaches to specific, identifiable assets and gives the chargee control. A floating charge hovers over a class of assets until crystallisation. As a general rule, a fixed charge over a specific asset has priority over a prior floating charge that covers that asset as part of a class, provided the fixed chargee did not have notice of a prohibition in the floating charge document (which is not mentioned here). This is because the floating charge, by its nature, allows the company to deal with assets in the ordinary course of business, which includes granting fixed ch...

questions.text: Mr. Khan had an existing mortgage with Lender X. He found a better rate with Lender Y. Lender Y advanced funds to Mr. Khan, which he used to pay off the outstanding debt to Lender X in full. Lender X discharged its charge. Due to a solicitor's error, Lender Y’s new legal charge was never registered before Mr. Khan unexpectedly sold the property to a third party, who was registered as proprietor. Lender Y has no security. What equitable remedy might assist Lender Y?

options.label: A
options.text: Foreclosure, to obtain the legal title.

options.label: B
options.text: Subrogation to the rights of Lender X.

options.label: C
options.text: Tacking its advance onto the old mortgage.

options.label: D
options.text: Rectification of the Land Register.

options.label: E
options.text: A claim for damages against the solicitor only.

questions.explanation: B is correct. The doctrine of subrogation applies where one person (Lender Y) pays off a secured debt of another (Mr. Khan’s debt to Lender X), intending to have that security for themselves. Equity will, in appropriate circumstances, treat Lender Y as being subrogated to the rights and priority of Lender X, as if Lender Y held the discharged charge. This is to prevent unjust enrichment of the borrower (who would otherwise own the property unencumbered). This equitable remedy can give Lender Y a security interest despite the failure to register its own charge. A is incorrect; foreclosure is a ...

questions.text: In 2018, Lisa granted a legal charge over her property to FastMoney Ltd. The charge deed included a clause stating, "The mortgagee shall have the power to appoint a receiver at any time after the execution of this deed." In 2024, Lisa was one day late on a payment. FastMoney immediately appointed a receiver. Lisa argues the power to appoint could only be exercised after a default was continuing. When can the power to appoint a receiver be exercised?

options.label: A
options.text: Only after serving a default notice and allowing a reasonable time to remedy.

options.label: B
options.text: At any time after the mortgage is created, if the deed expressly says so.

options.label: C
options.text: Only after the mortgagee has taken possession of the property.

options.label: D
options.text: Only when the mortgagor is in arrears for at least two months.

options.label: E
options.text: Only if the court grants an order under s.109 of the LPA 1925.

questions.explanation: B is correct. The power to appoint a receiver is a contractual power. The parties can agree in the deed when it arises. It is common for deeds to state the power arises "at any time after the execution of this deed," giving the mortgagee a very wide power. Statutory powers under s.109(1) LPA 1925 arise when the mortgage money has become due, but a well-drafted deed will often expand these. Therefore, if the deed says "at any time," it can be exercised even without a formal default. A and D are incorrect. It reflects typical statutory or common conditions, but they can be contracted out of or e...

questions.text: Mr. Jones granted a legal charge over his freehold house to Bank One in 2020. In 2022, he granted a second legal charge over the same property to Bank Two. Both charges were registered, Bank One’s first. Mr. Jones defaulted on both. Bank One appointed a receiver who sold the property. The net proceeds after costs were £275,000. Bank One was owed £250,000. Bank Two was owed £100,000. How should the proceeds be distributed?

options.label: A
options.text: Bank One: £250,000, Bank Two: £25,000, Mr. Jones: £0.

options.label: B
options.text: Bank One: £250,000, Mr. Jones: £25,000, Bank Two: £0.

options.label: C
options.text: Bank One: £175,000, Bank Two: £100,000, Mr. Jones: £0.

options.label: D
options.text: Bank One: £250,000, Bank Two: £100,000, with Bank Two pursuing Mr. Jones for the shortfall.

options.label: E
options.text: Bank One and Bank Two share proportionately: Bank One gets ~£206k, Bank Two gets ~£69k.

questions.explanation:
A is correct. Charges rank in priority according to the order of their creation/registration. Bank One, as the first chargee, has first claim on the proceeds to satisfy its secured debt, costs, and interest. Only if there is a surplus does the second chargee (Bank Two) receive anything. Here, the surplus after paying Bank One is £25,000 (£275k - £250k). This surplus is paid to Bank Two, but only up to the amount of its debt. Bank Two therefore receives £25,000, leaving a £75,000 unsecured debt it must pursue against Mr. Jones personally.
B is incorrect; the surplus goes to satisfy junior charg...

questions.text: In 1995, Simon, the freehold owner of a large estate known as "Oakwood," sold Plot 1 to Thomas. The conveyance deed contained a covenant by Thomas "not to build more than one dwelling house on Plot 1." The covenant was expressed to be for the benefit of Simon's retained land, Oakwood. Thomas registered the conveyance but did not register the covenant as a land charge. In 2010, Thomas sold Plot 1 to Uma. The transfer made no mention of the covenant. In 2023, Uma begins constructing a second house on Plot 1. Simon's successor in title to Oakwood, Priya, seeks an injunction to stop the building. Uma claims she is not bound by the covenant. Is the covenant enforceable against Uma?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because it is a restrictive covenant that touches and concerns Oakwood and Uma had notice of it.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the burden of a restrictive covenant does not run with freehold land at law.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because the covenant was contained in the 1995 conveyance, which Uma should have investigated.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because the covenant was not registered as a Class D(ii) land charge under the Land Charges Act 1972.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only if Priya can prove she owns the exact part of Oakwood intended to be benefited in 1995.

questions.explanation:
For unregistered land (as it was in 1995 when the covenant was created), a restrictive covenant is an equitable interest that must be registered as a Class D(ii) land charge under the Land Charges Act 1972 to bind successors in title. The facts state it was not registered. Uma is a purchaser of the legal estate for money or money's worth. Under s.4 of the LCA 1972, an unregistered Class D(ii) land charge is void against such a purchaser. Therefore, the burden did not pass to Uma.
Option A is incorrect because, although the covenant meets the substantive rules from Tulk v Moxhay, the lack of st...

questions.text: In 1980, as part of a building scheme for the "The Meadows" estate, every purchaser of a plot covenanted with the developer, and each other, "to contribute a fair proportion towards the maintenance of the private roads and communal gardens." This obligation was included in every conveyance. In 2023, Leo, the current owner of Plot 5, refuses to pay his annual share. The management company, formed by the residents, sues him. Leo argues the covenant is positive and its burden cannot run with freehold land. Can the management company enforce the covenant against Leo?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the burden of a positive covenant never runs with freehold land.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because the covenant was part of a building scheme, which creates a local law enforceable by and against all plot owners.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, under the doctrine of mutual benefit and burden, as Leo uses the roads and gardens.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because the management company was not a party to the original 1980 conveyances.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, because Leo's predecessor in title entered into a chain of indemnity covenants with the original developer.

questions.explanation:
In a valid building scheme (or scheme of development), a reciprocal set of covenants is created for the common benefit of all plots within a defined area. The principles from Elliston v Reacher establish that such schemes create a local law, enabling any plot owner to enforce both positive and restrictive covenants against any other, regardless of the usual rules about the running of burdens. The covenant to contribute to maintenance is positive, but within a building scheme, it can be enforced.
Option A is incorrect because, while the general rule from Rhone v Stephens is that the burden of a...

questions.text: In a 2005 conveyance of "The Paddock," the buyer, Claire, covenanted with the seller, David, "to maintain the boundary fence between The Paddock and David's retained field in good repair." The conveyance also granted Claire a right of way over David's field to access a public road. In 2023, David sells his field to Eva. The fence is now dilapidated. Eva, who uses the right of way daily, demands that Claire, still the owner of The Paddock, repair the fence. Claire refuses, arguing the burden of a positive covenant does not bind her as a successor to the original covenantor. Can Eva enforce the fencing covenant against Claire?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because the covenant touches and concerns the land and was intended to run.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the burden of a positive covenant does not run with freehold land.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, under the doctrine of mutual benefit and burden, because Claire uses the right of way.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because Eva was not a party to the original 2005 conveyance.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only if the covenant was registered as a land charge.

questions.explanation:
The doctrine of mutual benefit and burden, established in Halsall v Brizell, states that a person who claims a benefit under a deed must accept any corresponding burden attached to that same benefit. Here, Claire (as successor to the original covenantor) is claiming the benefit of the right of way granted in the 2005 conveyance. The burden of maintaining the fence is arguably imposed in the same deed and is related to the use of the land. Therefore, if Claire wishes to exercise the benefit (the right of way), she may be required to bear the attached burden (fence maintenance).
Option A is inco...

questions.text: In 1975, a deed granted the owners of "Marine Villa" a right to use a private seawall for access and recreation. The same deed imposed a covenant on those owners "to contribute to the cost of maintaining the seawall." For decades, all owners paid. In 2022, Mr. Khan bought Marine Villa. He uses the seawall for walking but refuses to pay the maintenance contribution, arguing he never personally agreed to the covenant. The management association sues for his share. What is the strongest legal basis for the claim against Mr. Khan?

options.label: A
options.text: The burden of the positive covenant runs with the land because it is connected to an easement.

options.label: B
options.text: Mr. Khan cannot take the benefit of using the seawall without accepting the burden of maintaining it.

options.label: C
options.text: The covenant is implied into Mr. Khan's purchase contract by virtue of section 62 LPA 1925.

options.label: D
options.text: Mr. Khan is liable as the original covenantor through privity of contract.

options.label: E
options.text: The covenant is a rentcharge, which is a legal interest binding successors.

questions.explanation: This is a classic application of the doctrine of mutual benefit and burden from Halsall v Brizell. The right to use the seawall is a benefit granted by the deed. The obligation to contribute to maintenance is a burden imposed by the same deed. The doctrine states that a person who wishes to take the benefit must also submit to the burden. Mr. Khan is using the benefit; therefore, he must pay. Option A is incorrect; the burden of a positive covenant does not run with freehold land simply because it is connected to an easement. The connection allows enforcement via the Halsall doctrine, not a di...

questions.text: In 1985, as part of a sale of land, the purchaser covenanted "to build and thereafter maintain a stock-proof fence along the northern boundary." The covenant did not mention the vendor's retained land. The purchaser built the fence. In 2020, the current owner of the originally sold land (the successor to the covenantor) allows the fence to fall into disrepair. The current owner of the vendor's retained land (the successor to the covenantee) seeks specific performance to compel repair. Will the court order specific performance?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because the covenant touches and concerns the land.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because the burden of a positive covenant does not run with freehold land.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, under the doctrine of mutual benefit and burden if the claimant can show they rely on the fence.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because specific performance is not available for covenants to repair fences.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only if the covenant was registered as a land charge.

questions.explanation:
The covenant "to build and thereafter maintain" is positive. The general rule from Rhone v Stephens is that the burden of a positive covenant cannot run with freehold land at law or in equity. Therefore, the successor to the original covenantor is not bound by the burden. The claimant can only sue the original covenantor for damages. Specific performance is an equitable remedy that would require the defendant to be subject to the covenant, which they are not.
Option A is incorrect; while it may touch and concern the land, that relates to the running of the benefit, not the burden. The central ...

questions.text: In 2010, Fiona sold part of her garden to George. George covenanted for himself and his successors in title "not to park any commercial vehicles on the property." The covenant was for the benefit of Fiona's retained house. In 2023, George sells to Hannah. Hannah parks her sign-written van for her gardening business on the drive. Fiona's successor in title, Ian, objects. Hannah argues the van is essential for her small business and that the covenant is an unreasonable restraint on trade. Is the covenant enforceable against Hannah?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because covenants in restraint of trade are void as against public policy.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because a restrictive covenant affecting freehold land is a property right, not a restraint on an individual's trade.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the covenant does not touch and concern Ian's land.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if Ian can prove that the van causes a nuisance.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the covenant is not registered.

questions.explanation:
A covenant restricting the use of land (e.g., no commercial vehicles) is a proprietary obligation that runs with the land. It is not a personal restraint on trade of the type that is void under common law. Its validity depends on property law principles, not employment/competition law. As a restrictive covenant that touches and concerns the benefited land, it is enforceable provided the benefit and burden have passed.
Option A is incorrect; the doctrine of restraint of trade applies to contracts restricting a person's freedom to work or carry on business, not to covenants regulating the use of...

questions.text: In 1998, a developer sold plots on the "Forest View" estate. Each conveyance contained identical covenants, including one "not to erect any fence over one metre in height." The common intention was to maintain open, landscaped front gardens. In 2023, Mr. Lee, an owner on the estate, erects a two-metre high solid fence. Ms. Chen, an owner of another plot on the estate, seeks an injunction. There is no express assignment of the benefit of covenants between plot owners. Can Ms. Chen enforce the covenant?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because there is no privity of contract or estate between her and Mr. Lee.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because the covenants form part of a building scheme, creating reciprocal rights between all plot owners.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the covenant is a positive obligation (to keep a low fence) and its burden does not run.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if she can show her property is affected by the breach more than other plots.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the benefit of the covenant was not expressly assigned to her when she bought her plot.

questions.explanation:
The facts describe the classic elements of a building scheme: a defined estate, a common vendor, identical covenants imposed on all plots, and an intention that the covenants are for the mutual benefit of all plots. Under the principles from Elliston v Reacher, such a scheme creates a "local law," allowing any plot owner to enforce the covenants against any other. There is no need for an express assignment of the benefit. Option A is incorrect; privity is not required within a building scheme. The scheme itself creates the necessary nexus.
Option C is incorrect; a covenant "not to erect" a hig...

questions.text: In 2005, Adam sold land to Bella. Bella covenanted with Adam "to use the land for agricultural purposes only." The covenant was expressed to be for the benefit of Adam's retained farm. In 2015, Adam sold half of his retained farm to Charles. The conveyance to Charles did not mention the 2005 covenant. In 2024, Bella starts using her land for storing construction machinery. Charles seeks to enforce the covenant. Can Charles enforce it?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because the benefit of a restrictive covenant runs with the land.

options.label: B
options.text: No, because when Adam sold part of the benefited land to Charles, the benefit was not assigned to him.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, if the benefit was annexed to the whole of Adam's retained farm, it passes with any part of that land.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because Charles was not the original covenantee and the covenant was personal to Adam.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only if Bella had notice of the assignment of the benefit to Charles.

questions.explanation: Where the benefit of a restrictive covenant is annexed to the whole of a defined piece of land, it is generally considered annexed to every part of that land, unless a contrary intention appears. This is the principle from Federated Homes Ltd v Mill Lodge Properties Ltd, where section 78 of the LPA 1925 was held to have this effect. Therefore, when Adam sold part of the benefited land to Charles, the benefit passed automatically with that part. There is no need for an express assignment. Option A is incorrect. It is too general and does not address the issue of severance of the benefited land....

questions.text: In 2005, Sienna sold a plot of land, "Plot A," to Theo. The transfer deed contained a covenant by Theo "to maintain the boundary fence between Plot A and Sienna's retained land, Plot B, in good repair." In 2010, Theo sold Plot A to Uma. The transfer deed between Theo and Uma contained a covenant by Uma to observe the 2005 covenants and to indemnify Theo against any breach. Uma did no maintenance and the fence fell into disrepair. In 2023, Sienna sold Plot B to Vince. Vince now seeks to enforce the fence maintenance covenant against Uma. The land is unregistered. The 2005 covenant was never registered as a land charge. Can Vince compel Uma to repair the fence?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, because the burden of the positive covenant passed to Uma under the rule in Tulk v Moxhay.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because Uma covenanted directly with Theo to observe the covenant, creating a chain of indemnity.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the burden of a positive covenant does not run with freehold land at law or in equity.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if Vince can also prove that Uma had notice of the covenant when she bought Plot A.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because Sienna sold Plot B, so the benefit of the covenant was extinguished.

questions.explanation:
C is correct. This is a classic positive covenant (to spend money on maintenance). The burden of a positive covenant cannot run with freehold land to bind successors in title, either at law (Austerberry v Oldham) or in equity (Rhone v Stephens). This is a fundamental rule of land law. The chain of indemnity (B) creates personal contractual obligations between Theo and Uma, but does not allow Vince (a stranger to that contract) to enforce the burden against Uma. Vince can only enforce the covenant against the original covenantor, Theo, in contract.
A is incorrect; Tulk v Moxhay only allows the ...

questions.text: In 1985, the owner of a large lakeside estate, "Lakeview," sold a plot to Dr. Foster. The conveyance granted Dr. Foster "the right to use the private lake for boating and swimming." In return, Dr. Foster covenanted "to contribute a fair share towards the maintenance costs of the lake and its surrounding jetties." Dr. Foster paid these costs for years. In 2022, Dr. Foster sold the plot to the Goodwin family. The Goodwins use the lake but refuse to pay the maintenance contribution, arguing the obligation is a positive covenant whose burden does not bind them. The estate owner claims they must pay to use the lake. Is the estate owner likely to succeed?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the burden of a positive covenant to pay money cannot run with the land.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, as the Goodwins are claiming the benefit of using the lake.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the obligation to pay is not fixed in amount and is therefore void for uncertainty.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, because the covenant is a rentcharge, which is a legal interest that binds successors.

options.label: E
options.text: No, unless the obligation was registered as a land charge.

questions.explanation: B is correct. The doctrine of mutual benefit and burden, originating from Halsall v Brizell, states that a person who claims a benefit under a deed or agreement must accept any corresponding burden that is intrinsically linked to that benefit. Here, the right to use the lake (the benefit) and the obligation to contribute to its maintenance (the burden) are created in the same conveyance and are clearly linked. The Goodwins, by exercising the right to use the lake, must also bear the burden of contributing to its upkeep. This is a recognised equitable exception to the general rule that positive...

questions.text: Thomas is acting for Liam, a first-time buyer purchasing a Victorian freehold terrace house for £350,000. After receiving the draft contract and official copy entries from the seller’s solicitor, Thomas explains to Liam the next stage of the process. Liam is confused about the purpose of the various searches his solicitor is ordering, asking why they are necessary when the bank is also doing a valuation. Thomas prepares to explain the fundamental purpose of these pre-contract searches from a legal perspective. What is the primary legal purpose of the buyer’s solicitor conducting pre-contract searches?

options.label: A
options.text: To value the property for mortgage purposes.

options.label: B
options.text: To uncover hidden legal, environmental, or practical risks.

options.label: C
options.text: To finalise the mortgage offer from the lender.

options.label: D
options.text: To approve the seller’s legal title to the property.

options.label: E
options.text: To satisfy the requirements of the estate agent.

questions.explanation: B is correct. The core purpose of pre-contract searches (local authority, environmental, drainage, etc.) is due diligence to discover issues not evident from the title documents or a physical inspection, such as planning breaches, contamination, or drainage liabilities. A is incorrect, as valuation is a separate process for the lender. C is incorrect; searches inform the transaction but do not finalise the mortgage. D is incorrect; title approval comes from investigating the official copies or epitome, not searches alone. E is incorrect; estate agents have no formal role in the legal search pr...

questions.text: Eleanor is selling her 1930s semi-detached house. During a meeting with her solicitor, David, she mentions that the ground-floor bathroom addition was built by a previous owner and she has never seen any building regulations certificate for it. She asks David if she needs to volunteer this information to potential buyers. David advises her on the principle of caveat emptor and its application to her situation. In the context of pre-contract enquiries, what does the principle of caveat emptor primarily mean?

options.label: A
options.text: The seller must disclose all known physical defects in the property.

options.label: B
options.text: The buyer bears the risk of discovering defects through their own enquiries.

options.label: C
options.text: The seller guarantees the property is fit for habitation.

options.label: D
options.text: The solicitor must ensure all material facts are revealed.

options.label: E
options.text: The buyer can claim compensation for any defect found after completion.

questions.explanation: B is correct. Caveat emptor ("let the buyer beware") is a cornerstone principle, placing the onus on the buyer to investigate the property's condition. The seller's duty to disclose is limited, primarily to answering enquiries accurately (as established in cases like Keates v Cadogan). A is incorrect; there is no general duty to volunteer information. C is incorrect; there is no implied guarantee of fitness. D is incorrect; the solicitor's duty is to advise their client (the seller) on the law, not to independently disclose. E is incorrect; post-completion remedies are very limited unless misr...

questions.text: Michael is acting for Chloe, who is buying a freehold cottage. The Local Authority Search (CON29) reveals an extant enforcement notice related to an unauthorised rear extension constructed five years ago. Michael receives the search results two weeks before the anticipated exchange date. What is the most appropriate immediate action for Michael to take upon receiving this adverse search result?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately advise Chloe to withdraw from the transaction to avoid risk.

options.label: B
options.text: Contact Chloe’s mortgage lender and await their instructions before proceeding.

options.label: C
options.text: Raise a detailed pre-contract enquiry with the seller’s solicitor to investigate the notice.

options.label: D
options.text: Recommend that Chloe purchases indemnity insurance to cover the enforcement risk.

options.label: E
options.text: Proceed to exchange contracts, as the risk will pass to Chloe upon exchange.

questions.explanation: C is correct. The solicitor's duty is to investigate adverse findings. The first step is to raise further enquiries (e.g., via the TA6 form or additional questions) to ascertain the full facts, whether the notice is still live, and if retrospective consent is possible. A is incorrect; withdrawal is a premature decision before investigation and potential negotiation. B is incorrect; while the lender must eventually be informed, the primary duty is to the client to investigate first. D is incorrect; insurance is a potential solution, but only after investigation shows the problem cannot be easil...

questions.text: Sophie’s solicitor, Mike, is conducting due diligence for her purchase of a converted warehouse apartment. The environmental search report flags that the site was previously a small industrial laundry, indicating a potential for land contamination. Mike explains to Sophie the significance of this under current legislation. Why is the environmental search result particularly critical under the Environmental Protection Act 1990?

options.label: A
options.text: It determines the cost of buildings insurance for the property.

options.label: B
options.text: It shows whether the local authority will require a monitoring fee.

options.label: C
options.text: It can reveal if the seller is liable for clean-up costs.

options.label: D
options.text: It identifies potential liability for the buyer to fund clean-up costs.

options.label: E
options.text: It indicates if the property is eligible for a green grant.

questions.explanation: D is correct. Under the Environmental Protection Act 1990, liability for cleaning up contaminated land can fall on the current "appropriate person," which can include the present owner or occupier, even if they did not cause the contamination. This creates a significant potential financial liability for the buyer. A is incorrect; while it may affect insurance, the Act's main thrust is liability. B is incorrect; this is not a primary concern of the Act. C is incorrect; while the seller could be liable, the search is crucial to protect the buyer from inheriting liability. E is incorrect; grants ...

questions.text: Daniel and Priya are purchasing their first home together as a couple. Their solicitor, Fiona, is discussing how they wish to hold the legal title. Daniel has contributed 75% of the deposit from an inheritance, while Priya has contributed 25% from her savings. They want this financial contribution to be legally reflected in their ownership. What is the most appropriate way for Fiona to implement their wishes?

options.label: A
options.text: Advise them to hold as joint tenants, as this is standard for couples.

options.label: B
options.text: Recommend a tenancy in common, supported by a declaration of trust.

options.label: C
options.text: Suggest sole ownership in Daniel’s name with an informal agreement.

options.label: D
options.text: Advise a joint tenancy but with a restriction (Form A) on the title.

options.label: E
options.text: Recommend they hold as tenants in common without any written document.

questions.explanation: B is correct. A tenancy in common allows for ownership in distinct, unequal shares. A declaration of trust is a vital document to expressly record their beneficial interests (75%/25%), preventing future disputes. A is incorrect; a joint tenancy presumes equal shares and includes the right of survivorship, which does not reflect their unequal contributions. C is incorrect; this does not give Priya any legal ownership and is insecure. D is incorrect; a Form A restriction is used to protect a tenancy in common, not a joint tenancy. E is incorrect; while a legal tenancy in common can exist without...

questions.text: Olivia’s sale and James’s purchase of a freehold house are ready to exchange. James’s solicitor, Ben, holds both signed parts of the contract. Olivia’s solicitor, Anya, holds the deposit as stakeholder. They agree to exchange using the Law Society’s Formula B. Which of the following best describes the key mechanism of exchange under Formula B?

options.label: A
options.text: Both signed parts are held by one solicitor who dates them upon a telephone agreement.

options.label: B
options.text: Exchange is conditional upon the simultaneous exchange in a related chain of transactions.

options.label: C
options.text: The solicitors agree over the telephone, and then the buyer’s solicitor posts the seller’s signed part.

options.label: D
options.text: The deposit must be physically transferred before the telephone call takes place.

options.label: E
options.text: The seller’s solicitor must be in possession of the buyer’s signed contract before the call.

questions.explanation: C is correct. Under Formula B, the buyer’s solicitor typically holds both signed contracts. Exchange is effected by a telephone agreement, after which the buyer’s solicitor dates both parts and posts the seller’s signed counterpart to the seller’s solicitor. A is incorrect; this describes Formula A. B is incorrect; this describes Formula C for chains. D is incorrect; the deposit is usually held by the seller’s solicitor as stakeholder from the outset, not transferred at exchange. E is incorrect; in Formula B, the buyer’s solicitor holds the buyer’s part.

questions.text: One week after exchanging contracts on a freehold house using the Standard Conditions of Sale (5th Ed.), a severe storm causes a tree to fall through the roof. Completion is still two weeks away. The seller, Catherine, had maintained buildings insurance, but the buyer, Robert, had not yet arranged his own policy. Who bears the financial risk of this damage under the standard contractual terms?

options.label: A
options.text: Catherine, the seller, as she was the one insured at the time.

options.label: B
options.text: Robert, the buyer, as risk passed to him on exchange of contracts.

options.label: C
options.text: The loss lies where it falls, so neither party can claim.

options.label: D
options.text: Catherine, because she remains the legal owner until completion.

options.label: E
options.text: They share the loss equally, as the damage occurred before completion.

questions.explanation: B is correct. Under SC 5.1.1, the property is at the buyer’s risk from the date of exchange. This is a fundamental principle confirmed in Rayner v Preston. The buyer should have arranged insurance from exchange. A is incorrect; the seller’s insurance is irrelevant to the contractual allocation of risk. C is incorrect; the contract clearly allocates risk. D is incorrect; legal ownership is separate from risk, which passes earlier. E is incorrect; the contract does not provide for sharing loss in this way.

questions.text: Mark is selling a freehold property as executor of his late aunt’s estate. His solicitor, Helen, is drafting the contract. Helen explains that Mark will be giving a different title guarantee than a typical individual seller. What is the key implication of giving a limited title guarantee rather than a full title guarantee?

options.label: A
options.text: The seller guarantees there are no restrictive covenants affecting the property.

options.label: B
options.text: The seller promises they have not created any encumbrances during their ownership.

options.label: C
options.text: The seller warrants the property’s condition and fitness for habitation.

options.label: D
options.text: The seller insures the buyer against all pre-existing title defects.

options.label: E
options.text: The seller is personally liable for all historical breaches of covenant.

questions.explanation: B is correct. A limited title guarantee, typical for executors and trustees, implies only that the seller has not themselves created or allowed any encumbrances during their period of ownership. It does not guarantee against issues that existed before. A is incorrect; a limited guarantee does not cover pre-existing covenants. C is incorrect; title guarantees relate to legal rights, not physical condition. D is incorrect; this describes title indemnity insurance, not a guarantee. E is incorrect; liability is limited to the seller’s own acts/omissions.

questions.text: The day before completion on a freehold purchase, Noah’s solicitor, Maria, conducts an OS1 priority search at HM Land Registry. What is the central function of this final pre-completion search?

options.label: A
options.text: To verify the seller’s identity for anti-money laundering purposes.

options.label: B
options.text: To confirm there are no planning enforcement notices against the property.

options.label: C
options.text: To protect the priority of the buyer’s application to register their title.

options.label: D
options.text: To check the seller has discharged their mortgage.

options.label: E
options.text: To obtain an updated official copy of the register for review.

questions.explanation: C is correct. The OS1 search reserves priority for the buyer’s application to register the transfer for 30 working days. This prevents another interest (e.g., a charge from the seller’s creditor) being registered first. A is incorrect; ID verification is done earlier. B is incorrect; planning issues are revealed by the local search. D is incorrect; discharge of the mortgage is arranged via undertakings, not an OS1. E is incorrect; while it may reveal new entries, its official purpose is to secure priority.

questions.text: On the morning of completion, Grace’s solicitor, Paul, is preparing to transfer the balance of the purchase price. He instructs his accounts team to send the funds via CHAPS. What is the principal reason for using the CHAPS payment system on completion day?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the most inexpensive method of electronic funds transfer.

options.label: B
options.text: It provides a guarantee that funds will clear on the same day.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows for the transaction to be reversed within 24 hours if needed.

options.label: D
options.text: It does not require the receiving solicitor to have a client account.

options.label: E
options.text: It automatically generates the completion statement for both parties.

questions.explanation: B is correct. CHAPS is a same-day, guaranteed cleared funds transfer system. This is essential for completion, where keys and the transfer deed are released upon confirmation of irrevocable receipt of funds. A is incorrect; CHAPS is typically more expensive than BACS. C is incorrect; CHAPS payments are irrevocable once processed. D is incorrect; funds must be sent to a nominated account, almost always a client account. E is incorrect; completion statements are separate documents.

questions.text: Following completion of her purchase of a London freehold flat for £475,000, Emma’s solicitor, Ahmed, is managing the post-completion formalities. Emma is not a first-time buyer. Within what statutory timeframe must Ahmed submit the SDLT return and payment to HMRC?

options.label: A
options.text: 14 calendar days from the date of exchange of contracts.

options.label: B
options.text: 30 calendar days from the date of completion.

options.label: C
options.text: 14 calendar days from the date of completion.

options.label: D
options.text: 30 working days from the date of completion.

options.label: E
options.text: On or before the date of registration at the Land Registry.

questions.explanation: C is correct. Under the Finance Act 2003, the SDLT return (SDLT1) and any tax due must be submitted to HMRC within 14 calendar days of the ‘effective date,’ which is usually the date of completion. A is incorrect; the trigger is completion. B and D are incorrect; 30 days is the deadline for Land Transaction Tax (LTT) in Wales. E is incorrect; the SDLT deadline is independent of, and prior to, the Land Registry application.

questions.text: After completing on a freehold purchase, David’s solicitor, Lisa, is preparing the application to register him as the new proprietor at HM Land Registry. She recalls she conducted an OS1 priority search two days before completion. For how long does the priority period conferred by that OS1 search last?

options.label: A
options.text: 14 calendar days from the date of the search.

options.label: B
options.text: 30 working days from the date of the search.

options.label: C
options.text: 30 calendar days from the date of the search.

options.label: D
options.text: Indefinitely, until the Land Registry processes the application.

options.label: E
options.text: 60 calendar days from the date of completion.

questions.explanation: B is correct. The priority period granted by a successful OS1 (or OS2) search is 30 working days from its date. The registration application must be lodged within this period to maintain the buyer’s priority against any intervening interests. A, C, D, and E are incorrect; they do not reflect the statutory priority period under Land Registry rules.

questions.text: As part of the completion process for a sale, the seller’s solicitor, Jennifer, provides an undertaking to the buyer’s solicitor. She promises to redeem her client’s existing mortgage using the completion monies and to forward the electronic discharge to the Land Registry. What is the legal nature of this professional undertaking?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a binding promise made personally by the solicitor, enforceable by the courts.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a conditional promise that only becomes binding if the seller’s lender cooperates.

options.label: C
options.text: It is an informal courtesy between solicitors with no disciplinary consequences.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a contract between the two law firms, requiring consideration to be valid.

options.label: E
options.text: It is a guarantee provided by the solicitor’s professional indemnity insurer.

questions.explanation: A is correct. A solicitor’s undertaking is a solemn, personally binding promise enforceable through the courts and the Solicitors Regulation Authority (SRA), regardless of consideration. Breach can lead to serious professional consequences. B is incorrect; the solicitor must only give an undertaking if they are sure they can fulfil it. C is incorrect; undertakings are formal and carry significant weight. D is incorrect; consideration is not required for an undertaking to be binding. E is incorrect; the insurer is not a party to the undertaking.

questions.text: During title investigation for a freehold house, Ben’s solicitor, Chloe, discovers a 1950s restrictive covenant stating "not more than one dwelling house shall be erected on the land." Ben’s surveyor suggests the large plot could potentially accommodate a second home in the future. Chloe advises on the available options. What is often the most practical initial solution for managing this type of historic, seemingly dormant covenant?

options.label: A
options.text: Apply to the Upper Tribunal (Lands Chamber) immediately to have it discharged.

options.label: B
options.text: Advise Ben to proceed regardless, as the covenant is likely unenforceable due to its age.

options.label: C
options.text: Recommend the purchase of title indemnity insurance against the risk of enforcement.

options.label: D
options.text: Require the seller to obtain a formal release from the original covenantee’s successors.

options.label: E
options.text: Report it to the lender as a fatal defect that prevents the mortgage from proceeding.

questions.explanation: C is correct. For old covenants where the beneficiary is hard to identify and there is no history of enforcement, title indemnity insurance is a common, cost-effective, and practical solution to protect the buyer and lender against future claims. A is incorrect; a Tribunal application is lengthy, costly, and uncertain, making it a last resort. B is incorrect; age alone does not extinguish a covenant, and advising to ignore it is risky. D is incorrect; this is often impossible if the beneficiaries are unknown. E is incorrect; while it must be reported, it is not automatically a fatal defect if ...

questions.text: Laura is selling an unregistered freehold farmhouse. Her solicitor, Simon, provides the buyer’s solicitor with an epitome of title. The first document in the epitome is a conveyance dated 12 years ago. The buyer’s solicitor reviews the papers. What is the correct response from the buyer’s solicitor regarding this root of title?

options.label: A
options.text: Accept it, as it clearly shows ownership for over a decade.

options.label: B
options.text: Reject it and insist on a root of title at least 15 years old.

options.label: C
options.text: Accept it if the seller also provides a statutory declaration as to possession.

options.label: D
options.text: Proceed but recommend the buyer only accepts a possessory title at first registration.

options.label: E
options.text: Accept it, provided the seller agrees to give a full title guarantee.

questions.explanation: B is correct. For unregistered land, a valid root of title must be at least 15 years old (typically a conveyance). A 12-year-old root is defective. The seller’s solicitor must deduce title correctly; the buyer should reject the epitome and request a proper root. A is incorrect; 15 years is the minimum. C is incorrect; a statutory declaration cannot cure a defective root for the purposes of deducing title pre-contract. D is incorrect; the defect is in the pre-registration title proof, not the class of title that will be applied for. E is incorrect; the title guarantee is unrelated to the validi...

questions.text: The seller, Mr. Higgins, completed the TA6 Property Information Form stating there were "no disputes" with neighbours. After moving in, the buyer, Ms. Archer, is immediately approached by the next-door neighbour asserting a right to use a path on her property and referencing a long-running argument with Mr. Higgins. Ms. Archer’s solicitor now considers potential claims. What is the buyer’s strongest potential legal claim against the seller in these circumstances?

options.label: A
options.text: Breach of the covenant for quiet enjoyment implied in the transfer deed.

options.label: B
options.text: A claim in misrepresentation based on a false statement in the TA6 form.

options.label: C
options.text: A claim under the principle of caveat emptor for failing to discover the issue.

options.label: D
options.text: A claim for breach of the seller’s full title guarantee.

options.label: E
options.text: A negligence claim against the seller’s solicitor for poor drafting.

questions.explanation: B is correct. A false statement of fact on the TA6 ("no disputes") can found a claim for misrepresentation, potentially allowing rescission or damages (as seen in cases like With v O’Flanagan). A is incorrect; the covenant for quiet enjoyment is a future covenant against the seller’s own acts, not a representation about past disputes. C is incorrect; caveat emptor is a defence for the seller, not a cause of action for the buyer. D is incorrect; title guarantee relates to ownership rights, not disputes with neighbours. E is incorrect; while possible, the primary direct claim would be against th...

questions.text: Sarah is purchasing a new-build freehold house from a developer. Her solicitor, Kevin, is reviewing the planning documentation included in the pre-contract pack. He pays particular attention to any agreement made under Section 106 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990. Why is reviewing a Section 106 agreement critically important for a buyer of a new-build property?

options.label: A
options.text: It certifies that the building regulations have been fully complied with.

options.label: B
options.text: It may impose ongoing financial or other obligations on the homeowners.

options.label: C
options.text: It proves that the property is not subject to any restrictive covenants.

options.label: D
options.text: It replaces the need for a Local Authority Search on a new development.

options.label: E
options.text: It guarantees the developer has obtained all necessary highway approvals.

questions.explanation: B is correct. Section 106 agreements are planning obligations used to make a development acceptable. They often require contributions for infrastructure (e.g., schools, roads) or the provision of affordable housing. These obligations can create financial charges or other liabilities that may bind the property and its owners. A is incorrect; building regulations are a separate regime. C is incorrect; S106 agreements are planning obligations, not private restrictive covenants. D is incorrect; a local search is still essential to reveal other matters. E is incorrect; highway approvals are separat...

questions.text: The completion statement prepared by the seller’s solicitor includes an apportionment of the annual council tax charge. Completion is set for the 20th of June. The full annual bill of £1,200 is due from April. How should the council tax be correctly apportioned on the completion statement?

options.label: A
options.text: The seller is liable for the entire quarterly bill covering June.

options.label: B
options.text: It is apportioned daily, with the seller liable from 1st June up to and including 19th June.

options.label: C
options.text: It is split 50/50 between the buyer and seller for the month of June.

options.label: D
options.text: The buyer is responsible for the whole amount from the start of the month of completion.

options.label: E
options.text: No apportionment is needed; the buyer simply takes over the council tax account from completion.

questions.explanation: B is correct. Under SC 6.3, outgoings are apportioned on a daily basis. The seller is responsible for the day up to, but not including, the date of completion. Therefore, the seller is liable for 19 days of June (1st-19th inclusive), and the buyer from 20th June onwards. A, C, and D are incorrect; they do not follow the standard contractual formula for daily apportionment. E is incorrect; while the buyer will set up a new account, the seller remains liable for their period of ownership, necessitating an apportionment and financial settlement on completion.

questions.text: Two days before the scheduled completion, Ben informs his solicitor, Rachel, in strict confidence that he has just been made redundant and is very worried about affording the mortgage. Rachel’s firm is also acting for the mortgage lender in this transaction. Ben asks Rachel what he should do. In light of this confidential information, what is Rachel’s first and most important professional obligation?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately inform the mortgage lender of this material change in circumstances.

options.label: B
options.text: Advise Ben to keep the information to himself and hope to find a new job quickly.

options.label: C
options.text: Continue to act for both parties, as the contract is already binding.

options.label: D
options.text: Cease acting for both the buyer and the lender due to an immediate conflict of interest.

options.label: E
options.text: Proceed with completion as planned, as the funds have already been drawn down.

questions.explanation: D is correct. Rachel now holds confidential information (the redundancy) material to the lender’s security. She cannot disclose it to the lender without Ben’s consent (breaching confidentiality to her client), but she also cannot continue acting for the lender while withholding material information (breaching her duty to the lender). This irreconcilable conflict means she must cease acting for both parties immediately. A is incorrect; this would breach her duty of confidentiality to Ben. B and E are incorrect; they involve giving negligent advice and failing to manage the conflict. C is incorr...

areas.name: Ethics and Risk Management in Conveyancing.

questions.text: Jonathan and Emily are close friends. Jonathan is selling his flat, and Emily wishes to buy it. They approach the same solicitor, Clara, asking her to act for both of them to save costs. They assure Clara they have agreed on the price and terms and trust each other completely. Clara considers the SRA Code of Conduct and the specific risks of acting for both parties in a residential conveyancing transaction. What is the most appropriate initial advice for Clara to give Jonathan and Emily?

options.label: A
options.text: Agree to act for both, as they are friends and the transaction is non-contentious.

options.label: B
options.text: Decline to act for either party, as dual representation is always prohibited in conveyancing.

options.label: C
options.text: Explain the inherent conflicts and that she can only act if she is satisfied it is a commercial transaction with a substantially common interest.

options.label: D
options.text: Agree to act but recommend they both seek independent legal advice on the key terms.

options.label: E
options.text: Refuse to act for the seller only..

questions.explanation:
C is correct. While acting for both buyer and seller in a residential transaction is generally prohibited under SRA r. 6.2 due to inherent conflicts, the Code allows exceptions in limited circumstances, such as non-contentious commercial transactions with a substantially common interest or where the parties are related. Clara must first assess if this can be treated as such, obtain informed consent, and implement safeguards.
A is incorrect; friendship does not override the fundamental conflict of interest in a typical arm’s-length sale.
B is incorrect; it is not always prohibited, but the exce...

questions.text: Sophie, a solicitor, is acting for both a buyer, David, and his mortgage lender on a standard residential purchase. Two days before completion, David informs Sophie in strict confidence that he has just been made redundant. He begs her not to tell the lender as he is sure he will find a new job quickly and doesn’t want to lose the property. What is Sophie’s primary professional obligation upon receiving this confidential information?

options.label: A
options.text: Maintain David’s confidentiality and proceed with the completion as planned.

options.label: B
options.text: Immediately inform the mortgage lender of this material change in circumstances.

options.label: C
options.text: Cease acting for both David and the lender due to an immediate conflict of interest.

options.label: D
options.text: Advise David that he must inform the lender himself, but take no further action.

options.label: E
options.text: Continue acting but advise David to take out payment protection insurance.

questions.explanation:
C is correct. Sophie now holds confidential information material to the lender’s decision to lend (the borrower’s ability to repay). She cannot disclose it without David’s consent (breaching confidentiality), nor can she continue acting for the lender while withholding it (breaching her duty to the lender). This creates an unmanageable conflict under SRA r. 6.1 and 6.3, obliging her to cease acting for both parties.
A is incorrect; it would breach her duty to the lender.
B is incorrect; it would breach her duty of confidentiality to David.
D is incorrect; while she may advise this, her profess...

questions.text: At the request of the seller’s solicitor, Michael’s firm provides an undertaking to hold the purchase funds after completion and forward them to the seller’s overseas bank account the following day, pending the arrival of the signed transfer deed. Michael’s cashier informs him the funds have been received but the transfer deed has not arrived. What is the most critical action for Michael to take in relation to the undertaking?

options.label: A
options.text: Forward the funds as promised to maintain the firm’s reputation for reliability.

options.label: B
options.text: Wait indefinitely for the transfer deed, as the undertaking did not specify a time limit.

options.label: C
options.text: Contact the seller’s solicitor immediately to clarify the position and seek instructions.

options.label: D
options.text: Return the funds to the buyer’s solicitor as the condition has not been met.

options.label: E
options.text: Notify the SRA that the other solicitor has failed to comply with their side of the arrangement.

questions.explanation:
C is correct. An undertaking is a strict, personal promise. If its fulfilment is threatened (here, the condition of receiving the deed), the solicitor must take immediate steps to resolve the situation, starting with communication with the counterparty. They cannot unilaterally vary the undertaking (A or D) without potentially breaching it.
B is incorrect; passivity could lead to a breach if the undertaking implied a reasonable timeframe.
D is incorrect; returning the funds without agreement would breach the undertaking to hold and forward them.
E is incorrect and  premature; the first step is...

questions.text: Sarah, a conveyancing assistant, receives an email that appears to be from a regular client, a property developer. The email provides new bank details for the return of a deposit after an aborted transaction. The email address is very similar to the client’s but has one letter different. The message urges urgent action. What is the most important step to take to prevent a potential fraud?

options.label: A
options.text: Reply to the email asking for confirmation of the new details.

options.label: B
options.text: Action the request immediately due to its urgency.

options.label: C
options.text: Contact the client using a previously verified phone number to confirm the instructions.

options.label: D
options.text: Forward the email to the firm’s IT department to check for viruses.

options.label: E
options.text: Make a payment to the new account but ring-fence it pending confirmation.

questions.explanation:
C is correct. This is a classic ‘Friday afternoon fraud’ or phishing attempt. The only secure response is to verify the instruction through a separate, pre-verified channel (e.g., a phone number on file from original ID documents), not by replying to the potentially compromised email.
A is incorrect; replying to the fraudulent email confirms its validity to the fraudster.
B and E are incorrect; they risk irrevocable loss of client money.
D is incorrect. It is a good security practice but does not address the immediate need to verify the client instruction.

questions.text: Thomas and his sister, Priya, are purchasing a house together. Thomas is contributing 80% of the deposit from a business sale, and Priya 20% from savings. They instruct one solicitor, Anya, to act for them both. What is Anya’s key professional conduct duty in this situation?

options.label: A
options.text: Refuse to act due to a conflict between their financial interests.

options.label: B
options.text: Advise them to hold the property as joint tenants for simplicity.

options.label: C
options.text: Explain the different forms of co-ownership and recommend a declaration of trust reflecting their shares.

options.label: D
options.text: Act only for the party contributing the larger share.

options.label: E
options.text: Obtain consent from any mortgage lender to the unequal shares.

questions.explanation: C is correct. Acting for multiple buyers is permissible if no conflict exists. However, the solicitor must advise them fully on their options (joint tenancy vs. tenancy in common) and the implications. Given their unequal contributions, a tenancy in common with a declaration of trust is the appropriate way to reflect their beneficial interests and prevent future dispute. A is incorrect; a conflict does not automatically arise from unequal contributions if both wish to proceed on that basis. B is incorrect; a joint tenancy presumes equal shares and includes a right of survivorship, which may no...

questions.text: James is obtaining a mortgage to finance his business. He asks his wife, Rebecca, to agree to a legal charge over their jointly-owned home to secure the loan. Rebecca does not work in the business and will not benefit directly from the loan. They attend a meeting with their usual solicitor, Fiona. What must Fiona do to comply with the Etridge guidelines and protect against a future claim of undue influence?

options.label: A
options.text: Advise them that as she acts for them both, she can explain everything together.

options.label: B
options.text: Recommend Rebecca seeks independent legal advice on the transaction.

options.label: C
options.text: Proceed with the charge, as both parties are present and consenting.

options.label: D
options.text: Refuse to act, as there is a clear and unmanageable conflict of interest.

options.label: E
options.text: Draft the charge but include a clause stating Rebecca has been advised.

questions.explanation:
B is correct. The Royal Bank of Scotland v Etridge guidelines impose strict duties where one party (especially a spouse) stands as surety for debts from which they receive no direct benefit. The vulnerable party (Rebecca) must be advised separately, in the absence of the other, by a solicitor who explains the risks in plain English. The solicitor must then confirm to the lender that this advice has been given.
A is incorrect; joint advice is insufficient.
C is incorrect; proceeding without ensuring independent advice risks the transaction being set aside.
D is incorrect; while a conflict exist...

questions.text: During a mortgage transaction, a solicitor, Ben, acting for both the borrower and the lender, discovers a restrictive covenant that might limit the property’s use. The UK Finance Handbook requires such covenants to be reported to the lender if they might affect value or enforceability. Ben believes the covenant is likely unenforceable but isn’t certain. What should Ben do to manage the conflict between his duty to the borrower (confidentiality) and his duty to the lender (disclosure)?

options.label: A
options.text: Withhold the information from the lender, as it might unnecessarily jeopardise the borrower’s loan.

options.label: B
options.text: Disclose the covenant to the lender with his opinion that it is unenforceable.

options.label: C
options.text: Ask the borrower for consent to disclose the covenant to the lender.

options.label: D
options.text: Cease acting for the lender but continue acting for the borrower.

options.label: E
options.text: Proceed without reporting, as his duty to the borrower as the primary client takes precedence.

questions.explanation:
C is correct. When acting for both, the solicitor’s duty is to both clients. For material title issues, the lender’s instructions (the Handbook) require reporting. The solicitor should explain the issue to the borrower and seek their consent to disclose it to the lender, as it is information about the borrower’s affairs. If consent is refused, a conflict arises requiring the solicitor to cease acting for the lender (and possibly the borrower).
B is incorrect as that might be the outcome after obtaining consent.
A and E are incorrect; they breach the specific instructions in the Handbook and th...

areas.name: Title Investigation; Examining Ownership and Rights.

questions.text: Amelia is reviewing the official copy entries for a freehold property her client, Ben, wishes to purchase. She notes that the Proprietorship Register contains a Form A restriction: "No disposition by a sole proprietor of the registered estate (except a trust corporation) under which capital money arises is to be registered unless authorised by an order of the court." The seller is the sole registered proprietor. What is the primary legal implication of this restriction for the transaction?

options.label: A
options.text: The seller cannot sell the property without court approval.

options.label: B
options.text: The buyer must ensure the purchase money is paid to at least two trustees or a trust corporation.

options.label: C
options.text: The buyer must obtain a court order to register the transfer.

options.label: D
options.text: The property is subject to a pending matrimonial home rights notice.

options.label: E
options.text: The seller's title is possessory and therefore defective.

questions.explanation: B is correct. A Form A restriction indicates that the legal estate is held on trust (usually under a trust of land). When a sole legal owner sells, the equitable interests (e.g., of a non-owning spouse or cohabitant) must be "overreached" to prevent them from binding the buyer. Overreaching is achieved by paying the purchase money to at least two trustees or a trust corporation, who then hold the proceeds on trust for the beneficiaries. A is incorrect; court approval is not required if overreaching is used. C is incorrect; the buyer does not need a court order if the payment is correctly made....

questions.text: Daniel is investigating the title of a registered freehold property for a buyer. The Charges Register includes an entry: "The Transfer dated 1st January 1995 made between (1) ABC Ltd and (2) David Evans contains the following covenant: 'Not to use the property for any purpose other than as a single private dwelling house.'" There is no indication that the benefit of this covenant has been assigned to any neighbouring land. The seller's solicitor provides no information about who might enforce it. In advising the buyer, what is the most accurate statement about the enforceability of this restrictive covenant?

options.label: A
options.text: It is enforceable by ABC Ltd only, as the original covenantee.

options.label: B
options.text: It is enforceable by the owner of any land that was intended to benefit from it at the time it was made.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not enforceable against the buyer because it is not noted on the title plan.

options.label: D
options.text: It is automatically enforceable by any local resident.

options.label: E
options.text: It is unenforceable because the benefit has not been expressly assigned.

questions.explanation: B is correct. For a restrictive covenant to be enforceable in equity against a successor in title, it must "touch and concern" land and be intended to benefit identifiable land (the dominant tenement). Under the principle in Federated Homes Ltd v Mill Lodge Properties Ltd, the benefit can pass without express assignment if the land is identifiable. The covenant is protected by its entry in the Charges Register. A is incorrect; the original covenantee may have sold the benefiting land, passing the benefit. C is incorrect; covenants are entered in the Charges Register, not the title plan. D is i...

questions.text: Sophie is acting for a buyer, Liam, who is purchasing a registered freehold house. The Property Register states that the property benefits from a right of way over a neighbouring track "as set out in the Transfer dated 12 March 1985." A copy of that Transfer is not with the official copies. The seller's solicitor has not provided it. What should Sophie do as part of her duty of title investigation?

options.label: A
options.text: Advise Liam that the right is adequately described and no further action is needed.

options.label: B
options.text: Assume the right is valid and recommend purchasing the property.

options.label: C
options.text: Insist on obtaining a copy of the 1985 Transfer to verify the exact terms of the right of way.

options.label: D
options.text: Recommend taking out indemnity insurance for the missing right of way.

options.label: E
options.text: Report to the lender that the title is defective and the mortgage cannot proceed.

questions.explanation: C is correct. When a right is granted by reference to a document, that document forms part of the title and must be inspected to understand the scope, extent, and conditions of the right. The buyer's solicitor must obtain a copy to ensure the right is as expected and to advise the client properly. A and B are incorrect; they constitute inadequate due diligence. D is incorrect as it is not the first step; the solicitor must first try to obtain it. E is premature; the title is not necessarily defective, but further investigation is required.

questions.text: Thomas is reviewing the title for a rural freehold property. The Charges Register contains a unilateral notice in favour of a Mr. Arthur Jones. The entry states: "Claim to a beneficial interest under a resulting trust arising from contribution to the purchase price." The seller is the sole registered proprietor and lives alone. Mr. Jones does not live at the property. What is the most appropriate step for Thomas to take to protect his buyer client?

options.label: A
options.text: Ignore the notice, as it is only a claim and not a proven interest.

options.label: B
options.text: Require the seller to obtain and provide a withdrawal of the unilateral notice before completion.

options.label: C
options.text: Advise the buyer that Mr. Jones will have an overriding interest due to his financial contribution.

options.label: D
options.text: Recommend indemnity insurance to cover the risk of Mr. Jones making a claim after completion.

options.label: E
options.text: Report to the lender that the title is unmarketable and the transaction must be abandoned.

questions.explanation:
B is correct. A unilateral notice indicates a third-party claim to an interest in the property. It is a caution to a buyer. The buyer's solicitor should require the seller to resolve this, typically by obtaining a withdrawal or cancellation of the notice, to ensure the buyer takes the title free from this claim.
A is incorrect; the notice is an entry on the register that must be dealt with.
C is incorrect; Mr. Jones is not in actual occupation (the property is occupied solely by the seller), so his interest may not be overriding, but the notice must still be cleared.
D is incorrect as it is a ...

questions.text: Emma is acting for a buyer, Noah, who is purchasing a freehold property. The title is registered with absolute title. During a final inspection, Noah notices that the current owner's adult son, Jacob, lives in a self-contained annexe in the garden. Jacob has lived there for five years, paying a modest rent to his father. The TA6 form stated there were no other occupiers. What is the most significant legal risk arising from Jacob's occupation?

options.label: A
options.text: Jacob may have a secure tenancy under the Housing Act 1988.

options.label: B
options.text: Jacob may have an overriding interest.

options.label: C
options.text: Jacob is a trespasser and can be evicted easily after completion.

options.label: D
options.text: The seller is in breach of his mortgage terms by having a tenant.

options.label: E
options.text: The presence of an occupier will invalidate the buildings insurance.

questions.explanation: B is correct. A person in actual occupation of the property may have an overriding interest that binds the buyer, even if not on the register, if they have a beneficial interest (e.g., under a trust). Jacob's occupation is apparent, and his payment of rent might indicate a lease or licence, but more importantly, if he has contributed to the property (e.g., to the annexe's construction), he could have an equitable interest. This risk was highlighted in Williams & Glyn’s Bank v Boland. A is incorrect as it is less central than the overriding interest risk. C is incorrect as it is unlikely if he ...

questions.text: James is reviewing a title for a freehold property. The class of title in the Proprietorship Register is "possessory freehold." The seller's solicitor explains that the title was registered based on 12 years of adverse possession by the seller's predecessor. What is the key implication of buying a property with a possessory title?

options.label: A
options.text: The title is guaranteed by the Land Registry against all claims.

options.label: B
options.text: The title is subject to any rights that may have existed prior to first registration.

options.label: C
options.text: The buyer will be unable to obtain a mortgage on the property.

options.label: D
options.text: The seller must upgrade the title to absolute before the sale can proceed.

options.label: E
options.text: The buyer will take the property free from all existing easements.

questions.explanation:
B is correct. A possessory title is granted where title is based on possession rather than documentary evidence. It is subject to any adverse interests that existed at the time of first registration and were not extinguished by limitation. The Land Registry's indemnity does not cover these pre-existing rights.
A is incorrect; the guarantee is limited with possessory title.
C is incorrect; some lenders may accept it, often with indemnity insurance.
D is incorrect; the sale can proceed, but the buyer may wish to apply for an upgrade later.
E is incorrect; easements that existed at first registra...

questions.text: Chloe is investigating title for a leasehold flat. The Property Register notes that the property benefits from a right of way over the estate's common parts "as set out in the lease dated 1 January 2000." However, the lease provided by the seller's solicitor does not mention this right. The estate's management company confirms the right exists in the head lease, from which the flat's lease is derived. What should Chloe do to ensure the right is properly protected for her client?

options.label: A
options.text: Rely on the management company's verbal confirmation.

options.label: B
options.text: Require an express assignment of the right from the management company.

options.label: C
options.text: Insist on seeing the head lease to verify the right and ensure it passes to the buyer.

options.label: D
options.text: Recommend indemnity insurance for the missing right.

options.label: E
options.text: Advise the client not to proceed, as the right is not documented in their lease.

questions.explanation:
C is correct. The right is granted by reference to the head lease. The buyer's solicitor must inspect the head lease to confirm the existence and terms of the right and to ensure that the right is appurtenant to (passes with) the flat's lease. The leasehold title should include reference to the head lease if the right is dependent on it.
A is incorrect and insufficient; verbal confirmation is not legally reliable.
B is incorrect; the right should pass automatically if it is appurtenant, but an assignment may be needed if it is a personal right.
D is incorrect as it is premature without first t...

questions.text: David is acting for a buyer, Sophia, who is purchasing a freehold house. The Charges Register includes an entry: "The land is subject to a rentcharge of £10 per annum payable to the XYZ Estate Company Limited." The seller has no documentation about this rentcharge and does not know if it has been paid. What is the most important step for David to take to protect Sophia?

options.label: A
options.text: Ignore it, as £10 per annum is a negligible sum.

options.label: B
options.text: Require the seller to provide evidence that all payments are up to date and to redeem the rentcharge before completion.

options.label: C
options.text: Advise Sophia that she will be liable for the payments but they are small.

options.label: D
options.text: Recommend indemnity insurance to cover the risk of non-payment.

options.label: E
options.text: Report to the lender that the title is encumbered and unmarketable.

questions.explanation:
B is correct. A rentcharge is a periodic payment charged on the land. If it falls into arrears, the rentcharge owner may have the right to enter the land and take income or even levy a distress. The buyer should require the seller to discharge the rentcharge or provide evidence that it is up to date and that there is a mechanism for future payments. Under the Rentcharges Act 1977, most rentcharges are extinguished after 60 years, but some can exist in perpetuity.
A and C are incorrect; they fail to address the potential risk of enforcement.
D is incorrect as it is a possible fallback if the re...

questions.text: Isabella is reviewing a title for a freehold property. The official copy entries show that the land is registered with absolute title, but there is a note in the Property Register: "The subsoil of the property is excepted from the registration and is believed to be vested in the Crown." The seller's solicitor states that this is a standard note for properties in the area, relating to mineral rights. What should Isabella advise her client about mineral rights?

options.label: A
options.text: The client will own everything below the surface, as the title is absolute.

options.label: B
options.text: The client will not own the subsoil and may have no right to prevent mining underneath.

options.label: C
options.text: The client must purchase the subsoil from the Crown before completion.

options.label: D
options.text: The note is merely historical and has no legal effect.

options.label: E
options.text: Indemnity insurance is required to cover any subsidence caused by mining.

questions.explanation: B is correct. If the subsoil (mineral rights) is excepted from the registration, then the registered title does not include it. The owner of the minerals (here, believed to be the Crown) may have the right to extract them, possibly even from beneath the property, subject to statutory controls. This is a potential encumbrance. A is incorrect; absolute title does not guarantee ownership of excepted parts. C is incorrect; it may not be necessary or possible to purchase them. D is incorrect; the note reflects a legal exception. E is incorrect as it does not address the ownership issue directly.

questions.text: Oliver is acting for a buyer, Eva, who is purchasing a freehold property. The seller inherited the property from her mother six months ago. The Proprietorship Register shows the seller as proprietor, but the class of title is "qualified." The qualification states: "The title is subject to the possibility of the existence of interests under a trust affecting the estate prior to the date of registration which are not reflected on the register." What does this qualified title mean for the buyer?

options.label: A
options.text: The title is guaranteed by the Land Registry except as to the potential trust interests.

options.label: B
options.text: The title is not marketable and cannot be sold until the qualification is removed.
