options.label: C
options.text: The seller must obtain court approval to sell the property.

options.label: D
options.text: The buyer will take the property free from any trust interests due to overreaching.

options.label: E
options.text: The Land Registry will upgrade the title to absolute upon application by the buyer.

questions.explanation: A is correct. A qualified title is one where the Land Registry has identified a specific defect or potential defect in the title. Here, the qualification relates to potential pre-registration trust interests. The state guarantee of title does not cover loss arising from that specific defect. B is incorrect; a qualified title can be sold, but the buyer accepts the risk of the qualification. C is incorrect; court approval is not required. D is incorrect; overreaching applies to interests arising under a trust where capital money is paid to two trustees; here, the interests predate registration a...

questions.text: Grace is investigating title for a freehold property. The Title Plan shows the boundary of the property with a red line. However, during a site visit, Grace's client, Henry, notices that the neighbour's shed appears to be built partially on the land within the red line. The seller says the shed has been there for as long as he can remember and the neighbour has always maintained it. What is the most significant legal risk associated with this observation?

options.label: A
options.text: The neighbour may have acquired title to that strip of land by adverse possession.

options.label: B
options.text: The shed is a trespass and can be easily removed after completion.

options.label: C
options.text: The Title Plan is inaccurate and must be corrected at the Land Registry before sale.

options.label: D
options.text: The neighbour has no right at all.

options.label: E
options.text: The presence of the shed violates a restrictive covenant against outbuildings.

questions.explanation: A is correct. If the neighbour has been in factual possession of the strip for a sufficient period (12 years for unregistered land pre-registration, or 10 years under the Land Registration Act 2002 for registered land) with the necessary intention, they may have acquired title to that strip by adverse possession. This is a significant risk as it could mean the buyer does not acquire that part of the land. B is incorrect; if adverse possession is established, the neighbour may have a right to the land. C is incorrect; the plan may be accurate, but the physical situation may have changed. D is i...

questions.text: Lucas is acting for a buyer, Mia, who is purchasing a freehold house. The Charges Register includes an entry: "Agreed notice in respect of an option to purchase contained in a deed dated 10th October 2010 made between (1) Samuel Grant and (2) Home Developments Ltd." The seller is Samuel Grant's successor in title. The option gives Home Developments Ltd the right to purchase a strip of land at the rear of the garden for £50,000 at any time within the next five years. What is the key implication of this notice for Mia's purchase?

options.label: A
options.text: The option is personal to Home Developments Ltd and does not bind successors in title.

options.label: B
options.text: Mia will take the property subject to the option and may be forced to sell the strip.

options.label: C
options.text: The option is unenforceable because it is not registered as a land charge.

options.label: D
options.text: The seller must exercise the option and sell the strip before completion.

options.label: E
options.text: The notice is merely informative and does not affect the title.

questions.explanation: B is correct. An option to purchase is a proprietary interest in land. When protected by an agreed notice (as here) on the registered title, it binds successors in title. Therefore, if Home Developments Ltd exercises the option within the time frame, Mia would be obliged to sell the strip for £50,000. A is incorrect; options can bind successors if properly protected. C is incorrect; for registered land, protection is by notice on the register, not a land charge. D is incorrect; the option is in favour of the developer, not the seller. E is incorrect; an agreed notice confirms the existence of ...

questions.text: Hannah is reviewing the title for a freehold property. The seller's solicitor has provided official copies showing the title is registered with absolute title. However, Hannah notices that the Property Register describes the property as "1 High Street, Anytown" and refers to a title plan, but there is no specific mention of a garage that is shown on the title plan and is used by the seller. The seller confirms the garage is included in the sale. What should Hannah do to ensure the garage is included in the legal title?

options.label: A
options.text: Rely on the title plan, as it shows the garage within the red boundary.

options.label: B
options.text: Require the seller to provide a separate conveyance for the garage.

options.label: C
options.text: Search the index map to see if the garage has its own separate title.

options.label: D
options.text: Recommend that the buyer obtains a surveyor's report to confirm the garage is within the boundary.

options.label: E
options.text: Advise the buyer that the garage is a chattel and must be listed in the TA10 form.

questions.explanation: A is correct. The title plan defines the extent of the registered title. If the garage is within the red edging on the title plan, it is part of the registered land. The Property Register description is general, and the plan prevails in defining the physical extent. B is unnecessary if the garage is within the registered title. C is a precautionary step if there is doubt, but the title plan is the primary evidence. D is useful for physical condition but not for legal title. E is incorrect; if the garage is a permanent structure attached to the land, it is a fixture and part of the real propert...

questions.text: Daniel is acting for a buyer, Zoe, who is purchasing a freehold property. The seller's solicitor provides an epitome of title for the unregistered land, showing a good root of title from 1990. However, Daniel notices that the 1990 conveyance includes a covenant that "the transferee shall maintain the boundary fence at his own expense." This covenant is not mentioned in the contract or the seller's replies to enquiries. What is the legal status of this positive covenant for Zoe?

options.label: A
options.text: It is enforceable against Zoe because it is in the root of title.

options.label: B
options.text: It is not enforceable against Zoe because the covenant does not run with freehold land.

options.label: C
options.text: It is enforceable only if the original covenantee still owns adjoining land.

options.label: D
options.text: It is enforceable as an overriding interest.

options.label: E
options.text: It must be registered as a land charge to be enforceable.

questions.explanation:
B is correct. As a general rule, positive covenants (requiring expenditure) do not run with freehold land at law or in equity to bind successors in title. Therefore, Zoe would not be personally liable for maintaining the fence unless she enters into a new covenant.
A is incorrect; being in the root does not make a positive covenant enforceable against successors.
C is incorrect; even if the original covenantee owns adjoining land, the positive covenant does not run.
D is incorrect; overriding interests are not typically positive covenants.
E is incorrect; registration of a positive covenant as...

questions.text: Sophie is acting for a buyer, Noah, who is purchasing a freehold property. The Charges Register contains an entry: "Deed of Grant of Easement dated 5 June 2015 made between (1) The Owner of Title Number AN123456 and (2) The Owner of Title Number AN789012 granting a right of way over the access road coloured brown on the plan attached." The seller's solicitor has not provided a copy of the deed. What is the minimum action Sophie must take to properly advise Noah about this easement?

options.label: A
options.text: Assume it is a standard right of way and proceed.

options.label: B
options.text: Obtain a copy of the Deed of Grant to verify the precise terms and the plan.

options.label: C
options.text: Rely on the description in the register as sufficient.

options.label: D
options.text: Recommend indemnity insurance in case the easement is defective.

options.label: E
options.text: Search the index map to identify the dominant tenement.

questions.explanation:
B is correct. When an interest is granted by reference to a document, that document is part of the title and must be inspected. Sophie must obtain a copy to understand the nature, extent, and conditions of the right of way (e.g., who can use it, for what purpose, maintenance obligations). A and C are incorrect as they constitute inadequate due diligence. D is incorrect as it is a possible fallback if the deed cannot be obtained, but it is not the first step. E is incorrect. It is useful but does not replace reviewing the deed itself.
D.Pre-Contract Enquiries and Searches.
Chapter 4: Pre-Contra...

questions.text: George is acting for Priya, who is purchasing a Victorian freehold terraced house. The local authority search (CON29) reveals that the property is located within a Conservation Area. The search also shows that the previous owner obtained planning permission for a rear dormer window extension five years ago, but there is no corresponding completion certificate from Building Control. Priya is concerned about the lack of building regulations sign-off and its implications for her planned refurbishment. What is the most accurate and complete advice George should give Priya regarding this search result?

options.label: A
options.text: The lack of a completion certificate is a minor administrative issue and can be ignored.

options.label: B
options.text: The property being in a Conservation Area only affects future external alterations, not past works.

options.label: C
options.text: The missing certificate means the works may not comply with building regulations, potentially requiring costly remedial work and affecting saleability

options.label: D
options.text: The planning permission is sufficient proof of compliance, so no further action is needed.

options.label: E
options.text: This is a matter solely for the seller's solicitor to resolve before completion.

questions.explanation: C is correct. A missing Building Regulations completion certificate is a significant red flag. It means the local authority has not confirmed the works meet safety and structural standards. This could lead to enforcement action, difficulties with future sales, and costly repairs. Priya should instruct her solicitor to raise enquiries with the seller and consider a retrospective regularisation application or indemnity insurance. A and D are incorrect; the absence of certification is a material risk. B is incomplete; while the Conservation Area status primarily controls future works, it is a sep...

questions.text: During the pre-contract stage for a freehold house purchase, David’s solicitor, Anya, receives the CON29DW Drainage and Water Search results. The report states that a public sewer runs directly beneath the footprint of the property itself. David has ambitions to build a substantial side extension in the future. What is the primary legal and practical implication of this discovery that Anya must advise David on?

options.label: A
options.text: It will increase his water rates slightly, but has no other impact.

options.label: B
options.text: It grants him a right to connect to the public sewer easily and cheaply.

options.label: C
options.text: It may severely restrict or prevent his planned extension

options.label: D
options.text: It means he is personally responsible for maintaining that section of the public sewer.

options.label: E
options.text: It is a positive feature that adds value to the property.

questions.explanation: C is correct. A public sewer under the property is a "building over" issue. Water authorities have strict regulations and may refuse consent for foundations or structures near or over the sewer. If consent is granted, it may come with onerous conditions. This directly impacts David’s development plans. A is incorrect; it doesn't directly affect rates. B is incorrect; while connection may be possible, the primary issue is building over it. D is incorrect; maintenance of public sewers is typically the responsibility of the water authority, though the owner may have obligations regarding access. ...

questions.text: Sophie is purchasing a rural freehold cottage. Her solicitor, Michael, orders an environmental search. The desktop report identifies that the property is located within 250 metres of a former landfill site, which is now a public park. The report classifies the overall risk of contamination as "low" but recommends further, more intrusive investigation for absolute certainty. Sophie is worried about potential health risks and liability. Under the Environmental Protection Act 1990, what is the core reason this search result necessitates careful consideration?

options.label: A
options.text: The local authority will require Sophie to pay for ongoing monitoring of the park.

options.label: B
options.text: Sophie could become liable for the costs of remediating any contaminated land

options.label: C
options.text: The seller is automatically liable for all historical contamination and must provide a guarantee.

options.label: D
options.text: The mortgage lender will definitely refuse to lend on any property near a former landfill.

options.label: E
options.text: It will be impossible to obtain buildings insurance for the property.

questions.explanation: B is correct. The Environmental Protection Act 1990 creates a regime where the "appropriate person" (which can include the current owner or occupier) can be served with a remediation notice for contaminated land, with liability for clean-up costs. This liability can attach to the land itself. A "low" risk is not "no risk," and the potential liability is significant. A is incorrect; monitoring obligations fall on the authority, not automatically on the homeowner. C is incorrect; liability is not automatically on the seller; it depends on who caused or knowingly permitted the contamination. D an...

questions.text: Thomas is reviewing the TA6 Property Information Form completed by the seller of a 1930s semi-detached house. In response to the question "Has any building work been carried out at the property?" the seller has ticked "Yes" and written "Loft converted to bedroom, 2015." In response to "Were Building Regulations obtained?" the seller has ticked "Yes" and written "Certificate available." However, the Local Authority Search shows no record of a building regulations application or completion certificate for that address during that period. Thomas raises this discrepancy with the seller’s solicitor. What is the most likely explanation and appropriate next step for Thomas?

options.label: A
options.text: Assume the search is wrong and accept the seller's written confirmation.

options.label: B
options.text: Immediately advise his client to withdraw due to suspected fraud.

options.label: C
options.text: Request that the seller provides a copy of the purported certificate for verification. If it cannot be produced, treat the works as unauthorised.

options.label: D
options.text: Tell his client the loft conversion is illegal and must be demolished.

options.label: E
options.text: Report the seller to the local authority's planning enforcement team.

questions.explanation: C is correct. A direct conflict between the TA6 and the official search must be investigated. The first step is to ask the seller’s solicitor to provide the documented evidence they claim exists. If it cannot be provided, the logical conclusion is that the works were not regularised, and the buyer must then consider the risks and potential solutions (indemnity insurance, price reduction, retrospective application). A is incorrect and a negligent decision; the official search is prima facie evidence. B is incorrect and premature; investigation is required first. D is an overstatement; while it ...

questions.text: Isabella is buying a freehold property in a picturesque village. Her solicitor, James, conducts a chancel repair liability search. The search result states: "The property is located within a parish where a potential chancel repair liability has been identified." James explains the historic nature of this liability to Isabella. In light of the case of Aston Cantlow PCC v Wallbank, what is the most practical and common way to manage this risk for a modern residential purchase?

options.label: A
options.text: Require the seller to obtain a formal release from the Parochial Church Council (PCC).

options.label: B
options.text: Recommend that the buyer purchases chancel repair indemnity insurance.

options.label: C
options.text: Advise the buyer to withdraw from the purchase, as the liability is unlimited.

options.label: D
options.text: Negotiate a substantial reduction in the purchase price equal to the potential liability.

options.label: E
options.text: Do nothing, as such liabilities were abolished by the Human Rights Act 1998.

questions.explanation: B is correct. As established in Aston Cantlow, the liability is still enforceable. The standard and most practical solution in conveyancing is for the buyer (or sometimes the seller) to take out a one-off premium indemnity insurance policy. This protects against a future financial claim from the PCC. A is often impractical and may prompt a claim. C is an overreaction, as the risk is insurable. D is difficult to quantify and does not remove the legal liability. E is incorrect; the Wallbank case confirmed the liability's existence post-Human Rights Act.

questions.text: Oliver is acting for a first-time buyer, Chloe. The mortgage valuation report has been obtained by the lender. Chloe asks Oliver, "Does this valuation mean the property is structurally sound? Do I need my own survey?" Oliver prepares to explain the fundamental difference between a mortgage valuation and a survey. What is the most accurate explanation Oliver should provide regarding the purpose and limitation of a mortgage valuation?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a detailed structural survey that serves both the lender and the buyer.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a brief inspection to assure the lender the property provides adequate security for the loan.

options.label: C
options.text: It is legally required and replaces the need for any other survey.

options.label: D
options.text: It guarantees the purchase price is the correct market value.

options.label: E
options.text: It investigates legal title issues like restrictive covenants.

questions.explanation: B is correct. A mortgage valuation is a limited assessment for the lender’s benefit only. It is not a survey of condition. The solicitor must clearly advise the buyer that it does not protect them against structural defects and that an independent survey (e.g., HomeBuyer Report or Building Survey) is strongly recommended. A is incorrect; it is not detailed nor for the buyer’s benefit. C is incorrect. D is incorrect; it is an opinion of value for lending, not a guarantee. E is incorrect; legal issues are for the solicitor to investigate.

questions.text: The seller of a property, Mr. Evans, completed the TA10 Fittings and Contents Form. He listed the freestanding fridge-freezer in the kitchen as "included" and the antique mirror in the hallway as "excluded." On the day of completion, the buyer’s moving van arrives to find the fridge-freezer gone and the mirror still on the wall. The buyer’s solicitor contacts Mr. Evans’s solicitor. Based on the Standard Conditions of Sale (5th Ed.), what is the likely outcome regarding these items?

options.label: A
options.text: The buyer has no recourse, as the TA10 is not legally binding.

options.label: B
options.text: The seller is in breach of contract for removing the fridge-freezer and must return it or pay compensation.

options.label: C
options.text: The buyer must accept the situation, as items can be changed up until completion.

options.label: D
options.text: The mirror must be removed at the seller’s expense, but the fridge-freezer is the buyer’s loss.

options.label: E
options.text: Both parties share the loss equally.

questions.explanation:
B is correct. The TA10 form is incorporated into the contract by reference. It forms a binding part of the agreement. Removing an included item (the fridge-freezer) is a breach of contract. The buyer is entitled to compensation or the return of the item. The seller is entitled to remove the excluded item (the mirror), but if they leave it, it may be considered abandoned or gifted, but they are not in breach for leaving it.
A is incorrect; the TA10 is contractual. C is incorrect; the contract is binding from exchange. D is incorrect regarding the fridge. E is incorrect; there is clear breach by...

questions.text: Emma is reviewing the pre-contract search pack for a leasehold flat purchase. The local search is clear, but the solicitor also orders a company search against the property management company named in the TA7 Leasehold Information Form. The search reveals that the company was struck off the Companies House register six months ago for failure to file accounts, but the seller has continued to pay service charges to it. What is the most significant legal and practical problem this discovery creates for Emma’s client?

options.label: A
options.text: The service charges paid were illegal and must be refunded.

options.label: B
options.text: There is effectively no legal entity to manage the building, creating a major risk.

options.label: C
options.text: The lease is automatically invalidated.

options.label: D
options.text: The freeholder immediately takes over management duties.

options.label: E
options.text: It is a minor issue that can be resolved after completion.

questions.explanation: B is correct. A struck-off company ceases to exist as a legal entity. It cannot hold funds, enter contracts, or fulfil its management obligations. This leaves the building without a functioning management structure, jeopardising insurance, repairs, and maintenance. It is a serious title defect. A may be a consequence, but B captures the core systemic problem. C is incorrect; the lease remains valid, but the management mechanism is broken. D is incorrect and not automatic; the freeholder may have a right to step in, but it may require legal action. E is incorrect; this is a fundamental issue th...

questions.text: In the TA6 form, the seller indicated there were "no issues" with the roof. The buyer’s HomeBuyer Survey, conducted after exchange of contracts, reveals extensive and expensive repairs are needed to the roof structure, which were likely necessary at the time the TA6 was completed. The buyer is furious. What is the most accurate assessment of the seller’s potential liability in this situation?

options.label: A
options.text: The seller is not liable due to caveat emptor; the buyer should have surveyed earlier.

options.label: B
options.text: The seller is liable for misrepresentation, as the statement in the TA6 was arguably false.

options.label: C
options.text: The seller is only liable if they actively concealed the defects.

options.label: D
options.text: The surveyor is liable for not discovering this before exchange.

options.label: E
options.text: The seller’s solicitor is liable for not verifying the condition of the roof.

questions.explanation: B is correct. A statement in the TA6 is a representation of fact. If the roof issues were present and known (or should have been known) to the seller at the time of completing the form, the statement "no issues" could be a misrepresentation, giving the buyer a potential claim. Caveat emptor (A) does not protect against positive misstatements. C is incorrect; active concealment is a separate, more serious issue. D and E shift blame incorrectly; the surveyor’s liability depends on their terms, and the solicitor is not responsible for physical inspections.

questions.text: The environmental search flags that the property is in Flood Zone 2 (medium probability). The buyer, Mr. Khan, is obtaining a high loan-to-value mortgage. His solicitor, Felicity, must advise him. What is the most immediate and relevant consequence Felicity should highlight?

options.label: A
options.text: He will be unable to obtain any form of buildings insurance.

options.label: B
options.text: The lender may refuse the mortgage or impose special conditions regarding insurance.

options.label: C
options.text: He will be legally required to install flood defences at his own cost.

options.label: D
options.text: The local authority will revoke the property’s occupancy permit.

options.label: E
options.text: The seller is legally obligated to purchase flood indemnity insurance for the buyer.

questions.explanation: B is correct. Lenders are highly cautious about flood risk. A property in Flood Zone 2 may be declined by some lenders, or they may require evidence of affordable and comprehensive flood insurance as a condition of the loan. This is a core part of the solicitor’s risk advice. A is incorrect; insurance may be available but costly. C and D are not automatic legal requirements. E is incorrect; there is no such obligation on the seller.

questions.text: The buyer’s solicitor is drafting the TR1 transfer deed for a freehold purchase. The buyers are two friends holding as tenants in common in unequal shares. The seller is giving full title guarantee. The lender requires a specific covenant about maintenance of a shared driveway. Which of these must be included in the TR1?

options.label: A
options.text: The price paid for the property.

options.label: B
options.text: A declaration of trust stating the beneficial shares.

options.label: C
options.text: The lender’s covenant about the driveway.

options.label: D
options.text: A clause excluding the seller from future liability.

options.label: E
options.text: The date of the original contract.

questions.explanation: B is correct. When co-purchasers hold as tenants in common, a declaration of trust (typically in Panel 10 of the TR1) is used to specify their beneficial shares. This is a core function of the TR1 in such a scenario. A is included but is not a "must" in the sense of being unique to this scenario. C is incorrect; lender covenants are in the mortgage deed, not the TR1. D is incorrect; future liability is governed by the title guarantee given. E is incorrect; the completion date is inserted, not the contract date.

questions.text: On completion day, the buyer’s solicitor initiates a CHAPS transfer of the completion funds at 10:00 AM. Due to an internal bank error, the funds do not arrive in the seller’s solicitor’s client account until 4:30 PM. The seller’s solicitor had stipulated "completion by 2:00 PM" and at 3:00 PM, declared the buyer in breach and rescinded the contract. Is the seller’s rescission valid?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the funds were sent on time; the bank's delay is not the buyer's fault.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because completion is when funds are received, not sent.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the 2:00 PM deadline was not made "of the essence."

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, if time was expressly made of the essence for completion.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the seller’s solicitor must wait until the close of business.

questions.explanation: B is correct. Completion requires the receipt of cleared funds. A CHAPS transfer is usually same-day, but risk of delay remains with the payer until funds are received. If the contract specified a time for completion (2:00 PM) and time was of the essence, failure to complete by that time is a breach allowing rescission (see Union Eagle v Golden Achievement). A is incorrect; the buyer bears the risk of payment method. C is incorrect; stipulating a specific time for completion can make time of the essence for that obligation. D is a more precise version of B and is also essentially correct, but ...

questions.text: Under a contract using the Standard Conditions of Sale, completion is set for Friday, 1st December. The buyer’s funds are delayed and do not arrive until Monday, 4th December. The seller, ready to complete, does not serve a Notice to Complete but immediately on Monday morning instructs their solicitor to rescind the contract and forfeit the deposit. Is the seller entitled to rescind?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because they did not first serve a Notice to Complete.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because time was of the essence for the completion date.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the delay was only over a weekend.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, because any delay automatically allows rescission.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the buyer tendered performance only one working day late.

questions.explanation: A is correct. Under SC 6.1, time is not initially of the essence for the completion date. For a delayed completion, the innocent party must first serve a Notice to Complete making time of the essence. Only if the buyer then fails to complete within the 10-working-day notice period can the seller rescind. Immediate rescission on Monday was invalid. B is incorrect; under SC, time is not of the essence unless made so by notice. C and E are incorrect as they are practical observations but not the legal reason. D is incorrect.

questions.text: In a contract for a leasehold flat assignment, a special condition states: "Completion is conditional upon the landlord’s licence to assign being granted in a form satisfactory to the buyer’s solicitor." The landlord provides a licence, but it contains a clause giving the landlord an absolute right to enter the premises on 24 hours' notice. The buyer’s solicitor finds this unacceptable. What is the legal position?

options.label: A
options.text: The buyer must complete, as the condition is for a licence, not its specific terms.

options.label: B
options.text: The buyer can withdraw without penalty, as the condition is not satisfied.

options.label: C
options.text: The seller is in breach for failing to procure a satisfactory licence.

options.label: D
options.text: The condition is void for uncertainty ("satisfactory").

options.label: E
options.text: The buyer must complete but can sue the landlord over the clause.

questions.explanation: B is correct. The condition is precedent to the buyer’s obligation to complete. It is subjective ("satisfactory to the buyer’s solicitor"). If the buyer’s solicitor is not satisfied, the condition is not fulfilled, and the buyer can rescind. A is incorrect; the condition relates to the form of the licence. C is incorrect; the seller’s obligation is to use reasonable efforts, but the condition’s satisfaction is subjective. D is incorrect; subjective conditions are generally enforceable. E is incorrect; the condition provides an exit before completion.

questions.text: After exchange, the buyer’s solicitor discovers a new local land charge (a Tree Preservation Order) registered against the property. It was not revealed by the pre-exchange local search due to the local authority’s administrative delay. Who bears the risk of this newly discovered charge?

options.label: A
options.text: The seller, because it affects the property at the time of completion.

options.label: B
options.text: The buyer, because risk in the property passed at exchange.

options.label: C
options.text: The local authority, for its delay.

options.label: D
options.text: The seller’s solicitor, for negligent searching.

options.label: E
options.text: The buyer’s solicitor, for not ordering a new search on completion day.

questions.explanation: B is correct. Under SC 3.1.2, the seller is obliged to sell the property subject to all matters registered after exchange as if they were disclosed in the contract (unless they arise from the seller’s own act). However, the risk of such matters (their impact on value and use) is borne by the buyer, who became the equitable owner at exchange. The buyer must complete but may have a claim for breach of the seller’s obligation if the charge materially affects the property. A is incorrect; risk passes at exchange. C and D do not alter the contractual risk allocation. E is incorrect as it is a profe...

questions.text: In a contract race, the seller’s solicitor informs two interested buyers’ solicitors that a race is underway. Buyer A’s solicitor is told they are the "preferred buyer." Buyer B exchanges contracts first. Buyer A had already incurred significant survey and legal costs. Does Buyer A have any claim against the seller or seller’s solicitor?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because they were in a contract race and lost.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, for misrepresentation, as being "preferred" induced them to incur costs.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, for breach of a collateral contract to sell to them.

options.label: D
options.text: No, unless the seller’s solicitor guaranteed they would win.

options.label: E
options.text: Yes, but only if they can prove the race was fictitious.

questions.explanation: A is correct. In a properly conducted contract race, all bidders know they are competing. The seller is free to negotiate and give non-binding indications of preference. The term "preferred buyer" is generally not a legally binding promise, but a statement of present intention. Without clear evidence of a binding promise or fraudulent misstatement, there is no claim. B, C, and D suggest higher thresholds of commitment that are not met here. E would be fraud, but the scenario does not suggest that.

questions.text: Following completion on a freehold purchase in England for £510,000, the buyer’s solicitor, Chloe, is managing the post-completion formalities. The buyer is not a first-time buyer and owns another property. Chloe calculates the SDLT liability, applies the 3% higher rate for additional dwellings, and files the SDLT return (SDLT1) online with HMRC 16 days after the completion date, having been delayed by a bank holiday. She pays the correct amount of tax calculated. The Land Registry application, including the SDLT5 certificate, is submitted well within the 30-working-day priority period. What is the most significant legal consequence arising from Chloe’s actions?

options.label: A
options.text: The Land Registry will reject the application due to the late SDLT filing.

options.label: B
options.text: HMRC will automatically impose a fixed penalty and interest for late filing.

options.label: C
options.text: The buyer’s title is at risk as the priority period started from the wrong date.

options.label: D
options.text: The SDLT calculation is wrong because the higher rate doesn’t apply to freehold purchases.

options.label: E
options.text: No consequence, as the payment was made and the return was only two days late.

questions.explanation: B is correct. The SDLT return and payment must be submitted within 14 calendar days of the effective date (completion). Filing on day 16 is late, triggering an automatic fixed penalty (minimum £100) and daily interest on the unpaid tax from day 15. A is incorrect; the Land Registry requires the SDLT5 certificate but its issuance is not automatically voided by a late filing (though HMRC penalties apply). C is incorrect; the priority period runs from the OS1 search date, unrelated to SDLT filing. D is incorrect; the 3% higher rate applies to purchases of additional residential properties, includ...

questions.text: After completing on the purchase of an unregistered freehold farm, the buyer’s solicitor, Daniel, prepares the application for first registration. He submits Form FR1 to HM Land Registry along with the transfer deed, the SDLT5 certificate, and a selection of the old title deeds. However, he does not include a list of the documents in duplicate (Form DL) or a full certified copy of the epitome of title tracing ownership back 15 years. The Registry raises a requisition. What is the fundamental reason for this requisition?

options.label: A
options.text: First registration applications cannot be made using Form FR1; Form AP1 must be used.

options.label: B
options.text: The Registry requires a full documentary history to assess the title and determine its class.

options.label: C
options.text: The SDLT5 certificate is invalid for first registration applications.

options.label: D
options.text: The application is premature; first registration can only occur 12 months after completion.

options.label: E
options.text: The property is automatically registered upon completion, making the application unnecessary.

questions.explanation:
B is correct. For first registration of unregistered land, the applicant must provide sufficient documentary evidence to satisfy the Registrar of the title’s validity. This typically requires submitting original deeds and a chronological list (on Form DL) to allow the Registry to investigate the title’s root and decide whether to grant absolute, possessory, or qualified title.
A is incorrect; FR1 is the correct form for first registration.
C is incorrect; the SDLT5 is required.
D is incorrect; the application must be made within two months of the purchase.
E is incorrect; registration is not a...

questions.text: Upon receiving the transfer deed after completion, the buyer’s solicitor, Liam, prepares the Land Registry application. He notes the transfer was signed by the seller and witnessed, but the witness’s signature is illegible and the printed name says “Alex Smith.” The witness’s occupation is not stated. Liam’s assistant contacts the seller’s solicitor, who confirms Alex Smith is the seller’s spouse. What is the most likely outcome when submitting this transfer to the Land Registry?

options.label: A
options.text: The application will be registered without issue, as the witness’s details are not critical.

options.label: B
options.text: The Registry will raise a requisition due to the witness being the spouse of a party.

options.label: C
options.text: The Registry will cancel the application and require a fresh transfer to be executed.

options.label: D
options.text: The Registry will register the title but with a caution against dealings.

options.label: E
options.text: The witness’s occupation must be stated, but the spouse being a witness is not a fatal flaw.

questions.explanation: B is correct. Land Registry Practice Guide 8 states that a witness should be independent not a party to the deed or their spouse or cohabitant. A witness who is the spouse of the signatory calls the validity of the execution into doubt. The Registry is likely to raise a requisition requiring evidence to satisfy themselves the deed was properly executed (e.g., a statutory declaration from the witness or the seller). C is possible if the requisition cannot be satisfied, but B is the immediate and most likely outcome. A is incorrect. D is unlikely. E understates the issue; the spouse’s status is ...

questions.text: Completion of a freehold purchase took place on 10th October. The buyer’s solicitor obtained an OS1 priority search on 8th October. Due to an oversight, the Land Registry application (AP1) was not submitted until 5th December. On 25th November, a unilateral notice was registered against the title by a creditor of the seller claiming a beneficial interest. What is the legal consequence for the buyer’s title?

options.label: A
options.text: The unilateral notice takes priority, as the application was submitted outside the 30-calendar-day priority period.

options.label: B
options.text: The unilateral notice takes priority, as the application was submitted outside the 30-working-day priority period.

options.label: C
options.text: The notice is void because it was registered after the buyer’s completion.

options.label: D
options.text: The Land Registry will cancel the notice as it was registered in error.

options.label: E
options.text: Priority is determined by the date of completion, so the buyer’s interest ranks first.

questions.explanation: B is correct. The priority period conferred by an OS1 search is 30 working days. If an application to register the transfer is not delivered to the Land Registry within that period, the protection lapses. Any interest registered after the search date but before the application is delivered (like the notice on 25th November) will have priority. A is incorrect. C is incorrect; registration of a notice is effective from its entry. D is incorrect; the Registry will not cancel it without cause. E is incorrect; for registered land, priority of interests is determined by the order of registration, no...

questions.text: After completion, a buyer’s solicitor, George, is processing the SDLT return for a £1.2m residential purchase. The buyer already owns a property abroad. George considers the 3% higher rate for additional dwellings. He files the return and pays the tax. Six months later, HMRC opens an enquiry, contending the higher rate should have applied as the overseas property is a “dwelling.” The buyer argues it is commercial. Who is primarily responsible for the accuracy of the SDLT return and any subsequent penalties?

options.label: A
options.text: HMRC, as they have the discretion to determine the property’s status.

options.label: B
options.text: The buyer, as the taxpayer who signs the declaration in the return.

options.label: C
options.text: The solicitor, as they are the professional who filed the return.

options.label: D
options.text: The lender, as they required the purchase.

options.label: E
options.text: The seller, for not disclosing the SDLT status in the contract.

questions.explanation: B is correct. SDLT is a self-assessed tax. The buyer (the taxpayer) is legally responsible for the accuracy of the return and any declarations made within it. The solicitor acts as an agent. While the solicitor may be liable in negligence if they give incorrect advice, the primary legal responsibility to HMRC rests with the client. A is incorrect; HMRC enforces the law but doesn’t bear responsibility for the taxpayer’s filing. C is incorrect regarding primary responsibility to HMRC, though they may have professional liability. D and E are incorrect and irrelevant.

questions.text: Following a late completion, the seller’s solicitor, Irene, serves a Notice to Complete on the buyer, giving 10 working days to complete. On day 9, the buyer’s solicitor tenders completion but deducts £2,000 from the balance, claiming it is owed to the buyer for a pre-completion repair the seller had agreed to but not done. Irene rejects the tender as it is not for the full contract sum. Is the seller entitled to rescind the contract after the 10-day notice period expires?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because the buyer tendered performance within the notice period.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because the tender was defective.

options.label: C
options.text: No, because the deduction was for a valid cross-claim.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the seller returns the partial payment first.

options.label: E
options.text: No, because the Notice to Complete was invalid for not mentioning the repair issue.

questions.explanation: B is correct. A Notice to Complete requires the defaulting party to complete in accordance with the contract. Completion requires payment of the full balance due (subject to lawful apportionments). An unagitated deduction for a disputed cross-claim renders the tender defective. The seller is not obliged to accept it. If the full sum is not paid by the expiry of the notice, the seller can rescind. A is incorrect; the tender was not valid. C is incorrect; the cross-claim is separate from the obligation to pay the full price on completion. D is incorrect. E is incorrect; the Notice doesn’t need t...

questions.text: Post-completion, the buyer’s solicitor, Leah, is preparing to discharge her undertaking to the lender. She had undertaken to “register the charge at HM Land Registry and send you the title information document.” The charge is registered, but Leah discovers a unilateral notice was registered against the title by a third party after her OS1 priority period lapsed but before her application was received. The lender’s handbook requires reporting any encumbrances not already agreed. What is Leah’s professional duty regarding the unilateral notice?

options.label: A
options.text: Say nothing, as the charge is registered and the notice is a matter for the buyer.

options.label: B
options.text: Inform the lender immediately, as it is a new encumbrance affecting their security.

options.label: C
options.text: First try to have the notice removed before informing the lender.

options.label: D
options.text: Inform the buyer and let them decide whether to tell the lender.

options.label: E
options.text: It is not reportable as it was registered after completion.

questions.explanation: B is correct. The solicitor’s duty to the lender continues post-completion. The unilateral notice is a third-party interest registered against the title, which materially affects the lender’s security by potentially taking priority. This must be reported to the lender as per the UK Finance Handbook, regardless of when it arose. A and D breach the duty to the lender. C is incorrect; while removal may be attempted, the duty to report is immediate. E is incorrect; the timing of the notice’s registration is precisely what makes it a problem for priority.

questions.text: After a difficult completion that was five days late, the seller’s solicitor serves a Notice to Complete on the buyer. The buyer completes within the 10-working-day notice period. The seller wants to claim contractual interest for the initial five-day delay. Is the seller still entitled to claim this interest?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because serving the Notice to Complete waived the right to interest for the prior delay.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, contractual interest for late completion is a separate right accruing up to the actual completion date.

options.label: C
options.text: No, once a Notice to Complete is served, only the notice remedies apply.

options.label: D
options.text: Yes, but only if the Notice to Complete expressly reserved the right to interest.

options.label: E
options.text: No, interest can only be claimed if completion did not occur within the notice period.

questions.explanation: B is correct. Under SC 7.3, the right to interest on late completion is distinct from the right to serve a Notice to Complete. Interest runs from the contractual completion date to the actual completion date. Serving a Notice to Complete does not extinguish this accrued right; it adds a new, more drastic remedy (rescission) if the notice itself is not complied with. A and C are incorrect. D is not required by the standard conditions. E is incorrect; interest is for the period up to actual completion.

questions.text: The buyer’s solicitor, Oscar, submits the registration application but forgets to include the scanned copy of the signed mortgage deed. The Land Registry raises a requisition. By the time Oscar responds, the 30-working-day priority period from his OS1 search has expired. A local search company acting for an unknown third party lodges a caution against the title the day after the priority period lapses. What is the effect of the caution?

options.label: A
options.text: It is void because it was lodged after the buyer’s application was made.

options.label: B
options.text: It will prevent Oscar’s application from being completed until it is dealt with.

options.label: C
options.text: It is irrelevant as it was lodged after completion.

options.label: D
options.text: The Land Registry will cancel it as it was lodged in bad faith.

options.label: E
options.text: It does not take priority over the buyer’s application

questions.explanation: B is correct. A caution against dealings, once registered, prevents the registration of any subsequent dealing (like the buyer’s transfer) unless the cautioner consents or the caution is cancelled by the Registrar or court. Because Oscar’s application was incomplete (requisition raised), it was not yet “protected” by the priority period when it lapsed. The caution, lodged after the lapse, will be an obstacle the Registry must address before completing Oscar’s application. A is incorrect; the application wasn’t complete. C is incorrect; timing relative to completion is not the key factor. D is ...

questions.text: Maya, a solicitor, is acting for a first-time buyer client, Leo, who is purchasing a £400,000 flat. Leo has a 10% deposit: £20,000 from his savings and £20,000 gifted from his aunt, who lives abroad. Leo’s mortgage broker has recommended a 5-year fixed-rate mortgage. During a phone call, Leo asks Maya, “My broker says this is a good deal, but with interest rates rising, do you think I should lock in for five years or take a two-year fix instead?” Maya, wanting to be helpful, replies, “Given the economic forecasts, the five-year fix gives you more certainty, which I think is wise.” Which of the following best describes the professional conduct issue arising from Maya’s advice?

options.label: A
options.text: Maya has acted outside her retainer but has not breached any financial services rules.

options.label: B
options.text: Maya has provided regulated mortgage advice without FCA authorisation, breaching FSMA.

options.label: C
options.text: Maya’s advice was incidental to her legal work and is permitted under the solicitor’s exemption.

options.label: D
options.text: Maya has created a conflict of interest by discussing financial products.

options.label: E
options.text: Maya has given appropriate legal advice about the terms of the mortgage deed.

questions.explanation: B is correct. Under FSMA 2000 and the Regulated Activities Order, “advising on investments” (which includes mortgages) is a regulated activity. Giving a personal recommendation on which mortgage product to choose constitutes regulated advice. Solicitors can only give such advice if FCA-authorised or under the “incidental” exemption. The exemption (Part 20, FSMA) only covers advice that is incidental to legal services (e.g., explaining the legal effect of a mortgage clause). Recommending a product based on economic forecasts crosses the line into regulated financial advice, for which Maya is no...

questions.text: Thomas and his wife, Sarah, jointly own their home. Thomas’s business needs a loan, and the bank will only lend if the loan is secured by a legal charge over the matrimonial home. Sarah does not work in the business and will receive no direct benefit from the loan. They jointly instruct their long-time family solicitor, David, to act for them both in creating the charge. David meets with them together, explains the documents, and they both sign. If Sarah later claims undue influence, what is the most significant failing in David’s conduct based on the Etridge guidelines?

options.label: A
options.text: Acting for both parties when a conflict of interest existed.

options.label: B
options.text: Failing to ensure Sarah received independent legal advice, in private, on the risks of the transaction.

options.label: C
options.text: Failing to register the charge at the Land Registry promptly.

options.label: D
options.text: Not advising Thomas that the loan was too risky for his business.

options.label: E
options.text: Not obtaining a valuation of the property before creating the charge.

questions.explanation: B is correct. The House of Lords in Royal Bank of Scotland v Etridge (No 2) established strict safeguards for situations where a wife (or vulnerable party) stands as surety for her husband’s debts. The solicitor must advise the surety separately, in the absence of the other party, about the risks and must confirm to the lender that this has been done. Joint advice is insufficient. A is a related issue, but the specific Etridge failing is the lack of independent advice for the vulnerable party. C, D, and E are not core Etridge requirements.

questions.text: Under the Levelling-up and Regeneration Act 2023, which came into force in April 2024, the enforcement time limits for breaches of planning control in England have changed. What is the default position for taking enforcement action against operational development and change of use to a single dwelling?

options.label: A
options.text: A 4-year limit for both, as was previously the case.

options.label: B
options.text: A 10-year limit for both.

options.label: C
options.text: A 4-year limit for operational development and a 10-year limit for change of use.

options.label: D
options.text: A 10-year limit for operational development and a 4-year limit for change of use.

options.label: E
options.text: Enforcement is now at the local authority’s discretion with no time limit.

questions.explanation: B is correct. The Levelling-up and Regeneration Act 2023 unified the enforcement periods in England. From 25 April 2024, a single 10-year limit applies to all breaches of planning control, including operational development and material change of use (including to a single dwelling). The old 4-year rule for these breaches has been abolished. Transitional provisions protect breaches that occurred before this date. A and C are incorrect as they reflect the old law. D is incorrect, and the  reverse of the new rule. E is incorrect; time limits still apply.

questions.text: Charles grants a 10-year lease of an office suite to David Ltd, a start-up company. The lease is prepared by Charles’s solicitor and sent to David Ltd’s solicitor for review. In the covering email, Charles’s solicitor states, “We have included a clause contracting out of the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954, as agreed.” David Ltd’s director signs the lease on behalf of the company and returns it. No statutory declaration or simple declaration was ever signed by David Ltd. Charles also signs, and the lease is dated. David Ltd occupies the premises for three years, after which Charles serves a notice to terminate the lease. What is the most likely legal status of the lease’s attempt to contract out of the 1954 Act security of tenure provisions?

options.label: A
options.text: The lease is void ab initio for attempting to unlawfully oust the jurisdiction of the statute.

options.label: B
options.text: The contracting-out procedure was defective, so the lease is protected under the 1954 Act.

options.label: C
options.text: The email from Charles’s solicitor constitutes sufficient written warning for the purposes of the Act.

options.label: D
options.text: As the lease is for a term of less than 21 years, the 1954 Act does not apply regardless of procedure.

options.label: E
options.text: David Ltd is estopped from claiming protection because its director signed the lease containing the clause.

questions.explanation: B is correct. Contracting out of the security of tenure provisions of the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954 (Part II) requires strict compliance with a statutory procedure under s.38A. This involves the landlord serving a warning notice on the tenant in the prescribed form at least 14 days before the lease is entered into, and the tenant making a simple declaration or, if within 14 days, a statutory declaration. Mere inclusion of the clause in the lease and an email reference is insufficient. Therefore, the procedure is defective, and the tenant retains statutory protection. Option A is incorrect b...

questions.text: James is the tenant under a 15-year commercial lease granted in 2005. He wishes to assign the lease. The lease, granted before the Landlord and Tenant (Covenants) Act 1995 came into force, contains a qualified covenant against assignment. James finds an assignee. The landlord gives consent but requires James to enter into a guarantee of the assignee’s performance. James refuses, arguing the old lease does not allow this. Under the pre-1996 regime (privity of contract), what is James’s ongoing liability after assignment?

options.label: A
options.text: He is automatically released upon assignment because the landlord has given consent.

options.label: B
options.text: He remains liable for all tenant covenants for the entire original term due to privity of contract.

options.label: C
options.text: His liability is limited to the duration of the assignee’s ownership.

options.label: D
options.text: He is only liable if he enters into an express guarantee, which the landlord can compel him to sign.

options.label: E
options.text: His liability ends if the assignee subsequently assigns the lease to another party.

questions.explanation: B is correct. For leases granted before 1 January 1996, the common law doctrine of privity of contract applies unless expressly released by deed. The original tenant remains liable on the covenants for the entire term, regardless of assignment and despite the landlord giving consent to that assignment. This is the harsh rule mitigated by the 1995 Act for new leases. Option A is incorrect; consent to assignment does not equate to release from liability. Option C is incorrect; that describes liability under ‘privity of estate’, which binds the assignee while they own the lease, but does not rele...

questions.text: Under a lease, the landlord has the right to enter and carry out repairs at the tenant’s cost if the tenant fails to do so after notice (a Jervis v Harris clause). The tenant fails to repair a broken window. The landlord serves a notice, the tenant ignores it, and the landlord carries out the repair, incurring a cost of £2,000. The landlord invoices the tenant, who refuses to pay. How can the landlord best recover this £2,000?

options.label: A
options.text: By suing for damages.

options.label: B
options.text: By forfeiting the lease for non-payment of the sum.

options.label: C
options.text: By deducting it from future rent payments.

options.label: D
options.text: By suing for the debt

options.label: E
options.text: By applying for a charging order on the tenant’s assets.

questions.explanation: D is correct. A Jervis v Harris clause (or self-help repair clause) typically provides that costs incurred by the landlord become a debt due from the tenant. This is distinct from damages for breach of covenant. It is a simpler cause of action for debt recovery. Option A is incorrect. Option B is incorrect as it is possible only if the lease expressly makes non-payment of such costs a ground for forfeiture, which is not typical. Option C is incorrect as it is risky and potentially a breach of covenant if done without express right of set-off. Option E is incorrect as it is an enforcement mecha...

questions.text: Charlotte is advising a client, Mr. Patel, who is purchasing a residential property in London for £850,000. Mr. Patel already owns a buy-to-let flat in Birmingham which he rents out, and he lives in a house owned by his wife. He is purchasing the London property in his sole name. He asks Charlotte to calculate the Stamp Duty Land Tax (SDLT) liability and explain the rates. Charlotte must consider the higher rates for additional properties, the standard residential rates, and any applicable reliefs. Mr. Patel has never owned a property in his own name before, but his wife owns their marital home. What is the correct SDLT calculation for this purchase?
questions.explanation: B is correct. Mr. Patel is purchasing an additional residential property (he already has a beneficial interest in the marital home and owns a buy-to-let). Therefore, the 3% higher rate surcharge applies. The calculation is: 3% on the first £250,000 = £7,500; then 8% (5% standard + 3% surcharge) on the next £600,000 = £48,000. Total: £55,500.  Therefore, A, C, D and E are incorrect.

questions.text: Sophie is acting for a developer client who is selling a newly constructed commercial office building in Manchester for £2,000,000 plus VAT. The developer has opted to tax the property. The buyer is a VAT-registered investment company that intends to lease the building to various businesses. The buyer plans to also opt to tax. Sophie is advising on the VAT implications and the SDLT consequences. What is the correct statement regarding VAT and SDLT in this transaction?

options.label: A
options.text: The sale is exempt from VAT, and SDLT is calculated on the £2,000,000 price.

options.label: B
options.text: The sale is subject to VAT at 20%, and SDLT is calculated on the VAT-inclusive price (£2,400,000).

options.label: C
options.text: The sale is subject to VAT at 20%, but SDLT is calculated on the net price (£2,000,000) if the buyer provides a VAT registration number.

options.label: D
options.text: The sale is zero-rated for VAT, and SDLT is calculated on £2,000,000.

options.label: E
options.text: The sale is subject to VAT at 20%, but SDLT is only payable on the rent if the buyer leases the property.

questions.explanation: B is correct. The seller has opted to tax, so the sale of the commercial building is standard-rated (20% VAT). SDLT is calculated on the total consideration, which includes any VAT payable, unless the transaction qualifies for VAT zero-rating or exemption. Here, it is standard-rated, so SDLT is due on £2,400,000. Option A is incorrect because the seller's option to tax makes the sale taxable, not exempt. Option C is incorrect because SDLT is based on the VAT-inclusive price for standard-rated supplies; there is no such reduction for providing a VAT number. Option D is incorrect because the sal...

questions.text: James purchased a buy-to-let flat in Bristol in 2010 for £200,000. He lived in it as his main residence from 2010 to 2015, then moved out and rented it continuously. He sells it in 2025 for £450,000. He has never owned another property. He asks his solicitor, Fatima, about his Capital Gains Tax (CGT) liability, specifically regarding Principal Private Residence (PPR) relief and lettings relief. What is the key factor in determining the proportion of the gain eligible for PPR relief?

options.label: A
options.text: The entire gain is exempt because he once lived there.

options.label: B
options.text: Only the period of actual occupation as his main residence qualifies, plus the final 9 months.

options.label: C
options.text: The entire gain is taxable because it was a rental property at the time of sale.

options.label: D
options.text: The proportion of the gain equal to the fraction of total ownership during which he lived there qualifies.

options.label: E
options.text: He can claim lettings relief for the entire letting period, making the gain exempt.

questions.explanation: B is correct. PPR relief applies to the period the property was the taxpayer's only or main residence, plus the final 9 months of ownership (regardless of occupation). The gain is apportioned on a time basis between exempt (occupation period + last 9 months) and taxable (other periods). Option A is incorrect because PPR relief is not all-or-nothing; it is apportioned. Option C is incorrect because the period of residence still qualifies for relief. questions.text: Ms. Roberts is selling a property she inherited from her mother 2 years ago. Her mother had purchased it in 1980 for £50,000. The probate value at the time of inheritance was £400,000. Ms. Roberts now sells it for £450,000. She has never lived in it. She is a higher-rate taxpayer. Her solicitor, David, advises her on CGT and the base cost for calculating the gain. What is the base cost for CGT purposes?

options.label: A
options.text: The original purchase price of £50,000.

options.label: B
options.text: The probate value of £400,000.

options.label: C
options.text: The average of the purchase price and the probate value.

options.label: D
options.text: The selling price of £450,000.

options.label: E
options.text: The market value at the date of inheritance, but only if it is higher than the purchase price.

questions.explanation:
B is correct. For inherited assets, the base cost for CGT is the market value at the date of death (probate value).
Option A is incorrect because the base cost is stepped up to the value at inheritance. Option C is incorrect because averaging is not used.
Option D is incorrect because the selling price is not the base cost.
Option E is incorrect because the base cost is always the probate value, regardless of whether it is higher or lower.

questions.text: Mr. Singh is selling a rental property he has owned for 15 years. He originally bought it for £100,000 and spent £20,000 on an extension (which is capital improvement). He sells it for £300,000. He is a higher-rate taxpayer. He has no other capital gains. His solicitor, Anil, advises him on CGT and the deduction of costs. What is the amount of the chargeable gain?
questions.explanation:
B is correct. The chargeable gain is the sale price minus the original purchase price and any allowable costs, such as capital improvements (the extension).
So, £300,000 - £100,000 - £20,000 = £180,000.
The annual exempt amount is deducted later to find the taxable gain.
Option A is incorrect because it does not deduct the improvement cost. Option C is incorrect because the annual exempt amount is not deducted in calculating the chargeable gain; it is deducted later.
